rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because of an observed and projected population decline of more than 80%, inferred from the effects of chytridiomycosis on this species.
habitat: The species lives along steep Andean slopes in the upper part of cloud forests, and Polylepis formations (De la Riva 2005). Adults are semi-aquatic and are found under stones and logs near rivers and small creeks. The tadpoles are found in rapid streams, where they adhere to rocks using their oral sucker (De la Riva 2005). It breeds by larval development in streams.
threats:
Local inhabitants' comments to I. De la Riva, in addition to extensive field work during 2006-2007, are suggestive of a severe population decline at the Peruvian localities; the cause of which is not known. The chytrid-associated declines observed in other Andean frogs in Peru suggest that this could be a potential threat in this case, although this requires verification. In 1999–2001, specimens tested positive for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, in Bolivia (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017), suggesting that chytridiomycosis could also be a threat to the species in this country.

It is possible that the species may be utilized (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008).
population:
The species was common in the Rio Pelechuco valley, Bolivia in 2001 (De la Riva 2005, De la Riva and Lavilla 2008, I. De la Riva pers. comm. January 2011). The presence of this species was documented in 2017 in Apolobamba, which was the only survey in the area since 2001 (J. Aparicio pers. comm. September 2019). It was considered uncommon in 2017, but no data on abundance or densities were obtained (J. Aparicio pers. comm. September 2019).

In Peru, the species was last collected in Ollachea in July 1986 (reported by Cadle and Patton in 1998, I. De la Riva pers. comm. January 2011). Surveys in 2006 and 2007 in both of the historical localities in Peru and other areas with suitable habitat did not find any individuals, and local inhabitants in the different valleys indicated that the frogs matching the description of this species had all died two years before (De la Riva and Lavilla 2008, I. De la Riva pers. comm. January 2011). General surveys in Puno in 2016-2017 did not record this species or observe it in any markets, and conversations with local people revealed that the species has not been seen in many years (A. Catenazzi and A. Shepeck pers. comm. November 2019).

The population is thought to have declined by more than 80% over the past three generation lengths (18 years; 2001–2019) and is likely to continue into the future (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
range: This species is known from Limbani and an area about 6 km (airline) SW of Ollachea, both in the Region of Puno, southern Peru, and from Pelechuco, in the Cordillera de Apolobamba, Department of La Paz, northern Bolivia (De la Riva 2005). The airline distance between the two most distant localities (Pelechuco and Ollachea) is around 180 km. The northern distribution of this species is unknown; specimens identified as this species have been collected in the Department of Cusco, as far north as Amparaes and Abra Málaga (De la Riva et al. 2005) and these have been excluded from the range map. It occurs between 3,100–3,800 m asl (De la Riva 2005). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 274 km2.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized, however it may be vulnerable to overexploitation (Aguilar et al. 2010).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is not present in any protected areas in Peru. Bolivian populations can be found in the Area Natural de Manejo Integrado Apolobamba (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008) and may also be present within Madidi National Park. It is listed as Endangered (VU) in Bolivia’s Red Book of Threatened Vertebrates (Aguayo 2009) and in Peru it is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) with legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection of the localities in Peru is urgently needed to ensure the maintenance of suitable habitat for this species. 

Research Needed
Systematic surveys are urgently needed to determine if the species is still extant (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. December 2017). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population.
habitat: This species was observed to be active at night on leaves up to 5 m above small streams and ponds in primary or old secondary-growth Low Montane Evergreen Forest, as well as in pasturelands and forest borders (Batallas and Brito 2016). Other centrolenid frogs occurring in sympatry with this species are Cochranella cochranae and an undescribed species of Centrolene (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006). The species may use temporary (seasonal) sources of running water during the reproductive period. During the non-reproductive period the species appears to inhabit the forest canopy (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2008).
threats: No major threats are known (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016).
population: The species was thought to be rare when it was described, however further research has revealed that it is common (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2008). A healthy subpopulation of this species occurs around Cordillera Kampankis, Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina, Peru, where 50 individuals were observed in an hour of searching in 2011 (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012).
range: This species is known from around 20 localities along the slopes of Cordillera Oriental and Amazonian Ecuador in Sucumbios, Napo, Orellana, Morona-Santiago and Zamora-Chinchipe provinces, Ecuador (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006, 2007; Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin 2006). The species is also found in Cordillera Kampankis, Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina, Amazonas Region, Peru (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012). It can be found between 1,400 and 1,820 m asl (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2007).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is found within several protected areas, including Podocarpus National Park, Parque Nacional Sangay, Cayambe-Coca Ecological Reserve and Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its commonness within its distributional range, and its presumed large population.
habitat: The species is found in humid montane forest. Individuals were found during the day on the ground and at night on the ground and in low vegetation up to 0.5 m above the ground. Sympatric anurans include Pristimantis caeruleonotus, P. cajamarcensis, P. colodactylus, and P. galdi (Lehr et al. 2007). Its breeding strategy remains unknown.
threats: No major threats are currently known for this species.
population: This is considered to be a common species (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008), and the population is believed to be stable.
range: This species is known from three sites: Alto Samaniego (2,200 m asl), "Quebrada Parramata", Río Blanco basin, (2,500 m asl), and Río Blanco riverbank (2,000 m asl), all in District of Carmen de la Frontera, Huancabamba province, Department of Piura, Peru. The species is found in montane forests at elevations between 2,000–2,500 m asl (Lehr et al. 2007).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether this species occurs in any protected area, and there are no conservation measures are known for this species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations, and although it occurs in a national park with extensive, suitable habitat there is a continuing decline in the extent of its habitat in Oxapampa.
habitat: The species is found within forested areas (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). One female contained 22 pigmented eggs with a diameter of 1.6 ± 0.09 mm (n = 10). One stomach content revealed a diet consisting of arthropods belonging to Blattelidae, Carabidae, Cryptorhynchinae, Galumnidae, Oribatidae and Formicidae, suggesting that the species is a leaf litter inhabitant (Lehr and Trueb 2007). Although the reproduction mode is unknown, it is possible that the species may use terrestrial bromeliads similar to Ctenophryne carpish (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008).
threats: Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park is currently well protected and there are no major threats to the species within this protected area (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). There is some encroachment of agriculture and cattle grazing in the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park as well as selective logging that could be a potential threat to this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
population: The current populations size and trends for this species is unknown, but it is likely to be a rare species (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008, December 2017). The type series, comprised of five specimens, was collected in 1994 at Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillen. It was observed sometime during 2006-2007 in the vicinity of the type locality (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is only known from Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, District of Oxapampa, Province of Oxapampa, Department of Pasco, Peru, at ca 2,500 m asl (Lehr and Trueb 2007). The zoological collection of the Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén administration (INRENA) contains one unnumbered specimen belonging to this species from San Alberto, just outside of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park (Lehr and Trueb 2007). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km2 and is considered to occur at two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs within the boundaries of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, which measures 122,000 ha in area and reaches an elevation of 3,643 m asl (Lehr and Trueb 2007). It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.  

Conservation Needed
As there is ongoing use of forest by local communities, continued protection of forest habitat and management for wildlife is required within the National Park to safeguard this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further survey work at the type locality is necessary to determine whether the species is still extant.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location], and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to [specific threat, e.g. illegal collection for the pet trade]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,406 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat primarily caused by water pollution, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to illegal offtake from the wild.
habitat: This is a semi-aquatic frog that inhabits permanent streams in puna and cloud forests (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). It is presumed to breed by larval development in streams.
threats: Major threats include water pollution derived from agriculture (potato cultivation) and the use of agrochemicals and waste derived from the mining industry, and deforestation. It is also possible that the species may be used as a food source and in traditional medicine (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). Similar to its congeners, this species is likely to be very susceptible to chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis. The pathogen has yet to be reported from this species and no analyses have been done for samples of this species; however there are several reports of infections in congeners in southern Peru (Seimon et al. 2005, Catenazzi et al. 2011, A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population:
This is considered to be a rare species (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). Two-week long herpetological surveys in August 1998 and April 1999 in Chaglla and vicinities did not render any individuals. However, four specimens brought in by local farmers during the 1998 survey (together with T. brevirostris) are presumed to have been collected in the vicinity of Chaglla (Lehr 2002, Lehr et al. 2002, Lehr 2005), given that requests for frogs were made in the morning and specimens were brought in the afternoon the specimens are likely to have been collected there as enough time had passed between the request and the time when the specimens were delivered (C. Aguilar pers. comm. December 2010). In the 1999 surveys, requests for specimens did not produce any records (C. Aguilar pers. comm. December 2010). The most recent record of the species was from Sacsahuanca, Ambo, Huanuco in 2014 at 3,411 m asl in an interandean forest by Vilma Duran and Lesly Lujan (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017).

The population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, and harvesting for human consumption.
range: The species is known from three localities: Chaglla (Lehr 2002, Lehr et al. 2002, Lehr 2005), Santa María de Valle (type locality; Vellard 1955) and Ambo (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017), Huánuco Region, Peru. It could be also found in Pachitea Province (specimens were collected and brought in by locals) in the Region of Huánuco. Its elevational range is 2,300–3,000 m asl (Lehr 2005), its EOO is 1,406 km2 and all individuals are considered to occur in one threat-defined location.
useTrade: Aquatic species from this genus are known to be harvested in large numbers for human consumption and medicinal uses, and is often sold at local markets (Lehr 2005).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to be present in any protected areas. It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Water and habitat protection are needed in those areas where the species may be affected by pollution and mining.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and natural history. Studies should focus on obtaining positive identification of the species in local markets and on determining the rate of harvest.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,531 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat along the Cordillera Vilcabamba in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species inhabits primary cloud forests, where individuals have been found on the ground. Reproduction occurs via direct development. A gravid female was found during the dry season, suggesting that the species may reproduce throughout the year (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008).
threats: While there is some habitat loss due to agricultural activities, it is believed to be localized (J.M. Padial pers. comm. December 2009).
population: It is considered to be a rare species (J.M. Padial pers. comm. December 2009).
range: This species is restricted to Cordillera Vilcabamba, where it is known from two localities in the Region of Cusco: the type locality (Apurimac River Valley, Camisea Natural Gas Pipeline, 2,445 m asl) and from 40 km from Vilcabamba, at 2,850 m asl (Padial et al. 2012). The localities are separated by an airline distance of ca 60 km and constitute two distinct threat-defined locations. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,531 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It does not occur in any protected areas. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
The creation of additional protected areas in the Andean piedmont is recommended (J.M. Padial pers. comm. December 2009). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since there is still very little information as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It inhabits montane cloud forests (Boano et al. 2008). Individuals have been found at night sitting on understory vegetation up to 3 m above the ground (Boano et al. 2008, R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). It is expected to breed by direct development.
threats: It is found in a very well protected part of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and in the southern part of the park's buffer zone (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). Although the site in the buffer zone from where the species is known is surrounded by agricultural activities, there still appears to be a significant amount of forest cover in the vicinity (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017); it is not known to what extent these activities may impact the species.
population: It is known from the holotype (Boano et al. 2008), two specimens collected during July–August 2011 surveys in the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park (Chávez et al. 2012) and one specimen collected in August 2014 found near the type locality (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). No population status information is currently available for this species. Additional specimens have been found outside of the park that may pertain to this species, but the identity of these specimens need to be confirmed (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). The apparent rarity of the species could be an artifact of its arboreal lifestyle, therefore future surveys for this species should target higher portions of its habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known only from two localities, one in the southern portion of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and the other in the park's buffer zone (upper Llamaquizú basin), on the Amazonian slopes of the Peruvian Andes, district of Chontabamba, Oxapampa province, region of Pasco, Peru (Boano et al. 2008, Chávez et al. 2012). It occurs between 2,150–2,500 m asl. It is possible that it may occur more widely in central Peru (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is currently known only from Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park (Boano et al. 2008) and its buffer zone (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large and stable population.
habitat: This nocturnal species occurs in tropical humid lowland, premontane and montane forests (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009). It has been found at dusk and at night on leaves (1–3 m above water bodies) along streams and rivers (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2010). Calling males were found on the underside of leaves guarding 27–30 egg clutches (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2010). Only a single female was found on a leaf with a male guarding the clutch (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009). Eggs are laid on leaves overhanging fast-flowing streams and the larvae develop in the water (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009).
threats: The main potential threats for this species are habitat loss by logging and the eutrophication of water due to agriculture, human settlements, livestock, hydroelectric dam constructions (in Aripuanã, Brazil) affecting both, the aquatic and terrestrial habitats of the species (Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2010, S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. April 2011). It is presumed to tolerate mild habitat disturbance but not major habitat alterations, such as those produced by large-scale logging activities (S. Castroviejo pers. comm. April 2011).
population: This species is abundant in the areas where it has been found (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009). For example, at the southern border of Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillen (Pasco, Peru), the species appears to be moderately common and have healthy subpopulations in most of the habitats present, even in areas strongly impacted by human activity or buildings (J.C. Chaparro and J. Icochea pers. comm. in Chávez et al. 2012). The population is presumably stable. In Brazil, the population status of this species is not known.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian forest slopes of the Andes in Peru and Bolivia and also from near Aripuanã, Brazil (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2010). In Peru, it is known from Tingo María (Huánuco), the valleys of Marcapata and upper Tambopata (Cusco and Puno), Lamas (San Martín), the vicinity of Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillen (Pasco) and Puente Chino (Ucayali) (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Chávez et al. 2012). In Bolivia, it has been found in the provinces of Chapare and Carrasco (Departamento Cochabamba) and Parque Nacional Amboró (Provincia Ichilo, Departamento Santa Cruz) (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). In Brazil, it has been found in an area near the Faxinal II hydroelectric power plant, municipality of Aripuanã, northern state of Mato Grosso, and also in the states of Acre and Amazonas (Bernarde et al. 2011). Its elevational range is between 300 and 2,230 m asl. It is presumed to occur more widely across suitable habitat between known localities and across the Amazonian slopes of the central Andes (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009; S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. April 2011).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within Parques Nacionales Carrasco and Amboró, Bolivia and in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillen, Peru. It could also be present in Amazonas Region of Peru and therefore in at least one of the following protected areas: Parque Nacional Isiboro Secure (Bolivia), Parque Nacional Madidi (Bolivia), Parque Nacional Pilon Lajas (Bolivia), Reserva Nacional de Tambopata (Peru), Parque Nacional Manu (Peru), Reserva Megantoni (Peru), Cordillera Azul (Peru) or Área de Conservacion Regional Cordillera Escalera (Peru) (Castroviejo et al. 2009; S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. April 2011). In Brazil, there are no known records of this species in protected areas.

Research Needed
Further survey efforts in suitable neighbouring areas would help to fully understand this species' distribution (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. April 2011).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern given that it is known from several sites over a large area, with the possibility of having an even more extended distribution, it occurs in an area with vast tracts of suitable habitat, and it is known from well protected areas.
habitat: It inhabits fairly undisturbed terra firme rainforest and is frequently encountered on large mature forest trees (Moravec et al. 2009). It has also been recorded in floodplain forests (R. von May pers. comm. September 2012). The forest where this species occurs is characterized by relatively well-defined tree strata and a dense canopy at approximately 25–35 m above the ground and the understory is usually dominated by various tree seedlings, young trees, herbaceous lianas, palms and ferns (Moravec et al. 2009). The forest floor is covered by leaf litter with scattered large fruit capsules of the Brazil nut tree (Moravec et al. 2009). Individuals were found sitting on vegetation around 0.5–2 m height. This species breeds in water-filled fruit capsules of the Brazil nut tree, which are opened by agoutis or indigenous Brazil nut collectors and abandoned on the forest floor, and to a much lesser extent, water-filled palm bracts lying on the ground (Moravec et al. 2009). It also breeds in tree holes (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. to R. von May February 2010). The water-filled capsules contained tadpole assemblages with up to tens of individuals (Moravec et al. 2009). In some cases the assemblages consisted of larvae of highly different sizes and different stage of development (Moravec et al. 2009). Occasionally, white ingested eggs were visible through the transparent venter of the larger larvae, indicating oophagous diet (Moravec et al. 2009). While it is not known whether it can tolerate forest degradation, Brazil nut collector activity appears to increase habitat availability in the form of abandoned Brazil nut capsules (J. Moravec pers. comm. December 2011).
threats: In Pando, there is ongoing habitat loss due to agricultural activities and habitat conversion for cattle ranching. In Madre de Dios, illegal gold mining is a major threat to the floodplain forests contiguous to terra firme forests (Lehr and von May 2009). The threat levels posed by human settlements, cattle ranching and mining operations can be considered relatively moderate when compared to other areas in the region where nearly all of the original habitat has been lost (R. von May pers. comm. August 2012).
population: In Bolivia, it is considered to be a locally common species (J. Moravec pers. comm. December 2011). In Peru it varies from locally rare to common: in 2008 a total of five individuals were recorded in two different habitats at four sites over 160 person/hour surveys, whereas in 2012 only one individual was recorded surveying two habitats over the course of a 40 person/hour survey (R. von May pers. comm. September 2012 and see von May et al. 2010 for details on 2008 survey efforts). Its population is not considered to be severely fragmented.
range: This species is known from lowland Amazonia in the Department of Pando, northern Bolivia (Moravec et al. 2009), and from the Region of Madre de Dios, southeastern Peru (von May et al. 2010). In Bolivia, individuals were collected from the vicinity of the settlement of San Antonio de Filadelfia (ca. 200 m asl), and from San Antonio del Matti (ca 270 m asl), both localities in Provincia Manuripi (Moravec et al. 2009). In Peru, it occurs at Los Amigos Conservation Concession and an additional two nearby sites (von May et al. 2010), and Manu National Park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. to R. von May February 2010), ranging from 260-400 m asl (R. von May pers. comm. September 2012). It could potentially also occur in the state of Acre, Brazil, although this requires verification (J. Moravec pers. comm. December 2011). In Pando, 16 geographical localities were thoroughly surveyed over the course of ten years but the species was only found at two of them (J. Moravec pers. comm. December 2011). However, given that there are large tracts of suitable habitat in between known localities in both Bolivia and Peru it is possible that this species may occur in between known localities.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas in Bolivia. In Peru, it occurs in Manu National Park and Los Amigos Conservation Concession (R. von May pers. comm. September 2012), both of which are generally considered to be well protected. More information is needed on this species' distribution and population status.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern given that, even though it has localized threats, it has a widespread distribution and occurs over an area that still has large swaths of suitable habitat.
habitat: It occurs in lowland tropical rainforest, having been found specifically within terra firma forest (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. December 2012). This species appears to inhabit closed sections of forest, always found perching on leaves or palm trunks up to 150 cm high (Moravec et al. 2009). Although no breeding information exists on this species, the closely related and widespread Scinax ruber, which also occupies the same area, breeds in roadside ditches and small temporary ponds. It is not known to what extent this species may be tolerant to habitat disturbance.
threats: Human activity has recently increased in the area of Puerto Almendras, leading to habitat loss and fragmentation (J. Moravec pers. comm. October 2012) and resulting in a fragmented landscape consisting of cleared tracks interspersed with forested areas. Here individuals were found due to the construction of a new modern University campus built between the “Arboretum” and the bank of Rio Nanay (Moravec et al. 2009). The forest areas have not been cleared but a net of regular trails are maintained (J. Moravec pers. comm. October 2012). In Jenaro Herrera the species is found in the area of the biological station of the Instituto de Investigaciones de la Amazonia Peruana (IIAP), which is beside a 5 m-wide dirt road and which connects Jenaro Herrera with Colonia Angamos. The paving of this road is a potential future local threat as it is a recurring theme during election campaigns (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. December 2012). The Río Maquia area is under great pressure from illegal logging, in addition to being subject to logging concessions (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. December 2012).
population: It was described from six individuals (Moravec et al. 2009). However, the species is likely to be more common in the area of lowland northern Peru (J. Moravec pers. comm. October 2012).
range: This species is known from the vicinity of Puerto Almendras (on the shores of Río Nanay), Río Yavari, Jenaro Herrera (on the right margin of Río Ucayali) and Río Maquia, Loreto Region, Peru at 120 m asl (Moravec et al. 2009; G. Gagliardi pers. comm. December 2012). Given that there is suitable habitat in between known localities and beyond these it is thought that it may have a more widespread occurrence, including perhaps also in Brazil, although at this time this still requires confirmation.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: There are no special forms of protection for this species (J. Moravec pers. comm. October 2012), although it is possible that it could occur in Pacaya Samiria National Reserve given its proximity to IIAP's biological field station, where it has been recorded. It is also possible that it may occur within Reserva Nacional Allpahuayo Mishana, which is a few kilometres away from its type locality (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. December 2012). Further surveys are required to determine the population status, ecology and distribution of this species.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,647 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and in the number of mature individuals in southern Peru due to habitat loss, through mining and agricultural activities, and small-scale harvesting for food and medicine.
habitat: It is a riparian, semi-aquatic frog, occurring in streams and small rivers in the high Andes. Breeding takes place in streams throughout the year. Individuals have been observed copulating in semi-frozen streams and glacial streams in mid-winter (July) in Arequipa (Péfaur et al. 1978). Tadpoles are present at all times of the year in deep pools of streams (Péfaur et al. 1978). The species is not known to occur in modified or degraded habitats.
threats: Threats to this species include habitat loss, through mining and agricultural activities, and small-scale harvesting for food and medicine. Similar to its congeners, this species is likely to be very susceptible to chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis. The pathogen has yet to be reported from this species; however there are several reports of infections in congeners in southern Peru (e.g., Seimon et al. 2005, Catenazzi et al. 2011).
population: The population, as well as, the total number of mature individuals in the population are inferred to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat and the harvesting of individuals from the wild.
range: This species is known from the south-eastern Andes of Peru in the regions of Arequipa, Moquegua and Tacna, between 1,980–4,300 m asl. However, specimens from Caylloma province in Arequipa might represent a different, undescribed species (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018), therefore these records are coded as presence uncertain in the species' distribution map and are excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation. Specimens from Río Tambo, Moquegua - Arequipa are now thought to belong to Telmatobius arequipensis (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018). This species does not occur in Chile; previous records from Putre, Parinacota Province, Chile, have been assigned to T. marmoratus based on phylogenetic analyses (Sáez et al. 2014). Therefore, the estimated EOO of this species' currently known range is 10,647 km2 and the species is thought to occur at 10 or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: Small-scale collection occurs for food and medicine. During a 2009-2013 study, 10 individuals were purchased from a market in Lima (Chero et al. 2014).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has not been recorded from any protected areas, though its geographic distribution overlaps with the Vilacota Maure Regional Conservation Area in Tacna. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
There is a need for improved habitat protection at sites at which the species has been recorded. 

Research Needed
Population monitoring is required for this species given the potential threat of chytridiomycosis. Further studies should monitor trends in harvest levels. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its area of occupancy (AOO) and extent of occurrence (EOO) are estimated to be 8 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the central Andes of Peru.
habitat: This diurnal species lives in streams or wetlands inside secondary montane forests, where individuals are active on the leaf litter by day and under the leaf litter at night. It has been recorded from rocky stream-side habitats and is also associated with various modified habitats: secondary forests close to pine plantations, small streams and ditches, an inactive fish farm, and small-scale agriculture (Angulo et al. 2018). They have also been found in small streams and ditches, and passion fruit and chilli plantations and within short vegetation along a ditch within an inactive fish farm (A. Angulo, R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). The breeding habitat and tadpoles are not known, although the larvae are presumably deposited in water.
threats: The major threat to this species is habitat loss and degradation due to expanding agricultural activities, mostly through cultivation of granadilla and chili peppers (known locally as rocoto); increasing amounts of agrochemical substances in the soil and water which is prolific throughout the region; and selective logging of trees such as Cedrella spp. and Juglans spp (Angulo et al. 2018). Many afforestation plans involve the planting of Pinus spp. and Eucalyptus spp. in the deforested areas; however, these species are not native to Peru and would not restore natural conditions inside the forest (Peru Red List Assessment Workshop April 2017).
population: It is a localised species which is not easy to detect visually, however it can often be heard where it is found (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). From 2007 to 2009, at least six trips were made to the type locality in attempt to locate the species, which was found in August 2007 (Chávez and Enciso 2009). During surveys at the type locality during May 2007–April 2008, 11 individuals were recorded with a total sampling effort of 23 person-days (Medina-Müller and Chávez 2008, von May et al. 2008). Seven additional individuals were detected during surveys in the Lower Llamaquizú Basin, located in the Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park buffer area, between July and August 2011 (Chávez et al. 2012). During 2011, c. 20 individuals were observed calling during surveys in the vicinity of Llamaquizú (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Between April 2014 and July 2015, four surveys were conducted in the cloud forest of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and its buffer zone with a survey effort of 12-person days, and the species was detected at 10 nearby sites (Angulo et al. 2018).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of Llamaquizú on the western slope of the Cordillera Yanachaga-Chemillén, Oxapampa Province, Pasco Region, Peru, from 1,924–2,080 m asl (Morales and Velazco 1998, Medina-Muller and Chávez 2008, von May et al. 2008, Chávez et al. 2012, Angulo et al. 2018). The geographical coordinates provided by Morales and Velazco (1998) do not match the description of the type locality, placing the species outside the Llamaquizú River Basin. Data based on field observations suggest its distribution is genuinely very restricted. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 0.89 km2 measured by a minimum convex polygon of its known range; however the EOO has been adjusted to 8 km2 as AOO values should not exceed EOO (IUCN Standards and Petitions Subcommittee 2016) and it is considered to occur in a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: Although this species has not been found in trade, and all species of the genus Ameerega are included in Appendix II of CITES, there is a general demand for poison frogs for the pet trade (CITES 2018).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Although the type locality is less than 0.5 km from the boundary of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, the species has not yet been reported from this protected area in spite of recent surveys close to known sites (Angulo et al. 2018). It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
There is a need to develop environmentally friendly and responsible agricultural practices to reduce the use of agrochemicals, to explore more benign options to control crop pests, and to investigate the use of native species as commercially viable options for timber plantations (Angulo et al. 2018).

Research Needed
Long-term monitoring is necessary to understand the population status of this species and confirm its presence within the park.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,779 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This diurnal, terrestrial species lives on or close to the ground in lowland and premontane tropical forest. Individuals are found on banks of steep streams with limited vegetation (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). A male and female were found in axillary amplexus during August (Lötters et al. 2002). Two to three weeks later, 600 eggs were deposited in water and six days after that tadpoles hatched and fed on algae (Lötters et al. 2002). It is not known how adaptable the species is to habitat modification. They have also been observed in June and July in north-central Peru in amplexus for a period between 18–46 days (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
threats: The chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, was confirmed in this species in the Cainarachi Valley in 2003 (Lötters et al. 2005), and post-infection subpopulations appear to be threatened by habitat destruction through conversion to agricultural land. Pollution, increased algae growth and climate change, implicated in Atelopus declines (La Marca et al. 2005), are also threats to this species (Lötters et al. 2005, Lötters 2007).
population: This species has experienced dramatic declines in the past, likely to be due to chytridiomycosis. In the 1980s, this species was abundant near montane rivers in eastern San Martín, as 20–40 individuals could be found in a single day at a single locality (R. Schulte and W.E. Duellman pers. comm. in Lötters et al. 2005). During 2004-2007, surveys in San Martín found about 50 individuals over more than 300 person-days (von May et al. 2008). Similar surveys in San Martín detected 16 individuals over 3 person-days during 2007, and again in 2008 (von May et al. 2008). Since 2008, individuals within these subpopulations have continued to be observed (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). However, out of 72 transects surveyed during a two month period (May-July), no juveniles were recorded (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is distributed along the lower Andean versant in the upper Río Huallaga drainage, regions of San Martín and Loreto, Peru. It is present at approximately 500–900 m asl. There are subpopulations resembling this species from the north-eastern versant of Peru, but they are not included in this account until their taxonomic status can be more conclusively verified (Lötters et al. 2002). There were also some subpopulations from adjacent Ecuador that were reported to resemble this species in the 2004 assessment, however they actually belong to an undescribed species (S. Lötters pers. comm. February 2018). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,779 km2.
useTrade: Until the early 2000s, this species was collected commercially (Lötters and Schulte 2005). It has the potential to be collected for the pet trade, although recent activity is not known (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. A captive-breeding program for this species has been established, and there is ongoing research investigating the biology of a subpopulation of this species that has been infected with chytridiomycosis by the Instituto de Investigación Biológica de las Cordilleras Orientales.

Research Needed
Given that chytrid has been found in this species, populations should be monitored closely. Additional surveys need to be carried out to verify its full distribution and determine population density.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,507 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This arboreal species inhabits montane tropical rainforest, where individuals have been found in bromeliads and palm leaves. Its breeding habits are not known, though it presumably breeds by larval development.
threats: The species is threatened by ongoing habitat loss caused by livestock farming.
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. One individual was recorded over six person/hours in Bosque Protección Alto Mayo in October 2016 (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">However, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known was formerly known only from the type locality in Rodriguez de Mendoza Province in Amazonas Region, Peru (Duellman and Schulte 1992). It is now also known from Pedro Ruiz Gallo in Bongará Province, Amazonas Region, and Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo, Rioja Province, San Martín Region (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017, R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs from 2,400–2,920 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,507 km2 and it is considered to occur at three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo.

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat:
It is an arboreal species associated with streams and edges of large rivers, from lowland to upland primary and slightly disturbed forest. The eggs are laid on leaves overhanging the streams; the larvae develop in streams. The site at Tutumbaro (Peru) is a disturbed cloud forest in a river valley with bamboo, ferns and elephant ear plants. The sector of Chacos in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillen is used for agricultural activities and the riparian forest where the species has been found is surrounded by small holdings of agricultural land (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). 

Individuals have been recorded calling at night from the upper sides of leaves of herbaceous plants and elephant ear plants within 1 m of a slow stream. Several of the males were observed calling from the undersides of leaves 1-3 m above stream at night. This species occurs in sympatry with Hyalinobatrachium carlesvilai; both occupy approximately the same elevational range and have the same reproductive strategy. Despite the similarities in their niches, both species are relatively common, suggesting low rates of competition (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009).
threats: There are no known threats to the species in Bolivia. In central Peru, pollution runoff from agricultural herbicides threatens this species as it depends on good water quality primarily for reproduction (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). In 2008, the chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, was detected in this species at Kosñipata Valley, Parque Nacional Manu (Catenazzi et al. 2011), so the population should be monitored.
population: It is common in Bolivia and also in Marcapata and Kosñipata in Peru, however it is uncommon in the remaining parts of its range in Peru. During March–April 2000 surveys in National Park and Natural Area for Integrated Management Madidi (PNANMI Madidi), this species was encountered with relatively high frequency (Cortez-Fernandez 2005). On the other hand, similar surveys during September 1999–February 2000 in National Park and Natural Area for Integrated Management Cotapata (PNANMI Cotapata) found the species to be rare (Cortez-Fernandez 2006). In February 2008, during a survey in the Quimbiri River in Cusco, Peru, males were very abundant along the river and its small tributaries; however, these specimens may represent a different species (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is known from Bolivia through to central Peru. In Bolivia, it occurs in the departments of Cochabamba, La Paz (near the locality of Coroico) and Santa Cruz (Cannatella 1980, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Cortez-Fernandez 2015). In Peru, it is known from several localities in cloud forest of the Cordillera Oriental: Kosñipata, Marcapata, and Puente Fortaleza (Cusco Region), Tutumbaro (Ayacucho Region), Santo Domingo de Carabaya (Puno Region), and Chancas (Pasco Region). Some previous identifications of this species were erroneous and actually belong to the recently described species Hyalinobatrachium carlesvilai (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009), however, the two species occur in sympatry. Specimens north of the Urubamba (Cusco, Pasco, and Junín regions) are probably part of an undescribed species (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. March 2018), and have been coded as Presence Uncertain in the range map until further taxonomic work is completed. This species has an elevational range of 300–2,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Manu (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017) and in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén in Peru. In Bolivia it is present in Parques Nacionales Pilón Lajas, Madidi, Cotapata and Amboró.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends. Studies are needed to obtain information on its susceptibility to threatening processes, including chytrid fungus.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This species occurs in lowland tropical rainforest and flooded areas. Individuals are usually found on vegetation along and above streams and pools. It lays its eggs on the underside of leaves over rivers, streams and flooded areas, and when hatched the larvae fall in to the stream below where they develop further.
threats: The Orinoco delta is very important for oil in Venezuela, and hence it is very vulnerable to oil spills and other pollution. There is some localized habitat loss throughout its range due to logging, agriculture and livestock farming.
population: It is a common species, and the population is believed to be stable.
range: This species was previously only known from along the Venezuelan Guayana shield, in the states of Monagas and Delta Amacuro, in areas considered as flood plains in the Orinoco River delta, between sea level and 100 m asl (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2001). Additional research has revealed records in Bolivia (a single individual in the vicinity of the settlement San Antonio; Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2011a), Peru (two localities in Loreto and Madre de Dios; Chávez et al. 2019, speciesLink 2020), Colombia (two localities in Amazonas and Caquetá; Díaz-Ricaurte and Guevara-Molina 2020), Guyana (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2011b), Suriname (Fouquet et al. 2015), and the Brazilian states of Acre (Venâncio et al. 2014), Amazonas (speciesLink 2020), Pará (Ávila-Pires et al. 2010, Araujo de Oliveira et al. 2015), and Amapá (Figueiredo et al. 2020). It is widespread in French Guiana (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2011b; A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017). This species has now been recorded at elevations up to 300 m asl. It is likely to occur throughout the intervening areas of Amazonia between known localities (A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017). A record from Vitória do Xingu, in the state of Pará, Brazil (Oliveira et al. 2015) is now assigned to the newly described species, Hyalinobatrachium muiraquitan (Oliveira and Hernández-Ruz 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within many protected areas throughout its range.

Research Needed
Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This species is found in primary and secondary forest (Guayasamin et al. 2020), in both cloud and lowland forest. Males were observed calling from the upper and lower surfaces of herbaceous leaves up to 2 m above small rivulets. It breeds in small rivulets, and eggs are laid under leaves and fall into the water to develop. Parental care is unknown.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.) and human settlement.
population: It is apparently a rare species, however, it is presumed that this is a consequence of inadequate sampling at the forest canopy level (Guayasamín et al. 2020). The population is considered to be stable. In Brazil, the population status of this species is not known.
range: This species is known from the eastern Amazonian lowlands of Ecuador, Meta Department in Colombia (Lynch and Duellman 1973; A. Acosta pers. comm.), and Huanuco and Cusco Departments in Peru (Guayasamín et al. 2020). Following the synonymy of H. ruedai with this species, this species is now also known from Parque Nacional Natural de Chiribiquete in Caqeutá, Colombia (Guayasamín et al. 2020). Morphological and bioacoustic analyses revealed that most Peruvian records belong to Hyalinobatrachium carlesvilai (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009), and all Bolivian subpopulations correspond to H. carlesvilai and H. bergeri (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). It also has been found in Brazil in the states of Acre (Bernarde et al. 2011) and and Amazonas (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2021). This species occurs at elevations from 190 to 1,840 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is known from Parques Nacionales Limoncocha and Yasuní in Ecuador, and Parque Nacional Natural de Chiribiquete in Colombia. In Brazil, its distribution overlaps with protected areas, including PARNA dos Campos Amazonicos, PARNA Nascentes do Lago Jari and RDS Igapo-Acu.

Research Needed
More information is needed about this species' distribution.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,432 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat on the eastern slopes of the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This is a diurnal, riparian species of primary cloud and montane forest, which presumably lays terrestrial eggs, with the larvae then being transported to streams for development. Males have been observed calling beside streams, perched on moss-covered rocks or fallen vegetation, or hidden among rocks or vegetation (Grant and Rodríguez 2001). It is most active early in the morning and late in the afternoon.
threats: At San Pedro, near Manu National Park, subpopulations of the species have disappeared after epizootics of chytridiomycosis and the species has not been observed since 1999. In San Gaban, the species is mainly affected by agricultural activities (mostly smallholder cultivation of coffee), but no recent surveys have been conducted at this locality.
population: It is uncommon and the population is considered to be decreasing. Several subpopulations of this species were known from around the type locality at San Pedro and along the Paucartambo-Pilcopata road in the buffer zone of Manu National Park (Cusco Region). Following epizootics of chytridiomycosis in the early 2000s, the species has not been observed again at these known sites, despite intensive surveys in 2008-2009 and annually since 2012 (Catenazzi et al. 2011, 2014, 2017).
range: This species is currently known only from two localities separated by over 100 km: San Pedro, Kosñipata (Cusco Region) and San Gaban (Puno Region) in southeastern Peru. Its altitudinal range is 820–1,480 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,432 km<sup>2</sup> and it occurs at two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded within Manu National Park.

Conservation Needed
Ongoing management and protection of its habitat within Manu National Park and its buffer zone is needed to ensure the species has a chance to survive infection with chytrid.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends. Further survey work is necessary to determine whether the species is still extant.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is relatively widespread, it is considered common, and it can tolerate at least a moderate degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This diurnal species is known from both lowland and montane dry forest, as well as thorn scrub and humid montane forest (Duellman 2004). It has also been recorded from small creeks and pools, as well as irrigation ditches in cultivated areas (Duellman 2004, Koch et al. 2018). In natural habitats this frog appears to be confined to streams, especially in dry and thorn forest, occurring in both rocky and muddy streams (Koch et al. 2011). Males have been recorded calling from small crevices beneath partially submerged stones, or from along the margins of small streams (Koch et al. 2011). Males, and in one instance a female, have been recorded transporting larvae on their backs, in batches of 5-27 young (Duellman 2004, Koch 2014, Koch et al. 2018). Tadpoles of all stages have been found in pool habitats in streams between January and late July (Duellman 2004, C. Koch pers. comm. June 2011).
threats: Declines have been noted in suitable habitat at high elevations, and the species may have become extinct in the vicinity of Loja, Ecuador. The cause of the past declines are unknown, but may be due to chytridiomycosis. Habitat destruction and degradation due to logging, cattle ranching and agriculture may represent a current threat to this species, although its occurrence in cultivated land suggests an ability to tolerate some degree of habitat modification. Pollution and non-native predatory fish may also threaten this species.
population:
In Ecuador, the species can no longer be found in Loja and nearby localities at higher altitudes (Coloma et al. 2018) due to declines which took place more than 10 years ago, possibly due to chytridiomycosis. Lowland subpopulations in Ecuador are still abundant and have been recorded consistently (QCAZ database - Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador).

In Peru, this is considered to be an abundant species (P. Venegas pers. comm. 2008). Forty-seven individuals were observed during a survey in Reserva Ecológica de Chaparri between April and July 2005 (Koch et al. 2011, C. Koch pers. comm. June 2011). In this reserve, situated in a part of Peru where amphibian diversity is low, this species was one of the two most abundant species recorded, and the only one heard calling during the survey period (C. Koch pers. comm. June 2011). During 2008–2009, twenty-eight individuals were collected over 297 person/hours in Jaén Province, Cajamarca, Peru (Koch 2014).
range: This species was formerly known just from the western slopes of the Andes in southern Ecuador, and slopes of the Andes in the Huancabamba depression, Piura Department, northern Peru (Coloma 1995, Duellman 2004, Icochea et al. 2004). It is now also known from Guayas and Bolívar provinces in Ecuador (QCAZ database - Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador) and localities in Jaén Province in Cajamarca Department and from Zapatalgo/Chiñuña in Utcubamba Province, Amazonas Department in northern Peru (P. Venegas pers. obs. 2010, Koch 2014, Koch et al. 2011, 2018). It occurs at elevations from 540–2,760 m asl. The identification of a subpopulation close to the village of Ayabaca (Duellman 2004), between this frog's previously-known distribution centres (one in southwest Ecuador, the other in Peru's Huancabamba Depression), suggests that it may occur, or have occurred historically, throughout this area.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, this frog occurs in Reserva Ecológica de Chaparri and Área de Conservación Regional Bosques Secos Salitral-Huarmaca. It also occurs in the proposed Área de Conservación Regional Reserva Ecológica Paisajística Cordillera Mishahuanga (Cueva and Iannacone 2015), however this habitat currently remains unprotected. In Ecudaor, it occurs in Reserva Ecológica Buenaventura and Reserva Laipuna. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. In Ecuador, it is considered Vulnerable (Coloma et al. 2018).

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine whether this species is still extant around Loja and other nearby localities in Ecuador.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, tolerance of a range of habitats and there are no major threats affecting the species.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits the the lowland rainforests, humid forests, and cloud forests of the Andean foothills and the semideciduous forests of the inter-Andean valleys of central Bolivia (De la Riva et al. 2000, Padial et al. 2008). The understory level is composed of palms, ferns, heliconias, shrubs and young trees. Köhler (2000) and Cortez (2001) note that it is common in disturbed areas. It can be observed calling on the ground or on low brushwoods. This species breeds by direct development and egg deposition site is in leaf-litter.
threats: While there is some localized habitat loss, there are no major threats to this species; it can survive in modified habitats including gardens.
population: This species varies from rare to abundant. Its population trend is considered to be stable.
range: This species occurs east of the Andes, from central Peru to northern and central Bolivia. It is not present in Argentina (this is O. discodalis). In Peru, it is found in the Regions of Madre de Dios, Cusco and Puno; the previous assessment included the possibility of it occurring in Huánuco and Junín, but this is not the case (A. Catenazzi and R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). In Bolivia, it is found in the Departments of Cochabamba, La Paz, Beni, Pando and Santa Cruz (De la Riva et al. 2000, Köhler 2000). It may also occur in Brazil. Its elevational range is from 200–2,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia, it occurs in Madidi and Cotapata National Parks and Natural Areas of Integrated Management, and in Carrasco and Amboró National Parks. In Peru, the range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu and Bahuaja-Sonene National Park (Madre de Dios) and Parque Nacional Manu (Cusco).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This is a terrestrial species of lowland primary tropical forest, which may also be found in rocky streambeds in ravines on mountain slopes. Its breeding biology is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The main, moderate-level threat to this species is habitat loss due to ongoing agricultural activities (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009). However, habitat loss is expected to be localized.
population: This is considered to be a rare species (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009). However, given its widespread distribution and extensive remaining habitat in the lowlands, the population is considered to be stable at present.
range: This species is presently known from the area of Ponga de Shilcayo and the areas surrounding Tarapoto, Zapatero and Shapaja in San Martín Region, from the vicinity of Satipo, Junín Region, from Estacion Biologica Panguana, Huánuco Region, and from   Río Kimbiri, Cusco Region, Peru. It is presumed that this species occurs in between these areas. It is known to occur at altitudes of 470–1,000 m asl (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been found within the Vilcabamba-Amboró Conservation Corridor (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009).

Conservation Needed
The creation of specific protected areas in the Andean foothills is recommended (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species can be found in both montane primary and lowland tropical moist forest of the Amazonian slopes and Andes foothills of the Andes. Breeding takes place in foam nests within stagnant waters. It does occur in relatively disturbed forests (Reichle 2006) and occasionally it is found close to roadside ditches in forest habitat.
threats: At present, there are only localized threats to this species. Certain subpopulations are probably impacted by deforestation, urban development, and the conversion of primary forest habitat into agriculture.
population: It is an uncommon species, though it is expected to have a stable population given its widespread distribution.
range: This species is known from the Andean slopes and adjacent foothills of central and southern Peru and northern Bolivia. In Peru, it occurs on the northeastern slopes of the Andes to central-eastern slopes, encompassing the Regions of Huánuco, Ayacucho, Junín, Pasco, San Martín and Ucayali (Heyer 1994). In Bolivia, it is present in the Departments of La Paz and Cochabamba (De la Riva et al. 2000, Reichle 2006). It may occur more widely. It has an elevational range of 100–1,800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no record of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia, it is present in Madidi and Carrasco National Parks. In Peru, this species might occur in Rio Abiseo National Park, Biabo Cordillera Azul Reserved Zone, Tingo Maria and Yanachaga Chemillen National Parks, Yanesha Communal Reserve, Bosque de Protección San Matías San Carlos and Apurimac Reserved Zone (although this requires confirmation).

Research Needed
Further research is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: The species lives in dry scrub, tropical deciduous and semi-deciduous forest, and occasionally in evergreen forests. It occurs also in secondary forest, forest edges, open areas and disturbed areas, such as margins of roads, pastures and agricultural fields (Cisneros-Heredia 2006a). In deciduous and semi-deciduous forest, it is restricted to the leaf litter in moist microhabitats, such as the margin of streams or pools, while in evergreen forest they can be found up to 100 m from streams (Cisneros-Heredia 2006a). Specimens of this species have been observed on the forest floor, as well as in and about drainage ditches and bushes at a farm (Heyer and Peters 1971). Eggs are deposited in foam nests in holes near bodies of water, which are subsequently flooded.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no known threats to this widespread, adaptable species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no major threats to this widespread, adaptable species.
population: This species is common Ecuador, including secondary forest and vegetation along streams in agricultural areas (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2017). Its<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its population trend is generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}"> population trend is generally stable.
range: The species is known from northern, central, and southern regions of western coastal Ecuador, northern and central western coastal Peru, and the dry interandean valleys of southern Ecuador and northern Peru (Cisneros-Heredia 2006a). In Peru, it occurs in the Regions of Ancash, Cajamarca, Piura, and La Libertad. University of Kansas specimens identified as belonging to this species from the Region of Cusco, Peru, were probably misidentified; unfortunately, the specimens have been destroyed (da Sá et al. 2014). Its altitudinal range is from sea level to 1,300 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Machililla, Manglares Churute, and Mache Chindu National Parks. It might also occur in Parque Nacional Cerros de Amotape and El Angolo Game Preserve in Peru. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' population size, distribution and trends.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,762 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species is restricted to primary cloud forests with (terrestrial) bromeliads, which are used as hiding places and for deposition of eggs and development of tadpoles (Lehr and Trueb 2007, E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). Specimens have been found on the ground, in terrestrial bromeliads (November and February, respectively) and in the centre of a water-filled arboreal bromeliads. One gravid female, found in July, contained 83 pigmented eggs with a diameter of 1.6 ± 0.14 mm (n = 10) (Lehr and Trueb 2007). Tadpoles were observed swimming at night in the center of an arboreal, water-filled bromeliad in humid montane forest; the plant was about 50 cm tall and located about 80 cm above the ground (Lehr et al. 2007, E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). Stomach contents of one specimen revealed arthropods belonging to the following orders/families: Coleoptera, Juliaformes, Formicidae and Staphylinidae (Lehr and Trueb 2007).
threats: The Cordillera de Carpish is not protected under Peruvian law, making it susceptible to deforestation for agriculture and timber extraction. In 2003, the forest where tadpoles were collected showed little evidence of human impact (Lehr et al. 2007). Since then, the main threat is habitat destruction as a result of agricultural activities, primarily from potato farming and livestock ranching, and firewood collection (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
population: This species is considered to be either a secretive and/or rare species (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008). It has not been observed since around the time of the species' description, however targeted searches have not been conducted (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from cloud forests in the vicinity of the type locality in the Cordillera de Carpish (Huánuco Province, Huánuco Region) in the central-eastern Andes of Peru (Lehr et al. 2002) and ca 364 km north of this locality at Laguna de los Cóndores, Juanjui, Huallaga, San Martín, Peru (Venegas 2005). It occurs at elevations between 2,750 and 2,960 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,762 km2 and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The San Martín record was collected within the boundaries of Los Chilchos Private Conservation Area. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Protection and maintenance of the remaining habitat a high priority.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 565 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: It is a terrestrial species, inhabiting montane cloud forest, but it is not known whether or not it occurs in degraded areas. Frogs were found under rocks and rotten wood next to the river bank of Río Yanamonte at 11:00–13:00 hr (Lehr and Aguilar 2006). It is presumed to breed by direct development. Lynch (1975) reported females having from 18 to 20 eggs.
threats: The major threat is habitat loss due to agricultural expansion, subsistence wood collecting, and human settlement.
population: This is considered to be a rare species (J.M. Padial pers. comm. November 2009). In 1941, 31 specimens were collected at Río Yanamonte (Lynch 1975), while six frogs were found over two hours of searching at the same locality in January 2006 (Lehr and Aguilar 2006).
range: This species is known from the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Oriental west of the Apurimac River, the Cordillera Vilcabamba, and Yanamonte in Ayacucho Region, Peru, between 1,650 and 2,900 m asl. It is believed to be a genuinely restricted-range species. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 565 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
