It occurs in Parque Nacional de Huascaran (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017), however it remains unclear if the species is present in any additional protected areas. It might occur in the Huayllay National Sanctuary, Junín National Reserve or Chacamarca Historical Sanctuary.

Research Needed
Taxonomic studies are needed to determine if this is a complex of more than one species. More research is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, despite being known mainly from isolated records from a large area, in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species has been found in premontane forest and partially cleared cloud forests. It is presumed to breed by larval development in stagnant water, such as small pools.
threats: The major threats are unknown. Agricultural development, for crops such as coffee, might be a threat to this species.
population: The population status is unknown, though it is likely to be common.
range: This species is known from the western slope of the northern portion of the Cordillera Central: several localities in Amazonas and Loreto Regions, the vicinity of Tingo Maria, Huánuco Region, and parts of San Martín Region, Peru. Its altitudinal range is between 1,330–1,850 m asl. It is presumed to occur more widely, in particular between the known sites.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has been recorded in Zona Reservada Santiago Comaina and Bosque de Proteccion Alto Mayo. It might also occur in Rio Abiseo National Park, Biabo Cordillera Azul Reserved Zone and Tingo Maria National Park, but this requires confirmation.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population status and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland forest, swamps and forest edges. It reproduces in shallow temporary ponds, either in the forest or closely outside it (Reichle 2006). The eggs are attached to leaves, and tadpoles fall into the water below where they develop further. It is tolerant to habitat disturbance and also found in the vicinity of human settlements, as long as some forest patches are still remaining (Reichle 2006).
threats: There are no known threats to the species.
population: This is a locally common species and the population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is known from the Andean foothills, northwestern Amazon, and the Yungas of Bolivia. It has also been reported from Peru in Parque Nacional Manu on the lower Amazonian slopes in Madre de Dios (von May et al. 2009, Catenazzi et al. 2013). It occurs at elevations from 180–1,500 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its range includes Parque Nacional Carrasco in Bolivia and Parque Nacional Manu in Peru.

Research Needed
Taxonomic research is needed to establish the relationship of this species to Dendropsophus minuta.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species lives in a very wide variety of habitats, including forest, degraded areas, gardens, and urban areas. It can be found in the canopy, but descends to lower vegetation at night to breed. It breeds in permanent pools, including artificial ponds.
threats: It is a very adaptable species that is not facing any major threats. Nevertheless, there is some localised habitat loss within its range. For example, surrounding Parque Nacional Cerros de Amotape in Peru, there are fires and land clearing for livestock, and logging for firewood (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is a very common species. In January 2010, field surveys recorded several individuals of this species in Cerro de Amotape National Park, Peru (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species occurs in the Pacific lowlands of Colombia (Chocó Department southwards), Ecuador (to south of Basaje) and Peru (Tumbes Region). It has been recorded between 100–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in many protected areas. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with the Parque Nacional Mache Chindul, Reserva Ecológica Cotacahi-Cayapas, and Reserva Ecológica Manglares-Churute. In Peru it has been reported for Parque Nacional Cerros de Amotape (Venegas et al. 2008).

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits lowland primary and secondary rainforest (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). A canopy dweller, it breeds by larval development in bromeliads, usually very high up in trees (up to 15 m above the ground). It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: This species is considered to be common in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its population trend is generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is known from the Río Napo drainage in the provinces of Napo, Francisco de Orellana and Sucumbíos in Ecuador, and from the Iquitos area in Loreto Region, Peru. It occurs from 200 and 600 m asl. Further research is likely to reveal that this species occurs much more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its distribution range includes Estación Biologica Jatun Sacha and Parque Nacional Yasuni in Ecuador, and it might also occur in protected areas in Peru.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' population size, distribution and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its probable wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal, arboreal species occurs in bromeliads in lowland rainforest. It reproduces by larval development in bromeliads and tree holes.
threats: It suffers some habitat loss in the southern part of the range due to human settlements and livestock farming. However, most of the range is unthreatened.
population: It is an uncommon species, and the population is believed to be stable.
range: This species is known from Amazonas Department (Tarapaca/Leticia and Río Pure), Colombia and around the junction of the Sucusari and Napo Rivers, Loreto Department, Peru (Lynch 2002). It occurs between 100–200 m asl. It is believed to occur much more widely, and it will probably be found in neighbouring Brazil.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Río Puré.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This is an arboreal species of primary tropical moist forest. It is not present in degraded areas. It breeds in phytotelmata such as bromeliads.
threats: Because of the large areas of suitable habitat still available to this species there are no major threats. There is some habitat loss through different human activities, principally agriculture (crops and ranching).
population: It is locally common in good habitat. Due to ongoing local decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is believed to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the eastern premontane slopes of northern and central Peru (Jungfer and Lehr 2001, Jungfer et al. 2013), as well as two additional localities in the eastern versant of the Andes in southern Peru (La Convencion Province, Cusco Region; Chávez et al. 2008). It can be found at elevations between 380–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs inYanachaga Chemillen National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This arboreal species inhabits primary forest and forest edge (Duellman 1978, Jungfer and Hödl 2002). In Ecuador, it has been found in secondary forest, as well as agricultural and open lands (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). It breeds by larval development in temporary ponds and slow moving streams.
threats: This species appears to be somewhat adaptable to a degree of habitat disturbance and is likely not threatened at present.
population: It is considered to be common in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Its population is generally stable.
range: This species can be found throughout much of Amazonian Ecuador, and has also been recorded from northeastern Peru in Loreto. It might range further south, as it is often confused with a similar Osteocephalus. Its elevational range is 200–1,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with several protected areas and it has been recorded from Yasuní National Park.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large and stable population, and because there are no significant threats impacting the habitat at present.
habitat: This species can be found in the leaf-litter of tropical rainforest. Its reproductive mode is unknown, though it is presumably by larval development. It is not known whether or not the larvae develop in plants, or in waterbodies.
threats: While there is some localised habitat loss due to agriculture, logging, and cattle ranching, it is not thought to be causing significant declines.
population: It is locally abundant, but its distribution is not well known. It is very abundant in the Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor and Reserva Extrativista Riozinho da Liberdade. The population trend is thought to be stable (L. Moraes and P. Peloso pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
range: This species is known from the municipalities of Cruzeiro do Sul and Tarauaca in the state of Acre, and from the municipality of Atalaia do Norte in western Amazonas State (López and Ortega 2013), Brazil, adjacent to the Peruvian border. It may also occur in Peru, but as yet there are no records. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of the mapped distribution is 157,010 km2.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor and Reserva Extrativista do Alto Juruá, in Acre State.

Research Needed
Additional information is needed on this species´ distribution, population size and trend, ecology and life history.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species inhabits montane and lowland tropical rainforests. Males have been observed calling from low bushes and rocks along streams (Trueb and Duellman 1970). Breeding takes place in pools and slow streams. In Ecuador, it has been found in secondary forest, as well as agricultural and open lands (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). The species can be found alongside roads and in very disturbed habitat.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.) and logging, but since the species is very adaptable, these are probably not having a very serious impact on the species.
population: This is a common species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Its population is generally stable.
range: This species is found on the Lower Amazonian slopes of the Andes in Ecuador and Colombia, and 203 km to the southeast in the Cerro Kampankis area of Loreto, Peru (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012). Specimens previously referred to from central Peru (Regions of Junin, San Martín and Ucayali) have been assigned to O. elkejungingerae (K. Jungfer pers. comm.). It is possible that specimens considered to be O. verruciger in Colombia might refer to a different species (K. Jungfer pers. comm.). It has an altitudinal range of 1,400–2,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva Ecológica Cayambe-Coca, and Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras. In Colombia it might occur in Cuevadea los Guacharos. In Peru, it occurs in Santiago-Comaina Reserved Zone.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and it occurs in a number of protected areas.
habitat: This species can be found in tropical primary and secondary moist forest, including terra firme forest and seasonally flooded forest. It has been recorded from open areas (Ron and Pramuk 1999), but this requires further investigation. Breeding takes place in temporary pools. It is not present in degraded areas.
threats: There are no major threats, it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: This species is reasonably abundant and the population is considered to be stable. It is considered to be common in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).
range: This species is known from the upper Amazon Basin in Ecuador within a latitudinal range encompassed by the Río Napo to the north and the Río Curary to the south. Also known from two localities near Iquitos, Junction of Río Yanamono and Río Amazonas, Quebrada Grande, junction of Río Sucusari and Río Napo, Loreto Region, in northeastern Peru. It has been recorded from Leticia in Colombia (Lynch 2002). All localities are from 100–250 m asl. Further work is likely needed to understand if this species occurs more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, this species might occur in Allpahuayo Mishana Reserved Zone and Pacaya Samiria National Reserve. In Ecuador, it occurs within Parque Nacional Yasuní.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This is a lowland tropical rainforest species. At Loreto, Peru, one specimen was found in rolling terrain with steep slopes and small, sandy bottomed streams in primary forest (Duellman and Mendelson III 1995). The breeding habitat is not known, though the larvae are likely to develop in streams. It is not known if it can adapt to modified habitats.
threats: It is generally a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as logging, livestock grazing and agriculture.
population: It is generally rare, with few specimens at each locality.
range: The distribution of this species is poorly known from isolated records in Peru, Colombia and Ecuador. It has been recorded from several localities in Loreto and San Martín Regions in Peru (Cope 1874, Duellman and Mendelson III 1995), two localities in Caquetá Department in Colombia, and several localities in Napo and Orellana Provinces in Ecuador (Read 2002, Cisneros-Heredia 2006, Vigle 2008). It probably occurs more widely than current records suggest, especially in areas between known sites. Its occurs up to 800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Estación Biológica Jatun Sacha (Vigle 2008) and Estación de Biodiversidad Tiputini (Cisneros-Heredia 2006) in Ecuador. Given its known habitat and geographic distribution in Peru, this species might occur in Bosque de Proteccion Alto Mayo, and might also be in Santiago Comaina Reserved Zone.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: Its habitat is lowland tropical rainforest. At Loreto, the holotype was found in a permanent or semi-permanent pond supporting Heliconia in a depression in rainforest. This specimen was perched on vegetation ca 4 m above the ground at the edge of a forest pond (Duellman and Mendelson III 1995). In Ecuador, it is found in primary and secondary forests, and forest borders (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017), suggesting a tolerance of low habitat disturbance, however it is not present in degraded habitats. The species deposits eggs on leaves overhanging temporary ponds; the larvae develop in the pools.
threats: The most western part of the Ecuadorian range is suffering from habitat loss (agriculture, logging, etc.).
population: It is not an abundant species. In Ecuador, it is considered to be uncommon to rare (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).
range: This species is known from the type locality in North Teniente Lopez, between Río Pastaza and Río Tigre, northern Departamento Loreto, Peru and from three single localities in Ecuador. Additional records of the species are located along the Amazon basin of Ecuador and northern Loreto, Peru (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014). While the species is known from only a few sites it is expected to occur more widely in the suitable habitat between these areas. It occurs up to 450 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, it is found within Parque Nacional Yasuní, Yachana Reserve and Estación Biológica Jatun Sacha. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits closed-canopy flooding forest, and generally it is found close to forest streams. It occurs in secondary forest, but it is not known if it can occur in degraded forest. Based on information from congeners, it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: There are no major threats and there are large areas of suitable habitat remaining. However, there is some localized habitat loss due to human activities such as agriculture for both crops and livestock.
population: It is an uncommon species. While there is ongoing local habitat loss, it is unknown what disturbance this species can tolerate and the population is believed to be stable.
range: This species can be found in Loreto Region, northeastern Peru and Amazonas Department in southeastern Colombia. Its altitudinal range is below 200 m asl. The limits of its distribution are not very well known, though it is expected to range more widely. This species is considered to have a very restricted distribution in northern Loreto, Peru (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014)
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The area within its range in Peru has been proposed as a Priority by the Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez 1996). In Colombia, it is present in Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu, Parque Nacional Natural Río Puré and Parque Nacional Cahuinari.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland forest and is found in terra firme and seasonally flooded forest with a close canopy and wide leaves. Individuals are usually found perched on leaves at night (10–15 m); by day they have been found in bromeliads and sleeping on the undersides of leaves on bushes and trees (Duellman 1978, Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). It is present in cultivated areas. It feeds on ants and termites. This is a direct developing species.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). Within Peru, selective wood extraction and oil exploitation (northern Peru) and colonization (central Peru) are specific threats.
population: It is locally abundant in Ecuador; known from relatively few individuals in Peru. The population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species was previously reported in the lowland reaches of the Andes in southern Ecuador; Loreto Department in northern Peru, southern Colombia, and Acre State in Brazil. However, following genetic and morphological analysis, subpopulations from eastern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago, Orellana, and Pastaza provinces) and northern Loreto Department in Peru, up to 960 m asl, have now been assigned to other species (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). This species is now restricted to the lowland reaches of the Andes in southern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago and Pastaza provinces) and in northern Peru, through the Pastaza Trench. It can be found in elevations of 100–900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is present in a number of protected areas. Within Peru, the range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. In Ecuador, it occurs in the Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, Parque Nacional Yasuní, and Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 18,223 km<sup>2</sup>, it is common, adaptable, and its population is considered to be stable.
habitat: This species’ habitat is the tropical montane dry forest, montane cloud forest, and sub-páramo (Duellman and Pramuk, 1999). It also occurs in disturbed habitats, including secondary forest, agricultural lands and pastures (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Although it sometimes is found on low vegetation at night, most individuals have been found by day; many were under rocks in sub-páramo, others were in either terrestrial or arboreal bromeliads in forest (Lynch and Duellman 1997). This species presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: In Peru (including within protected areas in the region), destruction and loss of habitats for livestock and selective wood extraction. In Ecuador, habitat destruction and degradation are the main threats. However, this species demonstrates a degree of tolerance for habitat disturbance.
population: It is a common species both in Peru (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017) and Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). This species is the most widespread species of the Genus in western Peru and Ecuador and its population is considered to be stable.
range: This species from the Western Cordillera of the Andes ranges from southern Ecuador (at Luz Maria in Azuay Province, and around Cuenca de Loja in the Loja Basin in Loja Province), through the Huancabamba Depression area of northen Peru, in the Regions of Lambayeque, Piura and Cajamarca, south at least as far as Huambos. It occurs at elevations of 1,800–3,100 m asl. It is probably a species complex (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, this species might occur in one small-protected area in NW Peru, Tabaconas Namballe National Sanctuary. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Area de Recreación Cajas, and Parque Nacional Podocarpus.

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed in the border area between Ecuador and Peru to better understand the species' distribution. Based on its wide geographic and elevational distribution and phenotypical variation, molecular research is suggested to determine whether this is a complex of more than one species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017, D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species occurs in lowland primary rainforest. It is nocturnal and is found on low vegetation (0.5–1.5 m) in dense forests (Lynch and Duellman 1980). The ability of this species to adapt to modified habitats is unknown, although it can be found in lightly disturbed habitats, such as secondary forests (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). It is presumed to be a direct development species; egg deposition site is not known.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.) and colonization.
population: It is common throughout Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017), but not over the entire range.
range: This species is known restricted to the upper Amazon Basin in southern Colombia, Ecuadora, and extreme northeastern Peru. It occurs from 75–700 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in several protected areas. The range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu in Madre de Dios, Peru. In Colombia, it is present in Amacayacu, La Paya and El Pure. It is present in Yasuni and a second protected area in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland humid tropical rainforest. The holotype was found in a rocky streambed in lowland rainforest by day. These frogs ascend low vegetation at night and take diurnal refuge amidst leaf litter on the ground (Duellman and Lehr 2009). It is not known if it occurs in modified habitats. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: Presumably there are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to human activities such as agriculture for crops and livestock.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known from lowland rainforest at Finca Panguana (200 m asl) on the Río Llullapichis, 4–5 km upstream from the Río Pachitea, (Huanuco Region), central Peru and Tambopata in Madre de Dios Region in southern Peru. It is not recorded from Bolivia, however this lowland species is expected to range more widely. It is present below 200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: The range of this species overlaps with Tambopata-Candamo National Reserve (Madre de Dios).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and tolerance to a degree of habitat disturbance.
habitat: It occurs in tropical dry forest, moist montane forest, sub-páramo, and páramo, where most individuals have been found along streams. It also is present in secondary forest, agricultural areas (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017), and in large bromeliads on rocky slopes and cliffs (Venegas 2005). This species breeds by direct development, though the egg deposition site is not known.
threats: Destruction and loss of habitats for livestock and selective logging is taking place, even within protected areas. In the 2004 assessment, the species was flagged as potentially susceptible to infection by the chytrid fungus as with other species in the genus that are associated with streams, but there is no further information on this threat.
population: In both Peru and Ecuador, it is a common species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its population trend is generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is widely distributed on the Pacific slopes and lowlands of southern Ecuador (Loja Province) and northern Peru (Cajamarca, Piura, Lambayaque Regions), between 450–3,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, this species occurs in the Zona Reservada de Tumbes and might occur in the Tabaconas Namballe National Sanctuary. In Ecuador, it occurs in Parque Nacional Podocarpus. It is considered Near Threatened in Ecuador (Ron et al. 2017).

Research Needed
Further research on this species' population size, distribution and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its likely wide distribution, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland closed-canopy flooding forest. It is not known whether it can occur in degraded habitats. It breeds by direct development.
threats: There are no major threats and there are large areas of suitable habitat remaining. However, there is some localized habitat loss due to human activities such as agriculture for crops and livestock.
population: The population is considered to be stable.
range: This species is known only from several localities (Colonia, 3 km NE Pebas, and Yagua village) in Loreto Region, northern Peru and from southern Amazonas Department, Colombia. This species is considered to have a very restricted distribution in northern Loreto, Peru (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014). It might occur more widely and is present below 200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species lives in an area that has been proposed as a Priority for Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez 1996). Its range overlaps with Yaguas Restricted Zone and Ampiyacu Apayacu Regional Conservation Area, however its occurrence in these areas should be confirmed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: It is an inhabitant of Eastern Cordillera Real Montane Forest and Napo Moist Forests in the eastern tropical Altitudinal Zone. Specimens have been observed by day on the forest floor and at night on low vegetation in forests. At Parque Nacional Yasuni it has been recorded in Terra Firme primary forest. It is also known from secondary forest, and clearings. It presumably reproduces by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as, logging are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: The population status of this species is not known.
range: This species is known from north of the Pastaza River, in Amazonian Ecuador, in the provinces of Sucumbíos, Orellana, Pastaza and Morona Santiago, from 300–600 m asl. It is likely to occur more widely, probably in neighbouring Colombia and Peru, although this requires confirmation.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its distribution range includes Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Parque Nacional Yasuni, Reserva Biólogica Limoncocha, and Reserva Ecológica Cayambe-Coca. It is considered Least Concern in Ecuador (Frenkel et al. 2018).

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to better understand its population status.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of primary and secondary forest and flooded forest (Duellman 1978). It is active mostly at night among fallen leaves and low vegetation, it is frequently found in epiphytes. It presumably breeds by direct development like other species in the genus, with egg deposition in the leaf-litter. The ability of the species to adapt to modified habitats is unknown.
threats: Habitat loss caused by deforestation for agricultural development, illegal crops, and livestock are localized threats, but there are no major threats to the species' overall survival at present.
population: In Ecuador, it is an uncommon frog, although widely distributed (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2017). There is no population information for Colombia or Peru.
range: This species is known from Amazonian Ecuador (Sucumbíos, Orellana and Pastaza Provinces) and adjacent Colombia in the Department of Putumayo. Duellman and Lehr (2009) documented a specimen from Moropón, in the vicinity of Iquitos, Loreto Region, Peru. It has been recorded between 330–570 m asl. It is likely to be distributed more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Colombia, it is known from La Payas Nature Reserve. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva Biológica Limoncocha and Parque Nacional Yasuní. It is not known from any protected areas in Peru.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It is present in the Amazon cloud forest (Lynch and Duellman 1980). In both Peru and Ecuador, all individuals have been found on low vegetation at night. It is a species that breeds by direct development; the egg deposition site is not known. It is not known if the species occurs in degraded habitats.
threats: Presumably, there are no major threats to this species. It is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), oil exploration and colonization.
population: It is a common species and its population is considered to be stable.
range: This species is distributed primarily on the eastern slopes of the Andes, where it is known in Ecuador from elevations of 92–1,740 m asl in the Cordillera Oriental, (Morona-Santiago) at 1,700 m asl in the Cordillera de Cutucù, and 1,500–1,550 m asl (Napo) on the western slopes of the Cordillera del Cóndor. In Peru, it is known from elevations as low as 200 m asl in the Amazonian lowlands (Amazonas Region). Its altitudinal range is from 200–1,900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The range of this species overlaps with the Reserva Comunal Santiago-Comaina, Peru. In Ecuador, it is present in several protected areas, including Reserva Ecológica río Anzu and Reserva río Zuñac.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population size, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2 - threats are mostly localized, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although its distribution is somewhat limited (estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,672 km<sup>2</sup>), the species adapts to disturbed habitats and it has an inferred stable and large population.
habitat: This species inhabits montane forests where individuals may be found perched on low vegetation. It has been recorded in degraded areas (G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2017). Reproduction occurs by direct development.
threats: Localized agriculture (including livestock) and human settlement are threats to the species. Direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affected by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: This species is abundant within its known range (G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2017). The population is likely to be stable.
range: This species can be found in the eastern slopes of the Andes in the Peruvian Regions of Ayacucho, Cusco, and probably Apurimac, from elevations between 1,000–2,650 m asl (Duellman and Lehr 2009). All Bolivian specimens previously considered to belong to this species, and some from Cusco and Puno, Peru are now considered P. pharangobates (Duellman and Lehr 2009, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,672 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the buffer zones of several national parks, however it is not known from within any protected areas. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: It is found in high-elevation, premontane and lowland primary forest (including swamp forest) with closed canopy and wide leaves. It is usually observed perched on leaves of trees and bushes at night in swamp forest. It has been found in rotten logs during the day. It breeds by direct development, though the egg deposition site is not known. In Ecuador, the species has been found in secondary forest and areas slightly disturbed by agriculture.
threats: Presumably there are no major threats to the population. It is a wide-ranging species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to human activities such as crop agriculture and livestock rearing. Climate change has been suggested as a threat to this species in Ecuador.
population: It is a common species and the population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is known from southern Ecuador, eastern Peru and northern Bolivia. The presence of this species in Brazil requires further investigation. It is found in lowlands and recorded as high as 1,700 m asl by Duellman and Pramuk (1999).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, the range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu and Tambopata-Candamo National Reserve (Madre de Dios). In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galereas, Reserva Ecológica Antisana and Parque Nacional Llanganates.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the potentially increasing threats of agricultural expansion and climate change.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, and presumed large population.
habitat: It occurs in deforested and disturbed areas, next to streams or far from them, in cloud forest and sub-páramo habitats. It is tolerant of substantial habitat disturbance. It also occurs inside old-growth forest, but it is not very common. It perches on vegetation up to 3 m above ground, and during the day it can be found on fallen leaves. It breeds by direct development and the egg deposition occurs under rocks.
threats: Extirpations in western Cundinamarca are presumably a result of water pollution from Bogotá. It should be noted that some congeners associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances, possibly due to chytridiomycosis, so the status of this species should be monitored (the disappearances in western Cundinamarca appear to predate the appearance of chytridiomycosis as a threat to amphibians).
population: This species is currently abundant in Colombia and common in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017), although it has been experienced declines in some localities in Ecuador. It appears to undergo population fluctuations. For example, in Huacalito, the species ranged from common to absent to common over the course of six years. Subpopulations in western Cundinamarca were common until the mid 1940s, but have not been observed in numerous trips between the late 1960s and 2000. In Ecuador, it was previously abundant at many localities. For example, although it has been recently found at sites such as Bosque Protector Cashca Totoras, Provincia Bolívar, Reserva Otonga (QCAZ database), it is not as common as in the past (Bustamante 2002, L. Coloma pers. obs.)
range: This species is known from lower montane and cloud forest at 800–3,300 m asl on both Pacific and Amazonian slopes of the Andes in Colombia, Ecuador, and extreme northern Peru (Duellman and Lehr 2009). It occurs from southern Ecuador, to the three Cordilleras and the northern area from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia. It is the most widespread Pristimantis in the Colombian Andes. The records from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta might be in error.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Colombia, because of its extensive distribution, many of this species' subpopulations are inside protected areas, including Munchique, Los Farallones, Las Orquideas, Tatama, Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Cueva de los Guacharos, Las Hermosas, Los Nevados, and Purace National Natural Parks; La Planada Natural Reserve. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva Ecológica Cotacachi-Cayapas, Reserva Ecológica Cayambe-Coca, Reserva Ecológica Antisana, Reserva Geobotánica Pululahua, Parque Necional Cotopaxi, Reserva Ecológica Los Illinizas, Parque Nacional Llanganates, Parque Nacional Sangay, Reserva de Producción Faunística Chimborazo, and Area de Recreación Cajas. In Peru, it has been recorded from Santuario Tabaconas-Namballe.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' population status.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: It is a terrestrial species of open montane puna grassland and semi deciduous forest habitats (De la Riva et al. 2000, Köhler 2000). It is very adaptable, being present in agricultural land and urban environments. Pairs build foam nests that float in small permanent and temporary pools.
threats: There are no major threats to this species in its range.
population: It is a common species throughout its range. The population is considered to be stable.
range: This is an Andean species ranging from southern Peru, through much of Bolivia (Departments of Santa Cruz, Tarija, Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosi) and northwestern Argentina. It occurs at elevations between 600–4,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is present in several protected areas in Bolivia and two (Los Andes Provincial Reserve and Laguna Pozuelos National Park) in Argentina, but it is not found in Peruvian protected areas.

Research Needed
Further research is required to resolve the taxonomy of this species. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: Aquatic species that lives in slow flowing watercourses, backwater of streams, and ponds and pools in tropical rainforest, hiding under submerged leaf-litter. They also occur in flooded forest. They seldom venture onto land, where they move clumsily. Direct development takes place on the dorsum of the adult.
threats: It is not seriously threatened, but local populations are probably impacted by habitat loss and degradation due to logging, agricultural expansion, and human settlement.
population: It is common throughout its range and the population appears to be stable.
range: This species is widespread in the Amazon basin of South America in Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, and Brazil. It is also present at scattered localities in southern and eastern Trinidad Island (in Trinidad and Tobago). It is a lowland species found below 400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in many protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species can be found in Amazonian primary lowland forest, including terra firme forest (nonflooded forest), várzea (flooded forest), and seasonally flooded forest (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Individuals can be most often found up to 40 m into the canopy, often associated with bromeliads, although they may also occur on low vegetation and on the forest floor (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Breeding occurs by direct development.
threats: No major threats are known for this species. Deforestation and forest fragmentation caused by petroleum operations and subsequent road building and colonization have been observed in the vicinity Tiputini Biodiversity Station (McCracken and Forstner 2014b). Nonetheless, Tiputini Biodiversity Station is only accessible by river and the area is still surrounded by undisturbed primary lowland rainforest (McCracken and Forstner 2014a). Four out of seven specimens collected during May–August of 2004 and 2006 from sites surrounding Tiputini Biodiversity Station tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (McCracken et al. 2009), however whether Bd constitutes a threat to this direct developing species remains unknown.
population: This appears to be an abundant species in the canopy; bromeliad patch sampling of 40 bromeliads among eight trees resulted in the collection of eight specimens (Guayasamin et al. 2006). The scarcity of this species in herpetological collections is likely an artifact of survey methodology (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is known from below 350 m asl in the upper Amazon Basin of eastern Ecuador and Loreto Region in northern Peru (Guayasamin et al. 2006).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within two biological stations in Ecuador, Yasuní Scientific Research Station and Tiputini Biodiversity Station.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' population size, distribution and trends is recommended.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because it is common, has a stable and presumed large population, and it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat.
habitat: The species occurs in páramo and humid montane forest. Individuals have been found during the day on moss and at night on the ground or on vegetation up to 1.7 m above the ground. It can sometimes be found in terrestrial or arboreal bromeliads. It likely breeds by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: No major threats are currently known for this species.
population: This is considered to be a common species (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2008), and the population is considered to be stable.
range: This species is known from four localities in northern Piura Region (District of Carmen de la Frontera, Province of Huancabamba), and adjacent Cajamarca Region (District of Tabaconas, Province of San Ignacio, Department of Cajamarca), Peru (Lehr et al. 2007). It occurs at elevations between 1,900–3,100 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range overlaps with Bosques Montaños y Páramos Chicuate-Chinguelas Private Conservation Area.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: The species is found in very humid montane forest and in patches of elfin forest. Individuals are found on leaves of low bushes, 30–150 cm above ground at night. Sympatric species at the different localities include Colostethus sp., Pristimantis wagteri, Gastrotheca ossilaginis, Rhinella arborescandens, Centrolene lemniscatus, Pristimantis bromeliaceus, P. rufioculis, P. schultei, P. stictoboubonus, Gastrotheca ossilaginis and Telmatobius atahualpai (Duellman et al. 2006). Its breeding strategy remains unknown.
threats: Enciso et al. (2008) reported Aeromonas caviae and other bacteria from skin samples, where this species was one of the sampled species, and suggested that there is a potential for infection and development of the disease if populations undergo stress. There are currently no other threats known for this species.
population: This species is considered to be relatively abundant (P. Venegas pers. comm. 2008).
range: This species is known from several localities at elevations between 2,347–3300 m asl in the regions of San Martín and Amazonas, Peru (P. Venegas pers. comm. 2008; Beraún et al. 2014). This area corresponds to the Cordillera Central in northern Peru (Duellman et al. 2006). It is now also found in eight additional localities in the Amazonas region, Peru: Área de Conservación Privada Huiquilla (ACP Huiquilla), Luya Province (2,935–2,941 m asl); Sunipampa (near Leimebamba), Chachapoyas Province (2,521 m asl);  Molinopampa, Chachapoyas Province (2,566–2,574 m asl); Bagazán, Rodríguez de Mendoza Province (3,067 m asl); Quebrada Salas (Vista Alegre), Rodríguez de Mendoza Province (2,575–2,578 m asl); Sedrusco (Vista Alegre), Rodríguez de Mendoza Province (2,403–2,405 m asl); San Pedro (Lonya Chico), Luya Province (2,826 m asl); and La Colpa, Rodríguez de Mendoza Province (2,347 m asl) (Beraún et al. 2014). In the San Martín region, Peru, the species is now found in one new locality: Laurel and Las Piñas, Mariscal Cáceres Province (2,756–3,281 m asl) (Beraún et al. 2014).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species is reported to occur in the Área de Conservación Privada Huiquilla (Enciso et al. 2008).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution over a large tract of suitable habitat.
habitat: This species appears to prefer primary lowland forests flooded by white and black waters, and is occasionally found in lowland nonflooded (terra-firme) forests. The type locality is a swampy area (water depth 5–20 cm), ca 50 m from a stream. At the Tiputini Biodiversity Station, the species has been found in small slow rivulets amidst the low riverine vegetation. In Loreto, Peru, it has been found at night sitting on a leaf, near stream (von May and Mueses-Cisnero 2011). One female was found to contain ca 70 unpigmented oviductal eggs of ca 2 mm (Faivovich et al. 2006). As with other congeners, this species is believed to have aquatic larval development.
threats: Although the species has a widespread distribution, several areas of its current distributional range are severely affected by deforestation. Colonization and the expansion of the agricultural frontier is a threat to the areas surrounding Limoncocha and Cuyabeno in northeastern Ecuador and Iquitos in northern Peru (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2008). Contamination of water sources due to residues of oil extraction threaten the species around Cuyabeno, northeastern Ecuador (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2008).
population: No population status information is available for this species; however, it is relatively uncommon to rare in most areas where it has been recorded (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2008; R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is distributed in the western Amazon Basin. Specimens reported in the original description originate from the northern and southern regions of eastern lowland Ecuador and from northeastern Peru at elevations from 120–600 m asl, and from lowlands of Colombia around Leticia. The northernmost locality is "Singue", province of Sucumbíos, Ecuador, whereas the southernmost record is Leticia, Colombia. Additional records of the species are located along the Amazon basin of Ecuador and northern Loreto, Peru (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014). The species probably has a wider distribution within Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, and likely also occurs in adjacent western Brazil (Faivovich et al. 2006).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species is known to occur at Reserva de Producción Faunıstica Cuyabeno, Yasuni National Park, Parque Nacional Sangay, and Tiputini Biodiversity Station in Ecuador, and the Gueppi Reserved Area, Allpahuayo-Mishana National Reserve, and Yaguas Reserved Zone in Peru (Faivovich et al. 2006, von May and Mueses-Cisneros 2011).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population. The southern part of its distribution is threatened by mining activities, but it does not affect most of the species distribution and it is found in several protected areas.
habitat: It lives in primary cloud forest. The holotype was found in a bromeliad in the spray zone of a waterfall and on a cliff (Lynch and Duellman 1973). It lays its eggs on vegetation and the larvae develop in water.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation, as a result of agriculture, logging and mining activities, are localized threats to this species in Ecuador (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). In Colombia, the Cauca locality is protected, but there is extensive deforestation in the region of the Putumayo locality (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).
population: It is locally common species in Ecuador (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). In Colombia, the species is known definitively only from a single specimen collected in 1974 (Mueses-Cisneros 2005) and another in 1998 (Donegan and Rojas-Díaz 2007), and it is known from only a single site in Peru (Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin 2014).
range: This species was formerly known from a few localities on the Amazonian slopes of the Andes: Río Salado and Cascada de San Rafael, Napo Province, Ecuador, and from 35 km southwest of San Francisco, Putumayo department, Colombia (Lynch and Duellman 1973, Mueses-Cisneros 2005). It is now also known from Reserva Biológica Narupa (Napo Province; Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2010), as well as, Nangaritza and Machinaza (Cordillera del Cóndor; Guayasamin et al. 2011, Almendariz 2014) in Ecuador, and Serrania de los Churumbelos, Cauca department in Colombia (Donegan and Rojas-Díaz 2007). Following the synonymy of E. fernandoi, this species is now also known to occur on the west slope of Abra Tangarana in San Martín, Peru (Duellman and Schulte 1993, Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin 2014). It is found at altitudes from 1,080–1,900 m asl. This taxon may represent a complex of species.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its distribution is within several protected areas, including Parque Nacional Natural Serranía de Cherrumbelos in Colombia, as well as, Parque Nacional Sangay and Reserva Biológica Narupa in Ecuador. In Peru, it likely occurs in Los Chilchos Private Conservation Area, designated in 2005.

Conservation Needed
Improved protection of the montane forest habitat in the southern part of the range of this species is necessary. 

Research Needed
Taxonomic work is needed to determine if this form is a complex of more than one species. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,588 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat.
habitat: This nocturnal glass frog occurs in habitats ranging from small creeks to torrential streams to spray zones of waterfalls in submontane and lowland forests. This species has never been registered from heavily disturbed habitat, but does occur in secondary forest (Twomey et al. 2014). The species has been found at night perched on low streamside vegetation (calling males have been heard as high as ~4 m) and on boulders and rock faces along streams (Duellman and Schulte 1993, Twomey et al. 2014). Neither eggs nor tadpoles have been found from this species, but reproduction is suspected to take place in streams.
threats: The main threat to this species is habitat loss due to agriculture, livestock farming, wood extraction, and human settlement. There is also a waterfall at the type locality of this species which is regularly visited by regional tourists, which could potentially negatively impact the species (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). The available habitat is very fragmented.
population: It is a common species at the type locality, and was originally described from a series of 30 adult males (Duellman and Schulte 1993). In 2004, over 50 individuals were found over the course of 20 person/day surveys (von May et al. 2008), suggesting that this species is not uncommon. In 2010 and 2011, a series of 14 specimens were collected from from four sites: three males and three females from the type locality of Ahuashiyacu, four males from 2.3 km E of Ahuashiyacu, three males from Abra Tangarana, and one male from 6 km SE from Abra Tangarana (Twomey et al. 2014). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known only from one locality (two sites in close proximity to each other) at 800 m asl on the south slope of the north-west-south-east range of the mountains immediately to the north of Tarapoto Province, San Martin Department, in northern Peru. Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analysis, Cochranella croceopodes and Rulyrana tangarana have been synonymised with it (Twomey et al. 2014). It is now known from the Cordillera Escalera, roughly between the cities of Tarapoto and Moyobamba, in the Department of San Martín, northern Peru, between 517–1,047 m asl (Twomey et al. 2014). It probably occurs more widely, but it is still likely to have a restricted distribution. It occurs in two threat-defined locations and its EOO is 1,588 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation ActionsThis species occurs in the Area de Conservacion Regional Cordillera Escalera. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Continued habitat protection is required.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. The potential impacts of localized climate change and possible infection with the chytrid fungus require further investigation.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: It can be found in the lowland and montane rainforest. Frogs are active on the forest floor by day; a few have been found on low herbaceous vegetation at night (Lynch and Duellman 1980, Beirne and Whitworth 2011). This species breeds by direct development. It may be found in primary, secondary and lightly modified habitats, as well as plantations and pastureland (Beirne et al. 2013).
threats: Presumably, there are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), oil exploration and colonization.
population: It is a common species. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its population trend is generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is upper Amazon Basin and adjacent Andean slopes in southern Colombia, Ecuador, and northern Peru. Its elevational range is from 200–1,935 m asl. Its potential presence in Brazil still needs to be confirmed.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, the range of this species is overlap with the areas have been proposed as Priority by Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez 1996). In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps several protected areas, including the Yacana Reserve, Sangay National Park, and Cofán Bermejo Ecological Reserve. It is present in three Colombian protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, it is found in several large protected areas in Ecuador.
habitat: This species occurs in sub-Andean and Andean forests, on vegetation alongside streams. Calling activity has been reported in June (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Eggs are laid on leaves over-hanging water and when they hatch the tadpoles drop into the streams below where they develop further. They require gallery forest to lay their eggs, and hence are sensitive to any disturbance of their forest habitat.
threats: Threats to this species include habitat fragmentation, loss and degradation due to the expansion of agriculture (including the planting of illegal crops), mining activities and timber extraction, and water pollution.
population: It is a rare species throughout its range. There are no recent records from Colombia. The Purace site is regularly visited, including in 2016, but the species has not been recorded (J. Guerrero-Vargas pers. comm. 2016). The population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species was previously only known from Colombia and Ecuador between 1,100–2,800 m asl; from Caldas (Samaná), Cauca (Inza) and Huila (San Jose Isnos) Departments on the eastern flank of the Cordillera Central in Colombia to cloud forests surrounding Yanayacu Biological Station (at 2,100 m asl) in eastern Ecuador (Guayasamin et al. 2006). It is now also known from on the extreme southwestern slope of the Cordillera del Condor and the eastern slopes of the Andes, Jaen Province, Cajamarca Department in northeastern Peru, at 1,200 m asl (Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2008).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The range of the species in Colombia and Peru does not include any protected areas, but in Ecuador the species is found in several protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: It occurs on the ground in lowland forest. It lays eggs in the leaf-litter, and the males probably take care of the eggs and then move the larvae to small waterbodies for their development.
threats: Localised habitat destruction caused by the expansion of agriculture is a potential threat, but there is plenty of suitable habitat in the region so the effect of these activities on the population is unknown.
population: It is a rare species with few specimens in collections, although it was collected again in 2003. Few collecting efforts have been carried out at its only known locality (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).
range: This species is known from Puerto Nariño, Amazonas Department, in extreme south-eastern Colombia, at 40-200 m asl (Rivero 1991). It is likely to occur more widely, and, since this locality is located close to the Colombian, Peruvian and Brazilian borders, it is likely to occur also in Peru and Brazil (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is not known from any protected area. It might occur in Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu, located 60 km NW of Leticia, although it has not been found there in two extensive collecting trips (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This diurnal and nocturnal species occurs in primary and secondary forest, and occasionally uses forest edge and clearings (Duellman 1978). It is terrestrial, and is often found in leaf-litter. In Ecuador, it has also been recorded in agricultural and open lands (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Breeding takes place in temporary waterbodies and slow-moving streams during the wet season. Its eggs on foam nest next to pools and tadpoles are found in the water.
threats: Local subpopulations are probably impacted by severe habitat loss, such as clear-cutting, and agricultural expansion. However, overall, this species is not significantly threatened.
population: It is a common species. Its p<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Population trends are generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">opulation trend is generally stable.
range: This species is known to occur in Amazonian Ecuador, northeastern Peru, and Amazonian Colombia. No voucher of this species occurs in Suriname (Hoogmoed 2013), however further research is needed to determine whether the records from French Guiana and other parts of the Guiana Shield are E. petersi, E. freibergi, or an undescribed species (Funk et al. 2008, P. Kok pers. comm. September 2017). We temporarily include these records in this assessment until this species' taxonomic status can be clarified. It occurs between 89 and 1,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in many protected areas, including Yasuní National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends. Molecular, morphological, and call analysis from French Guiana and other parts of the Guiana Shield is needed to determine whether these frogs are P. petersi, P. freibergi, or an undescribed species (Funk et al. 2008).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although this species is known mainly from isolated records from a large area, it has a wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This is generally a primary tropical moist forest species. This frog has been found in primary and secondary forests (Duellman 1978). In the Iquitos area of Peru, specimens have been found only in primary forest, where most individuals were found sitting on low vegetation at night (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). It is a direct development species, whereby eggs are carried in a pouch on the female's back. It is not present in modified habitats. The species eats other frogs, and probably only survives in areas of high frog density.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss to different human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), and selective logging.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trend, however the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat. During surveys in the upper reaches of the Ampiyacu River basin of Loreto, Peru in 2003, the species was observed in high abundance at Maronal (Pitman et al. 2004).
range: This species is known from the Amazonian lowlands of Peru, northeastern Ecuador and two sites in the southern part of Amazonas Department, Colombia. It is found up to 300 m asl. It presumably occurs more widely, in particular between known sites.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno, Parque Nacional Yasuní, Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Parque Nacional Llanganates, and Parque Nacional Sangay. In Colombia, it has been recorded from Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu. In Peru it occurs in the Yaguas Reserved Zone.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends. Further research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species generally occurs in primary tropical moist forest, though it has been found in both primary and secondary forests (Duellman 1978). In the Iquitos region, Peru, specimens have been found only in primary forest, where most individuals were found sitting on low vegetation at night (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). It breeds by direct development, whereby eggs are carried in a pouch on the female's back. It is not present in modified habitats. The species eats other frogs, and probably only survives in areas of high anuran density.
threats: There are no major threats. It is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to different human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is generally a rare species. There is some population decline in Ecuador, the causes of which are unclear.
range: This species occurs in the Upper Amazon Basin in southeastern Colombia, Ecuador and northern Peru. Its altitudinal range is from 100–1,200 m asl. Its presence in Brazil remains uncertain.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno, Parque Nacional Yasuní, Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Parque Nacional Llanganates, and Parque Nacional Sangay. In Colombia, it has been recorded from Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu. In Peru, it might be present in Gueppi Reserved Zone.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern based on its relatively wide range and presumed large population. In view of the absence of recent records from throughout its range, additional field studies are essential to determine whether this species is experiencing substantial population declines. Should such declines be documented, an immediate uplisting would be warranted.
habitat: This species inhabits montane cloud forests (Duellman 1974). At night juveniles have been found on leaves of bushes and herbs, and adults at 2–10 m above the ground, on branches of trees. It breeds by direct development, whereby the eggs develop directly in a pouch on the female's back and hatch into froglets (Duellman and Trueb 2015). It is among the largest species of Gastrotheca, with both sexes reaching a snout-vent-length of 86 mm (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat destruction and degradation throughout its range, mainly due to logging, human settlement, and agricultural development for livestock and crops (including some illegal crops).
population: It is considered a rare species and there are very few specimens in museums belonging to this species. It has apparently not been recorded recently, although any survey efforts to relocate the species are unknown. It might be difficult to find, and so its population status might be incorrectly estimated; nonetheless, the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of habitat.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Andes from southern Colombia (Huila and Caquetá Departments), through Ecuador (Morona Santiago, Zamora Chinchipe and Napo Provinces), to northern Peru (Amazonas Region). It has been found between 1,100-2,370 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Ecuador, its range overlaps with Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, the Reserva Ecológica Antisana, Parque Nacional Llanganates and Parque Nacional Sangay. It occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Alto Fragua-Indiwasi in Colombia.

Research Needed
Survey work is urgently needed to determine this species' population status, particularly whether or not it has experienced a drastic decline given the lack of recent records. Additional information is needed on this' species distribution and whether it occurs in between known sites.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because the population is suspected to decline at a rate of at least 50% over the next 10 years, primarily due to extensive mining activities and associated contamination of water bodies in the Cordillera del Cóndor region of Ecuador."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15145,"3":{"1":0},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"11":4,"12":0,"14":[null,2,0],"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of at least 30% over a 10 year period (2015–2025), due to the high rate of habitat loss throughout much of this species' range in Ecuador, Colombia and Peru as a result of infrastructure development, logging, and agricultural expansion, as well as, extensive mining projects in the Cordillera del Cóndor.
habitat: This species has been found in lower montane forest and dense cloud forest where it favours perches, such as branches of bushes and small trees (Trueb 1974). At Cordillera del Cutucú, Ecuador, specimens have been collected in very wet forest, where the ground and most trees were covered with moss (Duellman and Lynch 1988); it was also collected at the same habitat type in Peru. Species in the genus appear to be among the most sensitive of frog species to habitat alteration because all records come from pristine forest habitats—and subsequent visits to those sites (by experienced collectors) after habitat alterations failed to detect the animals (Lynch and Arroyo 2009). This species reproduces by direct development and the eggs are carried in a pouch on the female's back. It is probably a specialized predator on other frog species that only survives in areas of high frog density.
threats: This species is threatened by high rates of forest loss due to infrastructure development for human settlements, logging, and agricultural development (including for the cultivation of crops and the rearing of livestock). Towards the southern portion of its range, mining activities are wreaking havoc on the species' habitat (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, RAISG 2020).
