Although forest habitat still remains within the range of this species, it is very sensitive to slight habitat alteration and the rate of forest loss within the majority of its range (the Ecuadorian portion) is very high.
population:
It is a rare species. During 1967–1988, surveys detected 13 individuals/hour/person in Río Azuela, Sucumbíos, Ecuador. However, surveys in the same study area during 2000–2003 were unable to detect any individuals (Bustamante et al. 2005). In 2009, two specimens were collected in Miazi Alto in Zamora Chinchipe, Ecuador (E. Tapia and J. Guayasamín pers. obs. April 2009) and one specimen was collected from Nangaritza, Zamora Chinchipe in August 2010 (E. Tapia pers. obs.). It was most recently observed in Ecuador in Parque Nacional Podocarpus in 2015 (D. Rivadeneira pers. obs.) In Colombia, annual survey efforts during the period 2008–2016 within its reported range did not record the presence of the species (D. Mejia unpubl. data 2016). In 2017, however, the species was observed in well-preserved cloud forest in the watershed between Acevedo, Huila and Belén de los Andaquíes, Caquetá (Gutiérrez Lamus et al. 2020). 
Considering the high rate of habitat loss throughout much of this species' range as a result of infrastructure development, logging, and agricultural expansion, as well as, extensive mining projects in the Cordillera del Cóndor, the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of more than 30% over a 10 year period, from 2015–2025.
range: This species occurs in the upper Amazon Basin and lower Amazonian slopes of the Andes in southern Colombia (Caquetá to Putumayo), through Ecuador to northern Peru, from 300–2,000 m asl.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are few protected areas within its range in the Amazonian foothills of the Andes. Known records are within the Parque Nacional Cayambe-Coca and Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras in Ecuador. In Peru it has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is necessary for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This fossorial frog inhabits tropical moist forests. It lives in spaces between roots in the soil and in muddy areas next to water springs. Its reproduction involves depositing gelatin-wrapped eggs in underground chambers, where the eggs remain until they hatch (Gordo et al. 2006). It has not been recorded from anthropogenic habitats.
threats: Habitat loss caused by deforestation, agricultural development, and illegal crops are localized threats, but overall there are no currently known major threats to the species.
population: It is a very difficult species to find so it appears to be uncommon, but it is secretive due to small size and fossorial habits, and so it might be more common than it appears (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).
range: This species is known from southeastern Colombia (Vaupés and Putumayo departments), northeastern Ecuador and northwestern Peru. The first record from Peru was reported from the Matsés region (Gordo et al. 2006), representing a range expansion of at least 500 km. In 2009, it was recorded in Reserva Forestal Santa Cruz, Loreto Peru (López-Rojas and Cisneros-Heredia 2012), further expanding its range ca 230 km north of the first known Peruvian locality, 640 km SW of the type locality (Pyburn 1977), and 470 km SE of the nearest Ecuadorian locality (Tiputini Biodiversity Station, Orellana Province). It ranges from 100–700 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range in Colombia overlaps with La Paya National Park. In Ecuador, it occurs within Parque Nacional Yasuní, Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno and possibly occurs in Limoncocha Biological Reserve. In Peru, it occurs in Reserva Forestal Santa Cruz and Reserva Nacional Matsés.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population. This assessment is made on the basis that all subpopulations currently assigned to H. phyllognathus form part of a single clade. However, the taxon likely includes several cryptic species and several of these putative species have sharply declined throughout their ranges (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. 2018).
habitat: It is an arboreal and aquatic frog found in or along streams in submontane and montane cloud forest. Individuals have been seen on low bushes over torrential mountain streams, others have been found on vegetation along streams at night and in bromeliads by day (Duellman 1972). It is not found in secondary forest, and it presumably breeds in streams.
threats: The principal threats to the species are chytridiomycosis and habitat loss caused by shifting small-scale agriculture, livestock grazing, and timber harvesting. Subpopulations of H. phyllognathus disappeared from the upper Manu National Park (Cusco, Peru) following epizootics of chytridiomycosis in the early 2000s (Catenazzi et al. 2011, 2014). In 2007, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was detected in this species at Ahuashiyacu, San Martín (Kosch et al. 2012).
population: In Podocarpus National Park, Ecuador, it was uncommon in 1998. It is common in Colombia, and in 2002, it was common in San Martín, Peru. Some subpopulations from the cloud forests of Peru have declined and/or are locally extinct, while subpopulations from other parts of its range have not shown declines (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2017). Due to ongoing localised declines in the extent and quality of habitat, some subpopulations are suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs on the Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental in Colombia south to the Cordillera Central, along the length of the eastern slopes of the Andes in Ecuador, as well as in Cusco, Junín, San Martín, Pasco, and Ucayali Regions in Peru. It occurs at elevations of 410–2,190 m asl. This is likely to be a species complex (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in some Protected Natural Areas in Peru and in Yanachagana Chemillén, Manu, and Tingo María National Parks. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Parque Nacional Llanganates, Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Parque Nacional Sangay. In Colombia, it occurs in several protected areas.

Research Needed
Further research is necessary to understand the observed declines in certain subpopulations in Peru. Taxonomic work is needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2017).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It is a canopy species observed in primary and terra firme forest (Duellman 1974, Rodríguez and Duellman 1994, Ron et al. 2016). It has not been recorded from secondary or modified habitats. Individuals have been observed at night perching on vegetation 1.5–3.0 m above the ground and one individual was recorded from a tree hole filled with water (Ron et al. 2016). No amplectant pairs, clutches, or tadpoles have been observed, though it is likely to breed in water-filled tree holes (Ron et al. 2016).
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: This is a rare species. The lack of records, even at thoroughly sampled sites, such as Yasuni National Park, could be a consequence of small populations sizes or an artifact of low capture probabilities due to its microhabitat preferences (Ron et al. 2016).
range: This species' geographic range is the Amazon lowlands of Ecuador and northern Peru (Duellman 1974, Ron et al. 2016). The southernmost locality is Cordillera Escalera, San Martín, in northeastern Peru. Its elevational range is 130–1,075 m asl. The specimen from Ere River, Loreto, Peru previously assigned to this species actually represents Tepuihyla shushupe, a species recently described by Ron et al. (2016). Records from Amazonas, Brazil (Duellman 1974) and Colombia also probably correspond to T. shushupe, but this requires confirmation (Ron et al. 2016, Ron and Read 2017); this uncertainty is reflected in the species' distribution map.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, it has been recorded from Parque Nacional Yasuni and possibly occurs in Cuyabeno Reserva de Producción Faunística. In Peru, it is known from Area de Conservacion Regional Cordillera Escalera, and likely occurs in Reserva Nacional Allpahuayo Mishana.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: Its habitat is primary and secondary lowland tropical rainforest, often close to bamboo habitats. At Yasuní National Park, Ecuador, this nocturnal species has been collected in floodable forests (Ron 2001). Breeding takes place in bamboo internodes and tree holes, tadpoles are raised by the female on unfertilised eggs. It is not present in disturbed areas.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a relatively widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: This species is difficult to find, possibly in part because it lives in the forest canopy (A. Catenazzi and R. von May pers. comm. October 2017). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its population trend is generally stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is known from widely separated localities in Amazonian Colombia (Amazonas and Putumayo departments), Ecuador, and Peru. The locality from Putumayo, Colombia (Pérez-Villota et al. 2009) extended this species' range ca 83 km north from Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, the previous northernmost locality and ca 543 km from Leticia, the first Colombian record (Lynch 2005). It probably occurs more widely than current records suggest, especially in areas between known sites. Its altitudinal range is 200–1,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, it has been recorded in Parque Nacional Yasuní. It is not currently known from any protected areas in Peru or Colombia.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal, arboreal frog inhabits lowland and premontane wet and dry forests. It has also been found in disturbed areas, including secondary forest, agricultural and open lands (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). It is associated with medium and high canopy vegetation and lives in bromeliads and holes in tree trunks. It is an explosive breeder and eggs are deposited directly into lentic waterbodies. Males call from emergent vegetation in small pools at the edges of rivers (MECN 2010).
threats: Large parts of the habitat have been destroyed by deforestation for agricultural activities and cattle ranching, but the species is reasonably adaptable and not seriously threatened. In Colombia, this species may be threatened by the spraying of illegal crops (Lynch and Arroyo 2009).
population: This species is common in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017) and is considered to be uncommon in Peru. However, several individuals were seen in Parque Nacional Cerros de Amotape in January 2010 (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is found in the Pacific lowlands of extreme southern Colombia (Nariño Department) through Ecuador, to the lowlands of northwestern Peru (Piura and Tumbes Regions). Its altitudinal range is from 0–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is harvested only for home consumption. Trade is not known to occur.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its occurs within many protected areas, including Parque Nacional Mache Chindul, Parque Nacional Machalilla, Reserva Jama Coaque, Reserva Ecológica Manglares-Churute and Reserva Ecológica Arenillas. In Peru, it occurs in the Zona Reservada de Tumbes and was recorded from Parque Nacional Cerros de Amotape in 2010 (R. von May pers. comm. March 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population size and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"\nListed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This species has been found in terra firme lowland rainforest, close to large river channels. At the Peruvian locality, it occurs within an extensive complex of high terraces forest, close to the Algodoncillo River. Individuals have been found perching on low vegetation around ponds in primary forest (Motta et al. 2012). In captivity, a female laid a single clutch of 70 eggs attached to a substrate above the surface of the water, suggesting it lays terrestrial eggs in the wild (Motta et al. 2012). They may also lay clutches on leaves or other arboreal substrate under different conditions. Other Dendrosophus species occurring in the same area at both localities were D. rhodopeplus, including in the same ponds where this species was collected (Motta et al. 2012).
threats: There is some localised habitat loss due to agriculture and human settlements within its range, however there are large areas of suitable habitat remaining (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. March 2018). In Brazil, it is known from Parque Nacional do Jaú, where it occurs well within the limits of the park and does not suffer from any immediate threat (P. Peloso pers. comm. March 2018).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species in Peru and Colombia. In Brazil, it seems to be locally very abundant in Parque Nacional do Jaú, where many calling males and females with eggs were observed, signifying a very healthy subpopulation (P. Peloso pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is known from only three localities in the Amazon River Basin: near Leticia in Colombia (Motta et al. 2012); Piedras in the Putumayo basin in Loreto, Peru (Motta et al. 2012); and Parque Nacional do Jaú, Amazonas, Brasil (P. Peloso pers. comm. March 2018). It occurs at elevations ranging from 90–170 m asl. It probably occurs more widely, particularly in suitable habitat between known sites.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, it occurs in Maijuna Kichwa Regional Conservation Area, designated in 2015, and might also occur in Ampiyacu Apayacu Regional Conservation Area. In Brazil, it occurs in Parque Nacional do Jaú (P. Peloso pers. comm. March 2018).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It lives in leaf-litter and in tree holes in tropical rainforests and on the forest edge, as well as grasslands and shrublands. Breeding takes place in ponds, and eggs and tadpoles in water. Male specimens have been found calling from water up to 30cm deep, in flooded forest. It is tolerant of some habitat modification and can survive in rural gardens and pastureland.
threats: There are no major threats to this species but shifting cultivation, logging, fire, infrastructure development, agro industrial farming and water pollution might impact local populations.
population: It is considered to be common at some sites.
range: This species is found in Mesoamerica in the western Pacific lowlands of Panama. In South America this species has been recorded in Bolivia, Paraguay, Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela (Sucre and Bolìvar states), Trinidad Island, Trinidad and Tobago and the Guianas. Its distribution is poorly known, and its taxonomic status is in need of revision. It occurs up to 500 m asl.
conservationActions: It occurs in several protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: Individuals have been found in primary and secondary forest (Duellman, 1978), but it is usually found in grasses or bushes (leaves and branches) in flooded areas, seasonal swamps, slowly moving water, choked ditches or rivers. It is common to find it in pastures and fairly open country. The presence of this species might be associated with the plant Montrichardia arborescens. In the Iquitos region, Perú, this frog is common in permanent and semi permanent open ponds, where males call from water surface amidst grassy areas (Rodríguez and Duellman, 1994). Eggs and tadpoles develop in the water. It can occur in badly degraded habitats, rural gardens and sometimes in towns.
threats: There are no major threats to this widespread species that has large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as logging and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). It is sometimes found in the international pet trade but at levels that do not currently constitute a major threat.
population: It is a common species.
range: This species occurs throughout the Amazon basin in South America, south to the Chaco region of Paraguay and along the banks of the Río Paraguay-Parana, Argentina. It is present on Trinidad island, Trinidad and Tobago. It is found from the lowlands to 1,400 m asl.
conservationActions: It is present in numerous protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species occurs in primary forest, where it is most commonly seen on the ground, logs, or tree roots along small streams at night (Rodríguez and Duellman, 1994). The microhabitat is very moist and the forest floor is heavily littered with wet dead leaves. It occurs in areas of flooding forest with close canopy and wide leaves. It also occurs in the forests edges, near small streams secondary and modified forest. It breeds by direct development, leaf-litter Ovid position.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), oil exploration and colonization.
population: It is common in Peru, Ecuador and Colombia; it is uncommon in Brazil.
range: This species is known from lowland forest in western Brazil, southeastern Colombia, eastern Ecuador and eastern Peru (all Loreto and one record in Ucayali). Its altitudinal range is between 100-500 m asl.
conservationActions: The range of this species in Peru overlaps with some areas proposed as Priority by Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez, 1996). In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Parque Nacional Yasuní and Cuyabeno Reserva. It is present in at least three Colombian protected areas. In Brazil it has been recorded in Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor and Reserva Extrativista do Alto Juruá, Acre State.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This is an arboreal species occurring in primary and secondary forests (Duellman 1978, Rodríguez and Duellman 1994); this includes seasonally flooded, terra firme and upland tropical forests. It is presumed to breed by direct development; the egg deposition site is not known. It is not recorded from degraded habitats.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), oil exploration and colonization.
population: It is frequent in good habitat.
range: This species is present in suitable habitat throughout Amazonian Ecuador, Peru and presumably western Brazil. It ranges up to 1,000 m asl.
conservationActions: In Ecuador this species is known from many protected areas including Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, and Parque Nacional Yasuní. In Peru the range of this species overlaps with Manu Reserve Biosphere of southern and Pacaya-Samiria Reserve Zone of northern Peru.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its likely wide distribution, occurrence in an area where its habitats are not significantly threatened, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is an upland forest inhabitant. In Central Peru, the habitat is mainly covered with unexploited primary forest. The habitat type is not known for Brazil. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: There are presumed to be no major threats. It is now a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). In Peru, there has been a significant loss habitat through agriculture and colonization.
population: Its population is unknown.
range: This is a recently described species that is present in the region of Panguana (at 220 m asl) and Serrania de Sira (at 800-1,380 m asl) in a relatively small area in the extreme eastern portion of Huanuco, central Amazonian Peru. It was recently recorded from Acre and Amazonas States in Brazil, where it is found at elevations above 1,380 m asl.
conservationActions: It is present in Reserva Comunal El Sira; this is specifically an indigenous people reserve. It is not known if this species is present in protected areas in Brazil.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: All specimens were found in primary humid tropical rainforest. At Finca Panguana and Cosñipata Valley (Peru) many individuals were found by day, they were in leaf-litter on the forest floor, and others were calling from a log. It breeds by direct development and is not present in modified habitats.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.), oil exploration and colonization.
population: It is a common species.
range: This species is known from central (a single locality) and (presumably) northern Bolivia, central and southern Amazonian Peru (Departmentos Madre de Dios, Cusco and Puno) and recorded from western Acre State, Brazil. This is a lowland species.
conservationActions: The range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu and Tambopata-Candamo National Reserve (Madre de Dios) in Peru. In Brazil it is present in Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor, Acre. It is not known to occur in any Bolivian protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: Its habitat is both secondary and primary tropical moist forest. At Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, all individuals were found at night on vegetation. Males usually call from emergent swamp vegetation, or, less frequently, at the edge of forest (Duellman 1978). Eggs are deposited on leaves over waterbodies; larvae develop in these waters.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: This is an uncommon species.
range: This species is known from the Upper Amazon Basin of southern Colombia (Leticia), Ecuador, Peru, and western Brazil (Acre and Rondonia). It might be present in Bolivia, but requires confirmation. Its elevation is from 100-800 m asl.
conservationActions: In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, Yasuni National Park and Cuyabeno Reserva de Producción Faunística. Possibly occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu, Colombia. It is uncertain if it is present in a reserved zone within Peru.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: A high canopy species of primary tropical lowland rainforest, descending to low branches to breed (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). At Yasuní National Park, this species has been collected in Terra Firme Forest on branches and shrubs (Ron 2001). Breeding takes place in fallen trees containing small water pools; tadpoles have also been collected in small pools on the ground. The species may be found over small waterbodies.
threats: No major threats, a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to different human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is rarely encountered.
range: This species occurs in the Amazonian lowlands in Colombia, Ecuador and Peru (Departments Amazonas, Loreto and Madre de Dios); recently recorded from 50 km southwest of Manaus in central Brazil (M. Hoogmoed pers comm.). It is suspected to occur in Bolivia. Its altitudinal range is 50-600 m asl.
conservationActions: In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno, Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, and Parque Nacional Yasuní. In Peru it is known to occur in Parque Nacional Manu and very possibly in Reserva Nacional Pacaya Samiria and Zona Reservada Allpahuayo Mishana. In Colombia it is present in the El Pure protected area.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is present in swamps at the edge of tropical moist tropical forest. Breeding is assumed to take place in these wetlands. It may be found in slightly degraded habitat.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as logging and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is a reasonably abundant species.
range: This species is present in Rondonia State and western Acre State Brazil, southeastern Peru (Cusco Amazonico), and northern and central Bolivia. It is present below 300 m asl.
conservationActions: In Bolivia it is present within the Manuripi Heath Nature Reserve. It is found within a number of conservation areas in Brazil including Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor and Reserva Extrativista do Alto Juruá, in Acre State.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This semi aquatic frog is commonly found amidst floating vegetation, usually dominated by water lettuce (Pistia), in open permanent and semi permanent waterbodies (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994) including ponds, large lakes, flooded meadows and other lentic waterbodies (such as streams with standing water). It breeds in these wetlands. It may be present in altered habitats where waterbodies with floating vegetation are available.
threats: While there are no immediate threats to this species, localized habitat loss is no doubt affecting some populations.
population: It is generally common throughout much of its range.
range: This species’ geographic range is from the upper Amazon Basin of southeastern Colombia, Ecuador (three localities), Peru and Brazil. It has an altitudinal range of 50-300 m asl.
conservationActions: In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno, and Reserva Biológica Limoncocha. It is present in Parque Nacional Manu in Peru. Found in many conservation areas in Brazil.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is found in swampy areas in lowland tropical flooded rainforest, including floating meadows, and is associated with streams, rivers and waterways. The eggs and larvae develop in water, the egg deposition site is not known.
threats: There are no major threats to this widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to shifting cultivation and logging.
population: This is an abundant species.
range: This species is an Amazonian species of southern Colombia (Leticia); Departments of Madre de Dios, Ucayali, and Loreto, Peru; western Brazilian Amazonia; and northern Bolivia (De la Riva et al. 2000). It has an altitudinal range of 50-200 m asl.
conservationActions: In Peru this species is known to occur in the Tambopata National Reserve, Parque Nacional Manu, and might also occur in Allpahuayo Mishana, Alto Purus, Manu and Amarakaeri Reserved Zones, and Pacaya Samiria National Reserve and Bahuaja Sonene National Park. It is present in many protected areas in Brazil.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: A sub-canopy (c. 20 m) species of floodplain tropical forest, and terra firme forest. It may be found on tree branches and in open areas (Ron, 2001). It is a phytotelm breeder, with eggs laid in bromeliads. It is not present in disturbed habitats.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is a common species.
range: This species can be found in southern Colombia, Amazonian Ecuador and much of northern and central Amazonian Peru. Its elevation is between 200 and 700 m asl.
conservationActions: In Peru, this species might occur in Santiago Comaina and Gueppi Reserved Zones, Pacaya Samiria National Reserve, Biabo Cordillera Azul Reserved Zone, Bosque de Protección San Matias San Carlos, Yanachaga Chemillen National Park and Yanesha Communal Reserve. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción Faunística Cuyabeno, and Parque Nacional Yasuní. In Colombia it occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu and Parque Nacional El Pure.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species’ habitat is the Amazon lowland and submontane primary and secondary moist tropical forest. Specimens of this species have been collected on low vegetation in forested situations at night (Lynch 1974). During the day it shelters on fallen leaves on the ground. It is presumed to breed by direct development and the egg deposition site is not known. It may be found in selectively cut secondary forest.
threats: Presumably there are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: Generally, it is a rare to uncommon species.
range: This species can be found in the Amazonian lowlands and slopes of northern Ecuador and adjacent southern Colombia (Departamentos de Amazonas y Putumayo), south to south-central Peru and parts of western Brazilian Amazonia. Its altitudinal ranges from 100-1,300 m asl.
conservationActions: Some populations are distributed inside La Paya National Natural Park, Colombia. In Peru, the range of this species overlaps with the areas have been proposed as Priority by Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez 1996). In Brazil, the range is within a well-conserved region of the Brazilian Amazonia. It might be within Limoncocha Reserva Biológica and Cuyabeno Reserva de Producción Faunística, Ecuador.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: The habitat is lowland and premontane moist tropical forest. Generally, it is found in the understorey vegetation; it is a typical forest edge species. Breeding takes place in temporary pools. This species increases in number when habitats are disturbed, although it does require some nearby bushes and other low vegetation.
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: A common species, it is increasing in distribution in vegetation along newly constructed roads.
range: This species' geographic range is Western Brazil (Acre, Amazonas and Rondonia), northeastern Bolivia, and southeastern Peru. Its altitudinal range is from 200-1,200 m asl.
conservationActions: It is present in numerous protected areas in Bolivia, Brazil and Peru.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species can be found in primary and secondary flooding forest with close canopy and wide leaves. In Manu, the understorey level is composed of palms, ferns, heliconias, shrubs and young trees. This frog is most frequently observed perched on low vegetation in primary forest at night (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). It is presumed to be a direct development species; egg deposition site occurs on low vegetation. It is present in secondary forest and lightly degraded habitat.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging, agriculture (crops, livestock etc.) and colonization.
population: Outside Colombia and Ecuador, this is a common species.
range: This species is widespread over much of the upper Amazon basin. It is present throughout most of Amazonian Peru. Found in southern Colombia; in Brazil, it is known with certainty only from Solimoes River, Amazonas state. There are no exact locality records for Ecuador.
conservationActions: The range of this species overlaps with several Peruvian protected areas including Parque Nacional Manu, Tambopata Candamo National Reserve, Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul, Von Humbolt National Forest, Bahuaja-Sonene National Park, Machiguengo Communal Reserve and the El Sira Communal Reserve. In Colombia it is found in Parque Nacional Natural Amacayacu and El Pure National Park. There are no conservation measures in place in Brazil. It is not known as to whether or not there are any conservation measures in place in Ecuador.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits in primary and secondary lowland evergreen forest. Individuals have been found active at night on leaves of low vegetation, up to 3 m above ground. It is suspected that is an inhabitant of forest canopy. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The Peruvian record is within an oil concession which could represent a threat to that subpopulation (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015, O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. May 2018). Otherwise there are no known major threats at this time.
population: The species is known from the 24 specimens that comprise the type series: nine males, six females, four sub-adults, and five juveniles (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). There is little additional information available on the population size and trends of this species.
range: This species is known from northern Ecuador (Napo and Orellana provinces) and one locality from Loreto Department in Peru (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). It occurs at elevations ranging from 150–400 m asl. It is expected to occur in adjacent Colombia and possibly in Brazil based on ecological niche models (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 27,459 km2, but a wider distribution is likely, up to 147,787 km2 in the upper Amazon Basin (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within Jatun Sacha Biological Reserve and Yasuní National Park in Ecuador. It has not been recorded from any protected areas in Peru, though it may occur in Pucacuro National Reserve. It is considered to be Least Concern in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large, stable population.
habitat: This species inhabits Amazonian evergreen lowlands and piedmont habitats. Individuals were found active at night on leaves of low vegetation, up to 3 m above ground, but it is suspected that it is an inhabitant of forest canopy. It is presumed to reproduce by direct development.
threats: There are no major threats to this species. It appears to have a wide distribution, occurring in less developed areas (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. May 2018). However, selective logging and extraction can be considered localized threats for Peruvian subpopulations (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. May 2018).
population: It is known from the 21 specimens that comprise the type series (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). The population is presumed to be relatively stable.
range: This species is has been recorded in eastern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago, Orellana, and Pastaza provinces) and northern Loreto Region (Andoas, San Jacinto and Shiviyacu) in Peru, up to 960 m asl. It is expected to also occur in adjacent Colombia and possibly Brazil, based on ecological niche models (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). It is likely to have a wider distribution in the upper Amazon Basin (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in Parque Nacional Yasuní in Ecuador. Based on ecological niche models, its expected occur in Pucacuro National Reserve in Peru (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large and stable population.
habitat: This species occurs and reproduces along streams in lowland tropical rainforest. It lays its eggs on vegetation above streams into which the larvae drop and complete their development.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to general human activities such as logging, colonisation and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: This species appears common throughout its range. Because there are no major threats and it occurs across a large area, its population trend is inferred to be stable.
range: This species was previously only known from its type locality (Benjamin Constant, Alto Solimões, Amazonas State, Brazil), and from Leticia, Amazonas Department, Colombia. Following the synonymy of Vitreorana oyampiensis, its range has greatly expanded to include the Guiana Shield of Venezuela, Suriname, French Guiana, and probably Guyana, into Amazonian Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Brazil, and Bolivia (Lescure and Marty 2000; Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005; Lima et al. 2006; Guayasamín et al. 2008, 2009; Menin et al. 2009; Muñoz-Saravia and Aguayo-Vedia 2009). In Brazil, this species occurs in Amazonas, Amapá, Pará, Maranhão, Roraima and Mato Grosso states (Moraes et al. 2017, Lima et al. 2020, Penhacek et al. 2020). It is found at elevations below 300 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in many protected areas across its wide distribution.

Research Needed
Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,118 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in less than five threat-defined locations, there is continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat caused primarily by water pollution and siltation, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to uncontrolled exploitation as a food source.
habitat: It is an exclusively aquatic species. It is restricted to marshy lakes, such as Lake Junín, smaller, deep, isolated lakes, as well as, streams, rivers, wetlands, and canals around Lake Junín (A. Watson and A. Fitzgerald pers. comm. February 2018). Ideal stream habitat characteristics of this frog are free of predatory, invasive rainbow trout with moderate levels of silt and relatively clean water (Watson 2017a). It reproduces by larval development. Tadpoles prefer microhabitats characterized with a silt-like substrate, depths of more than 30 cm, low currents, presence of native fish (Orestias spp.), and submerged vegetation (Castillo 2017). In a study on diet composition and prey selection, Watson et al. (2017b) found that the Junín Giant Frog appeared to select snails (family Physidae) and mayflies (family Baetidae) from the available prey in the environment.
threats:
The species is generally threatened by introduction of trout into lakes, streams, and rivers in the high Andes, disappearance of native fish of the genus Orestias, uncontrolled exploitation as a food source, emerging infectious diseases (chytridiomycosis and ranavirus), climate change, and loss of habitat through the extraction of resources, agricultural, industrial, and residential pollution, eutrophication, over-grazing by livestock, and fluctuations in water levels controlled by the Upamayo dam (Watson et al. 2017a,b). The cleaning of channelised streams, which involves the periodic removal of submerged aquatic vegetation and sediment, represents an additional threat to the species and its habitat (L. Castillo Roque pers. comm. February 2018). Large amounts of acid mine drainage and heavy metals, such as copper, zinc and lead, from the Cerro de Pasco region are discharged into the lake, and its surrounding lagoons and wetlands via the San Juan River, the lake's main tributary (Rodbell et al. 2014, Watson et al. 2017b). This is particularly damaging to this frog, due to its high sensitivity to contaminants and the high permeability of its skin. 

Congeners in southern Peru have been infected with chytrid (Seimon et al. 2005, Catenazzi et al. 2011), and one species in nearby Ecuador has disappeared, suggesting this species might also be at risk. In 2014, 14 samples tested negative for the presence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (R. Elias pers. comm. March 2018), and there are no reports of the species being infected with this fungus as of yet (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population:
Previously common, this species has undergone a noticeable decline over the last thirty years. In 1996, there was a mass die-off in Lake Junín and other water bodies of the Sierra Central, the cause of which is still uncertain (Becerra Díaz 2012).

While current population estimates are not available, the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, and there is continuing decline in mature individuals due to overexploitation. Linear transects and diving surveys in lagoons, rivers, streams, and channels in and around Lake Junín during October to December 2012 detected 12 individuals, however the species was present in only 10.76% of the 65 surveyed sites (Loza Del Carpio and Mendoza Quispe 2017). During monthly surveys in three protected areas in Junín and Pasco between January 2015 and July 2016, adults and/or tadpoles were found in only eight out of twenty sites (Watson et al. 2017b).

The species appears to be restricted to water bodies with good water quality, and has not been recorded during recent surveys in the northern zone of Lake Junín where there are signs of contamination (Loza Del Carpio and Mendoza Quispe 2017). According to surveys of local inhabitants in 2012, 95% of interviewees stated that they had directly observed this frog in their natural habitats at some point, however 65% indicated that they last saw the frogs more than six years ago and only 10% saw this species as recent as in 2012 (Loza Del Carpio and Mendoza Quispe 2017).
range: This species occurs in the Departments of Junín and Pasco, Peru. It has been recorded in Lake Junín and surrounding tributaries in the Junín National Reserve and Historical Sanctuary of Chacamarca, and tributaries to the Mantaro River in the National Sanctuary of Huayllay, Pasco. Between 2010 and 2011, attempts were made by the Regional Government of Junín to introduce this species into the upper Mantaro valley, in the central Andes of Junín, however its occurrence there is currently unknown and needs to be verified with surveys (O.J. Damian Baldeón pers. comm. February 2018). Within its native distribution, it has an elevational range of 4,000–4,600 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,118 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in less than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: Overexploitation is one of the strongest threats to this species and contributed significantly to its population decline; exploitation levels have reached a point such that it is difficult to find this species in the wild (Angulo 2008, Aguilar et al. 2010). As these frogs are becoming increasingly more difficult to find, hunting is no longer a normal activity; however, when the regular cleaning of channelised streams takes place, local inhabitants take advantage and harvest the displaced frogs (O.J. Damian Baldeón pers. comm. February 2018). The species is still sold in local markets (A. Watson pers. comm. February 2018). Based on surveys of local inhabitants in 2012, 95% of interviewees stated that they had consumed this species at some point and 55% stated that they had once captured frogs, mainly for self-consumption (87%) (Loza Del Carpio and Mendoza Quispe 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in the Junín National Reserve, the Historic Sanctuary of Chacamarca, and the National Sanctuary of Huayllay (Watson et al. 2017b). An in situ frog monitoring and conservation education program called the “High-Andean Frog Conservation through Capacity-Building Program” funded by USAID Small Project Assistance grants was in place from 2014–2016 (S. Behmke pers. comm. April 2016). Since then, conservation, citizen science, and environmental education efforts have been initiated by a local NGO, Grupo RANA (Respuestas y Acciones para la Naturaleza y sus Amenazas; L. Castillo Roque and O.J. Damian Baldeón pers. comm. February 2018). In October 2016, a second workshop was held in Junín Municipality to establish a conservation strategy for the frogs of Junín (Telmatobius brachydactylus and T. macrostomus), and a conservation action plan was developed (Watson et al. 2016, A. Watson pers. comm. February 2018). In the past, attempts at captive breeding of this species have been made; however, the breeding centers around Junín National Reserve were closed in 2012 (Coronel and Rojas 2014, Watson et al. 2017a). In 2018, Huachipa Zoo will start a captive breeding programme with support of Amphibian Ark Seed Grant (R. Elias pers. comm. March 2018).

This species is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Measures are urgently required to control and manage the harvesting of this species from the wild and limit the impact of invasive trout on native fauna of the lake. The conservation and protection of Lake Junín’s surrounding rivers, streams, wetlands, and lagoons are of utmost importance. Watson et al. 2017a have identified these bodies of water as critical habitat for the conservation of the species considering that the influx of metals to Lake Junín will continue until efforts are focused on preventing these sediments from entering the lake.

Research Needed
More information is needed about this species' distribution, population status, life history, harvest levels, and threats. Additional studies on the food habits of introduced rainbow trout and comparison with this frog is needed (Watson et al. 2017b). Continued long-term monitoring is needed to inform appropriate conservation management of this threatened, high-elevation, endemic species (Watson et al. 2017a, Castillo 2017). Further studies should monitor trends in harvest levels, population demographics, the presence of emerging infectious diseases, and microhabitat utilization.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,045 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to road construction, agricultural expansion, and agrochemical pollution in the southern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This stream breeding species inhabits both primary and secondary montane cloud forest with bamboo, ferns, and elephant ear plants. Males have been heard calling from dense vegetation within 0.5 m of a low-gradient stream after a rain (Duellman et al. 1997). It is unknown whether it can tolerate habitat disturbance.
threats: The main threat to this species is habitat loss due to deforestation of forests for road construction, expansion of agricultural crops and cultivation of cocoa, coffee, coca plantations, and the pollution of streams (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018).
population: The previous assessment was based only on the specimens in the type series (Duellman et al. 1997). Since then, the species has been collected on various occasions, including seven specimens from Río Kimbiri, Comunidad Machiguenga Pomoreni in Cusco by De la Riva and colleagues in 2008; one specimen from the Tutumbaro river by V. Vargas in Ayacucho in 2011; thirteen specimens from the confluences of the Pichari and Meanterari rivers, within the territory of the Indigenous Community of Marontuari in Cusco by J.M. Padial and colleagues in 2016 (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018); and three specimens from the vicinity of Río Pichari, Cusco Region in 2017 (V. Díaz Vargas pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from two localities, ca 12 km apart in the Region of Ayachuco, Peru: San José on the Río Santa Rosa and Tutumbaro on the Río Piene in the provinces of La Mar and Huanta (Duellman et al. 1997). It is now also known from the confluence of Río Pichari and Río Meanterari within the territory of the indigenous communities of Marontuari and Kitemontinkiari, Pichari District (V.J. Vargas and V. Díaz Vargas pers. comm. March 2018), and Río Kimbiri, Comunidad Machiguenga Pomoreni, Kimbiri District in the Cordillera Vilcabamba, La Convencíon Province, both in Cusco Region (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018). Its elevational range is 1,005–1,840 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,045 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur in four threat-defined locations. It might range more widely than is currently known.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species might occur in the protected area of the Parque Nacional Otishi, although this requires confirmation (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018).

Conservation Needed
Improved protection of forest habitat is required for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of XXX km2, its population considered to be severely fragmented, a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location], and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to [specific threat, e.g. illegal collection for the pet trade]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,749 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from three to four locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat outside of protected areas in Cordillera Azul, Peru.
habitat: This terrestrial species is thought to be restricted to submontane tropical primary and riparian forest. Most specimens have been found close to streams (Martínez Ruiz 2008). Breeding is expected to breed in fast flowing streams by larval development, as with other congeners. This species is presumed to be susceptible to habitat change and is therefore not expected to occur in any modified or degraded habitats.
threats: It might be very susceptible to infection with chytrid, although Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has yet to be reported from this species. Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was not detected in any of the 20 individuals swabbed for Bd in 2007 and 2008 (Martínez Ruiz 2008, Kosch et al. 2012). Most of its range overlaps with a national park, where much of its habitat is well protected and undisturbed. Outside of the national park boundary, the species is threatened by ongoing habitat loss due to agriculture and logging, even within the park's buffer zone (Martínez Ruiz 2008). The site where the species was recorded in 2007–2008 is situated in Lot 34, a forest concession awarded to the Tingo María Sawmill Company (Martínez Ruiz 2008). In early 2018, park guards of the 63 Pucayacu Watch Post in Cordillera Azul National Park verified that there is currently no resource extraction occurring in the vicinity of Río Seco creek, upper reaches of the Pucayacu River (M. Ramírez Zarate pers. comm. April 2018).
population: Healthy subpopulations (i.e. where specimens were not rare and relatively easy to find) were found in 2000 in the Río Biabo region (L.O. Rodríguez pers. comm. in Lötters et al. 2005) and in February 2004 near Iquitos (D. Bernauer pers. comm. in Lötters et al. 2005). In 2005, the species was reported for the first time in the southwestern side of Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul's buffer zone during a joint expedition by Centro de Conservación, Investigación y Manejo de Áreas Naturales (CIMA) and the Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul Headquarters (Martínez Ruiz 2008). Surveys in same area, during June 2007 and January 2008, registered 68 specimens subsequently identified as Atelopus cf. andinus; 66 individuals were recorded using visual encounter surveys on 21 transects (50 m each) with an effort of 29 person-hours, while two individuals were recorded by searching 40 plots (5x5 m each) with an effort of 13 person-hours (Martínez Ruiz 2008). Tadpoles were not observed during any visits between 2007–2008, however individuals in amplexus and a gravid female were observed (Martínez Ruiz 2008).
range: This species is restricted to the upper Río Biabo valley in the Department of San Martín, the Río Pisqui in the Department of Loreto (Rueda et al. 2005), and the Río Cachiyacu on the border of the Departments of San Martín and Loreto (Alverson et al. 2001), eastern Peru. Since the previous assessment, the species has also been recorded in the Río Pucayacu valley in the Department of Huánuco, which is represents the southernmost portion of its distribution (Martínez Ruiz 2008). Initial molecular analyses have have tentatively identified these specimens as Atelopus cf. andinus, however additional analyses and comparisons with tissues from the type locality are recommended (Martínez Ruiz 2008, S. Lötters pers. comm. April 2018). Its elevational range is 1,000–2,000 m asl and its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,749 km2 and it occurs in three to four threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. There is ongoing monitoring and patrolling by park guards in the vicinity of Río Seco creek, upper reaches of the Pucayacu River, Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul (M. Ramírez Zarate pers. comm. April 2018). It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Continuation of rigorous management of the existing parks is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species. Given the susceptibility of this species to chytridiomycosis, successful conservation measures are likely to require some form of disease management programme and the maintenance of captive populations.

Research Needed
Additional analyses are needed to confirm the identity of the specimens collected from Río Pucayacu valley in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul's buffer zone (Martínez Ruiz 2008, S. Lötters pers. comm. April 2018). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. There is a need for close monitoring of the status of this species given the potential threat of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, and threatening processes.
habitat: The general habitat in the area of collection is humid mountain forest. It is presumed to be a stream-breeding species.
threats: Much of this species' habitat has been cleared for agricultural activities, including cattle pastures. In the past the habitat area where it occurs had been somewhat protected by the presence of terrorist groups (excepting drug crops used in drug trafficking); more recently, coca eradication campaigns and alternative development programs have diminished the presence of drug crops in the region (CIMA 2012). Current threats to this species are not well understood. Additionally, like other members of its genus, it is assumed to be at severe risk from chytridiomycosis.
population: It is currently known only from museum specimens and was last recorded in 1980. It is unknown whether there have been rigorous searches for this species. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the western versant of the Cordillera Azul, Huánuco Department, Peru, where it occurs between 1,650 and 1,800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection of the type locality is recommended. Should any specimens be found, a captive-breeding programme may also need to be established.

Research Needed
In view of the likely threat of chytridiomycosis, it is a very high priority to conduct surveys to locate this species and determine its current population status.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) given that no live individuals have been reported since 2004, despite intensive and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities. Should the species still be extant, it is likely that it survives in low numbers, possibly less than 50 mature individuals.
habitat: This species occurs in cloud forests on the Amazonian versant of the Peruvian Andes. The species is not expected to be tolerant of habitat degradation. Adults are usually found in the vicinity of small streams (Catenazzi et al. 2005) and breeding takes place in streams.
threats: There is very little habitat loss in Bahuaja Sonene and Manu National Parks, and Megantoni National Sanctuary. Specimens from Manu analyzed in 1999 were not infected by the chytrid fungus, and those captured in 2004 in the headwaters of the Timpía river in Megantoni were also not infected (histological analysis). While chytridiomycosis has not yet been recorded in this species, the disease is known to have spread throughout Peru and has been implicated in the decline of many Atelopus species. The disappearance of the species from Manu National Park happened during a period (mid- to late-1990s) when several species known to be susceptible to chytridiomycosis disappeared from streams in montane cloud forest, suggesting that an outbreak of this fungal disease played a role in these declines.
population:
The species has not been seen since 2004. It is possible that this species is already extinct, however if a population still exists it is thought to have less than 50 individuals. The type locality—at Santo Domingo in the buffer zone of Bahuaja Sonene National Park in Puno Region—was surveyed in November 2006, February-March and May-June 2007 (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. April 2017), and again in 2016 and 2017 (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018), but no records were made.

Once common within its range in Manu National Park, this species has not been observed since 1999 despite intensive monitoring along streams where they used to reproduce (Catenazzi et al. 2011, Catenazzi and von May 2014). In the Kosñipata Valley, in the buffer zone of Manu National Park, juveniles and adults were formerly found in leaf litter and along creeks from 1,900-2,000 m asl. Surveys in the same region during 2007-2009 (Catenazzi et al. 2011) and 2012-2016, were unable to detect any individuals (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).

In 2004, surveys conducted in Megantoni National Sanctuary in Cusco Region detected two individuals over 14 person days (Rodriguez and Catenazzi 2005, von May et al. 2008). These 2004 reports are the last time the species has been seen, but no surveys to the same site have been made since then (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from the Cordillera Carabaya on the Amazon versant of the Andes in the Regions of Puno and Cusco (Catenazzi et al. 2005). Its presence in the Regions of Huánuco and Ucayali (Rodriguez et al. 1993) require further investigation, but may have been confused with Atelopus siranus (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). It has an elevational range of 1,800–2,500 m asl. Its type locality is about 60 km from the border with Bolivia and many other species found at this locality are also found in Bolivia, so it is possible this species could occur there as well (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species was once common in Bahuaja Sonene and Manu National Parks, and Megantoni National Sanctuary (Catenazzi et al. 2005). It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
If subpopulations can be located, the population size should be determined and the site protected. Given the threat of chytridiomycosis, recommended conservation measures will probably need to include the establishment of a captive-breeding programme.

Research Needed
It is a very high priority to conduct surveys to locate this species and determine its current population status. There is a possibility that this species may be already extinct.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) given that, after it experienced a precipitous population decline in the mid 1990s, no individuals have been reported since 1998, despite intensive and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities, suggesting that if this species is still extant the pool of remaining mature individuals is likely fewer than 50.
habitat: It inhabits puna and sub-puna (high altitude) habitats, with scattered tussock grass and Baccharis sp. This species is sensitive to habitat degradation. Breeding takes place in streams, with larvae adhering to the undersides of rocks in fast flowing streams at a depth of approximately 30 cm.
threats: The disappearance of the species from its entire range happened during a period (mid- to late-1990s) when several species known to be susceptible to chytridiomycosis disappeared from streams in montane cloud forest, suggesting that an outbreak of this fungal disease played a role in these declines. A subpopulation in Cajamarca was previously lost due to water contamination from activities at a nearby gold mine. It has previously been reported in the pet trade, although this appears to have ceased.
population: This species was very abundant in many localities of Cajamarca and Celendín until 1992, but apparently declined between 1995 and 1998 and has not been observed since 1998 despite increased efforts to find it (Venegas et al. 2008, Miranda Leiva 2008, R. Schulte pers. comm.). In 1998, surveys in Cajamarca detected 20 individuals over eight person-days (von May et al. 2008). Surveys in Cajamarca and Ancash during 2002–2007 were futile; no individuals were observed over 112 person-days of surveys (von May et al. 2008). There is a possibility that this species may be extinct (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018), however if a population still exists it is thought to have less than 50 individuals.
range: This species is known from the northern Peruvian Andes near the surroundings of Celendín, Abra Comulica, San Miguel de Pallaques, and in the Province of Hualgayoc, all in the Department of Cajamarca. It is (or was) present at Charco, Huari Province, Department of Áncash, and also in the Department of Piura. Its elevational range is from 2,600–4,300 m asl.
useTrade: It was overexploited for use in the pet trade, especially during the 1990s.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Parque Nacional Huascarán, and might be present in Reserva Nacional Calipuy and Santuario Nacional Calipuy. In August 2008, the species was declared extinct throughout its range at the "Simpósio Internacional sobre Declinación de Poblaciones de Anfibios Altoandinos de los Países: Ecuador, Venezuela y Peru" (Miranda Leiva 2008, A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018). It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Disease management and captive-breeding programmes appear necessary given the threat of chytridiomycosis.

Research Needed
It is a very high priority to conduct surveys to locate this species and determine its current population status. There is a possibility that this species may be already extinct.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, and threatening processes.
habitat: This species inhabits primary montane tropical forest. It is a diurnal, terrestrial species (Lötters et al. 2002). Breeding is believed to take place in streams, like other species in the genus.
threats: Much of this species' habitat has been cleared for agricultural activities, including cattle pastures and tea. In the past, the habitat area where it occurs had been somewhat protected by the presence of rebel groups (excepting drug crops used in drug trafficking); more recently, coca eradication campaigns and alternative development programs have diminished the presence of drug crops in the region (CIMA 2012). Current threats to this species are not well understood. Additionally, like other members of its genus, it is assumed to be at severe risk from chytridiomycosis, however the chytrid pathogen has yet to be found in this species.
population: It appears that the last confirmed sighting occurred in 1992 (von May et al. 2008), but the lack of subsequent observations might be due to lack of survey work. Two subpopulations with different colorations have been eliminated, possibly by a large landslide that destroyed the bridge over the Chino River (Lötters and Schulte 2005). In 2006, surveys conducted around the type locality were unable to detect any individuals over 4 person days (von May et al. 2008). It is unknown whether there have been recent rigorous searches for this species, however due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the type locality on the eastern versant of the Cordillera Azul in the Department of Ucayali, Peru. It occurs at elevations from 1,300–1,600 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There have been no records of this species occurring in any protected areas, although its presence in the Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul and Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillen is possible. It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection of the type locality is recommended. Given the threat of chytridiomycosis, recommended conservation measures will probably need to include the establishment of a captive-breeding programme.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, natural history and threats. Additional field surveys are urgently needed to determine if this species is still extant.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,560 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from three threat-defined locations, and because there is ongoing decline to its montane forest habitat in the Andes of northern Peru.
habitat: This is a terrestrial species of pre-montane and montane primary forests on the eastern slopes of the Andes. It may tolerate some degree of disturbance as some individuals were found in modified forest habitats, such as instances where native montane forests have been cleared and replaced by subsistence agricultural plantations (coffee, pineapple and banana) and areas used by livestock (cattle, horses and mules). Nevertheless, it is not known whether the species will persist in disturbed areas in the long term, given that pesticides and fertilizers used in agricultural plantations may have negative effects on amphibians (Hayes et al. 2002). It is a stream-breeding species with larval development. It is possible that there are variants with slightly different colors in different streams.
threats: The major threats are habitat loss due to agricultural and livestock activities and pesticide use. The species' habitat appears to be impacted by the expansion of human settlements associated with urban development in Moyobamba and Balsapuerto in recent years (Cusi et al. 2017). Five individuals from Alto Mayo Protected Forest were tested for presence of chytrid fungus, but the results were negative (Cusi et al. 2017).
population: There is no information on population status or abundance. This species was thought to be extinct until it was rediscovered in Peru in 2001 (Scheffers et al. 2011). Between 2004 and 2014, a total of 16 individuals were observed in the wild, with usually one record of one individual per survey (Cusi et al. 2017).
