range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality, an unspecified site between Balsa Puerto and Moyabamba, from seven sites within the Alto Mayo Protected Forest reserve (Cusi et al. 2017), and near the village of Naranjos (R. Schulte pers. obs. 2004), all in the Upper Amazon Basin of San Martín, eastern Peru. It occurs between 1,100-1,902 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,560 km2. It may occur slightly more widely. It is considered to occur in three threat-defined locations (all sites within the Alto Mayo Protected Forest reserve are considered to be location, plus the site between Balsa Puerto and Moyabamba, and the site close to Naranjos).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the Alto Mayo Protected Forest reserve. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Subpopulations outside the reserve would benefit from habitat protection.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, natural history and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its type locality, the lack records despite many surveys in the area, and whether any threats may be affecting it.
habitat: This species is restricted to an isolated, and mostly inaccessible, mountain ridge in the upper Amazon basin, where the habitat is generally montane and premontane tropical forest. This is a terrestrial species that is presumed to breed in streams, and which is probably intolerant of habitat modification.
threats:
There is little human disturbance of this very isolated area and, while collection for the pet trade was previously suspected to be threat to the species, there is no evidence of the species being found in trade. Chytridiomycosis was also listed as a potential future threat, but because the species is known only from two specimens, it is not known whether this disease affected the species prior to or since the last assessment.

Illegal logging, coca plantations, cattle farming, subsistence farming, and illegal mining have been documented as taking place in the Sira region and there are concerns that these are also occurring within the boundaries of the Reserva Comunal El Sira. During 2015, the Peruvian government conducted several raids against illegal gold mining operations in the El Sira Communal Reserve. Although there is a series of mining camps, the level of deforestation due to this activity is still minimal. Deforestation due to agricultural activities, however is growing in the buffer zone of the reserve (Finer and Novoa 2016), and some disturbances, principally logging and illegal coca plantations, are encroaching up to 800–900 m Asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016).

In addition, due to their limited geographical range, this species is expected to show limited climatic adaptability (Lötters 2007).
population: There is very little information available on its population status and trend, and it was only described from two specimens. It appears to have last been recorded in 1988 as multiple surveys in the last 11 years have not recorded the species. Surveys at and near the type locality in 2006, 2007, and 2011 did not record the species (J. Brown pers. comm. 2017). During February 2015, systematic nocturnal surveys were performed on the northwestern slopes of the Sira: 1 h 30 min surveys with two observers at each 100 m elevation, between 800 and 1,500 m Asl; in March 2015, five observers conducted surveys on the same ridge for 4 h from 1,500–1,850 m Asl; in March 2016, two people searched for 2 h at the highest peak on the ridge, between 1,800 and 1,925 m Asl, and none of these surveys recorded the species (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). Two nights of surveying at the type locality also did not record the species in September 2016 (A. Whitworth pers. comm. April 2017). The type locality in 2013 and 2014 was also surveyed, but the species was not recorded there (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from the eastern slope of the isolated mountain range of the Serrania de Sira (Cerros del Sira), Huánuco Region, in the upper Amazon basin of eastern central Peru. It is only known from the type locality, but the precise location is not certain, and the approximate elevation of known records is 2,400 m Asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is found within the El Sira Communal Reserve. It is listed as Data Deficient (DD) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further survey work at the type locality and surrounding areas is necessary to determine whether the species is still extant.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because of an observed population decline, estimated to be more than 80% over the past 10 years, inferred from the impact of chytridiomycosis on this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Critically Endangered because of an observed population decline, estimated to be 80–90% over three generations (21 years; 1998–2019), inferred from the impacts of chytridiomycosis, or a combination of factors, on this species.
habitat: This species inhabits wet primary montane forest, corresponding to the Yungas Forest (De la Riva et al. 2000, Köhler 2000), most often close to small fast flowing rivulets and mountain streams (Reichle 2007). Breeding takes place in streams, where males call in groups of four to ten close to the water. Köhler (2000) observed this species perching at night 0.3–1.2 m above the ground, in vegetation in disturbed primary forest and secondary growth along roadsides. Occasionally, it can be found in disturbed forests, for example in the Serrania de Bella Vista, close to coffee plantations, small-scale agriculture and coca production (Reichle 2007, M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020).
threats: There is very little habitat loss taking place in Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene and Parque Nacional Manu in Peru. The disappearance of the species from Parque Nacional Manu took place during a period (mid- to late-1990s) when several species known to be susceptible to chytridiomycosis disappeared from streams in montane cloud forest, suggesting that an outbreak of this fungal disease played a role in these declines. The rapid, dramatic declines, including disappearances within undisturbed habitat, has been associated with chytridiomycosis as observed in many other montane, stream-associated species in the Andes. Predation by exotic trout or synergistic effects of multiple factors could have also played a role in the past declines (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Samples collected in 1990–2003 in Bolivia were tested for the presence of chytridiomycosis and roughly one third of them – all of which were collected in 1999 at Sehuencas, Cochabamba – were positive for the fungus (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017). Other major threats to the species include habitat loss, due to small-holder farming activities for coffee, coca, and chili peppers, and pollution as a consequence of increased stream sedimentation. In addition, this species is expected to show limited climatic adaptability (Lötters 2007).
population:
The species was always more abundant in the northern portion of its range, such as Serranía Eslabón and Serranía Bellavista in La Paz Department, Bolivia, compared to the southern part of its range, such as the Yungas of Cochabamba, where it was always considered rare (A. Muñoz pers. comm. 2020). It seems to be absent from apparently suitable areas of habitat, suggesting that drastic population declines have occurred in the past and/or are still occurring (De la Riva and Reichle 2014). It appears to have become relatively rare for unknown reasons (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. in Lötters et al. 2005). The species had not been recorded from Serranía Bella Vista since several individuals were observed there in 2003, and targeted surveys in the same area in 2007 did not record any individuals (A. Muñoz pers. comm. 2020). Evidently, individuals were last seen in December 2003 in Parque Nacional Madidi (J.M. Padial pers. comm. In: De la Riva and Reichle 2014). Targeted surveys in Parque Nacional Carrasco in 2006 were unsuccessful in finding this species (A. Muñoz pers. comm. September 2019). Regular efforts to find subpopulations in Bolivia have been undertaken in the Yungas of La Paz and Cochabamba from 2009–2019, but despite several visits under suitable climatic conditions, researchers were unable to detect any individuals of this species (I. De la Riva, pers. obs.; R. Aguayo and O. Quinteros pers. comm. September 2019). The species was not observed during the last visits to Serranía de Sadiri and Serranía del Tigre in 2007, where the last known reports from this area date back to 1969 (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019). In January 2020, four individuals were observed and photographed in the Serranía Bella Vista, at a locality close to Caranavi, in a stream with good habitat, but surrounded by deforested areas (M. Pacheco pers. obs. 2020). This represents the first record of the species in Bolivia since 2003. The gorge where this species was recorded in the Serranía Bella Vista is part of a complex of three adjacent streams in a stretch of 200 m, and yet the species was only present in one of them, the most rocky and least accessible, suggesting this species has very specific habitat requirements; several other streams at the same elevation were also surveyed, but this species was apparently absent (M. Pacheco pers. obs. 2020).

Surveys in Cusco during 2007 and 2008 were unable to find any individuals after searching for a total of 40 person-days from 1,400–2,000 m asl (von May et al. 2008). This species has not been seen in Parque Nacional Manu since 1999, despite intensive monitoring along streams where the frogs used to reproduce (Catenazzi and von May 2014). Visual-encounter surveys in montane forests (1,200–3,700 m asl) along the Paucartambo–Shintuya road in Kosñipata Valley, Parque Nacional Manu were unable to detect this species in 1999, 2008 and 2009 (Catenazzi et al. 2011) and 2012–2016 (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Surveys took place in the Puno Department in the buffer zone and within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene in November 2006, February-March and May-June 2007; just two individuals were recorded in February 2007 (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. April 2018), however surveys in the area in 2016 failed to record the species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).

It is reasonable to suspect that the population has experienced a decline of 80–90% over three generations, from 1998–2019 (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
range: This species is found in the eastern Andes in Peru and Bolivia, at elevations of 600–2,500 m asl. In Peru, it is known from the type locality in the Marcapata Valley in Cusco, and areas close to Puno Department, at 1,700-2,100 m asl (Duellman 1979, Köhler 2000). In Bolivia, it occurs throughout the La Paz Department, in the Yungas region (including Serrania Bella Vista and Serrania Beu in Parque Nacional Pilon Lajas and Serrania de Sadiri and Serrania del Tigre), and south in the Chapare and Carrasco (including La Chaquisacha in Parque Nacional Carrasco) Provinces,  Cochabamba Department (Fugler 1984, De la Riva 1990, Reynolds and Foster 1992, Köhler 2000, Reichle 2007, R. Aguayo pers. comm. September 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Bolivia, it has been recorded in Parque Nacional Carrasco, Parque Nacional Madidi and Parque Nacional Pilon Lajas and it is listed as Endangered (EN) in Bolivia’s Red Book of Threatened Vertebrates (Aguayo 2009). In Peru, it is known from Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene and Parque Nacional Manu, and possibly Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri and Reserva Nacional Tambopata; it is listed as Endangered (EN) and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and improved management of existing protected areas, as well as, the removal of exotic trout from waterways are essential actions for the conservation of this species. In areas where formal protection is not possible, efforts should be made to work with local communities to protect water sources, which are not only important for the livelihoods of the communities but also for healthy populations of amphibians (M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020). The option of a captive-breeding programme might need to be explored for this species. 

Research Needed
Research on the only known surviving population in Bolivia must be carried out to evaluate the population size, presence and effects of Bd, as well as, habitat requirements of the species to inform potential captive breeding programmes (A. Muñoz pers. comm. 2020). Targeted surveys are urgently needed in Serrania de Sadiri and Serrania del Tigre to determine the status of the subpopulations given the lower elevations of these areas (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Continued population monitoring is required, especially in light of the potential threat of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, its area of occupancy (AOO) is likely even more restricted, it is considered to occur in XXX threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in its AOO and the extent of its habitat in [Region]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 288 km<sup>2</sup>, its area of occupancy (AOO) is 16 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera de Carpish.
habitat: It is a species of primary cloud forest on the eastern Andean slopes of central Peru. It has also been found in vegetation around streams in disturbed areas at the forest edge. Its breeding habitat is not known, but it is partially arboreal and may breed in bromeliads, presumably by larval development. Gravid females contained as many as 286 eggs (Lehr et al. 2001).
threats: It is severely threatened by agricultural activities (especially potato cultivation) and an increase in forest fires (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). Agrochemical use has also contributed to the decline of this species at known sites. Furthermore, an interstate road which crosses Cordillera de Carpish (at both sides of Chinchao river) and the developing of mining concessions in the area, are additional threats to this species and its habitat.
population: This species is uncommon and the population is decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat. During 1998–2000, 35 individuals were observed over four person-days (von May et al. 2008). One individual was observed during visual encounter surveys in November 2001, February 2002, August 2002 (Rodríguez Mercado 2007), and June 2014 (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018), respectively. There have not been any more recent surveys since these observations (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is only recorded from Chaglla village (Palma Pampa), along the trail to Huanacaure ruins (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2017), and from Cordillera de Carpish, Huánuco Region, Peru. It is believed to have a genuinely restricted distribution, with an altitudinal range of 2,200–3,072 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 288 km<sup>2</sup>, its estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 16 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur at a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species is not known to be present in any protected areas. Due to the endemism of the Cordillera de Carpish, there is an intent to pursue formal protection for this area (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI).

Conservation Needed
Its remaining habitat is in urgent need of protection.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the major threat of habitat loss.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) given that, after it experienced a precipitous population decline in the early to mid-2000s, no individuals have been reported since 2005, despite intensive and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities, suggesting that if this species is still extant the pool of remaining mature individuals is likely fewer than 50.
habitat: This species inhabits puna and high-altitude plateaus, and dry scrubland. Breeding occurs in temporary small ponds and permanent shallow streams. It has also been found in agricultural land, particularly potato and maize fields, however it is unknown whether its presence in modified habitats suggests a tolerance to disturbance or if they represent relictual subpopulations.
threats: One of the main threats is the loss of habitat and contamination of water bodies by mining activities, expansion of agriculture and livestock, and pine plantations (Miranda Leiva 2008, Aguilar et al. 2010, 2012). Formal, extensive mining concessions, as well as, small-scale, informal mining concessions occur throughout this species' range (Aguilar et al. 2010, 2012). The modification of water ways, including the construction of irrigation channels with cement and PCV pipes constitute another threat to its breeding habitat (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018). Other threats, including chytridiomycosis and climate change, cannot be not ruled out (Aguilar et al. 2010, A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018), as its pattern of decline is similar to other amphibian species that have been impacted by chytridiomycosis. Occasionally it has been recorded in the national pet trade.
population: This species was formerly a common and abundant species (Miranda Leiva 2008), however it is now considered an uncommon species. Between 1999 and 2000, specimens were observed at Granja Porcón and El Empalme in Cajamarca; however, subsequent surveys of the same sites during 2003-2004 were unable to record the species again (Miranda Leiva 2008). Several specimens were recorded in 2003 in a mining concession in La Libertad (J. Suarez pers. comm. In: Aguilar et al. 2012), in 2004 in a mining concession in Ancash (Aguilar et al. 2010), and in 2005 in a mining concession in Cajamarca (M. Medina pers. comm. in: Aguilar et al. 2012). However, these sites were visited again during 2005-2007 (Ancash), 2006-2007 (Cajamarca), and 2008 (La Libertad), but the species was not recorded (Aguilar et al. 2012). The species experienced a drastic population decline sometime between the years 2000 and 2005, and it has not been observed since 2005, despite efforts to find it. There is a possibility that this species may be extinct (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018), however if a population still exists it is thought to have less than 50 individuals.
range: This species has been recorded from the Regions of Ancash (Pallasca), Cajamarca, and La Libertad (Santiago de Chuco and Otuzco), in Peru (Aguilar et al. 2010, 2012). It has an elevational range of 2,000–4,100 m asl.
useTrade: It is rarely encountered in the national pet trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is believed to occur in Parque Nacional Huascarán and Zona Reservada Chancaybaños, and possibly Reserva Nacional Calipuy. In August 2008, the species was declared extinct throughout its range at the "Simpósio Internacional sobre Declinación de Poblaciones de Anfibios Altoandinos de los Países: Ecuador, Venezuela y Peru" (Miranda Leiva 2008, A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018).

Conservation Needed
Conservation of remaining forest fragments in this species' range would be critical to its conservation, should it still be extant.

Research Needed
It is a very high priority to conduct surveys to locate this species and determine its current population status.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits montane primary and secondary tropical forest. It breeds by larval development in slow streams and roadside ditches. It can be found at the edge of agricultural areas, but not within these areas.
threats: Some localized deforestation for smallholder farming for coffee and tea is taking place. In 2009, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was detected in this species at Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Chytridiomycosis has been implicated in the severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011), so the potential impacts chytrid infections on this species require further investigation.
population: It is a common species and has a presumed stable population.
range: This species is restricted to southern Peru. It has been recorded from La Union, Ayacucho Region and the Amazonian slopes of Cusco Region. It has an altitudinal range of 900–1,900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Parque Nacional Manu, Amarakaeri Communal Reserve, and Bahuaja Sonene National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on the taxonomy, distribution, and population status of this species. Studies are needed to obtain information on its susceptibility to threatening processes, including chytrid fungus.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its population status, threats and ecological requirements.
habitat: Its habitat is montane tropical forest. This species' breeding habits are not known, though reproduction presumably takes place in water.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, and it is not known if it can survive outside montane forest habitat.
population: Its population status is not known. Lehr and Moravec conducted surveys in 2014 in the Chanchamayo valley, close to San Ramon, over a period of 3 hours a night over two days and failed to locate the species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). However due to the lack of detailed information surrounding this species, it is unknown whether it is due to whether the species no longer exists or whether searches were being conducted in the incorrect habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species occurs in the Andean valleys of Río Chanchamayo and Río Perene, in Junin Department, Peru. The original description paper lacked detailed information regarding the type locality such as elevational range which remains unknown, and the map is a rough approximation of the range of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information on this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation ActionsThis species might occur in the protected areas of the Bosque de Protección Pui Pui and the Bosque de Protección San Matías-San Carlos.

Research Needed
There is a need for further surveys to establish whether this species is still present within its known range.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable since this species has only been found at one location within Reserva Comunal El Sira. While it is locally common and there are no major ongoing threats at present, should logging activities encroach into this species' range in the future they could have devastating impacts on the species within a very short period of time.
habitat: This semi-arboreal species inhabits premontane and montane forest on an isolated mountain ridge of the upper Amazon Basin. It is generally caught on leaves or inside bromeliads (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). Nothing is known about its breeding strategy, although it has been suggested that it breeds by direct development (Duellman and Toft 1979). It is not known whether it can withstand any anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: The area where this species occurs is relatively remote which affords it some level of protection. Illegal logging, coca plantations, cattle farming, subsistence farming, and illegal mining have been documented as taking place in the Sira region and there are concerns that these are also occurring within the boundaries of the Reserva Comunal El Sira (Exploration Sira). However, these activities are predominantly taking place at lower elevations, outside of the species' range. If illegal loggers manage to reach the steep, montane areas where this species occurs in the future, it could be devastating to the species (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018).
population: The species is locally common (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). It was often found during surveys between July and August in 2010, November 2013, and June 2014, in the Cordillera del Sira, with a maximum density of seven individuals over eight person-hours of search effort (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. April 2017, G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). The current population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality of Camp Laguna, west slope of Serrania de Sira, Huánuco Region, Peru. The type specimen was recorded at 1,280 m asl, but the species may well occur from 600 to 2,000 m asl. It presumably ranges more widely than has been mapped, but it is nonetheless likely to be endemic to the Serrania de Sira. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known range is 65 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Reserva Comunal El Sira, an indigenous people's reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued maintenance of this, and other remaining habitat in the Serrania de Sira, is necessary.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,394 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to agricultural and mining activities in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: Its habitat is the montane dry forest ('matorral arbustivo'; Aguilar et al. 2012, D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018). Specimens have been found by day near streams and rivers (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018). It presumably breeds in water and requires good water quality.
threats: There are agricultural and mining activities throughout its range, which pose a threat to the species' habitat. It has been recorded in a mining concession in Cajamarca (Aguilar et al. 2012), and there are mining projects occurring in the Parcoy River basin which are causing pollution to the Parcoy river (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018).
population: It is a rare species. There are few recent records, perhaps because of lack of herpetological work within its range. In April 2017, three specimens were recorded in the Parcoy River, La Libertad (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species was previously only known from the type locality of Hacienda Yanasona in the upper Río Marañon area in Cajamarca, Peru (Leviton and Duellman 1978), but since the 2004 assessment, it has been documented from Celendín in Cajamarca (Aguilar et al. 2012) and Parcoy River, Pataz Province in La Libertad, Peru (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018). It has been recorded at 2,447 m asl (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018), its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,394 km2, and all individuals occur at three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Compliance and enforcement of national regulations for mining companies is necessary, particularly because this species likely depends on good water quality (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It is usually found in leaf-litter, and sometimes on low vegetation, in tropical rainforest, and premontane humid forest. There is no information known about breeding habits, although it presumably breeds by direct development. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance, and is not known to occur in secondary forest.
threats: The major threats to the species’ habitat include agricultural development, involving both cultivation of crops and livestock grazing, and logging.
population: It is uncommon where it occurs. In 2008, only a single individual was detected during surveys over 45 person-days in Huánuco, Peru (von May et al. 2008). In 2010, four individuals were recorded during 94 days of field work in the central Amazon of Ecuador (Ortega-Andrade 2010). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs at moderate and low elevations (from 100–1,700 m asl) on the eastern Andean slopes and in the upper Amazon Basin of Ecuador, and in the Cordillera de Cutucú and Cordillera del Condór, in Ecuador and Peru.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Parque Nacional Sangay, Estación Biológica Jatun Sacha and Bosque Protector del Alto Nangaritza in Ecuador. In Peru, it occurs in Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is Data Deficient in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Taxonomic research is needed to resolve the status of highland populations that might represent a different species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: This species presumably inhabits puna (high-elevation grassland). Its mode of reproduction is unknown.
threats: There is some habitat loss due to agriculture and the construction of roads in the area nearby the type locality (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018), but there is no direct information on whether these activities constitute threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. In 2011, <span class="MsoCommentReference">a survey in the vicinity of the type locality did not record the species (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, 5 km SW of Comas, in Junín Region, in the Andes of central Peru, at 2,745 m asl. It probably occurs more widely, but this has not been confirmed.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More research on its population status, distribution, habitat requirements and threats is needed.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 280 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the slopes of the Cordillera Oriental of the Andes in central Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits riparian vegetation along the Apurimac river in cloud forest and has been recorded in the leaf litter (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). Its breeding habits are unknown.
threats: The main threat is habitat loss for agriculture and an increase in fire frequency caused by local people (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018).
population: It is not considered a common species (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). In 2016, surveys in the vicinity of Chiquintirca recorded four individuals over 12 person-hours (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from Carapa and Yanamonte, on the slopes of the Cordillera Oriental of the Andes in central Peru, below Abra Tapuna, on the west side of the Río Apurimac, and from the patches of forests at vicinity of Chiquintirca village (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018), La Mar Province, Ayacucho Department. It occurs from 2,200–2,440 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 280 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required at sites where the species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, ecology, and threats.

rationale: No further information is available since the 2004 assessment. It is only known from a single female specimen collected in 1966, there is uncertainty as to its taxonomic status, and there is no data on its population status or threats to the population. Therefore in the absence of sufficient information, this species is listed as Data Deficient until further information becomes available to accurately evaluate this species' extinction risk.
habitat: This species is associated with stream habitats in montane tropical forest, where trees are generally widely spaced and separated by 2-3 m tall shrubland. Within these areas, there are also wet depressions and small ravines, with slightly taller (4-9 m) elfin forest. Eggs are deposited on leaves above streams, and larvae develop in the streams.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. General habitat loss due to agricultural expansion from smallholder farming and human settlement may represent a threat.
population: This species is known only from the female holotype and has not been recorded since 1966. There is no other data on its population.
range: This species is known only from the type locality: km 184, c. 3.3 km west of Fundo Nuevo Mundo (at 1,500 m asl), an isolated cloud forest of the Cordillera Azul between Tingo Maria and Pucallpa, in Huánuco Department, central Peru (Flores and McDiarmid 1989). It is believed to have a restricted range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It may occur in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI).

Research Needed
Given that this species was described based on a single female specimen, and is still only known from the holotype, taxonomic studies are required to determine whether this is a valid species or a synonym of another glassfrog (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. September 2018). Further research into the distribution, population status, and threats of this poorly-known species is needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 309 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the Pacific versant of the Cordillera Central in Peru.
habitat: This frog is associated with streams in montane forest. At night, individuals perch on the upper surfaces of leaves over streams and during the day they rest on upper leaf surfaces over streams, where breeding occurs (Cadle and McDiarmid 1990). Breeding for this species apparently begins with the onset of rains (January). Males call from the upper surfaces of leaves 0.5–3 m above streams. Eggs are deposited on leaves above permanent and temporary streams, and larvae develop in the streams. Breeding activity (based on the number of observed egg masses in some stream sections) is believed to be high, compared to other species of the genus (Cadle and McDiarmid 1990). It is not known if the species can adapt to modified habitats.
threats: It is probably affected by habitat loss as a result of livestock farming and selective wood extraction. It might also be vulnerable to the effects of localized climate change and infection with the chytrid fungus.
population: It was once believed to be a common species; the type series is represented by 68 specimens (Cadle and McDiarmid 1990). During 1989 surveys in two frequently-worked sections of a stream, male densities sometimes exceeded 30 individuals per ca 10 m. Between the years of 1986 to 2002, this glass frog was frequently recorded in the buffer areas of Parque Nacional Cutervo (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018). Surveys in Cajamarca during 2006–2007, however, detected only a single individual over 74 person-days, suggesting the population experienced declines (von May et al. 2008). Extensive searches in El Refugio de Vida Silvestre Bosques Nublados de Udima during 2010 and 2011 did not record any individuals (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from forested slopes of the Río Zaña watershed, on the Pacific versant of the Cordillera Central in the Cajamarca Region, northern Peru. It was also recorded in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Cutervo in Cajamarca between 1986 and 2002 (A. Miranda Leiva pers. comm. March 2018). It occurs at elevations of 1,500–1,800 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 309 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations. Its range is incompletely known, and it presumably occurs much more widely, but nevertheless probably has a somewhat restricted distribution.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its mapped range overlaps with El Refugio de Vida Silvestre Bosques Nublados de Udima, but its presence in this protected area needs to be confirmed. It was recorded in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Cutervo in Cajamarca, but has not been recorded from within the park. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.  

Conservation Needed
There is a need for improved habitat protection of sites at which this species is known to occur. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed to help better understand the distribution, population status, natural history, and threats to this species. Close monitoring of the population is recommended given the potential risk of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, and threatening processes.
habitat: This species is associated with streams inside cloud forest. Individuals have been found at night in rivulets and streams, and males have been seen calling from the upper surfaces of leaves 0.5–2.5 m above the water (P. Venegas and M. Pepper pers. comm. In Twomey et al. 2014). Eggs are presumably deposited on leaves above streams, with larvae developing in the streams. One clutch of 46 eggs, presumably belonging to this species, was found on the upper surface of a leaf (Twomey et al. 2014). This species appears to be associated with undisturbed habitats with relatively dense canopy cover; however, the Gocta site is open, although this site lies deep in a ravine (Twomey et al. 2014).
threats: The threats to this species are unclear. In general, there is ongoing regional habitat loss due to an increase in agricultural activities, selective wood extraction, and human settlement. Intervening valleys in the region are extensively cultivated. This species might also be at risk from chytridiomycosis, but this requires further investigation.
population: This species was described in 1993 from a single specimen collected in 1989 (Duellman and Schulte 1993) and was known only from the holotype until 2007. Six additional individuals were registered during two visits to the base of Gocta waterfall in Amazonas in 2007 and 2011, and another specimen was collected in 2011, from 7.4 km southeast of Puente Vilcaniza (Twomey et al. 2014). There have been numerous surveys at the type locality, but they have been unable to find this species (Twomey et al. 2014). This species ranges from abundant during some visits to completely undetectable during other visits (P. Venegas pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from three sites spanning the divide between the Huallaga and Marañón drainages in southern Amazonas, Peru (Duellman and Schülte 1993, Twomey et al. 2014). It occurs between 1,830 and 2,050 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 233 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur at three threat-defined locations. The specimens from Gocta waterfall may actually represent an undescribed species (Twomey et al. 2014), but are retained in this assessment until further taxonomic analysis is conducted.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It might occur within Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo, however this requires confirmation.

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Additional taxonomic work is needed, particularly on the specimens from Gocta waterfall as they may represent an undescribed species (Twomey et al. 2014).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,828 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat on the slopes of the Andes in northern Peru.
habitat: It is an arboreal species found in montane cloud forests in the close proximity of streams with thick forest cover (Duellman and Schülte 1993, Twomey et al. 2014). It has also been observed streams adjacent to highly disturbed areas in Peru (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). This species appears to have a narrow microhabitat requirement of flat damp areas with a constant source of water. Eggs are presumably laid on leaves and the larvae develop in streams.
threats: The valleys surrounding the type locality are being extensively cultivated (Duellman and Schülte 1993), so habitat loss due to agricultural practices, wood extraction and human settlement is suspected. The available habitat outside of protected areas appears to be very fragmented. It might be very susceptible to infection with chytrid, although Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has yet to be reported from this species.
population: This species was described from a single adult male collected in Abra Tangarana, San Martín, Peru (Duellman and Schülte 1993). In 2005, two individuals were found by day in a small stream ca 25 km SW from Tarapoto, San Martín. In June 2011, two adult males were collected from a small stream ca 7.5 km SE from the type locality. In addition, photographs have been seen of specimens from the village of Yurilamas and a site ca 14 km SE from the town of Shamboyacu, San Martín. In 2014, one individual was observed during surveys over six person-hours at Microcuencas Rumiyacu, Moyobamba in San Martín (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
range: This species was formerly known only from its type locality Abra Tangarana in northern San Martín, Peru (Duellman and Schulte 1993). It is now also known from Yurilamas; 5.9–7.5 km SE from the type locality; ca 25 km SW from Tarapoto; ca 14 km SE from the town of Shamboyacu (Twomey et al. 2014); and Microcuencas Rumiyacu, Moyobamba (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017), all in northern Peru. The specimen from Zamora-Chinchipe Province, Ecuador reported by Guayasamin and Bonaccorso (2011) belong to the new species, Nymphargus colomai (Guayasamin et al. 2020). This species occurs at elevations ranging from 1,000–1,470 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,828 km2, which represents five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul in Peru.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into its population status, ecology, and threats, including the potential impacts of localized climate change and infection with the chytrid fungus.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It can be found in wet montane forest and in montane and pre-montane forests, specifically in Amazonian forests, in semi-humid montane forest, and in Yungas forest (De la Riva et al. 2000). It is an arboreal species that can be observed perching on wet sites next to streams (Köhler 2000, Lötters and Köhler 2000). Egg clutches are deposited on rocks in streams. It is not found in open areas or cultivated areas (Vaira et al. 2009), but it has been found in forest that was once selectively logged and is now regenerating (Whitworth et al. 2017).
threats: Logging and illegal gold mining are the major threats to the species and they destroy and degrade the species' stream habitat (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The initiation of gold mining in 2014 within Peru's Amarakaeri Communal Reserve, may pose a threat, however satellite imagery shows that management efforts have mitigated any subsequent expansion within the protected area (Finer and Novoa 2017). There is localised habitat loss throughout its range for cattle ranching, agriculture, and wood extraction, hydroelectric development, and water extraction for agriculture and domestic use. Water pollution from agriculture is an additional concern.
population: If the environmental conditions are suitable, the species is easy to observe and is abundant and locally common (Köhler 2000, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from Florida and Ichilo Provinces in Santa Cruz Department (Harvey 1996, Köhler 2000, Lötters and Köhler 2000), La Paz Department (Köhler et al. 2006), and Cochabamba (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019) in Bolivia, as well as, Bahuaja Sonene National Park (Puno Region), Amarakaeri Communal Reserve (Madre de Dios Region) and Kosñipata, Cusco, southern Peru in the buffer zone of Manu National Park (Lujan et al. 2014, Deichmann et al. 2017, A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The La Paz and Cochabamba records and all records from Peru represent a significant range extension since the previous assessment. It occurs from 500–1,750 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia, it occurs in Parque Nacional Amboró, Parque Nacional Carrasco, Parque Nacional Pilon Lajas and Parque Nacional Madidi. In Peru, it occurs in Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene and Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri, and it is likely to occur in Parque Nacional del Manú.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and natural history.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient due to the lack of recent records of historical localities and resulting uncertainty around the true extent of its range, and the uncertainty around the identity of this species in relation to congeners.
habitat: This species inhabits secondary montane cloud forest and has been observed perched on vegetation at 1.4 m above the ground. It has been found in disturbed forest close to a fish farm in the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park, but it is unknown what degree of habitat disturbance it tolerates. Based on the breeding strategy of congeners, it is expected to deposited eggs on leaves and its larvae might develop in streams.
threats: It occurs in an area that is actively used for agricultural activities (chili and passion fruit plantations), which are currently expanding. In this area, there is heavy use of herbicides and this may affect the species if the chemicals leach into the surface water in which juveniles may develop.
population: Its population status is unknown. Surveys in November 2014 only recorded a single individual in <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">the southern buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park and this is the only known record in recent years (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017).
range:
This species is known from two sites in the Pasco Region along the Cordillera Oriental: 1) Huancabamba (the type locality); and 2) sector of Chacos, in the southern buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park. It occurs from 1,200–1,992 m asl and the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 316 km2.

Cannatella and Duellman (1982) report this species from Ayacucho, Huancabamba (Pasco Region), and Valle del Perene, however there are questions regarding the identity of the records in Ayacucho (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017) and they are excluded from the assessment. Furthermore, the reference to Valle de Perene is vague making it difficult to locate and map the actual locality and this part of its range has been coded as "Presence Uncertain". Furthermore, the previous assessment reported the species from southern Peru at Cosñipata, Cusco Department, but these records are now considered to be Nymphargus pluvialis and have been removed from this assessment (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species may occur within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 162 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Apurimac River drainage in Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits primary and secondary cloud forest (Cannatella and Duellman 1982). Individuals have been recorded calling at night from the upper sides of leaves within 1 m of a slow stream. Eggs are presumably laid on leaves, with larval development in streams. It is unknown whether it can tolerate habitat disturbance.
threats: The area where this species occurs is subject to localized loss and degradation of habitats due to human colonization, agricultural development (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018), and small-scale logging activities can be observed from satellite imagery. The forest in the vicinity of Cajadela is being destroyed due to the establishment of red chili and coca farms (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018).
population: There is little information about its population status, as it is only known from four adult males collected in 1975 (Cannatella and Duellman 1982) and one additional individual collected in 2010 (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018). In 2011, a survey in the vicinity of the type locality did not record the species (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was formerly known only from the type locality of Tutumbaro (at 1,840 m asl) on the Río Piene, Ayacucho Region, in southern Peru. Since the previous assessment, it has also been recorded in a stream of the vicinity of Cajadela Community (at 1,837 m asl) in the Apurimac River drainage, Ayacucho Region (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018). The two known localities are separated by 45 km (airline). It might range much more widely, but there has been little survey work of the surrounding areas. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 162 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required to conserve this species.

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed to better understand this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,041 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is strongly associated with streams. At Pistipata, the vegetation consists of coffee and tea plantations with remnants of cloud forest. In Bolivia, it has been collected in primary montane forest. Individuals call on rainy nights, on herbaceous plants on dripping wet cliffs and the upper sides of leaves over water, all adjacent to streams. Egg clutches are laid on the tips of the upper surfaces of the leaves, and the larvae develop in streams.
threats: In Peru, it is probably impacted by the loss and degradation of its habitats for human colonization and agricultural development, although it seems to survive in coffee and tea plantations (e.g. Pistipata). The habitat at the only known locality in Bolivia has been destroyed due to road widening and maintenance (S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019). In the buffer zone of Parque Nacional del Manú, most subpopulations have disappeared in the period between 2000-2007, when outbreaks of chytridiomycosis have been associated with the collapse of amphibian populations in the region (Catenazzi et al. 2011, 2014). This species has not been tested for the amphibian chytrid fungus in Bolivia, although another species in the genus (e.g., N. bejaranoi) has tested positive for chytrid (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017) suggesting chytridiomycosis could be a threat to this species (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
population: The population trend of this species is decreasing. Until 1999, the species was commonly seen in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Manu, and during 2008-2009 it was still found in two creeks in this area, but since 2012 it has only been recorded in a single creek in Kosñipata (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. November 2019). Where it still occurs, it is found in much lower numbers than historically. It was seen as recently as ca 2015 in the type locality at Pistipata (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. November 2019) and it is still being found around Machu Picchu (L. Mamani pers. comm. 2019). It has not been observed at the only known locality in Bolivia since 2003, despite several surveys; it may be locally extirpated because the habitat has been destroyed (S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019).
range: This species is known from three areas in Cusco Region in southern Peru: Pistipata, Machu Picchu and the buffer zone of Parque Nacional del Manú. It is also known from a single locality in central La Paz, Bolivia. It has an elevational range of 1,820-2,370 m asl. It presumably occurs in between known sites, but further surveys are required to verify this (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its currently known range is 3,041 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species has been recorded from within the boundaries of Parque Nacional del Manú and its buffer zone in Peru and may still persist there. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru (SERFOR 2018) and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Continuation of rigorous management of the existing parks is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed in the region to determine whether there are any additional subpopulations. More information is needed on the specific threats affecting this species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This species inhabits the lowland and upland forests of eastern Guiana Shield and western Amazon. It has always been found associated with streams. It is usually found on the upper surface of leaves in shrubs and trees along streams at about 1–3 m above water or ground level. It is also found in streams with jasper rocks. It lays its eggs on the underside of leaves overhanging streams, and when hatched the larvae fall into the stream below, where they develop further. Calling males have been found nearby (5 cm) clutches containing 22 eggs.
threats: Logging is an ongoing threat to this species' habitat, and mining for gold and diamonds was a past threat. In Yachana Reserve, Ecuador, cattle pastures surround the reserve almost entirely along its perimeter. The forest along the reserve boundary is disturbed by human traffic for hunting and logging. Pollution from agricultural herbicides and pesticides may be a problem, although this has not been shown directly (Guayasamin and North 2009). In Mabura Hill Forest Reserve in French Guiana, both logging and gold mining are a threat to the habitat (A. Fouquet pers. comm. November 2017).
population: It is not an uncommon species. During three night surveys (Nov/Dec 2008, Jan/Feb 2009, Apr/May 2009) in Reserva Biológica do Uatumã, Amazonas, Brazil, over 400 individuals of this species (as Hyalinobatrachium nouraguensis) were recorded in 45 plots of 250 m in length (Condrati 2009). However, only a single individual has been observed despite 672 survey hours in Yachana Reserve, Ecuador (Guayasamin and North 2009).
range:
This species is known from the Guiana region of Venezuela, central Guyana, Suriname (Sipaliwini, Nickerie and Marowijne Districts), French Guiana, Ecuador (Sucumbios and Napo Provinces), Peru (Loreto Region), and Brazil (Amazonas, Amapá, Pará, and Mato Grosso states). It presumably occurs much more widely, and is expected to occur in the Amazonian areas between the Ecuadorian and Peruvian localities and the Guiana region (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2011), and in adjacent Colombia. The recent records from Sucumbíos, Ecuador and Loreto, Peru (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009) have extended the known range of this species nearly 1,900 km from the nearest, previously known locality (Amazonas, Brazil), and represent the westernmost records of this species suggesting that it is widely distributed across the entire Amazonian lowlands (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009). The recent record from Amapá State, Brazil (e Silva and Costa-Campos 2016) extends the known distribution of the species 1,020 km east from the type locality (Quebrada de Jaspe, Bolívar State, Venezuela). It occurs between 50–1,000 m asl.

Records previously assigned to Hyalinobatrachium nouraguense from French Guiana (Lescure and Marty 2000) and central Guyana (Ernst et al. 2005) are now considered to belong to this species.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas throughout its range.

Research Needed
Taxonomic work is necessary to resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and tolerance of a degree of habitat disturbance.
habitat: This diurnal species has been collected in lowland tropical rainforest, and 'rolling hills' where it can be found in leaf-litter. It is a secretive species that is found mainly in primary forest and less frequently in secondary or regenerating forest. In Ecuador, it has been found in secondary forest and vegetation along streams in agricultural areas (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Males have been heard calling concealed above the leaf-litter and from boulder crevices. Eggs are laid in leaf-litter and the larvae are carried to streams (Jungfer 1989, Almendáriz 1991, Lötters et al. 2007).
threats: There is localised habitat loss due to deforestation for agriculture and livestock and the pollution of water sources from livestock, agriculture and mining. Roads for oil exploration and production have become a major factor in agricultural expansion, deforestation and colonization in the Ecuadorian Amazon. The Yachana Reserve is surrounded by large areas of pastureland, small active cacao farms and forest.
population: It is a locally abundant species. In Ecuador, it is considered to be common (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). In February 2004, surveys along an 8-km transect recorded c. 2.6 individuals/day for 10 consecutive days near the Río Arajuno in Napo Province, Ecuador (Darst and Cummings 2006). During April 2009–December 2010, 5.50 frogs per 70 trapping days (n=44) were encountered in pitfall traps in primary forest and 0.5 frogs per 70 trapping days (n=2) were found in regenerating plantations, throughout Yachana Reserve, Ecuador (Beirne et al. 2013). Visual survey transects during the same study detected 0.24 frogs per 450 m2 in primary forest (n=12), whereas no individuals were found along transects in regenerating plantations or abandoned pastureland (Beirne et al. 2013). In Peru (Province of Datem del Marañón, Loreto), 27 and 29 frogs were detected during wet season (February–March, 2009) and dry season (June–July, 2009) surveys, respectively (Valqui Schult 2015).
range: This species is known from the Napo and Pastaza drainages of Ecuador, east of the Andes, extending to the Region of Loreto, northern Peru. Its altitudinal range is 200–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Yasuní National Park, Sangay National Park, Yachana Reserve, and Jatun Sacha Biological Station in Ecuador, however it is not known from any protected areas in Peru. This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 18,344 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, and has a presumed large and stable population.
habitat: It is a diurnal, terrestrial species known from both humid and dry pre-montane and lowland forest (Duellman 2004), which is associated with streams. It has been recorded from disturbed (partially cutover) rainforest (Duellman 2004), implying tolerance of some degree of habitat modification. Larvae are carried to streams by the female.
threats: Because of the large areas of suitable habitat available in protected areas to this species there are no major threats. Outside protected areas, there is some localized habitat loss through different human activities, principally agriculture.
population: In the Cainrachi area, this species is abundant in both primary and secondary forested areas in both mid and low elevations (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It is considered to be the most abundant Dendrobatid (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017) and the population is thought to be stable.
range: This species' geographic range is the northeastern slope of the Andes of Peru, within the Cordillera Central (Departments of Amazonas and San Martin). Its known localities lie within the Río Cainarachi drainage (two sites) and the Río Marañón valley (two sites) (Duellman 2004), and it has an estimated altitudinal range of 400–1,700 m asl (Aguilar et al. 2010). It might occur more widely. Its EOO is 18,344 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs within the Santiago Comaina Reserved Zone and the Alto Mayo protected area. No species-specific conservation measures are known. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on EOO, area of occupancy (AOO), population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information on this species since the 1980s and in view of continuing uncertainties regarding its extent of occurrence, population status, and ecological requirements. It is known from a very restricted area, but no information is available on possible or ongoing threats.
habitat: This is a diurnal species known from humid tropical montane forest, where it has been found at seepages and along small streams (Duellman 2004). Males have been recorded transporting batches of 7–12 tadpoles on their backs; larval development is completed in slow-moving and sometimes marshy streams (Duellman 2004). Both adults and larvae have been recorded from disturbed forest and cultivated land close to human settlements (Duellman 2004), potentially indicating a level of tolerance of habitat modification.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss due to agriculture and human settlements within its range. It is unknown whether the subpopulations occurring in the vicinity of agricultural activities are remnant subpopulations of a species at risk from agricultural conversion, or whether the frog is genuinely tolerant of this degree of habitat modification. The fungal disease chytridiomycosis was first reported from Peru in 1998 (Lips et al. 2008), and has been responsible for severe declines and extinctions among Andean amphibians, especially of high-elevation, stream-breeding frogs with small ranges (Whittaker and Vrendenberg 2010). It is however unknown whether this disease represents a specific threat to this species.
population: Rivero (1991) described this species based on a single subadult specimen, but Duellman’s (2004) account was based on extensive material collected in the 1970's and 1980's, including the holotype and many adults and larvae from seven additional localities. There have been no published records since those in Duellman's account, and no known recent surveys for this frog. Its population status remains unknown.
range: This species is known from the type locality of Venceremos, 394–395 km along the Marginal de la Selva road (San Martín Region), on the eastern slopes of the central Andes in northern Peru, and has since been reported from seven additional localities in the Cordillera Central (Duellman 2004), including the eastern Abra Pardo de Miguel (San Martín), the vicinity of Balzapata, 11 km SSE Chachapoyas, and the vicinity of Pomachochas (Amazonas). Most records are from between 1,620–2,200 m asl, but there are two isolated records up to 2,840 m asl (Duellman 2004).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Alto Mayo Protection Forest and the Tilacancha Private Conservation Area, designated in 2010.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is present in arid areas including coastal 'desert' and dry shrublands. Generally occurs close to streams with dense vegetation; breeding takes place in quiet waters close to streams. The species is not greatly sensitive to habitat change.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. There is some agriculture within its range, however there is not information on whether it affects the species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
population: It is considered a common species, as many frogs have been heard calling, however the species is difficult to find (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). Its current population trend is not known.
range: This species has been recorded from several scattered localities in the Pacific inter-Andean valleys of Ancash, Huánuco, Amazonas, and Piura Regions, Peru, however its true distribution is not well understood (E. Lehr and C. Aguilar pers. comm. December 2017). The original subpopulation from which this species was described was apparently introduced to Lima from its original range, although this subpopulation may now be extinct. Its altitudinal range within its native distribution is 665–2,180 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from at least one protected area, Pantanos de Villa Reserved Zone in Lima.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends of both native and introduced subpopulations. Taxonomic work is needed to determine if this form is a complex of more than one species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
