rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"\nListed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range.
habitat: This diurnal frog inhabits tropical lowland moist forest. It occurs near streams, but has been found up to 25 m into the forest, therefore differing from some strictly riparian congeners confined to the streamside (Grant and Rodríguez 2001). Eggs are likely laid in the leaf litter and, upon hatching, adults probably carry the larvae to streams to develop.
threats: There are no major threats to this species as there are few human activities within its range and suitable habitat remaining, although there is limited tourism development ongoing in the region.
population: Little is known about the population status of this species.
range: This species is currently known from the lower Quebrada Sucusari in the Río Napo drainage, and from Quebrada Limera and Lago Preto in Río Putumayo, in Loreto, Peru (Grant and Rodríguez 2001, Pérez et al. 2003, Rodríguez and Knell 2003). It is likely that it is more widely distributed throughout the Amazonian lowlands. It occurs up to 200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its presence in the Tamshiyacu-Tahuayo Regional Conservation Area must be verified. 

Conservation Needed
No conservation measures are recommended at present, however there might be a need to establish protected areas for this species if habitat degradation significantly increases.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This is a diurnal species that was collected in tropical montane forest, where it was associated with streams (Duellman 2004). Its breeding habits are not known, but the larvae probably develop in streams.
threats: There is no information on major threats. The fungal disease chytridiomycosis was first reported from Peru in 1998 (Lips et al. 2008), and has been responsible for severe declines and extinctions among Andean amphibians, especially of high-elevation, stream-breeding frogs with small ranges (Whittaker and Vrendenberg 2010). It is however unknown whether this disease represents a specific threat to this species.
population: Its population status is not known, as this frog is only known from two specimens (Duellman 2004).
range: This species is only known from two sites in San Martín Region on the eastern slopes of the central Andes in northern Peru (Duellman 2004). Both localities, Abra Pardo Miguel (2,050 m asl) and Venceremos (1,620 m asl), lie along the road from Balzapata to Rioja, in the northern Cordillera Central. It probably occurs more widely over the Andean foothills of Peru.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not present in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed regarding the limits of its range, and concerning its population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This frog inhabits humid premontane forest and is mostly restricted to rocky stream habitats and waterfalls, where it is active primarily by day but also at night (Duellman 2004). It has also been recorded from dry forest in the vicinity of Chiriaco, Peru (Duellman 2004). Where it occurs, this species appears to be the only poison dart frog associated with these habitats (Duellman 2004). Eggs are laid on the leaf-litter near streams, and larvae are transported to streams by adults where they develop in quiet pools in or adjacent to the watercourse (Duellman 2004). In one reported case, a male was observed transporting 12 tadpoles (Duellman 2004). The species is known to occur in modified and lightly degraded habitat, including rural gardens and cutover forest.
threats: No immediate threats to this species are known. Extreme habitat destruction and pollution are the only potential threats.
population: This species has a fairly large range and is quite abundant throughout, furthermore population densities are usually very high (Twomey and Brown 2017). It is expected to have a stable population given its relatively widespread distribution.
range: This species' is known from the lower northeastern slopes and foothills of the Andes, in the Regions of Amazonas, Loreto, and San Martín in Peru and in Morona-Santiago Province in southeastern Ecuador. It has been recorded between 500 and 1,550 m asl in Ecuador (Coloma 1995). In Peru, it occurs mainly at lower elevations, between 325 and 810 m asl (Duellman 2004).
useTrade: Some Peruvian poison dart frogs are subject to smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008). It is unknown whether this is the case for the brightly-coloured Los Tayos rocket frog.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It may occur in the Santiago Comaina Reserved Zone and Alto Mayo Protection Forest in Peru and Sangay National Park in Ecuador, although this requires confirmation. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed into this species' distribution, population status, and potential threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This species has been reported from disturbed lowland rainforest and from humid montane forest at low elevations. It has been found by day in leaf litter, but nothing else is known about its ecology (Duellman 2004). Based on the discovery of six large eggs in one female specimen, Duellman (2004) suggests that this frog may lay its eggs on land, and the larvae also develop on land.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, although it could be threatened by habitat degradation through conversion to coffee plantations and general agricultural development.
population: There is no information on the population size and trends of this species.
range: This species is only known from two sites, both within 4 km of Tarapoto, San Martín Department, Peru (Duellman 2004). It has been recorded between 350–680 m asl. The locality and elevation information given in Morales (2000) is incorrect (Duellman 2004).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known from any protected areas, and there are no conservation measures in place for it.

Research Needed
More research is needed into its distribution, population status, ecological requirements and any threats. Further work may be required to confirm the validity of this species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species occurs in humid lowland and lower montane rainforest. Animals are active alongside small streams, especially near waterfalls where small caves provide shelter. The eggs are presumably deposited in leaf-litter, and a male has been observed carrying the hatched larvae to a stream to complete their development.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, although some lower parts of the Cerros del Sira are being selectively logged. Deforestation for cattle farming and illegal mining have been increasing in the Sira region in recent years, particularly in the foothills (Exploration Sira; G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018).
population: In the 2004 assessment, it was suspected to be reasonably common in suitable habitat. However, it has not been observed in recent years despite multiple biological surveys in the Cerros del Sira (A. Whitworth pers. comm. February 2018, G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2018). Several surveys performed in Cerros del Sira during 2013–2014 with an effort of 64 person-hours per survey were unable to find the species, although these surveys were not conducted in the exact sites where the species was previously recorded (G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality (5 km southeast of Comunidad Nativa de Davis) in Cerros del Sira, Pasco Region, Peru, where it has an altitudinal range of 210–800 m asl. It seems to have a very restricted distribution, however it could occur more widely along the foothills of the Pachitea River (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. It might be present in the Reserva Comunal El Sira, an indigenous people's reserve, however it has not yet been observed there (A. Whitworth pers. comm. February 2018, G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2018).

Conservation Needed
Continued maintenance of this, and other remaining habitat in the Serrania de Sira, is necessary.

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to better understand the species' distribution, particularly whether occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality, or inside Reserva Comunal El Sira. More information is needed on its population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This is a diurnal, terrestrial species, reported from moist lowland tropical forest, although it is not known if it was collected in primary or secondary forest, nor whether or not it can adapt to modified habitats. It is thought to be associated with stream habitats, where the larvae presumably develop.
threats: The major threat to this species is habitat degradation: the type locality is highly disturbed by agricultural activities (including coffee plantations) and urbanization (establishment of settlements and townships).
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the specimens that constitute the type series.
range: This species is only known from its type locality: between Chachapoyas and Bagua Grande Alva, on the slopes of the Cordillera Central above the Río Utcubamba Valley, Amazonas Region, Peru (Rivero 1991). It has been found at 1,000 m asl (Duellman 2004), and it is unknown whether it occurs more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not currently known from any protected areas, although it might occur in the Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo (but further investigations are required to confirm this). 

Conservation Needed
There is a need to protect habitat remnants at the type locality.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 790 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat in Huancabamba.
habitat: This cloud forest species is active along streams by day, and has been found under rocks within and along streams at night (Duellman 2004). Eggs are presumably laid in leaf-litter on the forest floor; once tadpoles hatch, adults transport them to muddy pool habitats in streams to complete development. Larval transport and free-swimming tadpoles of this species have been recorded in February (Duellman 2004).
threats: Where this species has been recorded in the Huancabamba depression, it is threatened by deforestation and agricultural activities (mostly cultivation of potatoes). The fungal disease chytridiomycosis was first reported from Peru in 1998 (Lips et al. 2008), and has been associated with severe declines and extinctions among Andean amphibians, especially of high-elevation, stream-breeding frogs with small ranges (Whittaker and Vrendenberg 2010), such as this one. It is however unknown whether this disease represents a specific threat to this species. As a cloud forest species of mountain summits, this frog may be susceptible to the effects of climate change, either through desiccation of its habitat or from the invasion of species from lower elevations into newly-suitable area; however, further research is needed to determine the impacts of this potential threat factor.
population: The species is not abundant. While there is no direct information, due to the continuing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is found along the Amazonian slopes of the northeastern Andes and in the Huancabamba depression in northern Peru (Cajamarca and Piura Regions). It occurs between 1,920–3,100 m asl, reaching the summit of the cordillera between Chanaque and Huancabamba (Duellman 2004). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 790 km<sup>2</sup> and it occurs at less than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known to occur in any protected areas (Aguilar et al. 2010).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into the limits of its range, population trends, use, threats and tolerance of habitat modification.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats affecting the species.
habitat: This species is presumed to have been collected in cloud forest, although nothing further is known about its habitat and ecology (but the larvae probably develop in streams).
threats: General threats to its habitat in the area mostly relate to agricultural activities (such as the cultivation of coffee and tea). If this species is confirmed to occur in cloud forest, then it may be a threat.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Tingo in the Río Utcubamba drainage, on the western slopes of the northern Cordillera Oriental (Amazonas Department), in the Andes of Peru, where it has been collected at an altitude of 2,391 m asl. It is likely to occur more widely than is currently known.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known to occur in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed regarding the limits of its range, its ecological requirements, population status, use and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 322 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the lower eastern versant of the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland primary tropical rainforest and prefers rock piles and small caves to open areas (Twomey and Brown 2009). While juveniles can occasionally be observed in the leaf litter, adults are usually only encountered at dusk when the males begin to call from crevices in rock piles (Twomey and Brown 2009). The female lays 12–16 eggs in water-filled coconut shells, hollows in leaf litter, or bromeliads (Halliday 2016). The male guards the eggs for up to two weeks and, upon hatching, he transports the larvae to pools in streams or water-filled plants on the ground, including fallen palm tree leaves (Lötters et al. 2000, Lötters et al. 2007, Schulte and Lötters 2013). Nothing is known about its adaptability to modified habitats.
threats: The major threat to the species is general habitat loss resulting from various human activities, including recreation and residential areas, as well as, agricultural development in lower elevations. The species has been recorded in the pet trade, but is part of a legal and sustainable captive breeding program (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). As of June 2016, this species has been recorded in the frog hobby, but it appears it is uncommon.
population: Population size estimates are extremely difficult because adults are rarely encountered, though tadpoles are commonly found, suggesting that adult scarcity is a function of shyness and not rarity (Twomey and Brown 2009). During nearly six months of surveys throughout 2004–2005 in the Cainarachi valley, this species went undetected until a single courting pair was heard calling inside a cave (Twomey and Brown 2009). Surveys in San Martín from 2004–2007, detected ca 15 individuals over 90 person-days (von May et al. 2008). Between 23 March and 8 May 2011, 27 tadpoles were collected in a premontane late-stage secondary forest at km 32 on the Tarapoto-Yurimaguas road, close to the upper Cainarachi River, San Martín, Peru (Schulte 2013). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality along Tarapoto-Yurimaguas Road and the town of Achinamisa on the lower eastern versant of the Andes, San Martín Region, Peru. It is presumed to have a restricted distribution. It occurs at elevations ranging from 200–1,200 m asl, its EOO is 322 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: The species has been recorded in trade. It was exported legally and sustainably in mid-2005 as part of the INIBICO project (Twomey and Brown 2009), and it is currently part of a legal and sustainable captive breeding program by Understory Enterprises (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in the Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. This species was exported legally and sustainably in mid-2005 as part of the INIBICO project (Twomey and Brown 2009).

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need to both encourage the protection of remaining lowland habitat as well as establish a conservation management plan that includes some form of legislation concerning trade.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats, especially with regards to the impact of use and trade. There is a need for population monitoring of the status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and harvesting.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 9,240 km2, it is known from ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in parts of its range due to agricultural expansion, mining activities and road building.
habitat: It is a diurnal species of lowland tropical moist forest (Twomey and Brown et al. 2008). Individuals were found either in low-lying parts of the forest or in forest adjacent to streams (Twomey and Brown et al. 2008). These streamside habitats are characterized by abundant Heliconia, which appears to be an important breeding site for this species as four tadpole-carrying males were found in or near Heliconia, suggesting these plants are used for tadpole deposition (Twomey and Brown et al. 2008). Frogs not found directly in phytotelmata (water bodies held by plants) were usually on the ground, suggesting that this species is at least partly terrestrial. Egg deposition may also be terrestrial, as an adult pair was observed for several minutes courting in the leaf litter (Twomey and Brown et al. 2008). This species has been only found within intact forest and it is unknown whether it might be able to tolerate any degree of habitat degradation (E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011).
threats: There has been illegal gold mining in the Santiago valley, but it is unknown how this threat might affect the species (E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011, March 2013). There is small-scale subsistence farming occurring at some sites within its Peruvian range which is likely to be causing local declines (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). In Ecuador, its habitat is under severe pressure by habitat destruction and fragmentation due to agricultural expansion, mining activities and road building (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Chytrid (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis) tests were consistently negative for adults and tadpoles although due to the small sample size this will need further verification (Twomey and Brown et al. 2008). No further investigations into the presence of chytrid have been carried out since 2008 (E. Twomey pers. comm. March 2013). While collection of this species for the pet trade does not currently constitute a threat, it is likely to become a threat if sites become more accessible in the future.
population:
It had not been seen alive since 1929 (Myers 1982), until 17 individuals were found during an expedition to its type locality in 2006 (Twomey and Brown 2008). The valley’s inaccessible nature (it is only accessible from the east, by river via the Pongo de Manseriche a gorge that constricts the 750 m-wide Marañón to a 120 m-wide rapid) and dangerous indigenous unrest (the Santiago valley is inhabited by Huambisa and Aguaruna natives, who, until recently, engaged in regular intertribal combat) prohibited exploration for 77 years before this first known herpetological survey of this region in 2006 (Twomey and Brown 2008), which reported the presence of this species from the Rio Marañón's banks.

This frog is locally common within its known distribution range and was found in high densities in only two small areas of the Santiago valley (17 individuals observed over 40 person/days as reported by von May et al. 2008, E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011). Further survey efforts in suitable neighbouring areas, such as the north side of the Marañón, along both east and west banks of the Santiago, the Cerros de Campanquis and the west bank of the Santiago 8 km from its junction with the Marañón were unsuccessful in finding this species (Twomey and Brown 2008). In addition, another survey in the Cerros de Campanquis carried out by the Field Museum around September 2011 did not find this species (E. Twomey pers. comm. March 2013). This suggests that this species may be continuously distributed in seemingly homogeneous lowland habitat (E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011). There is insufficient information available to determine whether there has been a population decline in this species (E. Twomey pers. comm. March 2013), however due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing. It is considered rare in Ecuador and is only known from a couple specimens (Santos et al. 2009).
range: This species occurs in northwestern Peru, where it is known only from the lowland valley formed between the Cordillera del Condor and the Cerros de Campanquis (177 to 600 m asl), and from southern Ecuador, near Panguintza, at ca. 800 m asl (Twomey and Brown 2008, Santos et al. 2009; E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011). The type series collected in 1929 and the majority of the specimens found in 2006 come from the same area, the south bank of the Río Marañón at the mouth of the Río Santiago in Amazonian Peru (Twomey and Brown 2008). Only a single individual was found in the north bank of the Marañón east of Río Santiago (Twomey and Brown 2008). Although the distribution of this species is larger than previously thought, it appears to be patchily distributed (Twomey and Brown 2017). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,240 km2; however, this species is presumed to occur slightly more widely across the Río Santiago valley and it could occur over an area of up to 14,000 km2 (E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011). All individuals are considered to occur at ten or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: Minor smuggling to Europe was reported after the species description was published in 2008, but it is thought to no longer occur due to this species' restricted and remote distribution (E. Twomey pers. comm. August 2011). However, a market exists for the species and trade might commence once its range becomes more accessible.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species may possibly occur within the Santiago-Comaina Reserve as it was found in close vicinity to this protected area (E. Twomey pers. comm August 2011). However, it has not been found in this reserve so far (E. Twomey pers. comm. March 2013). It is included under CITES Appendix II and is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Improved protection of lowland forest and rigorous management of existing parks are the main conservation measures required for this species.

Research Needed
More research is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 16,048 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, as well as a decline in the population due to illegal harvesting.
habitat: It is a diurnal species found only in older secondary growth and primary wet forests where larger arboreal phytotelms are common (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011). This frog uses phytotelmata (water-holding plants) to breed, where females usually deposit 2-5 eggs ( J. Brown pers. comm. July 2011) and males will then guard and tend the eggs, and later transport and deposit larvae (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011). Some subpopulations are quite arboreal (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011).  It is not known to occur in overly modified habitats  (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011).
threats: Harvesting for the international pet trade is an important ongoing threat, and so is habitat loss. Due to its breeding ecology requirements, this species is more vulnerable to habitat destruction and degradation taking place within its range, which is caused by human settlements and agricultural activities of small scale farming for coffee and bananas mainly.
population: It appears to be rare or uncommonly seen within its range (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011), although on occasion it can be locally abundant (J. Brown pers. comm. July 2011). The nominal morph, originally described by Boulenger in 1883, was thought to be possibly extinct due to rampant deforestation near the type locality of Yurimaguas, but was rediscovered in 2011 during fieldwork less than 20 km from the type locality (Brown et al. 2011). Surveys in 2006 in the northern extent of its range in the confluence of the Santiago-Marañón rivers (over five days) did not record any individuals of this species (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Its global population is not considered to be severely fragmented.
range: This Peruvian endemic occurs north of the Río Mayo and along the Río Huallaga and Rio Panpura, in the Regions of San Martín and Loreto, Peru. The northernmost subpopulations can be found along the Río Panapura, near Yurimaguas, while the northern spur of Cordillera Azul near Chazuta comprises the southernmost limit of its range (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011). There is one record (determined by gene sequencing) from Pongo de Manseriche, Loreto (Brown et al. 2011), however it requires further work to verify that it belongs to this species (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, it is included within the distribution map but it is excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation until its identity has been confirmed. The species has an altitudinal range of 180–1,200 m asl (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011). It is known from 13 geographical localities, representing fewer than 10 threat-defined locations (J. Brown pers. comm. July 2011), and its EOO is 16,048 km2.
useTrade: This species has been and still is collected in Peru for the international pet trade. Inhabitants of settlements in the vicinity of or in this species' range participate in facilitating the international illegal trade (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011). This frog was first legally exported in 2001 and is part of a legal and sustainable captive breeding program by Understory Enterprises (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017), however many of the frogs currently in the pet trade have been illegally acquired (J. Brown, E. Twomey and T. R. Kahn pers. comm. July 2011).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in the Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area (J. Brown pers. comm. August 2011), although it is not known to what degree the area's boundaries are enforced. There is a management programme under way for the species (ASPRAVEP Project), and it is covered in Appendix II of CITES as Dendrobates fantasticus.

Conservation Needed
Given habitat loss outside the protected area and within the species' range, habitat protection should be prioritized. The implementation of conservation and management programmes is important, and legislation regulating trade and enforcement of this is needed. 

Research Needed
Monitoring of harvest and trade levels for the pet trade is needed.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 717 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This diurnal frog inhabits primary pre-montane dry forest dominated by cacti, rocks and terrestrial bromeliads, and rock walls with Bromeliaceae plant species. They are primarily found in the upper and lower portions of steep cliff faces, where they have easy access to surrounding vegetation to forage for food (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). They are largely absent from the interior of the cliff faces, which is thought to be due to the danger of foraging in the steep cliff faces (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Breeding takes place only in bromeliads, which are the only stable and long-lasting water source in the immediate areas, particularly during the dry season (Schulte 1990, Papasera 2011). Males carry tadpoles on their backs and deposit each of them into tiny pools in a separate bromeliad cavity, where they complete development (Papasera 2011). The old-growth trees with Aechmea bromeliads on which this frog depends for reproduction, are very rare and have been mostly destroyed (Twomey and Brown 2009). Adult and juvenile frogs were observed to be feeding on ants and small, winged flies both inside the bromeliad and outside on rock walls, forest floor and on other plants (Papasera 2011).
threats: The main threat is forest clearance for agricultural use (including coffee and banana cultivation, cattle ranching and timber trade) and human settlements (Twomey and Brown 2009, Aguirre 2011, Martinez et al. 2013). The species now survives in only five or six small patches of forest (Halliday 2016). Uncontrolled slash and burn agriculture is common and of particular concern as fires do not adhere to the boundaries of reserves (Pasapera 2011). Smuggling decimated the population in the late 1990's (Twomey and Brown 2009) and may still present a threat.
population:
Much of the area is deforested and populations are only known from forest remnants that remain on some steep cliffs and slopes. Originally collected in the late 1920s, officially described by Myers in 1982 and rediscovered in the late 1989 (Schulte 1990), 60 years after its initial collection. Some of the trees that host the bromeliads in which this frog lives are scattered in a mosaic of degraded environments, which confounds the status of the population and hinders the movement of individuals and genetic exchange (Schulte 1990). The subpopulation near Pedro Ruiz is considered to be locally common from field observations over the period of a couple of hours (E. Twomey pers. comm. June 2017).

During 2005, surveys in Cajamarca detected approximately 70 individuals over 4 person-days (von May et al. 2008). Field surveys were conducted between July 2005 and November 2010 along a stretch of more than 350 km of the Marañón River; four individuals were observed during July 2008 and 12 individuals during May 2009, near Santa Rosa de la Yunga, Cajamarca (Koch 2014). A study conducted in 2010 during the dry season (June–November), in the vicinity of the village Santa Rosa in the southern end of the Cordillera del Condor, encountered 1,006 and 86 tadpoles, with most individuals found in three core areas (Pasapera 2011).
range: This species was previously only known from forest remnants located between the town of Santa Rosa and the western foothills of the Cordillera del Cóndor (Cajamarca Department), northeastern Peru. Of these localities, there are only three known sites remaining, two of which are believed to harbor fewer than 200 individuals (Twomey and Brown 2009). It is now also known from near Pedro Ruiz in Amazonas, Peru (E. Twomey pers. comm. June 2017). It occurs at elevations ranging from 600-1,305 m asl (Koch et al. 2018), but Twomey and Brown (2008) used 13 presence points for a niche model, ending up with a possible distribution between 200–1,500 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 717 km2.
useTrade: The species was commonly smuggled in the late 1990s. Consequently, this is a somewhat common frog in Europe, completely of illegal origin, and the potential for local conservation projects based on the legal sale of this species is now severely compromised (Twomey and Brown 2009). In 2007, the authorities in charge of animal confiscations attempted to release two dozen confiscated individuals outside of Tarapoto (R. Schulte pers. comm. in: Brown et al. 2008). According to CITES, the commercial import of seven live frogs were reported during 2004–2008 (Nijman and Shepherd 2010).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is reportedly present in the Cordillera del Cóndor Reserve. All known remaining individuals survive in three small forest remnants, which have been acquired by Conservation International (Twomey and Brown 2009). Two Wildlife Refuge and Rescue plots were established in 2004–2005 by Instituto de Investigación Biológica de las Cordilleras Orientales (INIBICO) & URKU Estudios amazónicos (funded by the IUCN-SPN-NL programme and the Dutch Postcode Lottery) to promote the conservation of this species (Conle and Hennemann 2005). In 2010, the Alliance for Zero Extinction (AZE) identified the Cordillera del Cóndor as one of the world's most irreplaceable sites, highlighting the need to further protect it and prevent the extinction of species that are restricted to the area (Alliance for Zero Extinction 2010). 

It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival. Ex situ breeding efforts were initiated in 2008 at Aquazoo Düsseldorf and Gerhart-Hauptmann school in Gelsenkirchen, Germany and have successfully bred this species in captivity (Barsch 2011, Barsch and Janzen 2014). 

Conservation Needed
The controlling of fires from slash-and-burn activities are needed. Compliance and enforcement of harvesting and trade of this species is recommended. 

Research Needed
Further research into the distribution, population status, natural history and threats of the species is necessary, and there is a need to monitor its presence in international trade.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on Mindanao in the Philippines, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 28,715 km<sup>2</sup>, it probably occurs at roughly 10 locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This diurnal species inhabits equatorial dry forest and montane forest, near streams, and can be found in some modified habitats, including cacao and banana farms, as well as, areas near roadways (R. Tarvin pers. comm. July 2018). The female lays a clutch of 15–40 eggs in the leaf-litter within a male's territory (Halliday 2016). The male guards the eggs and keeps them moist for up to two weeks, and upon hatching, he transports the larvae to a pool in a stream, where they complete their development. Some males have been observed carrying up to 14 tadpoles (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018). It has a generalist diet comprised of ants, beetles, mites, spiders, springtails and pseudoscorpions (Silverstone 1976, Zimmermann 1989, Walls 1994, Darst et al. 2005). In captivity, individuals reach sexual maturity eleven months after metamorphosis, although there are reports of males reaching adulthood at six months after metamorphosis, when they begin to call. In captivity, it has been reported that individuals have lived up to four years.
threats: Deforestation for intensive agriculture and livestock is considered a major threat throughout its range. The loss of shady areas (i.e. clear cutting land for cattle) has a huge impact on restricting the species' habitat (R. Tarvin pers. comm. July 2018). Pollution from agrochemicals used for fertilizer is also a major threat to this species in Peru (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018). It is also collected for medicinal use, and possibly for the pet trade in Ecuador, although not currently in sufficient numbers to be a threat.
population: In southern Ecuador, this is an abundant species. During 2008–2009, visual encounter surveys in Azuay and El Oro Provinces, Ecuador detected 293 individuals within 57 quadrants of 1,000 m<sup>2</sup> (Webster Bernal 2010). In 2010, 221 individuals were observed within 64 visual transects covering a total area of 6,400 m<sup>2</sup> in El Caucho Biological Station, inside Tumbes National Reserve, Peru (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in southwestern Ecuador (El Oro, Azuay and Loja Provinces) and northwestern Peru (Piura and Tumbes Regions), west of the Andes, at 150–1,770 m asl. The record from Ancash, Peru is doubtful (E. Lehr pers. comm.) and therefore not reflected in the species' range map. It is likely to occur a little more widely than current records suggest. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 28,715 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: In the 1970s–1980s, this species was highly harvested for pharmaceutical research and analyzing biological activity of alkaloids in the frogs' skin, however this has decreased due to restrictions under CITES, permitting requirements at the national level, and the development of a synthetic derivative (Angerer 2015). In Ecuador, the secretions of this species may be used by indigenous communities as a source of dart poison though this has not been confirmed (Angerer 2011). This species has been observed at pet shows in the United Kingdom and Germany (Arena et al. 2012). Between 2000–2007, nine individuals were confiscated from markets, pet stores, and fairs throughout three provinces in Ecuador: Pichincha, Guayas and Azuay (Siavichay Pesántez and Alvarado Montesdeoca 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Reserva Biológica Buenaventura and Bosque Petrificado de Puyango in Ecuador, but it is not known from any protected areas in Peru. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is listed as Least Concern in Ecuador. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. The impact of collection for medicinal use and commercial trade in wild specimens should be monitored.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 17,938 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in less than 10 threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera Oriental.
habitat: This diurnal species prefers to live alongside small streams and creeks in lowland and montane tropical moist forest. It has also commonly been observed up to 300 m from streams (Brown and Twomey 2009) and can be found in both primary and slightly degraded habitats. At lower elevations, these frogs occur exclusively in association with cool, humid microhabitats nearby small streams at the base of mountains, whereas at higher elevations, they appear to be less habitat-specific and can be found throughout the forest (Twomey et al. 2008). Eggs are deposited on the ground in leaf litter, where they are attended to by males. Upon hatching, the male transports the larvae to lentic water bodies, such as roadside ditches, forest pools, or pools formed alongside small streams (Twomey et al. 2008). Tadpoles are typically deposited in small ditches or backwaters near streams, but rarely in flowing water (Twomey and Brown 2016).
threats: There is significant habitat loss within its range due to agricultural activities (mostly coffee plantations). Since 2008, there has been an increase in commercial large scale agriculture activities (palm plantations) throughout San Martín (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Much of the suitable habitat has been converted to cattle pastures (Twomey and Brown 2016).
population: The population status of this species in the wild varies between morphs. Some, such as the nominal morph, can be found in great numbers over 600 m asl, while the chrome green morph is has very little habitat remaining and is less common (Twomey and Brown 2016). During 2004-2007 surveys, more than 100 individuals were observed over ca 300 person-days (von May et al. 2008). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in the Amazon drainage of Peru, from the eastern foothills of the Andes east to the Río Huallaga, in Huánuco and San Martín Regions. It is most common between 500–1,100 m asl, though individuals have been found as high as 1,262 m asl and as low as 180 m asl. It is likely restricted to mountain ranges throughout the Cordillera Oriental near Tarapoto and central Huallaga river valley (Twomey and Brown 2016). It occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17,938 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: Smuggling has not been a significant problem with this species, due to a legal and sustainable captive breeding program by Understory Enterprises (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). However specific morphs, such as chrome green, would not be able to withstand even low levels of collection and would be in grave risk of extirpation if smuggling were to begin (Twomey and Brown 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul, Parque Nacional Cordillera Esclera and possibly the Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable given that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,356 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in seven threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its available habitat in northern Peru, as well as a suspected decline in the number of mature individuals due to illegal collection and export for the pet trade.
habitat: This species inhabits old growth, secondary and riparian lowland tropical forest. It is active near small streams, and tadpoles appear to be deposited in slow-moving streams (Twomey and Brown 2009). It appears to be restricted to habitats in the vicinity of small and slow-moving streams (Twomey and Brown 2009).
threats: Its lowland rainforest habitat is being affected by encroaching agriculture due to farmers clearing new farms (Twomey and Brown 2009). Since 2008, there has been an increase in commercial large scale agriculture activities (palm plantations) throughout San Martín (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It is also being illegally harvested and exported.
population: The species can be regionally abundant throughout the Huallaga Canyon with dozens of individuals being observed in a few hours, whereas in other parts of its distribution, in the central range in Cordillera Escellera (such as the Cainarachi valley), it can be quite rare with only a few individuals found after several days of extensive surveying (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Approximately 30 individuals were found over 20 person/day surveys between July 2005 and June 2007 (von May et al. 2008). An additional single individual was recorded in 2005 (D. Edmond pers. comm. in Amphibian Red List Assessment Forum April 2013). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing. No further population information is available for this species, although a decline in the number of mature individuals is suspected in view of illegal export, and therefore harvesting activities.
range: This species is known from six geographical localities in eastern San Martín Region and one locality in southwestern Loreto Region, Peru. Each geographical locality is herein considered an individual threat-defined location. This frog is found between 200-800 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,356 km<sup>2</sup>, although it is possible that this species may be more widespread than currently understood as there are still areas of these two regions that have not yet been surveyed. However, this frog does appear to be restricted to areas adjacent to small and slow streams (Twomey and Brown 2009), which are unevenly distributed throughout the two regions.
useTrade: This species is subject to illegal export, which indicates that it is also being harvested illegally.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs within Cordillera Azul National Park and Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
Land protection in the areas where this species occurs is needed, as is improved enforcement for preventing its illegal collection and export on both a national and international level.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into its distribution, population status, ecology, and threats, including harvest levels. Additionally, targeted surveys are required to determine if this species occurs more widely within Cordillera Azul National Park.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 753 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat along the eastern foothills of the Cordillera Azul.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical moist lowland rainforest. Individuals have been observed in dense primary and secondary forest associated with the foothills of mountains (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It is active during the day among the leaf litter. It is not known if it can occur in degraded habitat, although it is possible that it occurs at forest edges. Eggs are deposited on the forest floor and the larvae are then transported to puddles and streams by the males.
threats: Within its current known range, this species is threatened by habitat loss due to smallholder subsistence farming (including cattle), smallholder ornamental plant farming, and logging for timber and subsistence use. This species is also found in the international pet trade, but smuggling pressure is not considered to be high (Twomey and Brown 2017).
population: This species is locally abundant at known sites. In December 2016 nearby Aguaytia, over the period of six hours, six individuals were caught and ca 50 individuals calling were recorded over a transect of 1 km (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). General surveys for dendrobatid frogs in August 2007 (24 person-hours) and December 2016 (16 person-hours), about 15-20 km east of its known distribution, failed to record this species (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the eastern foothills of the Cordillera Azul, Ucayali Region, Peru, from 300–550 m asl. The range of this species appears to be highly restricted, as surveys within accessible areas surrounding its known distribution have not recorded any individuals (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). The species may inhabit other areas nearby, but this is difficult to verify as the areas are inaccessible (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs in two threat-defined locations and its EOO is 753 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: It has been observed in the pet trade, though it is not likely to be under high smuggling pressure (Twomey and Brown 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul (Tasker and Twomey 2015). It is listed as Data Deficient (DD) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
The taxonomy of this species requires further work, as many specimens are misidentified in museum collections (K-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). More information is also needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further studies are needed into the possible impact of the pet trade on this species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,874 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations (based on the currently known disjunct geographical localities and trade pressure exerted in Cordillera Azul) and there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to illegal harvesting, as well as a decline in the extent and quality of habitat.
habitat: This diurnal, terrestrial frog is a montane tropical rainforest specialist. While mainly found in under logs and large piles of leaves, frogs have also been found in open areas in the forest and in cleared areas near a tea plantation (Myers and Daly 1979), and other agricultural areas. It probably breeds throughout the year (Halliday 2016). Eggs are deposited in leaf-litter and guarded by males until they hatch, then he carries the larvae to streams or puddles for their development. The male holotype was found in November guarding a clutch of 30 eggs in a dry leaf (Myers and Daly 1979).
threats: Much of this frog's habitat has been cleared for agricultural activities, including cattle pastures and tea farms (Twomey and Brown 2009). In the past the habitat area where it occurs had been somewhat protected by the presence of terrorist groups (excepting drug crops used in drug trafficking); more recently, coca eradication campaigns and alternative development programs have diminished the presence of drug crops in the region (CIMA 2012). It is also under threat due to heavy smuggling activity for the pet trade for the past 15 years (von May et al. 2008).
population: Current subpopulations appear to be a small fraction of what they once were (Twomey and Brown 2009). In 1979, 26 individuals were recorded with a survey effort of 6 person/days, while in 2006 only eight individuals were observed in 15 person/days (von May et al. 2008). In December 2016 near the town of Divisora, surveys of 9 person-hours encountered one adult, one sub-adult and several dozen tadpoles in water pools on a trail (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). This survey was conducted during heavy rainfall so no adult frogs would have been calling, therefore more individuals could have been present but could not be detected (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Reports from locals state that this species is abundant in both pristine forested and agricultural areas (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Surveys between 2004-2010 at the release site for the introduced subpopulation near Tarapoto have never recorded any individuals of this species (survey effort: varied between two to three people with two to five hours searching each - J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Due to harvesting of this species for the pet trade, the population is thought to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to the Cordillera Azul on the eastern side of the Andes, Huánuco Region, Peru. It can be found at elevations ranging from 1,200–1,800 m asl. It has also been introduced to the Tarapoto area of San Martin Region, although very little is known about this biological population<span lang="EN-CA">. It is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations (based on the currently known disjunct geographical areas and trade pressure exerted in Cordillera Azul). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,874 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This poison frog is a target for illegal collection and is consistently smuggled for the international pet trade, via Pucallpa in the Ucayali Region (von May et al. 2008, Aguilar et al. 2010, Halliday 2016). In the late 1980s, over 60 individuals were released at km 20 on the Tarapoto-Yurimaguas road by authorities in charge of animal confiscations (R. Schulte pers. comm. In: Brown et al. 2008). This species continues to be collected for illegal exportation; one farmer from the mountains east of Tingo Maria stated that he continues to sell “40–60 adults a month” and has done so for the last several years (pers. comm. In: Brown et al. 2011). Despite this, relatively few individuals have been found on the black markets, suggesting that most of them probably died during transit through the cities of Iquitos and Pucallpa (Brown et al. 2011). Conversations with locals in December 2016 indicate that the collection and selling by the farmer continues (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is found in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Conservation of other areas where this species occurs is required, as is enforcement on smuggling activities. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed into the distribution, population status, ecology and threats affecting this species, especially with regards to the impact of illegal trade. There is a need for population monitoring of the status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and harvesting.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and degree of tolerance to modified habitats.
habitat: This species inhabits the leaf-litter of lowland and premontane tropical rainforest. It can also be found on the forest edge species close to disturbed areas. Eggs are deposited on the ground and males carry the larvae to streams.
threats: There are no major threats affecting this species. It is widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to different human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is generally uncommon, but has a presumed large and stable population because of large area of suitable habitat.
range: This species is known from lower premontane Andean forest in the upper Río Madre de Dios watershed, and Río Candamo and Guacamayo, Peru (Cusco and Puno Regions). It has an altitudinal range of 300–600 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species occurs in the Bahuaja-Sonene National Park and Manu Biosphere Reserve. It is included in Appendix II of CITES.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species has been collected in lowland tropical rainforest. It appears to be most active around dusk, when males can be heard calling vigorously from the leaf litter (Twomey and Brown 2017). Tadpoles have been found in small pools formed in a nearly-dry creek bed and in small puddles throughout the forest floor (Twomey and Brown 2017).
threats: It is threatened by habitat loss due to agricultural activities taking place within its range. The type locality was converted to agricultural use, and there is also dense cattle ranching.
population: It is presumed to be very rare, and it is 30 years since it was last recorded. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from the type locality, Río Iscozacín (a tributary of the Río Palcazú, in the Pachitea drainage), Pasco Department, Peru, from 380–400 m asl. While it is not believed to be endemic to a specific area, surveys in nearby areas have not recorded this species (J. Icochea pers. comm).
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species was known to occur in the buffer zone of the Bosque de Protección San Matías-San Carlos. It is listed as Data Deficient (DD) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
A species conservation programme is urgently needed.

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to establish whether or not the species still occurs at the type locality or in any location outside the type locality. More information is also needed on its ecology, use and trade, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its distribution, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: This is a terrestrial species found above the tree line in grassy areas, bogs, and the fronds of terrestrial bromeliads. Eggs are carried in brood pouches and undergo direct development (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: The major threats to this species are unknown. The Cordillera de Colán is remote, which affords it some level of protection. If it occurs outside of Santuario Nacional Cordillera de Colán it might be impacted by regional agricultural activities, but this requires further investigation.
population: The population status is not known.
range: This species is known only from the type collection in the higher western slopes of the semi-isolated Cordillera Colán in the Huancabamba Depression in northern Peru, where it has been found at elevations between 2,970–3,330 m asl. It is difficult to determine whether or not it is endemic to the Huancabamba Depression. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 149 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species might occur in Santuario Nacional Cordillera de Colán, designated in 2009.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species has been recorded from cloud forest, montane dry forest, scrubby pasture and lightly disturbed areas. Individuals have been found by day in crevices between rotting logs and soil in scrubby pasture, and beneath stones in a pasture, and by night on branches of vegetation. The coossified head and short robust limbs, with little webbing between the toes, suggest that this species may be fossorial (Duellman 2015). This idea is corroborated by the limited ecological data; most specimens have been found on the ground or in crevices. The breeding habitat is not known, though the eggs are carried on the back of the female and undergo direct development.
threats: It might be impacted by regional agricultural activities, but this requires further investigation.
population: The population status of this species is not known. There have been no recent records.
range: This species is known only from east of Canchaque and in the surroundings of Huancabamba, on the western slope of the Huancabamba Depression (Piura Department), Peru, where it has been recorded from 1,740–2,130 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Addressing the lack of data is the first step towards ensuring the species' long-term persistence. Further research is needed into the distribution, population status, ecology, and threats of this little-known species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,348 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Tropical Andes of Ecuador and Peru.
habitat: This is an arboreal species in montane cloud forest. Individuals have been found perched in and around small streams with vegetation. It is probably dependent on forest habitat. At El Tambo, Peru, 13 brooding females were moving into a depression filling with water during a heavy rain (Duellman and Trueb 2015). These females contained 64–152 hatching eggs in Stages 31– 35; therefore this species produces free-living aquatic tadpoles that are released from the brood pouches to develop in ponds (Duellman and Venegas 2005, Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: There is some small-scale deforestation in the vicinity of the collection site that might represent a threat. There is likely to be broader-scale habitat loss across its range.
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. In Peru, several individuals were observed in Comunidad de Uyurpampa, Lamayeue Region during September 2012 (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. April 2017). Four individuals were collected during November 2013 in Cerro de Arcos, El Oro, Ecuador and this species was heard calling in La Enrramada during February 2014 (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2014). It is probably decreasing due to habitat loss.
range: This species is known from the type locality on the Pacific slopes of the Cordillera de Huancabamba (Piura Region) and Comunidad de Uyurpampa (Lambayeque Region) in Peru, and from Chillacocha, 17.6 km southeast of Chillacocha, and 38.5 km north of Chillacocha, El Oro Province, Ecuador. Due to the proximity of the El Oro localities with the provincial boundary between El Oro, Loja and Azuay, it is possible that this species occurs in those provinces as well (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2014). It occurs at elevations ranging from 1,020–3,665 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,348 km2, which represents 10 or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is present in primary, secondary, and disturbed grasslands and shrublands in the valleys of the central Andes. Taxa assigned to this species also commonly occur in most types of regional agricultural areas and flooded areas. It is sensitive to a degree of pesticide use (J. Aparicio pers. comm. via L. Zegada, September 2019). Breeding takes place in stagnant and slow flowing waters.
threats: The major threats to the habitat of this species is habitat destruction and degradation caused by grassland burning and agricultural activities. The species might be in small-scale international trade, although there is often confusion between this species and G. peruana or G. riobambae. The effects of climate change (e.g., droughts and decreasing precipitation and humidity) are also considered to pose a serious threat to the species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Specimens from 1987, 2000, and 2001 tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
population: It used to be locally common throughout its range. However, localised declines have been observed in the early 2000s in drier parts its range in Bolivia (J. Aparicio pers. comm. September 2019). The species is still found (e.g., every other year) in humid parts of its range, such Carrasco and Tunari National Parks (R. Aguayo, O. Quinteros and T. Camacho Badani pers. comm. September 2019). The population is presumed to be relatively stable at present.
range: This species occurs in the high Andes, from central Peru to southern Bolivia, between 2,500–4,360 m asl. It is possible that the species is also present in Argentina.
useTrade: This species may be in the small-scale international pet trade, however it can be confused for other species in the genus and this requires verification.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, it might occur in Huayllay and Ampay National Sanctuaries, Junin National Reserve, Chacamarca Historical Sanctuary and Apurimac Reserved Zone. In Bolivia, it occurs in Carrasco National Park, Tunari National Park, Cotapata National Park, and Pilon Lajas National Park.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the protected areas and the elimination of the use of fire is urgently needed to halt the loss of natural savannas and cerrado vegetation, working with local cattle ranchers to reach conservation agreements (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).

Research Needed
Taxonomic research into this species is needed to delineate the complex.

rationale: Listed as Endangered in light of its restricted range – estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 709 km<sup>2</sup> – and ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, which divides its population into three or fewer threat-defined locations.
habitat: It is known to use bromeliads as microhabitats (Duellman and Fritts 1972); all specimens have been found in small bromeliads growing on cliffs. The eggs undergo direct development in the females pouch (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: It is threatened by agricultural practices that clear land by burning for crop planting and livestock grazing. In addition, it occurs near archaeological sites that receive many visitors and this may put pressure on the species' habitat at those sites.
population: It appears to be rare. Surveys at the type locality recorded the species as recently as 2014 (L. Mamani Ccasa pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species' type locality is near Ollantaytambo in the Urubamba Valley, Cusco Region, Peru, from 2,700–2,800 m asl. There is a great deal of taxonomic uncertainty around the identity of some specimens assigned to this species. Specimens assigned to this species from the buffer zone of Manu National Park are in fact Gastrotheca nebulanastes (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017) and only the subpopulation situated in the vicinity of the type locality is treated in this assessment, which results in an EOO of 709 km2. All individuals are considered to occur at one to three locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species has not been reported from any protected areas, but it might occur in the Machu Picchu Historic Sanctuary. The species is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
This species would benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and taxonomy.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 279 km2, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Apurimac River valley in Peru.
habitat: This is a terrestrial species found in moist puna grasslands and montane forests. Specimens can be found under rocks and fallen logs, and within bushes (Duellman 1987, Vargas 2015). While no brooding females with developing embryos exist in collections, the size and number of ovarian eggs are indicative of direct development (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
