threats: The area of the type locality (7 km N of Mahuayara), on the main road to the Apurimac valley via Tambo, may be vulnerable to seasonal fires (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). At the other known locality, the Peru LNG pipeline and the Camisea natural gas pipeline pass through the species' habitat and there have been gas spills at different points along the pipelines which could further threaten the species (V. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018) and seasonal fires may also affect the area (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). Furthermore, the forested slopes of the Apurimac valley where this species occurs are threatened by intensive agricultural modification for coca, coffee plantations, and cattle (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018), and the construction of roads (V. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018).
population: In 2008, attempts to find this species in vicinity of the type locality were unsuccessful; however the search was short (ca 2 hours) and during the day (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). Surveys along the PERU LNG gas pipeline in 2012 lead to the discovery to the second known subpopulation of this species (Vargas 2015).
range: This species occurs on the eastern slopes of the Andes of Ayacucho, in the Apurimac River valley, in Peru. It was formerly only known from Abra Tapuna, near Tambo (Duellman 1987), however it is now also known from Chiquintirca, near Anco, on the crest of the Cordillera Oriental (Vargas 2015). It has been found at elevations between 2,735–4,600 m asl (Duellman 1987, Vargas 2015). The coordinates provided in the original description for the type locality are in error, and place this locality in an undisturbed area about 100 km east of the type locality, across the Apurimac Valley (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). The full extent of its distribution is not well known, but it might occur more widely (V. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known range is 279 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. 

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into the distribution, population status and trends, and natural history of this little-known species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 310 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: Its habitat is the cloud forest on the eastern slopes of the Andes. The eggs are presumably carried on the back of the female, but it is not known whether or not breeding is by direct development or larval development.
threats: There is ongoing degradation and destruction of the species' habitat by small-scale agriculture (including ricoto, which is intensively farmed at the lower elevations of the species' range), cattle grazing, and logging (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is common at the Chiquintirca site (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from the type locality of "Yuraccyacu on the Tambo-Valle del Apurimac trail", at 2,620 m asl (Duellman and Trueb 1988) and from Chiquintirca, down to 1,800 m asl (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017), both in Ayacucho Region, Peru. Its range has an EOO of 310 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur at two-threat defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
This species would benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
Further research is needed to improve understanding of the species' population size, distribution and trends.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,994 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat along the Cordillera Azul in Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits humid subpáramo and humid montane forest; it is sometimes present near villages and can be found in pastures with trees. Known specimens have been collected by local residences who claimed that the frogs were found in trees (Duellman et al. 2001). Indirect evidence indicates this species produces tadpoles which complete their development in ponds, but tadpoles in this species are unknown (Duellmann and Trueb 2015). A female was found with 82 eggs in her brood pouch, each with a diameter of about 5.3 mm; the number and size of the eggs indicates that eggs of this species hatch as tadpoles (Duellman et al. 2001).
threats: The Cordillera de Carpish is not protected under Peruvian law, making it susceptible to deforestation for agriculture and timber extraction. The main threat is habitat destruction as a result of agricultural activities, primarily from potato farming and livestock ranching, and firewood collection.
population: It is uncommon. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from a few sites on the southern end of the Cordillera Azul, east of the Río Huallaga Valley. It has been recorded from the Departments of Huánuco and Pasco, and it is probable that it could occur in Junín given the record so close to the border (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). The range is not completely known and it may occur more widely than current records suggest. It is known from elevations of 2,500–3,090 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,994 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur in five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Some form of habitat protection is needed to ensure the maintenance of some cloud forest within the range of this species. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Survey work is required to determine whether this species might occur between known sites.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This is an arboreal frog found in montane humid and Yungas forest. It has so far only been found at localities with mature undisturbed primary forests. At night adults have been found on branches of bushes and trees in cloud forest; juveniles have been found on leaves and stems of low vegetation. During the day, one adult was found in an arboreal bromeliad and another individual was under a log. At Cordillera de Cutucú, Ecuador, one specimen was found in a flat area on a ridge with cloud forest that had a relatively open canopy and many tree falls (Duellman and Lynch 1988). Eggs are carried in a pouch on the females back and undergo direct development into froglets (Duellman and Chavéz 2010). The number of eggs found in brood pouches of females ranges from 30–69 eggs (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: It is threatened in parts of its range due to habitat loss caused by agriculture, human settlements and logging.
population: This is generally a rare species throughout its range (De la Riva and Reichle 2014), although it is locally common within the Parque Nacional y Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Cotapata, La Paz, Ecuador (Cortez-Fernandez 2006). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species' geographic range is on the eastern slopes of the Andes from Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia; it also occurs in three isolated mountain ranges to the east of the main Andean cordillera: Volcán Sumaco and Cordillera de Cutucú in Ecuador, and Serranía de Sira in Peru (Duellman and Trueb 2015). It is possible that this species extends into adjacent Colombia. Its elevational range is 700–2,775 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Reserva Ecológica Antisana, Reserva Biológa San Francisco, Parque Nacional Llanganates, and Parque Nacional Sangay. It is known from three protected areas in Bolivia (Pilon Lajas and Carrasco National Parks, Parque Nacional y Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Cotapata) and Parque Nacional del Manu in Peru. It is considered to be Near Threatened in Ecuador (Ron et al. 2011). The pilot amphibian conservation centre at the Museum of Zoology of the Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador (PUCE) currently maintains this species (Coloma et al. 2010). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: While the majority of the observed population declines occurred in the mid-2000s (more than 10 years ago), during which the species had apparently disappeared from or became very rare at higher elevation sites, it is still present and possibly even showing signs of recovery in several lower elevation sites. However, declines of close to 30% are thought to have occurred over the last ten years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation and chytridiomycosis, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion A. Therefore, this species is listed as Near Threatened. Monitoring of the population and increased survey effort is recommended to detect and document any additional declines.
habitat: The habitat is primary and secondary montane and cloud forests on the eastern slopes of the Andes. It is always associated with fast-flowing streams and is highly adapted for breeding in these streams. It is not present in modified habitats.
threats:
Deforestation through small-holder farming and mining, as well as, water pollution from mining are major threats. 

Chytridiomycosis is the probable cause of severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Parque Nacional Manu (Catenazzi et al. 2011), and it is the expected cause of the drastic declines and near-disappearance of the species throughout its range. In 2009, the chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), was detected in an individual of this species at Kosñipata Valley, Parque Nacional Manu (Catenazzi et al. 2011) and Cortéz (2009) found dead specimens in Valle de Zongo, Bolivia perhaps indicating infection with the chytrid fungus. Specimens from La Paz, Cochabamba and Santa Cruz tested positive for Bd in 1998, 1999, 2001, 2002 and 2004 (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017).
population:
Surveys in Parque Nacional Manu, Peru in 1999 found the species to be common and easily located. However, the species has only been seen in the buffer zone of the national park in 2009, despite surveys taking place within the park in 2008–2009 and 2012–2016, indicating that the population there has crashed; it has also become very rare at all other known sites in Peru (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. 2017). In 2016, two juveniles were recorded in Santo Domingo in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Bahuaja-Sonene, Puno (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. 2019).

This species experienced a population decline in Bolivia in the mid-2000s. In 2006-2007, declines and dead individuals were reported in Valle de Zongo, La Paz (Cortez 2009). Efforts to find this species in Chaco (Sud Yungas Province, La Paz Department) in 2016 were unsuccessful despite it being recorded there in 1999 (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2020), and searches in several other historical sites of Yungas de La Paz, such as Cerro Uchumachi and Valle de Zongo, have also failed to find this frog in recent years (M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020). 

Recently, some recovery of the species has been observed at lower elevations (1,000–1,900 m asl), but it has remained absent from the highest elevations (2,000–2,600) of its range (M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020). It is still present in some lower elevation sites in the Yungas of La Paz, albeit in much lower abundances compared to historically (I. De la Riva and M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020). In 2016, a tadpole was observed near Coroico, which was the first observation of this species in the area since the declines of the mid-2000s, and surveys in 2019 found this species to be present, but scarce, in the Suapi region and around Caranavi (M. Pacheco pers. comm. 2020). Regular monitoring since 2009 in Parque Nacional Carrasco, Cochabamba suggests that population recovery started in 2011–2012 and as of 2019 the species now appears to occur in similar abundances as pre-decline levels (R. Aguayo, T. Camacho Badani and O. Quinteros pers. comm. 2019), and new subpopulations have been discovered within 5 km of Chaquisacha, between 1,300 and 1,900 m asl (O. Quinteros pers. comm. 2020). However, it is reasonable to suspect a population decline of 20-25% in the last 10 years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation and chytridiomycosis.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Andes of Peru (Cusco and Puno Regions) and Bolivia (La Paz, Cochabamba and Santa Cruz Departments). It has an elevational range of 1,000–2,600 m asl. There is a potential record from Chuquisaca, Bolivia that requires clarification (S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, this species formerly occurred within Parque Nacional Manu, but it has not been recorded there in many years. It has been recorded in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Bahuaja-Sonene and it may occur in Zona de Reserva Apurímac and Zona de Reserva Amarakaeri; but this requires confirmation. It is present in several Bolivian protected areas, including Parques Nacionales Carrasco, Isiboro Sécure, Pilón Lajas, Cotapata and Amboró. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Bolivia (Aguayo et al. 2009).

Research Needed
Population surveys are urgently needed to search for additional subpopulations in historical localities and other suitable habitat, and to track the impact of chytridiomycosis on the species. Taxonomic work is crucial in order to determine whether this form is a complex of more than one species and implications this might have for conservation decisions.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the currently known distribution is limited, the species is common, it adapts to disturbed habitats, and there are no current threats.
habitat: It lives in montane forests. It has also been found in modified environments, such as in pastures, near roads and close to canals. Frogs have been found at early evening and night in vegetation next to small streams and artificial ponds (Lehr and von May 2004). The tadpole was described by Lehr et al. (2011).
threats: The surroundings of Huancabamba are deforested due to extensive agriculture and cattle breeding (Lehr and von May 2004), however it is unknown whether activities are affecting this adaptable species. In 2007, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was detected in specimens collected from Llamaquizú and Chacos, Pasco Region (Kosch et al. 2012), although whether this constitutes a threat to the population is unclear.
population: It was described based on five specimens in 1912. It had not been recorded since the species description until eight individuals were collected at Huacabamba in 2003 (Lehr and von May 2004). The species was detected during surveys in the vicinity of the type locality in 2004 (Lehr et al. 2011). It is considered common with a stable population (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality of Huancabamba, in Pasco Region, Peru (Boulenger 1912, Lehr and von May 2004). It occurs from 1,780–1,900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas, but may occur in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park. In 2003, frogs were found in the pond of the old Hacienda Yanachaga which today is called PROSOYA and is involved in a social and ecological development project (Lehr and von May 2004). There are reforested areas near PROSOYA, and primary forests within the Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, ca 10 km east of Huancabamba (Lehr and von May 2004).

Research Needed
Further research is needed into this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 117 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and although it is not currently affected by habitat loss at known sites, continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat is inferred because the species possibly occurs more widely in areas where habitat loss does pose a serious threat.
habitat: This species inhabits low cloud forest. Adults have been found at night on vegetation by a pond (Duellman and Toft 1979). Reproduction occurs by larval development in temporary ponds.
threats: Illegal logging, coca plantations, cattle farming, subsistence farming, and illegal mining have been documented as taking place in the Sira region and there are concerns that these are also occurring within the boundaries of the Reserva Comunal El Sira. The two sites that the species is known from are not currently affected by threats because they are remote, the hill gradient is steep, and they are not surrounded by forest that would be of interest for logging. However, since the species is thought to occur more widely, these threats could affect it at other sites.
population: The species was recorded during surveys in 2013 and 2014 at both known sites; an average of seven individuals in six person-hours were recorded, but the species is not considered to be common (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known only from two sites the western slope of the Serrania de Sira, Huánuco Department, Peru, at 1,280–1,500 m asl. It is unlikely to occur below 1,200 m asl and surveys in wetlands around 500 m asl have not recorded this species (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 117 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in a single threat-defined location. It possibly occurs in the Cordillera Azul, but this requires further investigation because this area is separated from Sira by a lowland area (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in the Reserva Comunal El Sira.

Conservation Needed
Continued maintenance of this, and other remaining habitat in the Serrania de Sira, is necessary.

Research Needed
Further survey work is necessary to determine the precise limits of the distribution of this species, its population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This is a cloud forest species about which very little is known. Reproduction is by larval development, whereby the eggs are laid in folded leaves overhanging water and, upon hatching, the larvae drop off into water below to continue development (Cannatella 1982). Tadpoles have been found in a shallow (0.3 m) roadside ditch over which vegetation was hanging (Cannatella 1982).
threats: It might be threatened by the agricultural activity (such as cultivation of coffee) that is occurring in area surrounding the type locality.
population: Its population status is not known.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality, near Balzapata, and upper Río Chiriaco, in Amazonas Department, Peru. It has an elevational range of 1,850–1,910 m asl. It is not known if this species is restricted in range, or whether or not it is likely to be found more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It might occur in the Zona Reservada Cordillera de Colán and the Área de Conservación Privada Hierba Buena–Allpayacu (designated in 2011), but this requires confirmation.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits cloud forest and lower montane rainforest. It also occurs in secondary forest, open areas and even pasture and agricultural zones (Duellman and Wiens 1993, Lehr et al. 2010, Chávez et al. 2013). Individuals have been found on riparian vegetation, where they use bushes and trees as shelter and are usually, found on leaves 1–2 m above the ground (Chávez et al. 2013). It reproduces by larval development and breeds in streams, ponds, swamps, roadside ditches and open areas (Duellman and Wiens 1993, Lehr et al. 2010, Chávez et al. 2013).
threats: Specific threats to this species are not known, but there is general agricultural development throughout much of the region that is likely to be affecting it.
population: It can be abundant in some areas of northern Peru (Chávez et al. 2013). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the eastern slopes of the Peruvian Andes in the Regions of Amazonas, San Martín, and Pasco, from 1,600–2,400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It might occur in Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo, Zona Reservada Biabo Cordillera Azul, Parque Nacional de Yanachaga-Chemillén, Bosque de Sho'llet Área de Conservación, Reserva Comunal Yanesha, and Bosque de Protección San Matías-San Carlos (although this requires confirmation). It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.  

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 550 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes and a continuing decline in mature individuals inferred from the harvesting of adults from local consumption.
habitat: This is a semi-aquatic riparian species, found in small tributaries of Lake Junín, but not in the lake itself. Reproduction takes place by larval development.
threats: The species is generally threatened by the loss of habitat loss through the extraction of resources; agricultural, industrial, and residential pollution; eutrophication; over-grazing by livestock; climate change; and the introduction of trout into streams and rivers in the high Andes (Watson et al. 2017a,b). The cleaning of canals, which involves the periodic removal of submerged aquatic vegetation and sediment, represents an additional threat to the species and its habitat (A. Watson pers. comm. February 2018). This species is likely to be susceptible to overexploitation, but the degree to which this threatens the population is unknown. It might also be very susceptible to emerging infectious diseases (chytridiomycosis and ranavirus), as with other Telmatobius populations living at high elevations, although these diseases have yet to be reported from this species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: In the last assessment it was reported to be abundant where it occurs, however more recent evidence suggests the species has become much less common. Surveys in November 2015 recorded five adult individuals in the vicinity of Ondores and another two adults in the the hills to the southwest of Lake Junín during the cleaning of canals (K. Wilber pers. comm. February 2018). In 2014, one metamorph was recorded during surveys in a tributary of Lake Junín, south of Ondores (S. Behmke pers. comm. April 2016); surveys at the same site during 2015 and 2016 recorded more than 100 tadpoles which were thought to belong to this species, eight metamorphs and two adults (A. Fitzgerald and A. Watson pers. comm. February 2018). In August 2017, surveys during a BioBlitz event registered only one tadpole (L. Castillo Roque pers. comm. February 2018). The population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, and there is continuing decline in mature individuals inferred from the harvesting of adults from local consumption.
range: This species is historically known from small tributaries of Lake Junín, and highlands of Junín and Pasco Regions in the Andes of central Peru. At present, it is likely restricted to the western sector of Lake Junín in the vicinities of Paccha and Ondores (L. Castillo Roque pers. comm. February 2018). It occurs at altitudes of 4,000–4,600 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 550 km<sup>2</sup>,<sup> </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: This species is harvested for local consumption (L. Castillo Roque pers. comm. February 2018). There is no apparent evidence of this species being sold in local markets at present, however this remains a possibility as other aquatic species from this genus are known to be harvested and often sold at local markets (Lehr 2005, A. Fitzgerald. pers. comm. February 2018).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Reserva Nacional de Junin. An in situ frog monitoring and conservation education program called the “High-Andean Frog Conservation through Capacity-Building Program” funded by USAID Small Project Assistance grants was in place from 2014–2016 (S. Behmke pers. comm. April 2016). Since then, conservation efforts have been initiated by a local NGO, Grupo RANA (Respuestas y Acciones para la Naturaleza y sus Amenazas; L. Castillo Roque and O.J. Damian Baldeón pers. comm. February 2018). In October 2016, a workshop was held in Junín Municipality to establish a conservation strategy for the frogs of Junín (Telmatobius brachydactylus and T. macrostomus), and a conservation action plan was developed (Watson et al. 2016, A. Watson pers. comm. February 2018). It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Continued management within Reserva Nacional de Junin is necessary to mitigate the effects of threats to the habitat where this species occurs. Other important recommendations for the conservation of this species include: (1) identifying and engaging with stakeholders who have interest in raising public awareness on the conservation status of this amphibian; (2) better enforcement of the legislation prohibiting the harvesting, consumption, and trafficking of this species throughout its native range; and (3) promoting in-situ research (Watson et al. 2017b).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Continued long-term monitoring is needed to inform appropriate conservation management of this threatened, high-elevation, endemic species (Watson et al. 2017b). Further studies should monitor trends in harvest levels. There is a need for close monitoring of the status of this species given the potential threat of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because the number of mature individuals is estimated to be less than 10,000 individuals, with each subpopulation having less than 1,000 individuals, and there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals in each subpopulation due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its coastal dry forest habitat.
habitat:
These nocturnal frogs mainly inhabit Pacific coastal dry scrub, which is usually fairly open with a few trees, but remains green for about half the year. Other specimens have been collected in an open and sandy desert, with scattered, low, desert vegetation, and trees that are absent except in or near temporary streambeds (Peters 1967). Although it can inhabit altered areas, like pastures and roadsides, it relies on nearby forest and is absent from completely deforested areas (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016). 

This species is active only during the rainy season (January–May), when individuals spend the days buried in the ground, and emerge during humid nights to feed and reproduce (Székely et al. 2018a,b). All breeding activity being concentrated in a few hours each year (Székely et al. 2018a). For the rest of the year, the frogs remain buried in the ground in a dormant state, covered in a cocoon of dead skin layers that diminishes water loss. During the breeding season, individuals have been observed in and near to temporary ponds along a trail within forest, while subadults have been observed in a disturbed area with few trees and furrowed soil (Ortiz et al. 2013). The Pacific Horned Frog has a low age at maturity and a short reproductive life-span (2–3 years; Székely et al. 2018a).
threats: The major threat is habitat loss due to agriculture (especially cattle ranching), logging, and human settlement, particularly in the coastal dry forests of Ecuador. Soil pollution, due to agrochemicals, also represents a threat. Specifically within Bosque Protector Cerro Prosperina de Guayaquil, human expansion (informal settlements on the slopes of the mountain), forest fires, agriculture and roadkill caused by vehicles on the trails are threats to this species (Amador and Brito 2013). The total area occupied by Arenillas Ecological Reserve has been decreasing continuously, from 17.08 ha in 1994 to 14.28 ha in 2001, and 10.27 ha in 2012 (Camacho and Ullauri 2013), caused by illegal logging and the ongoing expansion of shrimp farms and cultivated land within the protected area (Székely et al. 2018b). A persistent drought of 2–3 consecutive years with low recruitment would endanger the survival of the whole population because of this species' short reproductive lifespan (Székely et al. 2018b). This species is also threatened by harvesting from the wild for the pet trade.
population:
It is a rare species. The entire population currently occurs in fewer than eight different subpopulations, which are severely fragmented and rather isolated from each other (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016). The number of adult individuals is estimated to be less than 10,000 individuals, with each subpopulation having less than 1,000 individuals (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). The number of mature individuals is suspected to be declining in Ecuador as a result of the destruction and fragmentation of coastal dry forests.

Three specimens were collected at Punto Los Piqueros (Minabí, Ecuador) in August 2000 (Cisneros-Heredia 2006). Eight specimens were collected during March 1991 and January 1992 (Cisneros-Heredia 2006). Fourty-four adults and sub-adults were collected at Reserva Ecológica Militar Arenillas (REMA), El Oro province, Ecuador, between 31 January and 1 February 2007 (Ortiz et al. 2013). Three juveniles were collected in March 2011 at Destacamento Pintag Nuevo, REMA, (El Oro, Ecuador) in a marshy area and at the margin of a pond, close to human habitation (Ortiz et al. 2013). Four individuals were detected during surveys in Reserva Ecológia Comunal Loma Alta (Santa Elena, Ecuador) throughout 2005–2010 (Amador and Martínez 2011). In March 2012, one individual was observed within the Bosque Protector Cerro Prosperina de Guayaquil, Guayas, Ecuador (Amador and Brito 2013). A second individual, though deceased, was found during May 2012 surveys in the same area. Subsequent surveys during June 2012 were futile, likely because of the seasonal habits of this species (Amador and Brito 2013). Surveys carried out during the rainy season (January–May) in Arenillas Ecological Reserve observed 20 amplexed pairs served in 2015 over 38 fieldwork days and 29 pairs in 2016 over 65 fieldwork days (Székely et al. 2018a).

There is no information on its population status in Peru. The species has a small range in Peru, but the coastal dry forest habitat is fairly well protected in some areas, such as Tumbes National Reserve, which is relatively remote and inaccessible (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is found in xeric environments of the Pacific coast in northwestern Peru (Tumbes Region) and central and southwestern Ecuador (Guayas, Manabí, El Oro and Santa Elena Provinces) where it occurs at elevations from 0–130 m asl.
useTrade: This species has been marketed as a pet in North America and Europe (El Comercio 2010, Wikiri 2012).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Parque Nacional Machalilla (Cineros-Heredia 2006), Reserva Ecológica Comunal de Loma Alta (Amador and Martínez 2011), Reserva Ecológica Arenillas (Ortiz et al. 2013; Székely et al. 2018a,b), Bosque Protector Cerro Prosperina de Guayaquil (Amador and Brito 2013), and Reserva Ecológica Manglares Churute in Ecuador, as well as the Reserva Nacional de Tumbes in Peru. A captive management programme for the species began in 2007 at ‘Balsa de los Sapos’ at the Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador (PUCE) for conservation purposes (Coloma et al. 2010). Breeding of the frogs have been so successful that a backup colony was sent to Amaru Zoo in southern Ecuador (Azuay Province). Breeding and exporting of this species is conducted by the Centro Jambatu de Investigación y Conservación de Anfibios (Quito Ecuador) under a permit issued by the Ministerio de Ambiente del Ecuador, primarily to counteract illegal trafficking of frogs in the hobbyist industry, with all profits invested in conservation, research and education in Ecuador (Wikiri 2012). It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Improved management of the existing protected areas is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species. Captive-management programmes should focus on the viability of populations in captivity, through genetic, pathological and behavioural studies, to ensure an efficient reintroduction of this species into its former habitats in the future (Ortiz et al. 2013). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, natural history and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine the population status of this species in Peru.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, uncertain provenance, extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic status, extent of occurrence, population status, and ecological requirements.
habitat: This is a terrestrial leaf-litter species of lowland and premontane tropical moist forest. It probably breeds in a foam nest at the edge of temporary ponds.
threats: General localized threats to this species include habitat clearance for smallholder agricultural development, and for coffee and other cash crop plantations.
population: This cryptic species is known only from a few specimens. There is no information about its population status due, in part, to a lack of surveys.
range: This species has been reported from two localities in central Peru, including the type locality, Huancabamba in the region of Pasco (Boulenger 1912), and Monte  Alegre,  Río  Pachitéa (Dunn 1949, Duellman and Morales 1990). Dunn (1949) referred to the two Monte Alegre specimens as collected from the region of Ucayali, but subsequently, Duellman and Morales (1990) referred to the the same two specimens as being from region of Huánuco. The distribution of this species is poorly understood and this uncertainty is reflected in its range map. Further investigations might reveal that this cryptic species has a wider range. Its elevational range is 220–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas, but future surveys may reveal its presence in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park or El Sira Communal Reserve.

Research Needed
There is a need to resolve the taxonomic status of this species (Dunn 1949). Further survey work is needed to establish the limits of the species' range and clarify its population status.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements. Furthermore, there is uncertainty about its taxonomic identity.
habitat: Its habitat is humid montane forest. The single known (male) specimen was calling from a reed leaf 0.5 m above the ground at night. Although there is no ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown, although there is regional destruction and loss of habitats for livestock rearing and selective wood extraction in the area, and these threats could affect this species.
population: This species has been named from a single specimen.
range: This species is known only from the type locality at 2,770 m asl on the western slopes of the Cordilera de Huancabamba, Piura Region, Peru. The range for this species is incompletely known; it is suspected to be endemic to Huancabamba, but this cannot be confirmed (E. Wild pers. comm.). A record from extreme southwestern Ecuador should be evaluated to confirm its identity (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. July 2016).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Research Needed
Further taxonomic research is needed to determine the validity of this species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. July 2016). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 212 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
habitat: This species has been found in páramo alpine habitat with scattered trees, bushes and spiny bamboo (Duellman and Pramuk 2009), as well as, tropical montane forest (Rios Alva et al. 2017). It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: There is regional destruction and loss of páramo habitat through an increase in livestock grazing and agriculture. The El Tingo locality, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba, is nearby the town of La Morada, which has deforested areas as a result of livestock activity (Rios Alva et al. 2017). On some occasions, the lack of control over the burning of forests for agriculture causes the loss of larger forest areas (Rios Alva et al. 2017), which could put the species at risk.
population: The population status of this species is unknown, however the species is apparently rare. It was described from just a single specimen (Duellman and Praumuk 1999). A second individual of this species was recorded at El Tingo, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba in San Martín, during surveys between August and September 2016, with a survey effort of 127 person-hours (Rios Alva et al. 2017).
range: This species was formerly known only from the type locality, 24 km (by trail) SW Leimebamba, Provincia Chachapoyas in the northern part of the Cordillera Central, in Amazonas Region, Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). It has since been recorded at El Tingo, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba, in San Martín Region (Rios Alva et al. 2017). It has been recorded at 3,370 m asl and the extent of occurrence (EOO) if its expanded range is 121 km2, representing two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The type locality overlaps with the San Pedro de Chuquibamba Private Conservation Area, which was designated in 2015. It also occurs in the Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba in San Martín (Rios Alva et al. 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,043 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two to nine threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat on slopes of the northern part of the Cordillera Central in Peru.
habitat: The species inhabits humid lower montane forest. Individuals have been observed on elephant ear plants and on leaves of herbaceous plants. It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: Within its current known range it is threatened by loss of habitat through agricultural development (including creation of coffee plantations), selective wood extraction and human settlement.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as only a few individuals have been observed.
range: This species is known from elevations of l,080 and 1,200 m asl on the Amazonian slopes of the northern part of the Cordillera Central and at an elevation of 680 m asl on a pre-Andean ridge, all in the Region of San Martín, Peru (Duellman and Lehr 2009). A specimen from Huasmin in Cajamarca Region, collected at 2,550 m asl, is tentatively assigned to this species (Duellman and Lehr 2009), but probably requires confirmation. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 3,043 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals occur in two to nine threat-defined locations. Its current distribution is poorly understood, however it most likely has a much wider range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas, however it occurs very close to the boundary of the Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area and probably occurs within this area.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where the species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It can be found in tropical moist montane forest with a high diversity of herbaceous plants, shrubs and lianas, and is not known from modified habitats. The paratype was found in a grassy bog above the tree line (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). It is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown, although selective wood extraction might be taking place at the site from which this species is known (and would therefore constitute a threat to it), but this requires confirmation.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as only a few individuals have been observed.
range: This species is known only from two localities on the western slopes of the Cordillera de Colán in the Province of Bagua, Amazonas Region, northern Peru, at elevations of 2,963–3,330 m asl. The complete range of this species is not known, and it might be endemic to the Cordillera de Colán.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the Zona Reservada Cordillera de Colán.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: All adults were found on mossy boulders, and some juveniles were also discovered on herbaceous vegetation, at night in a deep ravine in lower humid montane forest. The type locality is a rocky gorge into which two streams plunge. The sides of the gorge are nearly vertical rock walls, and the floor of the gorge is littered with huge boulders, many of which support thin layers of moss. The second locality is a wooded, boulder-strewn with cacade stream on the road. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: Within its current known range it is threatened by loss of habitat through agricultural development, including the establishment of coffee plantations, selective wood extraction and human settlement. If this species is restricted to specific 'rocky gorge' type habitats, it might be particularly sensitive to habitat disturbance.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information on the population size and trends of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is little information on the population size and trends of this species.
range: This species is known from two streams at altitudes of 500 and 730 m asl on ridges extending from the Andes into the Amazonian Basin in San Martín Region, and from Río Pauya, Loreto Region, in northern Peru. It is likely to range much more widely throughout the Amazon Basin.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Área de Conservación Regional Cordillera Escalera and may also occur in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because its known distribution is relatively widespread, it can adapt to disturbed situations as long as  there is enough vegetation cover nearby, and it has a presumed large population. There is uncertainty regarding its taxonomic status and, therefore additional studies are required to  clarify this issue, especially regarding the Peruvian subpopulations.
habitat: This arboreal frog is present within humid primary and secondry tropical montane forests. It uses riparian vegetation and has been found in isolated trees in pasturelands near forest patches. Individuals occur on low vegetation at night and inside bromeliads and young leaves of Heliconia spp. by day (Duellman and Pramuk 1999, Chávez et al. 2013). Breeding takes place by direct development although the egg deposition site is not known.
threats: In the Cordillera del Condor, it is threatened by habitat loss due to farming and mining activities (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). In the northern part of its range it is locally threatened by logging activities (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
population: In Ecuador, this is generally a rare species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). In Peru, it can be locally abundant, for example at the southern border of Yanachaga Chemillen National Park (Pasco, Peru), where it appears to be moderately common and have healthy subpopulations in most of the habitats present, even in areas strongly impacted by human activity or buildings (J.C. Chaparro and J. Icochea pers. comm. in Chávez et al. 2013). At El Tingo, Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba (San Martín, Peru), this species was the most abundant species of amphibian during surveys between August and September 2016 (Rios Alva et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental and northern and western slopes of the Cordillera del Cóndor in the provinces of Zamora-Chinchipe and Morona-Santiago in southern Ecuador. It has also been recorded in Peru, from the northern part of the Cordillera Central and Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba (San Martín; Rios Alva et al. 2017), the vicinity of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park (Pasco), Bagua Province (Amazonas), and La Mar Province (Ayacucho; Chávez and Catenazzi 2016). The specimens from Peru might belong to another species (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016, G. Chávez pers. comm. February 2018, J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. March 2018), however it is possible the subpopulations from northern Peru have been correctly assigned to this species (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. March 2018). While all Peruvian records are retained in this assessment until they can be attributed to another species, the central and southern Peruvian subpopulations are coded as 'presence uncertain' in the distribution map and excluded from its extent of occurrence. This species occurs at elevations between 1,707–3,300 m asl (Lynch 1980, Ramírez et al. 2009).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is found in Bosque Protector Tinajillas-Gualaceño, Área Conservación Privada Copallín, and Tapichalaca Reserve. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
Additional taxonomic studies are required to resolve the uncertainty of the Peruvian subpopulations. Further research is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,889 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur in five to 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of tropical low montane and montane forest. Males have been found calling from leaves and stems of herbaceous vegetation 14–40 cm above the ground along a road cut in cloud forest. Adults of both sexes were found in bromeliads by day. Breeding occurs by direct development.
threats: The major threat is the destruction and loss of habitat for agriculture, livestock ranching, and as a result of selective logging.
population: It is a common species where it occurs. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the western slopes of the Cordillera de Huancabamba (the Huancambamba depression is a complex system of relatively low ridges, basins, and valleys), and the Pacific slope of the Cordillera Occidental, northern Peru. It is has been recorded from several localities within the Regions of Piura, Lambayeque and Cajamarca, Peru, from elevations of 1,082–2,870 m asl. The range of this species is not completely known and it could occur more widely. There are two recent records of this species in Loja Province, southern Ecuador (Páez Rosales 2014), however these records are excluded from the species' extent of occurrence (EOO) until its presence in Ecuador is confirmed. Its EOO based on its known range is 3,889 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in six to 10 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It likely occurs in the Área de Conservación Regional Bosques Secos de Salitral-Huarmaca. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
There is a need for improved habitat protection at sites where the species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of a population decline, suspected to be taking place at a rate of more than 50% over the next 10 years, due to ongoing habitat loss as a result of agriculture, cattle ranching and logging throughout its range in the Andes of Ecuador and Peru and extensive mining activities in the Cordillera del Cóndor.
habitat: This species inhabits premontane rainforest and cloud forest, whereas the intervening valleys, which it is not known to occur in, are extensively cultivated. Adults were observed at night on rocks in and along cascading streams (Duellman and Lehr 2009). This species presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: Extensive large-scale copper and gold mining projects and associated deforestation and contamination are causing serious habitat loss within the Cordillera del Cóndor (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, RAISG 2020). Large-scale mining, especially open-pit mining, has caused intensive logging, destroying important habitats and microhabitats for this species (Valencia et al. 2017). Small-holder agriculture and infrastructure development is also increasing on the slopes of Cordillera del Cóndor (RAISG 2020).
population: Considering the severe decline in habitat as a result of extensive mining projects in the Cordillera del Cóndor (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, RAISG 2020), where most of the population is thought to occur, it is suspected to decline at an alarming rate, likely more than 50%, over the next 10 years.
range: This species is distributed in the eastern foothills of the Andes in southern Ecuador and northern Peru. Records from 2007 and 2009 in the Provinces of Morona-Santiago and Zamora Chichipe, southeastern Ecuador extended this species' geographic range 452 km northwest of the type locality of Tarapoto, San Martín, Peru (Camacho-Badani et al. 2012). It occurs at elevations ranging from 600 to 1,094 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Ecuador, known records are outside of the national system of protected areas (Sistema Nacional de Areas Protegidas-SNAP). In Peru, it occurs within Área de Conservación Regional Cordillera Escalera.

Conservation Needed
Necessary conservation measures include the protection of remaining forests, and an assessment and mitigation of mining and infrastructure projects (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021; Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population. Additional taxonomic studies could change this assessment in the future.
habitat: This species can be found in the cloud forest and sub-páramo of the high Amazonian slopes of the Andes (Lynch and Duellman 1980). The Huancambamba depression is a complex system of relatively low ridges, basins, and valleys. All individuals for which habitat data are available were found in terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads by day (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). Breeding takes place by direct development, but the site of egg deposition is not known. The ability of this species to adapt to modified habitats is unknown.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss throughout its range, as a result of agriculture, livestock farming, and selective logging.
population: It is an uncommon species. The species has not been found in Ecuador since the 1980's (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). However, additional information is needed to clarify the taxonomy status of this species because it is possible that several localities assigned to the species are misidentifications, and some recently collected specimens could be identified as this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
range: This species occurs on Cordillera Oriental, southern Ecuador (Lynch 1979, Lynch y Duellman 1980). In Peru it occurs on the crest and Pacific versant of the Cordillera  between Chanchaque and Huancabamba (Piurá Department), on the ridge above San José de  Lourdes (Cajamarca Department) in the Cordillera Occidental, and Laguna de Los Condores in San Martín (Duellman and Wild 1993, Duellman and Lehr 2009). It is found between 2,195 and 3,100 m asl. It probably occurs in areas in between known sites.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, it is found in Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Area Protectora Tinajillas. In Peru, it has been recorded in the Área de Conservación Privada Los Chilchos, established in 2012. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. In Ecuador, it is listed as Least Concern. 

Research Needed
Further research into its taxonomy, distribution, population trends, and ecology are recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is somewhat limited – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,583 km<sup>2 </sup>– the species is common and has a stable population, it is found in protected areas, and no major threats affect the species.
habitat: This species inhabits humid montane cloud forest. It has not been found outside old growth forest. Adults have been found perched on low vegetation at night; juveniles and adults were on the forest floor by day. This species breeds by direct development, but the site of egg deposition is not known.
threats: Localised threats are habitat loss and degradation through livestock ranching, logging and mining.
population: It is a common species in Ecuador in northern Peru. Its population trend is considered to be stable.<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">
range: This species is known from the Cordillera de Kutukú in Morona-Santiago and the Cordillera del Cóndor in Zamora-Chinchipe and Morona-Santiago, Ecuador. It is also found in adjacent areas of Peru, however the sites reported from Tumbes in the previous assessment were in error. It might occur more widely, especially in areas between known locations. It has been found between 800–1,975 m asl (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 9,583 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The range of this species overlaps with Santiago-Comaina in the Department of Amazonas, northern Peru. In Ecuador, it occurs in Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Reserva Biologica Cerro Plateado. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is also listed as Vulnerable in Ecuador.

Research Needed
Additional research is needed on this species' distribution, population trends, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) under criterion D because despite targeted and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities, this species has not been seen at all from 1999 to 2017, which suggests that if this species is still extant the pool of remaining mature individuals is likely fewer than 50.
habitat: This species inhabits riparian vegetation in submontane and montane cloud forest. It can be found in tall forest with some tree ferns and bromeliads and luxuriant undergrowth of mosses and ferns. Except for a single individual that was collected under a rock, all specimens have been recorded calling from low vegetation in cloud forest at night. It is not known from modified habitats. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: Outbreaks of chytridiomycosis are known to have caused collapse of amphibian communities around the type locality. Although this species is a direct developer thought to be less exposed to infection, it occurs along creeks where most of the species extirpated during chytrid outbreaks also occurred. This pattern suggests that chytrid might also be a threat to subpopulations of this species and may have caused a local extirpation in the buffer zone of Manu National Park, where it has not been seen since 1999.
population: It was last collected and seen in 1999 and has not been seen since despite targeted surveys in 2008, 2009, and every year between 2012–2016 (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Three individuals observed in 2008 and reported in von May et al. (2008) do not belong to the species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). If it is still extant, the population size would likely be less than 50 mature individuals (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. May 2017).
range: This species is considered to be restricted to the Kosñipata Valley on the northeastern slopes of the Cadena de Paucartambo, an extension of the Cordillera Oriental, in the buffer zone of Manu National Park in the Cusco Region, Peru. It occurs from 1,580–1,700 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 28 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Part of the range is well protected within Manu National Park. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI). 

Conservation Needed
Should it still be extant, ex situ and species recovery considerations are recommended for this species.

Research Needed
Further survey work is necessary to determine the species' distribution current population status and whether it is indeed confined to the Kosñipata Valley. More information is also needed on this species' ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22,317 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Ecuadorian and Peruvian Andes due to cattle grazing and logging, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: It inhabits paramo, sub-páramo and humid cloud forests (Lynch 1979c; Duellman and Pramuk 1999). Specimens have been found in terrestrial bromeliads or under rocks; one individual from Peru was found in a tree at night (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). The ability of this species to adapt to modified habitats is unknown. It is presumed to breed by direct development, although the site of egg deposition is not known.
threats: General habitat loss through deforestation for cattle grazing ranching and selective wood extraction is the main threat to this species, even within protected areas.
population: Formerly thought to be a rare species, it is now considered locally common (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). Only several specimens have been collected from Peru (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). The population is suspected to be relatively stable (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
range: This Andean species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental and on the the ridges north of the Cuenca de Loja, in southern Ecuador (Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1980). It has also been recorded from the western slope of the Cordillera de Huancabamba in Piura Province, northern Peru (Duellman and Wild 1993, Duellman and Pramuk 1999). It is found at elevations between 2,470 and 3,110 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22,317 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals occur at four locations, based on the known threats.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Parque Nacional Podocarpus. In Peru, this species might occur in one small-protected area (Tabaconas Namballe National Sanctuary). It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is listed as Least Concern in Ecuador.

Conservation Needed
Improved management of protected areas to mitigate encroachment of agriculture and wood extraction into the habitat where this species occurs.

Research Needed
Additional research is needed on this species' distribution, population trends, natural history, and threats

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is from primary and secondary tropical moist lower montane forest. Specimens are commonly perched on low (< 50 cm) herbaceous vegetation and ferns at night. This species breeds by direct development and is not present in modified habitats. Fifteen egg clutches found contained 28–40 eggs (Duellman and Lehr 2009).
threats: It is possibly locally threatened by deforestation for agriculture. In 2008, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) was detected in adult and juvenile specimens of this species at Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park, with a prevalence of 20.7% (n=116) and 21.4% (n=56), respectively (Catenazzi et al. 2011). In 2009, adult specimens collected from the same area tested positive for Bd infection with a prevalence of 11% (n=91) (Catenazzi et al. 2011). In 2009, Bd was detected in 29 additional individuals [four tadpoles (100% infected) 12 juveniles (83% infected), and 13 adults (54% infected)], at the same localities (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Chytridiomycosis has been implicated in the severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011). It is unknown whether this disease represents a threat to this direct-developing frog, so the potential impacts of chytrid infections on this species require further investigation.
population: It is a common species and has a presumed stable population.
range: This species can be found in the Andes of southern Peru and northern Bolivia. It is known from Kosñipata, Cusco, Peru, south to Valle de Zongo, La Paz Department, Bolivia. Its elevational range is from 500–1,800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, this species occurs in the Manu and Bahuaja-Sonene National Parks. It is present in several protected areas in Bolivia.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology. Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal species can be found in evergreen secondary and old growth humid montane forest with herbaceous plants, shrubs, and lianas. Specimens have been found in the leaf litter, among mosses, in leaves of bushes or palm fronds 1-2 m above the ground, and sometimes inside bromeliads (Lynch and Duellman 1980, Brito et al. 2017, J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017). It has occasionally been found alongside streams. Reproduction occurs by direct development.
threats: A major threat to this species is habitat destruction through an increase in livestock farming, agro-industrial development, and selective wood extraction.
population: It is a common species in Ecuador (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2014, Brito et al. 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from elevations of 1,000–2,900 m asl on the eastern face of the Cordillera Oriental and the Cordillera del Condor in the Ecuadorian Andes and occurs in all provinces from Sucumbíos to Zamora-Chinchipe (Brito et al. 2017). It is also known from the Provinces of Bagua (Amazonas Region), Huancabamba (Piura Region) and San Ignacio (Cajamarca Region) in northern Peru. It presumably occurs more widely, in particular in areas between the known Ecuadorian and Peruvian ranges. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 56,741 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The range of this species overlaps with the Zona Reservada Cordillera de Colán, Santuario Nacional Tabaconas-Namballe and Parque Nacional del Condor in Peru, and in Ecuador with Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras, Parque Nacional Sangay, Bosque Protector del Alto Nangaritza, Reserva Biológica Zuñac, Parque Nacional Podocarpus, Reserva Biológica Tapichalaca, Estación Científica Yanayacu and Estación Cocodrilo. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. In Ecuador, it is listed as Least Concern.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.
