rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: All known individuals were found on leaves on low vegetation less than 1 m above the ground in humid montane forest at night. Reproduction is by direct development.
threats: Major threats to this species is the destruction and degradation of its habitat due to increasing agricultural activity, selective wood extraction, and human settlement. However, it is known from within the boundaries of Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo, where there is suitable habitat remaining, and therefore the effect of these threats on the species remain unknown.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as only a few individuals have been observed.
range: This species is known only from two localities along the road from Abra Pardo de Miguel to Moyobamba on the east slope of the northern part of the Cordillera Central in northern San Martín Region, Peru, from 2,000–2,180 m asl. It probably occurs more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is known from the Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed at Least Concern as no threats are present, its population is stable, and it occurs within the buffer zone—and possibly within the boundaries of—Manu National Park.
habitat: It was collected on a bush at night in montane tropical cloud forest, but it is often perched around 2–3 m above the ground. Reproduction in this species is presumably by direct development.
threats: There is no information about threats to this species. In 2013, this species was collected from Kosñipata Valley near Manu National Park; among three individuals sampled, one was infected by Bd and another by Ranavirus (Warne et al. 2016), however direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affected by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is not abundant and continues to be an uncommon species, but the population seems to be stable (Peru Red List Assessment Workshop April 2017).
range: This species is known only from Kosñipata between 1,300–2,100 m asl on the northeastern slopes of the Cadena de Paucartambo, a frontal range of the Andean Cordillera Oriental, in Cusco Region, Peru. The true range of this species is not known and it might occur more widely, but the extent of occurrence (EOO) of the current known range is 65 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs in the buffer zone of Manu National Park.

Research Needed
Further surveys could help to improve the understanding of the species' population size, distribution and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical moist lowland and lower montane rainforest. Individuals have been collected at night on low vegetation. Reproduction is by direct development.
threats: There is localized deforestation and loss of habitat in the area through an increase in agricultural activity, selective wood extraction and human settlement, however there is plenty of suitable habitat remaining (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
population: The population status of this species is unknown, however it is relatively common in museum collections.
range: This species was formerly known only from three localities on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Central in San Martín Region, northern Peru. It is now also known from several scattered localities in the Regions of Loreto, Amazonas, Huánuco and Juniín (Duellman and Lehr 2009). It occurs through a relatively wide altitudinal range, from 140–1,200 m asl, and consequently might range much more widely. Taxonomic work is needed given the species' wide range (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo and Pacaya-Samiria National Reserve.

Research Needed
Taxonomic work is needed to determine if this form is a complex of more than one species. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: This is a cloud forest and lowland forest inhabitant. In Central Peru, specimens were found during the day in bromeliads, and males were calling at night from bamboo (Duellman and Lehr 2009). Some individuals were found in a pineapple patch by day, others were found in bromeliads by day. In Kosñipata Valley, one was found on a fern at night. It is a direct development species, that can be found in edge and slightly modified habitats.
threats: Presumably there are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. However, there is some localized habitat loss due to human activities such as agriculture for crops and livestock.
population: The population status is unknown, however it is considered to be stable given its widespread distribution.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental in central and southern Peru, within Huánuco, Pasco, Ayacucho, Cusco, and Madre de Dios Regions. Its altitudinal range is between 1,700–3,325 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu and Tambopata-Candamo National Reserve (Madre de Dios) in southern Peru and Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul in Central Peru.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits cloud forest and humid montane forests. It has not been recorded from disturbed areas. It is both nocturnal and diurnal, and can be found during the day or night on the ground or perching on leaves of bushes (Köhler 2000, Padial et al. 2006). Reproduction is by direct development, and juveniles are seen during December and January.
threats: Agricultural activity, logging, mining concessions, and the construction of roads and dams are major threats to this species' habitat in Bolivia. It occurs at elevations coincidental with and heavily used for coca and coffee plantations (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). In 2001, one individual was found dead on a rock, but the cause of death was unable to be determined (A. Muñoz pers. comm. September 2019). This species has not been tested for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
population: It is an uncommon species in Bolivia; known records originate from surveys conducted in 1998 and 2001 at Ayopaya (R. Aguayo and A. Muñoz pers. comm. September 2019), in 2008 at Parque Nacional Carrasco (O. Quinteros pers. comm. September 2019 ) and in 2016 at Valle de Zongo (C. Cortez and S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019). In Peru, it is considered to be very rare (J.M. Padial pers. comm. March 2018). Despite intense fieldwork (Padial et al. 2004), including surveys of the type locality, few specimens have been collected (in Peru) and knowledge of this species is still rudimentary (Padial et al. 2006).
range: This species was formerly known from only Chapare Province in Cochabamba Department, and La Paz Department in Bolivia (Lynch and Duellman 1997, De la Riva et al. 2000, Cortez 2001). It has since been recorded from additional localities within ca 300 km length in Bolivia, and a single record from Paucartambo, Cusco Region, Peru, separated by a distance of 480 km (airline) from the closest Bolivian records (Padial et al. 2006), including Valle de Zongo (C. Cortez and S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019), Parque Nacional Carrasco (O. Quinteros pers. comm. September 2019) and Ayopaya (A. Muñoz pers. comm. September 2019). It possibly occurs between known sites in Peru and Bolivia (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019). It has been recorded from 1,400–1,950 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Parque
In Bolivia, it occurs in Parques Nacionales Cotapata, Madidi and Carrasco. In Peru, it may occur in Parque Nacional Manu, but further surveys are needed to confirm this.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,081 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two to five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to agriculture.
habitat: This species occurs in equatorial dry forest at the type locality and is found in tropical lowland moist forest, especially near streams, in Ecuador. Both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads are locally abundant, and this region also supports thorn forest. It is not known how susceptible it is to habitat modification, but it is likely to be a forest-dependent species. Specimens have been observed at night under stones or dead logs on sandy areas of streams. They are excellent rapid-swimmers, usually jumping into the water after being disturbed (Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2009). This is a direct developing species.
threats: There is some localized habitat loss through human activities, principally agriculture, which might be affecting this species outside of protected areas.
population: Only a few individuals have been observed, so its population status is unknown. It was originally described based on two specimens collected at the River Marañon Valley, Department of Amazonas, Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). During April–May 2009, six specimens were collected at Centro de Estudios y Desarrollo para la Amazonía (CEDAMAZ), Zamora Chinchipe, Ecuador (Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2009, Ojeda and Loján 2010). Because of habitat loss, this species is suspected to be in decline.
range: This species is known only from two localities: the vicinity of the type locality in the Province of Bagua, Amazonas Region, Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999), and from the Centro de Estudios y Desarrollo para Amazonia, a reserve in northeastern Zamora-Chinchipe Province, Ecuador (Cisneros-Heredia et al. 2009). It is expected to be more widespread than currently documented, especially in between the known sites. It occurs at elevations ranging from 525–860 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,081 km2, which represents two to five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is present within the Zona Reservada Cordillera de Colán in Peru and Centro de Estudios y Desarrollo para la Amazonía in Ecuador.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is necessary at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because although this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of XXX km2, it occurs at three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its lowland forest habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Near Threatened because although this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 22,384 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at three to ten threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its cloud forest habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species inhabits montane cloud forests. Individuals have been found by day along streams, in cavities between stones. The frogs appear to imitate mossy stones (R. Schulte pers. comm.). This species breeds by direct development.
threats: There is localized habitat loss throughout its range due to agriculture (both the cultivation of crops and the rearing of livestock). Gold mining activities might affect this species in Ecuador.
population: Four adult females were used to describe this species, but were poorly preserved as they died en route from the type locality to the collector's home in Tarapoto, Peru. In 2012, four additional specimens were reported from Reserva Biológica Tapichalaca, Zamora Chinchipe, Ecuador, including the first known male of the species (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2012). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from the type locality at the eastern side of Abra Pardo Miguel, San Martín, Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999) and an unconfirmed locality in the southern part of the Cordillera Oriental in Ecuador (Duellman and Lehr 2009), from 1,800-2,000 m asl. However, new records in Ecuador have extended its geographic distribution 216 km northwest of the type locality, and expanded its elevational range up to 2,500 m asl (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2012, Almendáriz et al. 2014). It is possible that the species could occur in between or around known sites, at suitable elevations and within suitable habitat. While it has been suggested that the Ecuadorian subpopulations represent another species (P. Venegas pers. comm. March 2018), they are maintained as this species until further taxonomic work is carried out (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. April 2018). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22,384 km2, which represents three to ten threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present within Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo in Peru, and Reserva Biológica Tapichalaca and Parque Nacional Podocarpus in Ecuador. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Additional research is required to resolve the taxonomic status of the Ecuadorian subpopulations.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: The Bolivian localities comprise evergreen tropical premontane and montane forest. In Peru it is known from lowland and pre-montane forest areas. It has been recorded calling from bushes at the edge of the road during light rain and has been heard from the canopy at about 6-10 m above the ground during a heavy downpour. Reproduction in this species is by direct development.
threats: There are not thought to be any major threats to this species, which is presumed to be widespread with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to human activities such as wood collection, agriculture (crops and livestock), oil exploration, and human settlement. The species overlaps with large areas where creeks and streams are being destroyed by gold mining and this is a severe issue in the lowlands. The forest in which the species occurs is also destroyed by these activities, but because the species does not rely on running water for reproduction, it is possible that the species is able to survive in these areas (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: This species is abundant and the population is considered to be stable (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
range: This species was formerly known only from Paracti, Cochabamba Department in Bolivia, as well as, Kosñipata Valley, in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Manu (Cusco) and Pakitza within Parque Nacional Manu (Madre de Dios), Peru. It is now also known from additional localities in Madre de Dios, including Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri, and has been found to be widespread in Pando, La Paz and Cochabamba Departments in Bolivia (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Its elevational range is 350–1,300 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range overlaps with Parque Nacional Manu and Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri in Peru, and Parques Nacionales Carrasco and Madidi, as well as, Reserva Nacional de Vida Silvestre Amazónica Manuripi Heath in Bolivia.

Research Needed
Further work is required to improve the understanding of the size, distribution and trends of its population.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is an inhabitant of moist forests in the tropical eastern altitudinal zone. In the past, it was considered to be sensitive to anthropogenic disturbance (McCracken and Forstner 2014), however in the area of Santa Cruz Forest Reserve, Peru where this specimen was discovered, the habitat consists of a mixture of primary forest and 10–20 year-old secondary growth forest, suggesting the species may be more tolerant to anthropomorphic disturbances than previously suspected (Wray et al. 2015). It is an arboreal species, found up to 30 m above ground at the base of bromeliads, inside bromeliads, or on vegetation hanging over water (McCracken and Forstner 2014, Wray et al. 2015). The mode of reproduction is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: Agricultural development, for both crops and livestock, as well as logging, are major threats to this species’ habitat. Within Yasuní National Park, Tiputini Biodiversity Station is only accessible by river and surrounded by undisturbed primary lowland rainforest, and Yasuní Research Station is located c. 27 km west on an oil pipeline road that has been experiencing forest disturbance within its vicinity, but is still surrounded by large tracts of undisturbed forest (McCracken and Forstner 2014).
population: There is very little information known about its population status, but this is probably because it is a canopy species that is very hard to detect. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known from several specimens at six localities in primary forest of the eastern Ecuadorian provinces of Orellana, Pastaza, and Sucumbíos, from 250–350 m asl. In 2015, it was recorded from one locality in Loreto, Peru, at 100 m asl, extending the range of this poorly known taxon c. 375 km SE from the easternmost record in Ecuador, and represents the first record outside Ecuador (Wray et al. 2015). It is probably more widespread, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range includes Parque Nacional Yasuní (Estación de Biodiversidad Tiputini) in Ecuador and Santa Cruz Forest Reserve in Peru. It is listed as Data Deficient in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This is a montane forest species that is not well known. It breeds by direct development and it is not known if it can tolerate modified habitats.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, but there is general deforestation as a result of an increase in livestock and other agricultural activities, and selective logging.
population: There is no information on the population status and trends of this species. It is known from only three specimens in Peru (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known from the region of the type locality (near the crest of the northern part of the Cordillera Central) in the Province of Bagua, Amazonas Region, Peru, at 3,470 m asl. The record from Curintza, Zamora Chinchipe Province, Parque Nacional Podocarpus, Ecuador specified in the 2004 assessment cannot be confirmed; thus its presence in Ecuador remains uncertain (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru it has not been recorded from any protected areas. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties to its taxonomic status, extent of occurrence, and ecological requirements.
habitat: It has been found so far only in old growth cloud forest. It is presumed to be a direct developing species, although the egg deposition site is not known.
threats: Loss and degradation of habitat due to cattle grazing and mining are localized threats known to affect this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
population: Few individuals of this species have been ever been observed, and it is considered a rare and difficult to recognize species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). It was last observed during 2008–2012 surveys in Alto Machinaza, in Zamora Chinchipe (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
range: This species is known from the Cordillera Cutucú and on the western slopes of the Cordillera del Cóndor, in Morona-Santiago and Zamora-Chinchipe provinces, Ecuador (Lynch 1979, Duellman and Lynch 1988, Almendariz et al. 2014). It has an altitude range from 1,138 to 1,700 m asl (Duellman and Lehr 2009). The single specimen from Cordillera del Cóndor, Amazonas, Peru specified in the 2004 assessment remains unconfirmed, thus its presence in Peru is uncertain (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016, E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Bosque Protector Kutucú. 

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species. Taxonomic studies are needed to resolve the status of this species, particularly the Peruvian specimen.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is likely to occur more widely.
habitat: It can be found in humid and semi-arid montane forest, but it is not known if it can occur in modified habitats. Specimens have been collected from arboreal bromeliads by day in semi-arid forest (Duellman and Pramuk 1999, Koch 2014) and from vegetation ca 1 m above the ground by night (D. Rodríguez pers. comm. March 2018). Specimens from the eastern slopes of the Cordillera del Condór were found on low vegetation at night in humid montane forest. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: It is threatened by by deforestation for livestock and cultivation of crops, selective wood extraction, and human settlement.
population: Records of three adult males and one adult female were used to describe this species (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). Two individuals were collected from the type locality in July 2008 (Koch 2014). During 2013, 58 individuals of this species were observed during surveys over 34 person-hours in Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe in Cajamarca (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the Cajamarca and Amazonas Regions of northern Peru. It is present at two localities in Condorcanqui Province on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera del Condór (Amazonas Region); several localities in the northern part of the Cordillera Central (Chachapoyas, Bagua, Bongará, and Rodriguez de Mendoza Provinces, Amazonas Region); and Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe and Santa Rosa de la Yunga on the southern edge of the Cordillera del Condór (Cajamarca Region). It occurs from 1,100–2,400 m asl. This species is believed to have a continuous distribution between the Cordillera del Condór and the Cordillera Central, and might prove to be more widespread (Duellman and Pramuk 1999).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in the Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina, and is also believed to occur in the Zona Reservada Cordillera de Colán. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 550 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur at two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat along the Pacific slopes of the Cordillera Occidental in Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits dry, scrubby forest with scattered terrestrial bromeliads at the type locality and humid montane forest in the Rio Zaña Valley. Individuals of this species were observed in terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads or calling from rock ledges and low vegetation at night (Duellman and Lehr 2009). This species presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: Four of the five known localities are within the Udima Wildlife Refuge. Threats to this species at the type locality are not known, although in general there is regional loss of habitat due to increased agricultural activity and selective wood extraction.
population: There is little information on the population status of this species, however d<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">ue to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat in parts of its range, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the type locality ca 2 km west of Huambos, Provincia de Chota (Duellman 1991); Río Zaña, Provincia Santa Cruz (Duellman and Lehr 2007); Monte Seco, Provincia Santa Cruz; Quebrada Chorro Blanco, Provincia Santa Cruz; and Hacienda Granadilla, Provincia San Miguel (Duellman and Lehr 2009), all in Cajamarca Region, on the Pacific slopes of the Cordillera Occidental in Peru. It occurs from 1,500–2,500 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 550 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur at two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from throughout the Udima Wildlife Refuge, established in 2011.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered, as this species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,390 km2, it occurs in three to five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the northern part of the Cordillera Occidental in Peru.
habitat: This species is found in montane grassland. All individuals have been collected under stones by day. It has also been recorded in a mining concession (Aguilar et al. 2012). It is presumed to be a direct developing species.
threats: General threats throughout its range, which are likely to be impacting this species' habitat, include agricultural development (principally potato cultivation), livestock, and mining activities.
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from several localities in the northern part of the Cordillera Occidental in Peru, at elevations between 3,000–3,916 m asl. It is known from the region of the type locality in the Province of Celendín, from the high western slopes of the Cordillera Occidental near Chugur and Hacienda Taulis, and from Agua Blanca, all within Cajamarca Region, Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999, Duellman and Lehr 2009, Aguilar et al. 2012). Its range is not completely known, and it is difficult to estimate if this species has a much larger range, however the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current range is 2,390 km2 and all individuals are considered to occur in three to five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded from any protected areas, however its range overlaps with Bosques Nublados de Udima Sector Centro. It is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI).

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: It is an arboreal species present in primary (and disturbed) montane cloud and Yungas forest, and open areas, including sub-páramo (De la Riva et al. 2000, Köhler 2000, Cortez 2001). It perches on vegetation 0.5-2.0 m from the ground. Gravid females have been collected from January to July. It is possible that reproduction stops during the peak of the dry season, at least in some places. It is presumed to breed by direct development. The species may use bromeliads as a place for oviposition, but this needs confirmation. While it is present in disturbed forest, it does not occur in agricultural areas.
threats: There are no major threats to this species. There are some localized threats through degradation of habitats for agriculture, livestock and logging. In 2009, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) was detected in one adult and one juvenile of this species at Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011). In 2013, this species was collected from Kosñipata Valley near Manu National Park; among 32 individuals sampled, 34.4% were infected by Bd and 41.9% by Ranavirus (Warne et al. 2016). Chytridiomycosis is the probable cause of severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011), however direct developing frogs, such as this species, are not likely to be affect by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Still, the potential impacts of chytrid infections, as well as localized climate change, on this species require further investigation.
population: In Bolivia, this is an abundant species, as indicated by Köhler's studies in Cochabamba and Santa Cruz, Aguayo's (2000) work in Cochabamba, and Cortez's (2001) research in La Paz. It is also abundant in southern Peru (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The population trend is considered to be stable.
range: This species occurs east of the Andes from the Region of Ayacucho, Peru to west-central Bolivia (Departments of Cochabamba, La Paz and Santa Cruz). It occurs from 950–3,470 m asl (De la Riva et al. 2000, Köhler 2000).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia it is protected by Madidi and Cotapata National Parks and Natural Areas of Integrated Management, Pilon Lajas Biosphere and Indigenous Land Reserve; and Carrasco and Amboro National Parks. In Peru, the range of this species overlaps with Manu and Bahuaja-Sonene National Parks.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of chytrid fungus and climate change inducing droughts.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 11,409 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its montane forest habitat, particularly within the Cordillera del Cóndor of Ecuador.
habitat: This species can be found in montane cloud forests; specimens have been collected in bromeliads and in low vegetation by night (Lynch 1979). It prefers areas with abundant light, such as mountain peaks (Brito et al. 2017). In the Cordillera del Cóndor of Ecuador, gravid females were found in January and August. Breeding is considered to take place by direct development. A female with 11 eggs was recorded inside a terrestrial bromeliad (Brito et al. 2017).
threats: Habitat loss and degradation due to cattle grazing and mining activities affects the species in the Cordillera del Cóndor.
population: It is uncommon in Ecuador, while in Peru only a single juvenile specimen has been recorded.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the eastern Andes in southern Ecuador and the adjacent Cordillera del Cóndor and Cordillera de Kutucú (Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1980, Duellman and Lynch 1988, Brito et al. 2014, Almendáriz et al. 2014, Frankel and Guayasamin 2015). The only Peruvian record from the upper Río Comainas, Amazonas Department requires confirmation (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). Its elevational range is 1,710–2,620 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 11,409 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur 10 or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in several large protected areas, including Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Parque Nacional Sangay. In Ecuador, it is considered to be Endangered (Páez-Rosales et al. 2018).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to better understand the limits of the distribution of this species, population trends, natural history, and threats. Research is needed to verify the identity of the specimen from Peru.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its estimate extent of occurrence (EOO) is 821 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur at two to five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Andes.
habitat: It inhabits dense, humid montane and cloud forest, and it is not known if it can survive in degraded areas. Individuals have been found at night on low vegetation, and under ground cover by day. It breeds by direct development.
threats: The major threat across the range is habitat loss, due to deforestation for agriculture (mostly livestock farming) and selective wood extraction.
population: It is common where it occurs.
range: This species can be found in the Andes of Peru and Ecuador. It has been recorded from elevations of 2,770–3,050 m asl on the western slopes and crest of the Cordillera de Huancabamba, Piura Department, Peru. Southern subpopulations from Ecuador have to be taxonomically confirmed (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 821 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur at two to five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Within Ecuador it has been recorded from Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Reserva Biológica Tapichala, but it is not known from any protected areas in Peru. In Peru, it has not been recorded from any protected areas. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Both improved site and habitat protection and management are required.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further survey work is necessary to determine whether this species might occur more widely than currently known.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It is an arboreal species (> 3m) of primary cloud and montane forest. Specimens have been recorded from bromeliads in lower humid montane forest. It breeds by direct development.
threats: It is threatened by habitat loss across its range. In northern Ecuador, it is threatened by cattle grazing and mining activities, and in northern Peru it is threatened by agriculture, cattle, and logging activities.
population: It is a common species. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known only from its type locality along the road from Abra Pardo Miguel to Moyobamba on the northeastern side of Cordillera Central of Peru (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). In Peru, it is currently known from 1,080–1,788 m asl in the Departments of San Martín (Lamas, Moyobamba, Picota and Mariscal Cáceres Provinces), Amazonas (Condorcanqui Province) and Loreto (Datem del Marañón Province), which represents a range extension of 287 km to the northwest of the type locality (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012). In Ecuador, it is known from Zamora Chinchipe Province, at 1,200–2,400 m asl, extending the geographic distribution range 347 km northwest of the type locality (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2012, Almendariz et al. 2014). It perhaps occurs a little more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is unknown if the species is found in protected areas in Ecuador. In Peru, it is present in Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection and continued management of existing protected areas is needed to ensure the maintenance of suitable habitat for this species. 

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 15,619 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur at three threat-defined locations, and it is likely to occur in between known sites where there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat due to the expanding agricultural frontier in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species inhabits humid montane forest species. All individuals were collected on low vegetation up to 1 m from the ground at night. It not known to occur in degraded areas. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: Within the region there is a general loss and degradation of habitats due to agricultural activities, including livestock rearing.
population: Its population status is not well understood. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing localised declines in the extent and quality of habitat, some subpopulations are suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing localised declines in the extent and quality of habitat, some subpopulations are suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from four localities in norther Peru: Laguna de Los Condores and the east slope of Abra Pardo de Miguel in the northern Cordillera Central, as well as, two sites along the Río Comianas on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera del Cóndor in the Regions of Amazonas and San Martín. It occurs at elevations from 1,138–2,870 m asl. The elevational range of this species suggests that it might range more widely, especially in between known sites. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 15,619 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur at three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Two of the known localities are within the protected areas of Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo and Área de Conservacíon Privada Los Chilchos. It probably also occurs in Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina.

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed within the region. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because its population is relatively stable, it is frequently encountered and it is known from a well-protected area and there are no major threats to this species at present.
habitat: This species was found in cloud forest in areas with some tree ferns, bromeliads, and luxuriant undergrowth of mosses and ferns. All individuals were found on low herbaceous plants at night. It is presumed to be a direct developing species.
threats: In 2008, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was detected in a juvenile of this species at Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011) and in 2009, an adult specimen collected from the same area tested positive for Bd infection (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Chytridiomycosis is the probable cause of severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011), however direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affect by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is a fairly frequently encountered species, but is still known only from the type locality probably because the similarity between this and other species in the complex make it difficult to identify (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The population trend is unknown, though considered to be relatively stable.
range: This species is known only from Santa Isabel in Cosñipata Valley, at an altitude of 1,700 m Asl, and from the northeastern slopes of the Cadena de Paucartambo, a frontal range of the Andean Cordillera Oriental, both in Cusco Region, Peru. It is likely to occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: The species is currently known only from within the well-protected Manu National Park and its buffer zone.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 15,987 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are considered to occur in six to 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: It is known only from humid montane cloud forest. The type locality is on a mostly cultivated ridge with remnants of dense low forest (6-8 m high) bearing many orchids and bromeliads. One of the Peruvian localities is on a ridge overlooking the cultivated valley. Individuals have always been found in large terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads by day. It breeds by direct development.
threats: The major threat is habitat loss and destruction through an increase in agriculture, selective logging, and human settlement. Enciso et al. (2008) recently reported Aeromonas caviae and other bacteria from skin samples, where Pristimantis schultei was one of the sampled species. These authors suggest that there is a potential for infection and development of the disease if populations undergo stress.
population: The current population status of this species is poorly known. In 2006–2007, two individuals were observed over 30 person-days in Amazonas, Peru (von May et al. 2008), and additional surveys in Amazonas during 2007 detected five individuals over six person-days (von May et al. 2008). During 2013, 18 individuals of this species were observed during surveys over 40.5 person-hours in Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe in Cajamarca and Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo in San Martín (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from the Andes of northern Peru. In Peru, it is known from the type locality of 5 km north of Levanto, Chachapoyas Province, Amazonas Region, and several additional localities in Bongará, Rodríguez de Mendoza, Luya, Rioja, and Pedro Ruiz Gallo Provinces (Amazonas; Beraún et al. 2014, R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. April 2017), in Cáceres Province (San Martín, Beraún et al. 2014), and in San Ignacio Province (Cajamarca Region, J.C. Cusi pers comm. April 2017). It is thought to also occur in Tapichalaca Biological Reserve, Zamora-Chinchipe in Ecuador (Yáñez-Muñoz et al. 2012), however this needs to be confirmed and therefore is not represented in this assessment (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt, M. Yáñez-Muñoz and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). The record from Mitobamba, Cajamarca Department, Peru, provided by Duellman and Lehr (2009) may actually represent an undescribed species (Beraún et al. 2014). It occurs from 2,300–2,935 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 15,987 km2 and all individuals are considered to occur in six to 10 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, it is known from the Área de Conservación Privada Huiquilla, Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe, and Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo. If the species is confirmed in Ecuador, it may be present in Reserva Tapichalaca. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Conservation Needed
Recommended conservation measures include continued and improved management of the existing protected areas and habitat maintenance.

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species. Further surveys are needed in Reserva Tapichalaca to confirm this species' presence there. A detailed revision of the specimens from Cajamarca is necessary to assess the identity of P. schultei in the region (Beraún et al. 2014).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomy, extent of occurrence, population status, and natural history.
habitat: This species is known to inhabit tropical montane cloud forest. It is unknown whether it can tolerate habitat disturbance. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The area where this species occurs is subject to localized loss and degradation of habitats due to human colonization, agricultural development, and construction of roads (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018).
population: There is little information on the population status of this species, as it is only known from two specimens collected in 1971 (Duellman 1978). In 2011, a survey in the vicinity of the type locality did not record the species (V.J. Vargas pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the type locality in Yuraccyaco, Ayacucho Department, Peru, at 2,620 m asl. It might range much more widely, but there has been little survey work of the surrounding areas.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Additional field surveys are needed to obtain more information on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Taxonomic work is necessary to verify the taxonomic identity of specimens.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered in view of the small extent of occurrence (EOO) of the confirmed Peruvian range (258 km<sup>2</sup>), because it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
habitat: This is a montane tropical forest species. In Peru, males were recorded calling at night from leaves of low herbaceous plants in highly disturbed, humid, upper montane forest. In the Cordillera Colan, a sub-adult female was found on a bush near a stream, and two juveniles were collected in leaf-litter in humid montane forest. It is presumed to breed by direct development. It is not known if this species occurs in degraded areas.
threats: The major threat is likely habitat loss due to selective logging and agriculture (including livestock).
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information on the population size and trends of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is little information on the population size and trends of this species.
range: This species can be found in the Andes of northern Peru and southern Ecuador. In Peru, it has been recorded from elevations of 1,850 m asl on the upper western slopes of the northern Cordillera Central (drained by tributaries of the Río Chiriaco flowing northward into the Río Marañon), and from 1,700 m asl on the western slopes of the Cordillera Colan (both sites in Amazonas Department). The precise geographic locations of these sites are uncertain and have been approximated in the range map. The species has also been recorded from Zamora Chinchipe Province and Morona Santiago Provinces in Ecuador; however confirmation of these records is required (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016) and, therefore, are coded as Presence Uncertain in the range map. This species might range more widely, but the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known Peruvian range is 258 km<sup>2</sup>, which represent two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, the range of this species overlaps with the Cordillera de Colán Reserved Zone, a 60,000 ha protected area declared in 2002. In Ecuador, it has been recorded from Parque Nacional Podocarpus. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,710 km<sup>2</sup>, it is abundant, adaptable, and its population is considered to be stable.
habitat: It can be found in humid montane primary and secondary forest, where males have been observed from herbaceous vegetation 0.3-1.0 m above the ground. Individuals have also been collected from low vegetation in disturbed habitat where there were a few large trees present (Duellman and Wild 1993). This species is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: While there is some destruction and loss of habitats for livestock and selective wood extraction within its range, this species demonstrates a degree of tolerance for habitat disturbance and is not thought to be significantly threatened.
population: It is abundant where it occurs and, because of its adaptability to habitat modification, the population is considered to be stable. During 2013–2014, 14 individuals of this species were observed during surveys over 72.5 person-hours in the vicinity of Estación Biológica Chichilapa, Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe in Cajamarca (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species was previously only known from elevations of 1,735–1,840 m on the western slope of Cordillera de Huancabamba, Piura, Peru (Duellman and Wild 1993, Duellman and Pramuk 1999), as well as the Cordillera Occidental at Chota and Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe (Cajamarca Department) and Cerro Aypate and Toronche (Piura Department) in Peru, from 1,500–2,700 m asl (Duellman and Lehr 2007). In 2012, this species was reported from Loja, Ecuador, extending the geographic distribution 113 km north of the type locality and representing the first record outside Peru (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2012). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,710 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, it has been recorded from Estación Biológica Chichilapa, Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe and it occurs in Reserva Biológica Utuana in Ecuador. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is rather limited – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,769 km<sup>2 </sup>– the species is common, its population is stable, it occurs in several well-protected areas, and no major threats are known for the species.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical montane cloud forest. Individuals are active at night on vegetation up to 2 m above the ground. It breeds by direct development, but the site of egg deposition is not known.
threats: The habitat of this species is usually on steep slopes and thus is not suitable for cattle grazing or other farming activities (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). No major threats are known for this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
population: It is a common species and the population is currently considered to be stable. During March 2010–February 2011, it was one of the most abundant species in the high montane forests of the Reserva Biólogica San Francisco, Zamora Chinchipe, Ecuador (Sánchez Nivicela 2013). In May 2012, 26 individuals were recorded in the Reserva Biológica de Tapichalaca over 125 hours, making it the most abundant species during the survey period (Goldspiel 2012). This species was among the most frequently registered during June 2012–November 2012 and January 2013 surveys in Bosque Nublado San Francisco and Reserva Biológica de Tapichalaca (northern portion of Parque Nacional Podocarpus, Ecuador), with 63 individuals (52 juveniles and 11 adults) detected (Tandazo 2013).
range: This species occurs at intermediate elevations (2,100–3,100 m asl) in the Andes of southern Ecuador (Loja and Zamora-Chinchipe provinces); extending to lower elevations (665–1,750 m asl) in northern Peru (Amazonas Province on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera del Condor and upper Río Comainas). It is likely to occur more widely (Duellman and Pramuk 1999). Subpopulations below 1,500 m asl are doubtful and need to be confirmed (J.C. Sánchez, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 9,769 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The range of this species overlaps with the Reserva Comunal Santiago-Comaina in Peru. In Ecuador, is found in several large protected areas. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. In Ecuador, it is listed as Endangered. 

Research Needed
It is a species complex and further taxonomic research is needed to clarify the status of several subpopulations. Additional research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It is a humid montane cloud forest species that has also been recorded from disturbed habitats. Calling takes place from low vegetation and this species breeds by direct development.
threats: The threats to it are unclear, although there is some destruction and loss of habitat in the area due to agriculture and livestock grazing.
population: It was formerly thought to be common where it is found, although few individuals have been observed. Nothing is known about the current population status of this species.
range: This species is known from two localities on the western slope of the Cordillera de Huancabamba, in Piura Region, Peru, at elevations of 1,600 and 1,735 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. 

Research Needed
Further taxonomic and field research is needed into this little-known species. Additional surveys are needed to better understand its distribution, population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed at Critically Endangered because the remaining patches of forest in which the species occurs have an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 51 km<sup>2</sup>, there is historical and continuing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat in Marcapata Valley, which represents a single threat-defined location.
habitat: This species inhabits only the remaining patches of montane cloud forest in Marcapata Valley where it breeds by direct development (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
threats: The steep slopes of the Marcapata Valley are known to have been used for agriculture for well over one hundred years: the slopes are seasonally burned for planting of rocoto chilies, higher elevations are used for potato growing, and livestock is grazed on these slopes, too (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).  As a result there are only a few remaining patches of cloud forest in this valley and these are under pressure by wood collection by the local human population.
population: There is no information on the current population status of this species. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the southern Andes in Cusco, Peru near Marcapata. It occurs between 1,800–2,740 m Asl. It could occur more widely, but much of the valley in which it occurs has been deforested for agricultural use and surveys in the region have not recorded it elsewhere (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). As such its EOO is 51 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species not known to occur in any protected areas. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI).

Conservation Needed
Protection and management of remaining cloud forest in the Marcapata Valley is required.

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 157 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits Andean grassland (puna) habitats and transitional areas between puna and montane forest. It has also be found in disturbed grassland areas including gardens and potato fields, however it is unknown whether the species is able to persist in these modified habitats in the long term (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The major threat to this species in the past was loss of forest habitat in the transitional zone. In 2003, there were no apparent threats present at the type locality, however there is little understanding of current threats to this species. Agrochemical pollution might pose a threat, and there is likely ongoing habitat decline due to agriculture and human settlement throughout the range of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is an uncommon species. In 2001, 15 individuals were observed over two person-days, while two individuals were detected over two person-days during similar surveys in 2003 (von May et al. 2008). The current population trend is unknown as surveys have not been conducted since 2003.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, 15 km southeast of Maraypata near Laguna Gwengway, and from Alcas, San Rafael District, Ambo Province, Huánuco Region, Peru. It occurs between 3,480 and 3,680 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 157 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur at two threat-defined locations. It is expected to have a restricted distribution as known for the genus (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It does not exist in any protected areas. 

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Future surveys to determine whether the species is able to persist in modified habitats (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It is a terrestrial, nocturnal species inhabiting primary montane cloud forest and elfin forest with cold temperatures; it is not known if it occurs in degraded habitats. Males have been heard calling from inside lichens or in the leaf-litter. Breeding is by direct development.
threats: This species                  is currently only known from within Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, which is well protected; however, if the species occurs outside of the park, agriculture expansion into the park's buffer zone may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). The Yanachaga mountain chain is one the remaining large forested areas in this region of Peru, and there is increasing human pressure to convert the land for agricultural activities, for example, "Rocoto" (chili pepper) plantations, and selective logging inside the buffer zone of the park.
population: It is only known from several specimens, and therefore the population status is unknown. This species was considered to be one of the rarest during surveys at the upper San Alberto basin, near the southern border of Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park, during July–August 2011; only two individuals were found around the type locality (Chávez et al. 2012).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality which lies at the southern end of the Cordillera Yanachaga, Pasco Region, Peru, between 2,200 and 2,700 m asl. Although its geographic range is not well known, it may occur in suitable habitat within the buffer zone of the Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, however it is presumed to be confined to the Cordillera Yanachaga (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 83 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillen. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI). 

Conservation Needed
Given the pressures facing this region, the continued maintenance and management of this area will be essential to ensure the long-term survival of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further surveys are needed to determine whether the species occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 42 km2, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes. This assessment needs to be qualified on the basis that the species' distribution is extremely poorly-known and the recognized threats are highly localized around the known localities. If this species is found to occur more widely within protected puna grasslands, it will therefore warrant listing in a less threatened category.
habitat: This terrestrial species appears to be confined to wet puna grasslands and elfin forest habitats, and is not present in degraded areas. While it has been recorded from cloud forest within Manu, it is very rare in this habitat (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2011, April 2017). Males lack the vocal apparatus found in most frogs, and both sexes lack eardrums and internal ear structures (Halliday 2016). Breeding takes place by direct development. The female lays around 20 eggs in a nest of moss and guards them until they hatch into froglets, 6–7 mm long (Halliday 2016).
threats:
Grasslands along the western boundary of Manu National Park are being destroyed by the activities of smallholder farmers (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2011, April 2017), and this may represent the major threat to this species. Cattle grazing may also destroy the bunchgrasses where this frog occurs (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2011, April 2017). Fires set outside the reserve have also impacted the frog's habitat, and have destroyed at least one survey plot where the species was formerly abundant (A.
