threats: Agriculture and cattle farming are identified as threats in some regions of Paucartambo de Pasco (Lehr et al. 2004), and small-scale potato farming and grazing of sheep, alpacas and llamas have been observed at/near the area where this frog was found (M. Lundberg pers. comm. August 2011). However, the extent and impact of these potential threats on this frog are currently unknown.
population: The species is currently known only from the holotype, which was collected in March 2002 (Lehr et al. 2004). Extensive surveys conducted both at the type locality and neighbouring areas did not turn up any additional records, suggesting that it either has a very localized distribution, that it is very rare, or that it is difficult to find (M. Lundberg pers. comm. August 2011).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Cillapata, district of Paucartambo, Province of Pasco, Pasco Region, Peru, from 2,900–3,500 m asl (Lehr et al. 2004). Other congeners are known to have restricted ranges (M. Lundberg pers. comm. August 2011).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
No conservation actions are currently known for this species, and it is not known to occur in any protected areas (M. Lundberg pers. comm. August 2011). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It inhabits elfin forest, the transition zone between the lowland forests and the highland of the Andes (Chaparro et al. 2008). The single individual was found inside moss (Chaparro et al. 2008). It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: Little information is available on the threats to this species, however agriculture expansion into the buffer zone of the park may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Harvesting of moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It is known from only one female captured at the type locality in 2007 (Chaparro et al. 2008).
range: This species is known only from Santa Bárbara, Huancabamba District, Oxapampa Province, Pasco Region, on the eastern slopes of the Andes at 3,363 m asl in central Peru (Chaparro et al. 2008).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Needed
It occurs within the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species inhabits grasslands or “puna” areas in the highlands of the Andes (Chaparro et al. 2008). The holotype was collected during the dry season under a large stone (Chaparro et al. 2008). It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: Little information is available on the threats to this species, however agriculture expansion into the buffer zone of the park may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It is known from only one female captured at the type locality in 2007 (Chaparro et al. 2008).
range: This species is known only from Santa Bárbara, Huancabamba District, Oxapampa Province, Pasco Region, on the eastern slopes of the Peruvian Andes at 3,589 m asl (Chaparro et al. 2008).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Needed
It occurs within the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and may occur within the boundaries of the park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct)  given that there are no confirmed records of this species since 1994, despite intensive and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities. Recent reports (2016-2017) of this species in Ecuador might actually belong to another species, and therefore are considered uncertain until further studies are conducted. Should the species still be extant, it is likely that it survives in low numbers, possibly less than 50 mature individuals.
habitat: It has been found in paramo and subparamo habitats (tropical montane habitats above the treeline), notably under stones on dirt banks, within scrub covered with moss and lichen as well as in bromeliads found on the ground or in bushes, and around bamboo (Coloma et al. 2010). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to breed in flowing water by larval development, as with other congeners.
threats: In the past, the species suffered a large population reduction due to chytridiomycosis (Manzano-Pasquel 2014). At present, predation by trout (Martín-Torrijos et al. 2016) and cattle grazing are considered to be the major threats throughout its range.
population: The species had not been encountered since 1994 (Coloma et al. 2010) until it was re-recorded in 2016 and 2017 (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. April 2018). However, the recent records might correspond to an undescribed species as several differences have been observed (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. April 2018). Therefore, in the absence of confirmed records of this species and further evidence, it is reasonable to infer that the population size of this species is fewer than 50 individuals and due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing. In Peru, the last individual on record was seen in 1980 (Coloma et al. 2010) and this species is feared to be possibly extinct there.
range: This species is known from Provincias Loja and Zamora Chinchipe, in the southern Cordillera Oriental of Ecuador, and from the Cordillera de Huancabamba, Región Piura, in northern Peru (Coloma et al. 2010). Its known elevational range spans from 2,700–3,400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is known from Parque Nacional Podocarpus (Coloma et al. 2010). It is listed as Data Deficient (DD) in Peru according to the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI). In Ecuador, it is considered to be Critically Endangered.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective preservation of montane rainforest and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further field surveys are needed to determine if this species is still extant. Taxonomic studies are needed on the specimens recently observed in Ecuador to determine whether they belong to this species or an undescribed species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, despite having a relatively restricted range—extent of occurrence (EOO) of 317 km2—it appears to have a relatively high population density, there is no evidence of population declines, and no threats have been observed in its natural habitat in the Kosñipata valley in southern Peru.
habitat: This species occurs on steep slopes within montane cloud forest and montane scrub (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008). Preferred habitats appear to be within leaf litter, mosses and bamboos (Chusquea sp.) situated beneath forest with a closed canopy (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008). The closely related Bryophryne cophites breeds in terrestrial habitats by direct development, so it is presumed that this frog would have the same type of reproduction.
threats: There are no known serious threats affecting this species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2012).
population: During 10x10 m leaf litter surveys of forest in the Kosñipata Valley, 15.9 + 7.3 frogs/ha were observed during the 2007 dry season and 40.9 + 14.3 frogs/ha during the 2008 wet season (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008). There is currently no evidence of a decline in the number of individuals (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008), and the population is believed to be stable.
range: This species is known from four to five sites in the Kosñipata Valley, Kosñipata District, Paucartambo Province, Cusco Region, Peru, between 2,350–3,215 m asl (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008). The valley is situated on the eastern side of the Cordillera de Paucartambo, a mountain range between the larger Cordillera de Urubamba (to the north) and Cordillera de Vilcanota (to the south) (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008). Further surveys have been conducted in the area, but the species is not known outside of the Kosñipata valley, Cusco (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2012). Its EOO is 317 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the protected Manu National Park and Wayqecha Biological Station (Lehr and Catenazzi 2008).

Research Needed
More information is needed on its life history.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because, although the species is still reasonably widely distributed, much of its habitat is poorly protected and the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of at least 20–25% over a 10 year period (2015–2025) due to the high rate of habitat loss throughout much of this species' range in the Amazonian slopes of the Andes in Colombia, Ecuador and Peru as a result of logging, agricultural expansion, and mining activities.
habitat: This species inhabits lower montane rainforest and cloud forest, as well as, old-growth and secondary forests. Individuals have been found at night on the upper surfaces of leaves of trees or herbs, about 1.5–4.0 m above streams. Reproduction occur via larval development, where eggs are laid on vegetation and the larvae develop in streams. It is unclear as to whether or not it is tolerant of habitat disturbance.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation are the main threats to this species due to small-holder farming, logging, infrastructure development and human settlement. In southern Ecuador, mining activities are wreaking havoc on the species' habitat (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, RAISG 2020). At this stage, it is not clear whether or not this species has experienced declines within pristine habitats. A study aiming to predict glass frog distributions and the impact of deforestation in western Ecuador suggests that, in this country, almost half of the habitats suitable for this species have been deforested (Cisneros-Heredia 2008).
population: In Ecuador, it was never a very common species, but has disappeared from some historical sites. For example, Río Azuela in Napo, Ecuador, has been revisited several times since the 1970s without locating any individuals (Bustamante et al. 2005). There had been no observations in Napo Province since the 1970s, until the species was recorded in 2016 at Reserva Biológica Colonso Chalupas (M.H. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021). It has been recorded more frequently in southern Ecuador in recent years, with various observations in Morona Santiago from 2008 to 2016 (Ron et al. 2011, Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021). In the Cainarachi Valley in San Martín, Peru, three individuals were found over 20 person/days from 2004–2007 (von May et al. 2008), and was easy to observe during surveys in 2009–2011, despite being nearby a main road (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. 2018). In 2014, two individuals of this species were observed during surveys over 12 person/hours at Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo in San Martín (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. 2017). Considering the high rate of habitat loss throughout much of this species' range as a result of logging, agricultural expansion, and mining activities, the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of 20–25% over a 10 year period, from 2015–2025.
range: This species is known from Napo, Pastaza, Morona Santiago and Zamora Chinchipe provinces on the Amazonian slopes of the Ecuadorian Andes (Ron et al. 2011); from the regions of San Martín (Lamas, San Martín, and Rioja provinces; Duellman and Schulte 1993, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Wen et al. 2012; J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017), Cusco (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009), and most recently, Ucayali (Twomey et al. 2014), in Peru; and, most recently, from San José del Fragua municipality in Caquetá Department, Colombia (Díaz-Ricaurte and Guevara-Molina 2020). Its elevational range is from 500–1,740 m asl. It is possible that it may occur more widely, in the intervening area between known sites.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Ecuador, it occurs in Parque Nacional Sangay and Reserva Biológica Colonso Chalupas, Parque Nacional Cayambé-Coca, and Parque Nacional Llanganastes. In Peru, it is present in the Área de Conservación Regional Cordillera Escalera and Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. 2017). In addition, if it does occur in between the known Ecuadorian and Peruvian subpopulations, it could potentially occur in intervening protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Additional habitat protection, especially close to known sites, is needed.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into its distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, despite having a restricted extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,106 km<sup>2</sup>, there are no current threats to the species or its habitat, it occurs within protected areas and the population is believed to be stable.
habitat: This species inhabits upland forests near small streams. The type locality is located alongside a geothermal stream. It is more common in hot-water streams (> 90° C), but also occurs in lower abundances in cool-water streams. Most individuals have been found in the forest near a stream, however some frogs have been found in vegetation along sandy banks. Males call throughout the day, particularly after rain (Brown and Twomey 2009). A male has been observed transporting tadpoles.
threats: The Sierra del Divisor faces imminent threats from oil and mining development, road and pipeline construction and illegal logging. The potential construction of a road has been proposed for the last decade between Peru and Brazil, and if it goes ahead it may potentially cut through the middle of the species' range (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). There is currently no major threat to this species from the aforementioned threats, and while logging and agriculture are present in the area, it is not occurring in the protected areas where the species is found.
population: This species is fairly common where it is found (Brown and Twomey 2009, D. Vasquez pers. comm. in Perez-Peña et al. 2010) and its population status is relatively stable.
range: This species is known only from two sites in Loreto, Peru: in the Serrania de Contamana, at ca 240 m asl (Brown and Twomey 2009) and Rio Blanco Basin nearby and within the Zona Reservada Sierra del Divisor, at ca 250 m asl (Perez-Pena et al. 2010). It occurs at the foothills of isolated mountain ranges in lowland Amazonia in western Peru near the town of Contamana and the within the central range of the Sierra del Divisor on the Peru-Brazil border and it is likely to occur more widely throughout the foothills of the Serranía de Contamana, as well as other parts of the Sierra del Divisor, including within Brazil (Brown and Twomey 2009). Its known elevational range is 220–331 m asl (J. Brown pers. comm. August 2017) and its EOO is 2,106 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present in the buffer zone of the Sierra del Divisor National Park, established in 2015. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Research Needed
More information about this species' distribution, population status, life history, and threats are needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"\nListed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and remaining suitable habitat across its range."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,138 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat in the Cordillera Azul and in the upper Huallaga Valley of Peru.
habitat: This species occurs in undisturbed premontane forests and secondary premontane forest, particularly in habitats adjacent to streams. During the day, adults tend to hide amongst streamside boulders. Calling activity seems to peak during late evening. Males call from elevated positions on boulders, although courtship and oviposition appears to take place on the ground in the leaf litter. Clutches contain 22–44 eggs and are guarded by males (M. Pepper pers. comm. in Brown and Twomey 2009) and typically hatch in ca 18 days. Tadpoles have been found in shallow eddies or streamside pools, often left by receding water levels. Clay-bottomed streams appear to be most commonly used, and tadpoles will often submerge themselves under the sediment. Tadpoles complete development in as little as 5–6 weeks (Brown and Twomey 2009).
threats: There has been some habitat loss in the Cordillera Azul and in the upper Huallaga Valley caused by agricultural conversion to coffee, coca and banana plantations (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017), which may be causing local declines.
population: It is locally abundant around its riverine habitat (Brown and Twomey 2009). The population appears to be continuous and therefore is not considered to be severely fragmented. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from throughout the upper Huallaga Valley, south of Río Huayabama (near Huicungo) to the southern border of San Martín, Peru, at elevations from 380–1,000 m asl. While most of the known localities are primarily on the eastern side of Río Huallaga (i.e., the western slope of the Cordillera Azul), it also occurs on the western side of Río Huallaga (i.e., the eastern slope of the Andes) in San Francisco and Huicungo, and likely occurs throughout the area between these two sites (Brown and Twomey 2009). It occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,138 km2.
useTrade: Smuggling has not been a significant problem with this species, due to a legal and sustainable captive breeding program by Understory Enterprises (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species occurs in high Andean puna and can be found inside bunches of Peruvian feather grass (Stipa ichu) or inside moss. Similar to its congeners, it is likely that this species breeds in terrestrial habitats by direct development. Whether this species is tolerant of disturbed habitats remains unclear.
threats: A road was constructed at the type locality increasing human activity in the area (Chaparro et al. 2007), but at the same time a private conservation area was created in the same area (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). In March 2008, a syntopic anuran was found to be infected with the pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Lehr and Catenazzi 2010). The pathogen has yet to be reported from this species, but it has been found to infect individuals of the related species, Bryophryne cophites (Catenazzi et al. 2011). However, direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affected by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the six specimens that constitute the type series.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Abra Málaga, Province of La Convención, Cusco Region in southern Peru (Lehr and Catenazzi 2010). It occurs at 4,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is found within the Abra Málaga Private Conservation Area, a private reserve between Málaga Chico and Río San Luis, established in 2007. It has also been recorded in the buffer zone of the Machu Picchu Historical Sanctuary.

Research Needed
More research is needed about this species' distribution, population status and natural history.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species occurs in the high Andean puna, where it is found inside large layers of moss or between shrub roots. Males have been observed calling from inside the moss during day (10:00–16:00 hr). In March, females have been found with mature, unpigmented, cream-colored ovarian eggs and convoluted oviducts, suggesting reproductive activity (Lehr and Catenazzi 2010). Similar to its congeners, it is likely that this species breeds in terrestrial habitats by direct development.
threats: It is known from a remote site where there are no direct threats to the species. Direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affect by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species. The type series is comprised of seven individuals, however the calls of many males have been heard from the valley opposite from the type locality (Lehr and Catenazzi 2010).
range: This species is only known from the type locality: along the road between Vilcabamba and Pampaconas in La Convención Province, Cusco Region in southern Peru (Lehr and Catenazzi 2010). It occurs at elevations from 3,800–3,850 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 614 km<sup>2</sup>, it is currently known to occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the eastern slopes of the Andes in southern Ecuador and northern Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits primary and secondary tropical lowland and montane forest near water sources (Twomey et al. 2014, Páez-Rosales and Pinto 2017). Individuals have been found perched on vegetation along a edge of streams and rivers, up to 5 m from the ground (Twomey et al. 2014, Páez-Rosales and Pinto 2017). This species likely occupies other streams in undisturbed forest of the surrounding mountains (Twomey et al. 2014). A clutch of 34 eggs was found on a leaf at 2.20 m overhanging a stream (Páez-Rosales and Pinto 2017). Reproduction is presumably by larval development, whereby eggs are deposited on leaves and larvae drop off into water bodies and continue to develop.
threats: There is ongoing habitat loss throughout its range due to agriculture, small-scale logging, the construction of roads, and human settlement. Mining is a serious threat in the Cordillera del Condor (Mazabanda et al. 2018) and the Reserva Natural Maycu in Ecuador is currently under concession for mining (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
population: Little is known about the population status of this species. In addition, to the type series collected in 2010 from La Oliva in Amazonas, Peru (Twomey et al. 2014), the species is known from 12 specimens collected in Reserva Natural Maycu, Zamora Chinchipe, Ecuador in 2017 (Páez-Rosales and Pinto 2017).
range: This species is only known from the type locality: near the village of La Oliva past the village of Muyo (ca 49 km N from Bagua), Amazonas Region, Peru (Twomey et al. 2014), and from Reserva Natural Maycu, Zamora-Chinchipe Province, Ecuador (Páez-Rosales and Pinto 2017). It probably occurs in intervening areas between the two known sites. It occurs at elevations between 680–1,220 m asl. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 614 km2, which represents two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Known records are outside of the national systems of protected areas, but the species has been recorded within the Reserva Natural Maycu (community reserve) in Ecuador.

Conservation Needed
Improved management of the existing reserve to preserve intact forest and expansion of effective forest protection are needed for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More research about the population size and trends, distribution, natural history, and threats is needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2 because of the potential devastating impact of landslides in the only valley from which it is known. The very restricted distribution and small population size make this species vulnerable to stochastic events.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits fast-flowing streams in montane forests. Males call at night from foliage hanging over open water, where mating occurs. Eggs are deposited by females on top of leaves above water in fast-flowing sections of streams and, upon hatching, tadpoles drop into the water below (Catenazzi et al. 2012). Egg clutches contain between 35 and 45 eggs (Catenazzi et al. 2012).
threats:
Amphibian communities in upper Manu National Park have collapsed over the past decade, during an epidemic of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis that is the likely cause of the local extinction of most sympatric species of glass frogs (Catenazzi 2012). In addition to other glass frogs, two species of harlequin toads, other toad species, several treefrogs and other stream-breeding species have vanished from the otherwise intact montane forests of Manu National Park (Catenazzi 2012). The presence of B. dendrobatidis has not been detected in any of the specimens belonging to this species, collected in 2009 (n=1) and 2010 (n=4) (Catenazzi et al. 2011), and it does not appear that the species declined during the chytrid outbreak in the mid- to late-1990s (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).

About 500 m from the two creeks, massive landslides have destroyed other creeks in the Kosñipata Valley. These landslides are more common when roads are built in steep valleys, such as this one, and present a likely future threat to the species.
population: The species was first collected and recorded in January 1999 (Catenazzi and Rodríguez 2001). Intensive sampling of amphibian communities, along the elevational gradient of the Kosñipata Valley, over the past decade consistently revealed the presence of this species in only two adjacent high-elevation streams (Catenazzi et al. 2011, 2012). Its population status is unknown.
range: This species is only known from two streams along the road in the the Kosñipata Valley in upper Manu National Park, on the Amazonian slopes of southeastern Andean Peru, where its altitudinal range is 2,750–2,800 m asl. This species appears to occupy a narrow elevational and geographical range in southern Peru (Catenazzi et al. 2012) and it is not known whether the species occurs more widely, but it is the only record of a Centrolene species in southern Peru (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km2, based on the single known location, and this may be an overestimate.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Manu National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,231 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is adaptable to habitat disturbance, and it has a presumed large population.
habitat: This species is found in a wide variety of habitat types, from highly disturbed areas to primary forest. Males call from the upper surfaces of leaves and females deposit eggs on the upper sides of leaves along streams. Clutch sizes range from 16–38 eggs. In one stream in Abra Tangara, a small number of solitary males were heard calling once every 10–15 min, while in a nearby site 3.6 km south, males called in dense aggregations (Twomey et al. 2014).
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"It is an adaptable species that is unlikely to be facing any significant threats."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">It is an adaptable species that is unlikely to be facing any significant threats.
population: This species is commonly found in a wide variety of habitat types. Among known sites, the highest density occurs at 1,120 m asl, near Abra Tangara, in a stream flowing through a cattle pasture with low bushes growing along the edges. Its population is considered to be stable.
range: This species has been recorded in the Regions of San Martín and Amazonas in Peru, from 250–1,150 m asl. Prior to 2011, this species was only known from northern San Martín (Twomey et al. 2014), however a record from the Cordillera de Kampanquis in Amazonas Region extended its known distribution ca 400 km NW from the type locality (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012).
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no records of this species being utilized."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area and Cordillera Azul National Park.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 111 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in a two threat defined locations, and there is an ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals primarily due to chytridiomycosis.
habitat: This species inhabits the montane scrub and cloud forest, as well as the ridges of steep slopes covered with Andean alder, shrubs, terrestrial mosses, lycophites, and lichens. Males vocalize during the night from grasses, shrubs, trees, and terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads (Duellman et al. 2011). Reproduction occurs by direct development with eggs hatching directly into froglets. One female was reported to give birth to 17 froglets, while another female was found to contain eight oviductal eggs (Duellman et al. 2011).
threats: It appears that subpopulations have declined from the mid 90s to early 2000s, when an outbreak of chytridiomycosis caused declines of several sympatric species within the region (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been reported from the Kosñipata Valley and has been confirmed in one juvenile specimen of this species in January 2009 (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Fourteen other specimens captured in July 2007, February and October 2008, and February 2009 were negative for the fungus (Catenazzi et al. 2011). In another study, four specimens collected from the Kosñipata Valley tested positive for Bd (prevalence = 25%), though all frogs had low infection loads (Burkart 2015). Previous work exposed both G. nebulanastes and G. excubitor to high numbers of zoospores in Bd susceptibility trials. The results indicated that G. nebulanastes is highly susceptible to chytridiomycosis (16.6% survival; Burkart et al. 2017, Catenazzi et al. 2017).
population: This species is fairly common, and surveys between 1996-1999, 2008-2009 and 2012-2016 repeatedly recorded this species within its known distribution, although there appear to be slight declines in subpopulations due mainly to chytridiomycosis (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2017, Catenazzi et al. 2017). Records for juvenile and adult specimens captured in the field (n=33) indicates that this species is most abundant between 2,600–2,800 m asl (Duellman et al. 2011). During June–August 2012, eight individuals were collected along the Paucartambo-Shintuya road in the eastern slopes of the Cordillera de Paucartambo, Cusco (Burkart 2015). Visual encounter surveys during May–July 2014 found 36 individuals in the area surrounding Wayqecha Biological Station, on the mountainside of the Kosñipata Valley just outside of Manu National Park (Burkart 2015).
range: This species is known from the upper Río Kosñipata Valley on the northeast slope of Abra Acjanaco in the Cordillera Oriental in the Region of Cusco in Manu National Park, in southern Peru (Duellman et al. 2011). There are also records from the Río Marcapata Valley, about 70 km ESE of the Kosñipata Valley (Duellman and Trueb 2015), however these require genetic confirmation to verify their identity (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017) and for the purposes of this assessment these records are mapped, but excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation. It could occur more widely, however the adjacent area to its known distribution has not been surveyed yet (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs between 2,000–3,300 m asl, at two threat-defined locations, and the EOO of its current known range is 111 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Manu National Park. 

Conservation Needed
Continuous monitoring for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis infections, as well as the establishment of a management plan to mitigate the transmission and impact of chytridiomycosis is recommended.

Research Needed
More research about the population size and trends, distribution, natural history, and threats is needed. Given that chytrid has been found in this species, populations should be monitored closely to determine the infection dynamic and, if possible, ameliorate disease outbreaks and potential population crashes.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable because it is known from only a single location, it has a restricted area of occupancy, and it may be prone to the effects of stochastic events within a very short time period in an uncertain future."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because it is known from only a single location and it may be prone to the effects of chytrid or stochastic events within a very short time period in an uncertain future.
habitat: The type locality consists of wet puna and subpáramo grasslands (Lehr and Catenazzi 2011). This species produces eggs that hatch as tadpoles in the brood pouch. Female specimens contained between 45–49 eggs in their brood pouch (Lehr and Catenazzi 2011, Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats: There is currently no anthropogenic disturbance threatening the population within Río Abiseo National Park. The fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, which causes chytridiomycosis in amphibians and has been linked to population declines of anuran species in the Peruvian Andes (Catenazzi et al. 2011, Seimon et al. 2007), has been detected in a subpopulation of Atelopus near Río Abiseo National Park (Venegas et al. 2008). The presence of this fungus could pose a threat to Gastrotheca phelloderma within the park, therefore the species may be prone to the effects of stochastic events within a very short time period in an uncertain future.
population: The type series is based on 29 specimens that were collected between 1989 and 1999 at two localities in Río Abiseo National Park. The population status is unknown.
range: This species is known from two localities in the Andes of northern Peru, Pampa del Cuy and Alpamachay, both within Río Abiseo National Park in San Martín Region (Lehr and Catenazzi 2011). It has an altitudinal range from 3,380–3,470 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 369 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Río Abiseo National Park. 

Conservation Needed
Continued management of the buffer zone of the national park is needed to mitigate encroachment of agriculture into the habitat where this species occurs.

Research Needed
More research about the population size and trends, distribution, natural history, and threats is needed. Given that chytrid has been detected in Rio Abiseo National Park, the population should be monitored to determine the potential infection dynamic which could be a threat to the conservation of this species (Lehr and Catenazzi 2011).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 7,061 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in less than 10 threat-defined locations, there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in some areas of its range due to gold mining activities, continuing decline in number of subpopulations, and ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals with chytrid mainly implicated in these declines.
habitat: This species is found along creeks in primary and secondary cloud forest and in ditches along roads. Males are often heard calling in these habitats. Breeding occurs in streams by larval development.
threats:
Chytrid appears to be a threat to the species, but the extinction risk varies locally: surveys have found the species to be present in some localities and extirpated in others (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). A dead adult was found between Capira and Mamabamba, Marcapata valley. Tests for infection by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) were positive for adult individuals from San Juan del Oro area and Marcapata Valley (Jaime Bosch. pers. comm. In: Köhler et al. 2010). In 2013, this species was collected from Kosñipata Valley near Manu National Park; among 21 individuals tested, 65% were infected by Bd, 40% by Ranavirus, and 30% were co-infected (Warne et al. 2016).

Additionally, the species is threatened by gold mining occurring within its range and there are also planned hydroelectric stations in the lower Marcapata valley in the same areas where the gold mining is taking place (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: This species is fairly common and tadpoles were found to be abundant at some sites (Köhler et al. 2010). However, due to outbreaks of chytrid during the mid- to late-1990s many subpopulations of the species have disappeared from creeks where it formerly common (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). There is an ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals due to primarily to chytrid. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat the population is decreasing.
range: The species is known from the Regions of Cusco and Puno, Peru, between 1,097 and 1,975 m asl. It occurs at less than 10 threat-defined locations and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,061 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Manu National Park, Amarakaeri Communal Reserve, and in the Bahuaja Sonene National Park buffer zone.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threat of chytrid.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 92 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to be common, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, and it is expected to occur more widely.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits cloud forests and is primarily active on the ground during the rainy season (January–February). Males call from the leaf litter. Its breeding biology is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development similar to its congeners.
threats: The elevational range overlaps with areas where the pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has caused extirpation of other species, but this species does not appear to have declined (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is common in the buffer zone of Manu National Park, where it occurs continuously through its known elevational range.
range: This species is known only from the Kosñipata Valley, Cusco Region, Peru (Padial et al. 2012), but it is likely to occur more widely. It occupies an altitudinal range from 1,422–2,950 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 92 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within Manu National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species inhabits humid montane forest. The holotype specimen was found on the forest floor at night during the rainy season, where several large, orange ovarian eggs could be observed through the ventral skin (Padial et al. 2012). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"The threats to this species are unknown."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">The threats to this species are unknown.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends of this recently described species, as it is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from the type locality on the slopes of Cordillera Vilcabamba, in the Río Kimbiri Valley, which is part of the Río Apurimac Basin, Provincia La Convención, Cusco Region, Peru (Padial et al. 2012). It has been recorded at 1,400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Ashaninka, Otishi, Machiguenga Buffer Zone, however its presence within the boundary of any protected area remains unknown. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since it has only recently been described, and there is still very little information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This terrestrial species occurs in primary cloud forests and can be found in the leaf litter and under moss (Lehr et al. 2012). Since frogs were found in the afternoon it is believed that the species is diurnal. Similar to its congeners, it is presumed to breed by direct development. Both known specimens were adult gravid females (Lehr et al. 2012).
threats: The species is currently only known from within Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, which is well-protected; however, if the species occurs outside of the park, agriculture expansion into the park's buffer zone may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). The Yanachaga mountain chain is one the remaining large forested areas in this region of Peru, and there is increasing human pressure to convert the land for agricultural activities, for example, "Rocoto" (chili pepper) plantations, and selective logging inside the buffer zone of the park.
population: Population information for this species is scarce and trends are unknown. It is known only from the two adult females which constitute the type series.
range: This species is only known from the type locality: a summit of a mountain ridge of the Cordillera Yanachaga within the Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, District of Huancabamba, Province of Oxapampa, Pasco Region, Peru (Lehr et al. 2012). It occurs from 2,900–3,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
All known localities are within Yanachaga Chemillén National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further surveys are necessary to determine whether this species occurs outside of the type locality, especially outside of the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Considering it has a very restricted distribution, researchers should keep this in mind when collecting specimens of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic status, extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits high altitude grasslands of the Cordillera Oriental. All known individuals have been found under stones during the rainy season (March). Similar to its congeners, it is presumed to breed by direct development. Several females contained mature eggs which had an average diameter of 4.3 mm (Mamani and Malqui 2014).
threats: Its habitat is threatened by mining activities and increasing human activity in the area (Mamani and Malqui 2014). Given its high elevational range, new regimes of humidity and temperature caused by climate change are likely a threat to this species.
population: Population information for this species is scarce and trends are unknown, however it appears to be a small population (Mamani and Malqui 2014). It is known only from the six specimens collected in 2011 that constitute the type series.
range: This species is only known from Canchapalca, District of Comas, Province of Concepción, Junín Region, in the central Peruvian Andes. It has an altitudinal range from 4,205–4,490 m asl (Mamani and Malqui 2014). It is expected to have a restricted distribution as known for the genus.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions 
This species is not known from any protected area.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More research about the population size and trends, distribution, natural history, and threats is needed. Lehr and von May (2017) highlighted morphological similarities with Pristimantis attenboroughi and argued that genetic research is necessary to determine whether the current placement of this species in Phrynopus is justified (Lehr and von May 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since it has only recently been described, and there is still very little information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species occurs in transitional habitat between cloud forest and wet puna. The type locality is a slightly swampy plain covered by scattered bushes, small isolated trees, ferns, moss, and lichens. The single known specimen was an adult female found at 15:30 under a moss layer at approximately 10–15 cm depth. The female was gravid (small unpigmented eggs) and guarding a clutch consisting of nine terrestrial eggs and was partially sitting on them (Lehr et al. 2012). Two days after collection the eggs, three froglets hatched. The fact that the female was gravid, but was also guarding eggs suggests that the reproduction cycle is fast (Lehr et al. 2012). Calling males were heard by day in the leaf litter and moss layer (Lehr et al. 2012).
threats: The species is currently only known from within Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, which is well-protected; however, if the species occurs outside of the park, agriculture expansion into the park's buffer zone may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). The Yanachaga mountain chain is one the remaining large forested areas in this region of Peru, and there is increasing human pressure to convert the land for agricultural activities, for example, "Rocoto" (chili pepper) plantations, and selective logging inside the buffer zone of the park.
population:
Population information for this species is scarce and trends are unknown. It is known only from the single adult female and three hatchlings, collected
as eggs with the holotype, which constitute the type series (Lehr et al. 2012).
range: The species is only known from the type locality: a summit of a mountain ridge of Cordillera Yanachaga in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, District of Huancabamba, Province of Oxapampa, Department of Pasco, Peru (Lehr et al. 2012). It occurs at 3,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs within Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further surveys are necessary to determine whether this species occurs outside of the type locality, especially outside of the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Considering it has a very restricted distribution, researchers should keep this in mind when collecting specimens of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Its phylogenetic relationship with Phrynopus tribulosus and P. nicoleae is currently being investigated investigated (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species presumably inhabits remnants of humid montane forest and presumably reproduces by direct development, similar to its congeners. Little information on this species ecology and life history is known.
threats: The main threat to this species is habitat loss due to agricultural expansion. However, given the lack of recent surveys, it is not known whether and to what extent this threat could be impacting on this species and its habitats.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the two specimens that constitute the type series. It has not been observed since it was last collected in 1975, however this may be an artifact the lack of survey effort (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known only from two localities on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Oriental just north of the Río Huallaga in central Peru, at elevations of 2,740–2,800 m asl. It is expected to have a restricted distribution (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. Further survey work is needed to understand the habitat requirements of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This nocturnal, arboreal species inhabits cloud forests in Cordillera Huancabamba, of the eastern versant of the Andes in northern Peru. Tree species at the type locality are covered with abundant moss and epiphytes. All specimens have been encountered at night during the rainy season, perching on leaves and branches from 10–250 cm above the ground. Reproduction is likely to occur by direct development.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"No major threats to this species have been identified."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is some deforestation in the buffer zone of Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe due to encroaching agriculture, however it is unknown whether this species is likely to be threatened by these activities.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species. It is known only from the nine specimens that constitute the type series, collected in 2009 over 30 person-hours (Chaparro et al. 2012, J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. March 2018), and five additional specimens collected at the type locality in August 2013 over 18 person-hours (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017).
range: The recently described (2012) species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality in Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe: Quebrada del Vino, Namballe District, San Ignacio Province, Cajamarca Region, on the eastern versant of the Andes in northern Peru (Chaparro et al. 2012). It occurs at elevations between 2,745–3,150 m asl. It is unknown if it is expected to occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, and threatening processes.<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">
habitat: This species inhabits the humid puna on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Occidental (Venegas and Duellman 2012). All specimens have been found at the base of bunch grass or under rocks near small streams during the day (Venegas and Duellman 2012). It is unknown whether it can tolerate habitat disturbance. Reproduction presumably occurs by direct development.
threats: The destruction of the natural habitats in Cañaris by the local people has been continuous since the 1970s; however, the general area is currently under new human pressure because of mineral exploration (Venegas and Duellman 2012). Although some large patches of cloud forest still remain, the humid puna is strongly overgrazed by cattle and is frequently burned (Venegas and Duellman 2012).
population: It is known from the type series comprised of eight adult and two juvenile specimens collected in 2007, as well as some additional specimens collected from the type locality and stored in the Museo de Historia Natural in Lima (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). The type locality of Cañaris has been poorly explored herpetologically and, thus there is little information available on the population status and trends of this species; however due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This recently described (2012) species is known only from the type locality of Cañaris, Provincia de Ferreñafe, Región Lambayeque on the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Occidental in northwestern Peru, at 3,596 m asl (Venegas and Duellman 2012). It is unknown whether this species is thought to be restricted to its type locality or likely to occur more widely.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no records of this species being utilized."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection at the type locality is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

habitat: This species inhabits moist lowland rainforest. Specimens have been found on vegetation during the night, up to 1.7 m from the ground. Reproduction is likely to occur by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: Threats to this species at the type locality are not known, although in general there is regional loss of habitat due to agricultural activities.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the two specimens that constitute the type series. There have been no further surveys to search for the species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality in the upper Amazon Basin in central Peru: Villa América, Huancabamba Province, Pasco Region (Morales 2007). It occurs at 330 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has not been recorded in any protected area, however it may occur in the nearby Yanesha Communal Reserve or San Matias-San Carlos Protection Forest.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.
