useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection at the type locality is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Following the Red List Guidelines, a precautionary approach is taken by considering the lower bound estimate of the extent of occurrence (EOO). Based on the best supporting evidence, this species qualifies for Critically Endangered because its estimated EOO is 16 km2, it occurs at one threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat due to damming and regulation of streams, large-scale infrastructure projects, and contamination from mining and agriculture, as well as, an ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals likely due to chytridiomycosis. Should this species be recorded more widely than currently known, it may warrant listing in a less threatened category.
habitat: The type locality is a high-elevation stream c. 10 m wide, with a rocky substrate that alternates pebble and gravel pools with small waterfalls and riffles, and is surrounded by puna (Catenazzi et al. 2015). As with other congeners, it is presumed to breed by larval development in water. During a field study, tadpoles were observed in various developmental stages, suggesting that the species is breeding successfully over extended periods of time, including during the dry season (Catenazzi et al. 2015).
threats: The pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been detected from individuals at the type locality. In 2012, the prevalence of infection was 53.5% for tadpoles (n = 43), 40.0% for adults (n = 5) and the only juvenile found was infected (Catenazzi et al. 2015). Additional threats to the species include the damming and regulation of streams, large-scale infrastructure projects (reservoirs, pipelines, roads, etc.) and contamination from mining and agriculture (Catenazzi et al. 2015). The stream at the type locality is at the crossing with the highway connecting the coastal Panamerican highway to the city of Ayacucho and c. 500 m downstream of the type locality, the stream has been dammed to build a reservoir. The habitat downstream of the reservoir is not suitable for this species, although the reach upstream extends up to 4,300 m asl and could be used by the species for reproduction (Catenazzi et al. 2015).
population: The population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, and there is likely an ongoing decline of mature individuals due to chytridiomycosis. In October 2012, three observers searched 100 m of a stream reach for 60 min and encountered 43 tadpoles, one juvenile, and seven adults (Catenazzi et al. 2015).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Chicchobamba, a stream tributary of the Huaytará river, which is in the upper drainage of the Pisco River watershed, Huaytará Province, Region of Huancavelica, in central Peru, where it occurs at 3,900 m asl. In the case of extent of occurrence (EOO), the lower bound is 16 km2, representing a minimum convex polygon of the species' estimated geographic range based on known records and immediate suitable habitat. The valley of the type locality and adjacent valleys are dominated by arid environments that likely limit dispersal of this species, thus it is very likely that it is endemic to the upper Pisco watershed and adjacent river basins (Catenazzi et al. 2015). Hence, it is thought that this species is unlikely to have an EOO greater than 20,000 km2 (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: Aquatic species from this genus are known to be harvested in large numbers for human consumption and medicinal uses, and is often sold at local markets (Lehr 2005).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is recommended, complemented by more general actions to mitigate the effects of habitat loss from damming and infrastructure development projects.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population size, ecology, and threats. Further studies should monitor infection and assess the susceptibility of this species to chytridiomycosis (Catenazzi et al. 2015).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: All individuals have been found on low herbaceous vegetation growing along vertical rock walls within waterfall spray zones in a tropical lowland forest (Twomey et al. 2014). Individuals have been detected only in the spray zone of waterfalls. Males call from horizontal branches and the upper surfaces of broad-leaf herbs, 2–4 m above the ground. In captivity, a pair deposited 18 pigmented eggs in a smoky, viscous jelly along the lower margins of a leaf placed in the tank. Two additional clutches at the waterfall corresponding to this species were found on the margins of the underside of a leaf, in a smoky jelly approximately 2 m above the surface of the water.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. It is currently only known from within the boundaries of Área de Conservación Regional Cordillera Escalera, which affords it some level of protection.
population: Little is known about this species' population status, however it appears to be locally rare. Despite 12 nights working a large section of the stream, this species was only found near waterfalls. In addition, the lower parts of this stream had been extensively searched between the years of 2004-2006 and this species was never encountered (E. Twomey and J.L. Brown pers. obs. in Twomey et al. 2014).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: a stream near the village of San Jose in the Cainarachi Valley near Tarapoto, in the Department of San Martín, Peru (Twomey et al. 2014). It occurs at an elevation of 610 m asl. It is unknown whether it is thought to be restricted to the vicinity of the type locality or whether it might occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is found within Área de Conservación Regional Cordillera Escalera.

Research Needed
More research about the population status, distribution, natural history and threats is needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This diurnal species inhabits small streams with rocky bottoms in lowland evergreen forests. Males usually vocalize at night on or under rocks. Specimens have been collected from a 1 m wide rocky stream in an area with primary vegetation. Eggs are deposited in the litter of the forest, attended by the male until they hatch. Tadpoles climb onto the back of the male and are transported to water. Tadpoles usually inhabit quiet ponds within streams. One male has been found carrying eight tadpoles on his back. Three females contained, on average, 21 oocytes (range 15-30) with an average diameter of 2.39 mm (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).
threats: There is some localized habitat loss due to general human activities such as logging and agriculture (crops, livestock).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species, but the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat. In March 2007, 23 individuals from the type locality of Reserva de Bosque Tropical Fundación Hola Vida, Pastaza, Ecuador, and during July 2007, 17 individuals were collected from the same site (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).
range: This species is known from elevations between 200–1,000 m asl in the eastern foothills of the Eastern Cordillera in the Andes in Ecuador (provinces of Pastaza and Morona Santiago) and northern Peru (Amazonas and Loreto Regions).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Tuntanain Communal Reserve and Zona Reservada Santiago-Comaina in Peru (Catenazzi and Venegas 2012). It has not been recorded in any protected areas in Ecuador. It is listed as Near Threatened in Ecuador. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,799 km2, it is considered common, has a presumed large and stable population, and it is tolerant of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species is commonly found in open areas of secondary forest and in agricultural areas, including pasture lands or irrigation canals. Tadpoles, juveniles and adults are commonly found in creeks or streams along farms or towns, and are absent in streams inside primary forest and are common in areas of human impact (Chavez et al. 2012, E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Adults are active at night in lower vegetation next to water or in the water (Lehr et al. 2010). Males have been observed calling around stagnant water. Tadpoles of have been found in a swampy, slow-flowing creek on a cattle pasture and in ponds during February and July (Lehr et al. 2010, Lehr et al. 2011). A captive pair laid about 440 eggs in several small clutches attached to substrate below the water’s surface (Lehr et al. 2010).
threats: Within the range of this species there is ongoing agriculture, water pollution and human settlement, however this species appears to be tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017), and therefore is likely not threatened by these activities.
population: This species is considered to be common and occurs in impacted areas (Chavez et al. 2012, E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Its population is considered to be stable (A. Angulo and E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from several localities in the central Peruvian Regions of Pasco and Junín, from 1,225–2,080 m asl (Lehr et al. 2010). Its estimated EOO is 2,799 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, Pampa Hermosa National Sanctuary, and Pui Pui Protected Forest. 
 
Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 13,252 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits flooded areas in secondary forests and is generally found perched on vegetation 50–80 cm above the ground (Caminer and Ron 2014). It presumably breeds by larval development in streams or pools.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat degradation due to human activities, particularly agriculture and livestock (Caminer and Ron 2014).
population: It is known from the six males and two females from Ecuador that comprise the type series and one specimen from Loreto, Peru. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species has been recorded in Napo and Pastaza Provinces in the central Amazon of Ecuador and Loreto Region in Amazon Basin of northern Peru (Caminer and Ron 2014, Ortiz and Ron 2018). Some specimens collected from Madre de Dios and Ucayali Regions in southern Peru resemble this species (Padial et al. 2016), however they are thought to belong to an undescribed species from Clade G in the phylogeny provided by Caminer and Ron (2014) (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. May 2018) and are excluded from this species' distribution map. It occurs at elevations ranging from 180–420 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,252 km2, and it occurs at 10 or fewer threat-defined locations. It is likely to have a wider distribution (Caminer and Ron 2014).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Parque Nacional Yasuní in Ecuador. In Ecuador, it is listed as Endangered (Ortiz and Ron 2018).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited—extent of occurrence (EOO) of 11,873 km<sup>2</sup>—the species is common, threats are localised and not considered to be causing declines, and it occurs in a well-protected area.
habitat: This species inhabits humid montane forests and cloud forests. An adult female was found along the Santo Domingo stream on a rock 1.5 m above ground (Padial et al. 2008). An adult male has been observed calling close to a small waterfall (Padial et al. 2008). Its breeding biology is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development similar to its congeners.
threats: The elevational range overlaps with areas where the pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has caused extirpation of other species, but this species does not appear to have declined (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). As with most Andean cloud forest there is ongoing habitat loss, however, it is considered localized at present and not severe enough to be causing declines.
population: The species is very common at the type locality and locally common throughout its range (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. October 2017). Its population is considered to be stable at present.
range: This species is known from the eastern and western versants of the Cordillera Carabaya, in the Regions of Puno and Cusco, Peru. It is known from four localities between 1,050 and 2,000 m asl (Padial et al. 2008, Catenazzi et al. 2013). The most distant known localities are the Districts of Limbani (Puno) and Kosñipata (Cusco), separated by an airline distance of ca 230 km. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 11,873 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Manu National Park and the Bahuaja Tambopata buffer zone.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, has a presumed large population, and no major threats have been identified.
habitat: This species occurs in primary cloud forest and is most frequently encountered at night on leaves of herbaceous vegetation or low bushes in clearings or at the forest edge (Lynch and Duellman 1980). It has also been recorded from secondary forest and a coffee plantation (Koch et al. 2018). It breeds by direct development, but the site of egg deposition is not known.
threats: Habitat loss due to cattle grazing and small-scale agriculture is considered a localized threat, but not a major threat (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
population: In Ecuador, it is an uncommon species. In Cordillera del Cóndor, it is considered to be common. The population trend is not well understood; however d<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">ue to localized declines in the extent and quality of habitat, some subpopulations may be decreasing.
range: This species has been reported on the Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental and Cordillera del Cóndor from Sucumbíos to Zamora-Chinchipe Provinces, Ecuador (Lynch and Duellman 1980, Tobar-Suárez 2009, Almendáriz et al. 2014, Frenkel et al. 2016, Brito et al. 2017). It is also found in Cordillera del Cóndor, Cajamarca Region, northern Peru (Duellman and Lehr 2009, Koch et al. 2018). Further taxonomic studies are needed to clarify the status of the southern subpopulations (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). It is found from 1,000–1,910 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Ecuador, its distribution range overlaps several large protected areas. It is not recorded from any protected areas in Peru. In Ecuador, it is considered to be Near Threatened. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to determine if the species is continuously distributed between known records in Ecuador and Peru. Further research is needed to clarify the taxonomy of the southern subpopulations, as well as on this species' population status and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This terrestrial species occupies cloud forest habitats. Individuals may be found perched on low vegetation. It is not known if this species is tolerant of modified habitats. It breeds by direct development.
threats: In 2008, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) was detected in this species at Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park, with a prevalence of 4.4% (n=87) (Catenazzi et al. 2011). In 2009, an adult specimen collected from the same area tested positive for Bd infection and one juvenile tested positive (Catenazzi et al. 2011) and in 2013, of eight individuals sampled from Kosñipata Valley, 12.5% were infected by Bd and 37.5% by Ranavirus (Warne et al. 2016). While chytridiomycosis is the probable cause of severe population declines in amphibian assemblages of the upper Parque Nacional Manu (Catenazzi et al. 2011), this species in particular does not appear to be susceptible to the disease (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017, Catenezzi et al. 2017). In 2011, specimens from Caballero, Bolivia tested positive for Bd (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017).
population: The subpopulation in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Manu has been surveyed in 1999, 2008-2009, 2012-2016 and appears to be stable (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). In Bolivia, the species is regularly recorded and subpopulations appears to be stable, although they are found at lower densities compared to the early 2000s (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the southern part of the Cordillera Oriental in the regions of Cusco, Puno and Madre de Dios, Peru, south into the Bolivian Departments of La Paz, Cochabamba, and Santa Cruz (Duellman 1978, Duellman and Lehr 2009, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). It occurs at elevations from 1,180–2,750 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in Parque Nacional Manu and Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri in Peru, and Parques Nacionales Carrasco, Amboró, Madidi, Pilón Lajas, and Cotapata in Bolivia.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,849 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two to five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in southern Pacific Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits montane scrubland and grassland habitats. It has also been recorded in cultivated areas dominated by onion (Allium cepa), celery (Apium graveolens), and alfalfa (Medicago sativa; Paniura Palma 2016), but is not thought to be tolerant of habitat modification (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018). Reproduction occurs by larval development, during the wet season, in temporary ponds and slow flowing streams. Tadpoles have been observed in a slow-moving, shallow temporary stream with a sandy substrate (Aguilar and Gamarra 2004).
threats:
The main threats are agriculture and grazing livestock (including llamas, alpacas, sheep), predation by exotic trout, and the pollution of water bodies. It is possible this species is also harvested for local consumption.

Within Salinas and Aguada Blanca National Reserve, the species is found only at a single spring, in the town of Cabrerías. If this water body is modified or altered, this small subpopulation would be in imminent danger (Gutiérrez et al. 2010).
population: The population is declining in comparison with previous years (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018). It can be found in the margins of the Río Chili (type locality), at sites with low disturbance (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018).
range: This species is known from the Region of Arequipa and upper parts of western valleys, between Tacna and Camaná, on the western slopes of the Peruvian Andes (Gutiérrez et al. 2010). It occurs at elevations between 1,800 and 3,500 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,849 km2 and all individuals occur in two to five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: In Peru, Rhinella spinulosa is used for food and medicine, thus it is possible this species is also utilized (IUCN SSC Amphibian Specialist Group 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Salinas and Aguada Blanca National Reserve, where it has been reported from the locality of Cabrerías at 3,500 m asl (Gutiérrez et al. 2010).

Conservation Needed
Important considerations should be taken to maintain and and conserve water bodies within Salinas and Aguada Blanca National Reserve (Gutiérrez et al. 2010).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and threats. Further research is necessary to determine whether the species is harvested.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal, partially arboreal frog occurs in premontane and montane tropical forest and cloud forest, as well as, in the forest in dry interandean valleys (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). It can also occur in slightly disturbed forest. Reproductive activity takes place during the rainy season (January–March). It breeds by larval development in lotic water bodies (Cadle and Altig 1991).
threats: In Bolivia, the species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation as a result of cattle grazing, small-holder farming, expanding human settlements, as well as, construction camps for the Ivirizu Hydroelectric dam inside Parque Nacional Carrasco (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). This species appears to have undergone rapid, dramatic declines, including disappearances within undisturbed habitat, which has been associated with chytridiomycosis as observed in many other montane, stream-associated species in the Andes. Specimens of this species from 1998 tested positive for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017). Climate change or the synergistic effects of multiple factors could have played an additional role in the declines. However, the species appears to be recovering or has recovered and is now being found at levels similar to historically (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: A formerly widespread and abundant species in montane Andean Bolivian forests, it experienced a drastic decline and became remarkably rare (De la Riva and Reichle 2014). <span Cochabamba, it was common at the end of the 1990s, but in the mid-2000s the population apparently declined, even within suitable habitat which is suggestive of chytridiomycosis. However, it seems as though the population is recovering because as of 2015 it was found in similar abundances as the 1990s and has remained at those levels (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Regular surveys between 2006-2009, 2014-2015 and 2018-2019 have documented the species in Parque Nacional Carrasco (R. Aguayo, T. Camacho Badani, O. Quinteros and G. Calapa pers. comm. September 2019). As of 2019, the species is considered common throughout its Bolivian range (J. Aparicio pers. comm. September 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" status of this species in Peru is unknown; it has not been observed in recent years despite surveys in historical sites (A. Catenazzi and J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. November 2019). Overall, the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
range: This species is known from southeastern Peru and the departments of Cochabamba, La Paz, Santa Cruz, and Chuquisaca, Bolivia, in interandean valleys and the Amazonian versant. It occurs at elevations from 500–2,600 m asl (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). The species is known to occur in sympatry with R. leptoscelis and R. fissipes at Santo Domingo de Carabaya, Department of Puno, Peru and with R. leptoscelis in the Chapare region, Department of Cochabamba, central Bolivia.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, this species occurs in the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Bahuaja-Sonene. Given its known habitat and geographic distribution, this species might also occur in Parque Nacional Manu and Reserva Amarakaeri. In Bolivia, it occurs in Parques Nacionales Carrasco, Cotapata, Isiboro-Secure. and Serrania de Iñao, as well as, Reserva Municipal Espejillos and Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Río Grande Valles Cruceños. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in one threat-defined location which is not contained in a protected area, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat surrounding Madre Selva.
habitat: This species occurs in humid montane forests. It is predominately terrestrial and has been observed under rocks, logs, and in the leaf litter during the day (Catenazzi et al. 2015). Similar to its congeners, reproduction is presumed to occur via direct development.
threats: The major threats faced by this species are habitat loss and modification associated with agricultural activities in the region, which are primarily dominated by cultivation of coffee, tea and other crops (Catenazzi et al. 2015). These land use changes are particularly detrimental for montane forest species with limited geographic or elevational distribution (Catenazzi et al. 2014).
population: The population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat. In January 2011, three observers conducted intensive visual surveys during morning (9:00-12:00) and afternoon (18:30-24:00) hours at six sites in the area of La Convención (Catenazzi et al. 2015). The species was found at only one site, however it was the most common amphibian at that site (Catenazzi et al. 2015).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: in the town of Madre Selva, District of Santa Ana, province of La Convención, Cusco Region, Peru. Its altitudinal range is 2,330–2,370 m asl in the high-elevation forests in the Andes and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km2 based on the single known locality. It is likely to have a geographic distribution restricted to the upper watersheds of its type locality and adjacent valleys (Catenazzi et al. 2015).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is necessary to mitigate the effects of habitat modification due to agricultural expansion.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, and ecological requirements. It is known from a very restricted area, but no information is available on possible or ongoing threats.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits tropical montane cloud forest. Animals occur in association with small, rocky streams, where they have been found under streamside rocks during the day (Duellman 2004). In common with related species in the northern Andes, Hyloxalus aeruginosus probably lays eggs on land; a parent then transports hatched tadpoles to quiet pools within streams to complete development.
threats: This species has a very restricted geographic range, but there is no information on major threats. The fungal disease chytridiomycosis was first reported from Peru in 1998 (Lips et al. 2008), and has been responsible for severe declines and extinctions among Andean amphibians, especially of high-elevation, stream-breeding frogs with small ranges (Whittaker and Vredenburg 2010). It is, however, unknown whether this disease represents a specific threat to this species.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species. There are no known recent surveys for this frog.
range: This species is known from Rioja Province, Region of San Martín, northern Peru, where it occurs on the steep eastern slope of the Cordillera Central between 1,980–2,180 m asl (Duellman 2004). The two known localities are less than 5 km apart and lie along the road from Abra Pardo de Miguel to Moyobamba.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized. However, Peruvian species of Hyloxalus, in common with other poison dart frogs, may be at risk from smuggling to support the international pet trade (von May et al. 2008).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Alto Mayo Protection Forest.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is a leaf-litter species present in primary flooding forest with close canopy and wide leaves; and possibly in more open/edge areas. Eggs are deposited in shallow pools.
threats: Presumably there are no major threats; it is a generally widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to general human activities such as collection of wood, logging and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It can be abundant where it occurs.
range: This species is known from Leticia, Amazonas, in southern Colombia, and from Explorama and Río Pauya, Loreto in northern Peru. It has been recorded along the edges of Jurua River, Brazil. It has an altitudinal range of 100-300m asl.
conservationActions: It is present within areas northeast of Iquitos (Peru) that has been proposed as Priority by Conservation of Biodiversity (Rodriguez, 1996). It is present in a number of Brazilian protected areas.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 568 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the northern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species inhabit cloud forests in the cool, rainy highlands of the Alto Mayo drainage. Three clutches were found near vocalizing males, with clutch sizes ranging from 21–25 eggs (Twomey et al. 2014). The mode of reproduction is unknown, but it likely breeds in streams, with the eggs laid on leaves overhanging the water, as with other members of the genus.
threats: Specific threats occurring at the type locality are unknown; however the main ridge at Abra Patricia is traversed by a recently paved highway, and the area close to the road is under increasing pressure from slash and burn agriculture (Alliance for Zero Extinction). The El Tingo locality, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba, is nearby the town of La Morada, which has deforested areas as a result of livestock activity (Rios Alva et al. 2017). On some occasions, the lack of control over the burning of forests for agriculture causes the loss of larger forest areas (Rios Alva et al. 2017), which could put the species at risk.
population: This species ranges from extremely abundant, calling from all drainages surveyed, to completely undetectable despite humid (‘ideal’) conditions during other visits. The type locality has been visited at night on three occasions, between May 2010 and June 2011, and frogs were only heard or encountered on one night in 2011 (Twomey et al. 2014). On the one night these frogs were active they were abundant and conspicuous, with high densities of males calling along every drainage in the area (Twomey et al. 2014). A possible explanation is that the breeding season of this species ends in early to mid-May, which coincides with the end of the wet season. In addition, the vicinity of the type locality was visited at least once by R. Schulte while collecting glassfrogs in July 1989, yet the species was not documented (Twomey et al. 2014). One individual of this species was recorded at El Tingo, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba in San Martín, during surveys between August and September 2016, with a survey effort of 127 person-hours (Rios Alva et al. 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality, east slope of Abra Patricia (the divide between the river Maranon and Huallaga River drainages), and from near Puente Nieva (ca 2 km by road from the type locality), San Martín Region, Peru (Twomey et al. 2014). It has also been recorded at El Tingo, within Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba, in San Martín Region (Rios Alva et al. 2017). It occurs at elevations between at 2,000–2,050 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 568 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations. It might occur more widely in suitable montane habitats within the Regions of San Martín and La Libertad (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. April 2018).
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
At the type locality, it occurs in Área de Conservación Privada Abra Patricia-Alto Nieva and may occur in the adjacent Bosque de Protección Alto Mayo. It also occurs in the Concesión de Conservación Alto Huayabamba in San Martín (Rios Alva et al. 2017).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective preservation of montane rainforest and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because of its tolerance of some levels of habitat disturbance, its occurrence within a well-protected areas, and its abundant, stable population.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits humid montane forest. Most specimens have been found under rocks during the day in areas of disturbed montane forest vegetation, such as the sides of the trail and natural landslides (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). Males were heard calling in similarly disturbed areas of the montane forest and along the edges of forest bordering landslides and other open areas (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). An unattended nest with 11 eggs, measuring 4.5 mm in diameter on average, was found under a rock at the type locality. Ten female paratypes had 9.6 ± 1.5 eggs (range 7–12 eggs) at different stages of maturation; of these, one had 10 mature eggs.
threats: No direct threats have been identified: the entire area of the known distribution range of the species is protected and, despite agricultural activity throughout the Japumayo valley, current land use is limited and appears to be sustainable, so it is unlikely to negatively affect the population (for example, the land is not burned the way it is in other areas in this region) (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). Given this species’ affinity for naturally disturbed areas, it is even possible that the current anthropogenic use of the montane forest might enhance the distribution (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). Of 45 specimens tested for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, none of them were infected (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). Based on communications with members of the Japu Q’eros Community about recent amphibian declines in the Japumayo valley, it is possible that Bd has already caused declines of other amphibian populations in the valley, suggesting that Bd might not be as much of a threat for aquatic-breeding frogs such as this one (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016).
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Generally the species is frequently encountered and the population seems to be large and abundant (A. Catanazzi pers. comm. April 2017). For example, 25 frogs were found in seven person-hours at the type locality (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016).
range: This species is known from the Japumayo and Quespillumayo Valleys within the Ukumari Llaqta Private Conservation Area Distrito Paucartambo, Provincia Paucartambo, Región Cusco, Peru, where it occurs from 2,550–3,180 m Asl (Catenazzi and Ttito 2016). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 172 km<sup>2</sup>. The species occurs throughout these valleys and it is expected to occur slightly to the north of known sites (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
All known sites are within the boundaries of the Área de Conservación Privada Ukumari Llaqta, a protected area recognized by Peruvian environmental ministerial decree (No 301-2011-MINAM).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This is an arboreal, canopy-dwelling forest and forest-edge species. It occurs in a number of habitat types from savannahs and other open habitats to both dry and moist forests. It can be found in disturbed habitats, animals may even be found within human dwellings. It can live within second growth forest and plantations. This species breeds at the beginning of the rainy season, with males calling at night while floating in large temporary pools or intermittent streams. The floating egg clutches are laid in the water where the tadpoles also develop.
threats: There are no major threats, this is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss due to drying of wetlands, forest destruction, urbanization, pollution and fire. It is sometimes found in the international pet trade but at levels that do not currently constitute a major threat.
population: It is a very common species.
range: This species is found in Central America, from central Tamaulipas and southern Sinaloa, Mexico southward on both coasts to central Nicaragua and on to the Pacific lowlands through Panama, from 0-1,610m asl. In South America it occurs throughout the Amazon basin, south to Paraná (Brazil), Paraguay, northern Argentina. It is also present on both Trinidad and Tobago. It has an altitudinal range in South America of sea level to 800m asl.
conservationActions: The wide distribution range of this species overlaps with several protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern given its wide distribution over a vast tract of suitable habitat in the upper Amazon basin of Ecuador and Peru.
habitat: This species occurs in lower montane forests and lowland moist forests. Specimens have been found only occasionally, on trees or bushes around 6 m above the ground in primary forest. It is thought to be a canopy dweller, which is where males call from, and may breed by larval in bromeliads (up to 30 m above the ground), although individuals have also been found in understorey vegetation. It has also been recorded from banana plantations.
threats: The major threats to this species’ habitat are agricultural development (for both crops and livestock), and logging.
population: The population status of this species is not known, since only a few specimens have been found so far. This is primarily due to it occurring in the high forest canopy, making it very difficult to survey. The species is likely to be in decline due to habitat loss.
range: This species is known from the Río Napo drainage in the provinces of Napo, Francisco de Orellana, and Sucumbíos, Ecuador (Jungfer et al. 2000, Ron et al. 2001, Cisneros-Heredia 2003), and is also now known from nearby northeastern Peru between the rivers of the Napo and Putumayo and at Agua Negra, from 250 to 600 m asl (Catenazzi and Bustamante 2007, Yánez-Muñoz and Venegas 2008, von May and Venegas 2010). It is expected to occur more widely, and is likely to occur in Colombia.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its range includes Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras and Parque Nacional Yasuní in Ecuador, and Maijuna Regional Conservation Area and Güeppi-Sekime National Park in Peru. It may also occur in the Alto Nanay - Pintuyacu - Chambira Regional Conservation Area in Peru, although this requires verification.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which does not appear to be under significant threat and it has a presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits tall evergreen primary lowland rainforests (Moravec et al. 2008). Frogs can be found in very humid swampy or flooded shores of smaller streams running through undisturbed terra firme forest. These places are typically densely overgrown with herbaceous plants, ferns and palms, and also have abundant herbaceous lianas. Where there are long or heavy rains, males descend to 2–4 m above the inundated ground and call hidden from view (Moravec et al. 2008). Reproductive mode and larvae are unknown, although it is presumed that the species breeds in water as with congeners. It is unlikely to tolerate much habitat disturbance (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
threats: There are no threats to the species as it occurs in an area of vast suitable habitat (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
population: Population densities of this species are considered to be low to moderate, as observed local assemblages of calling males ranged from 4–6 individuals (Moravec et al. 2008) to 10–15 individuals (S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019).
range: This species is known from three localities over the western and central parts of the department of Pando, northern Bolivia, in the southwestern Amazon basin (Moravec et al. 2008). It may possibly occur more widely, including in Peru and Brazil, as there is ample suitable habitat. It occurs between 200–300 m asl (J. Moravec pers. comm. June 2009).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in Parque Nacional Manuripi and Estacion Biologica Tahuamanu in Bolivia.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to establish the limits of the species' range.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,824 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 3–5 locations with a continuous decline in its range and quality of habitat in the Amazonian slopes of the southern Andes of Ecuador due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier, logging and mining.
habitat: This species lives in tropical cloud forest, where specimens have been collected from the upper sides of leaves and ferns within 2 m of cascading streams (Wild 1994). It is found in old growth forest only. Eggs are laid on vegetation, and the larvae develop in streams.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation due to agricultural development, logging and mining are threats to this species throughout its range (Guayasamín et al. 2020, RAISG 2020).
population: It is a locally common species, but recorded infrequently. Although it was common at Yanayacu in 2003, it was rare when it was collected near Plan de Milagro in 1984. A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the Amazonian slopes of the southern Andes of Ecuador, in Morona Santiago and Zamora Chinchipe provinces, between 2,200 and 2,700 m asl (Wild 1994, Cisneros-Heredia and Meza-Ramos 2007, Ramírez et al. 2009, Guayasamin et al. 2010, Guayasamín 2013, Guayasamin et al. 2020). It may also be present in Peru (J.C. Sánchez pers. comm. 2016). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 4,824 km2, which represents 3–5 threat defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is found in Reserva Ecológica Tapichalaca. Its distribution range overlaps with Parque Nacional Podocarpus and Reserva Municipal Siete Iglesias, but it have not been recorded there yet.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: It occurs in crevices under roots of trees, in stilt palms or leaf-litter of primary and secondary humid tropical forest. Adults are not associated with streams, but instead breed in bracts of palms on the ground (the bracts fall to the ground and water collects in them), water filled segment of a fallen bamboo and other ephemeral small pools. Free swimming tadpoles also live in amazonian slow flowing water streams, with sandy substrates. During the night they rest over leaves of low herbs, up to 25 cm above the ground. It is probably able to adapt to some habitat modification (Duellman 1978, Cisneros-Heredia 2003, Poelman et al. 2010, Beirne and Whitworth 2011, Valencia 2011).
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging, and oil exploration are threats to the species’ habitat, especially towards the western part of the range.
population: It is considered very locally common or abundant. At Yasuni, it is the most common Allobates (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. obs.).
range: This species is known from the eastern lowlands of Ecuador at Sucumbios, Orellana, Napo, Pastaza and Morona Santiago provinces, between 200 and 570 m asl. It has more recently been recorded from Güeppí-Sekime National Park (Yánez and Venegas 2008), and Bajo Ere and Cabeceras Ere-Algodón campsites in Loreto, Peru (Venegas and Gagliardi-Urrutia 2013), extending its known distribution c. 215 km to the southeast. It is likely to occur much more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range overlaps several protected areas in Ecuador, such as Parque Nacional Cuyabeno, Parque Nacional Yasuní and Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras. In Peru, it has been recorded from Güeppí-Sekime National Park. It is considered Near Threatened in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, it is found in several protected areas, and no major threats are identified for the species.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of montane cloud forest, occurring in the understorey herbaceous layer. The type locality consists of a mixture of heavily disturbed forest, a cutover and cultivated hillside, and less-disturbed, secondary growth forest (Flores 1988). It has also been found in secondary forest surrounded by coffee crops (Cusi et al. 2015). It breeds by direct development.
threats: Cattle grazing and mining activities are considered localized threats. Chytridiomycosis is detected in some individuals (Cusi et al. 2015), but it is not thought to be a cause of population decline.
population: It is a rare species in most of its range; in two years of study in Parque Nacional Podocarpus, only two individuals were collected (Yañez-Nuñez et al. 2015). However, in some parts of Parque Nacional Sangay it is common (Brito et al. 2017). A single individual was found in the Alto Mayo Forest Reserve in Peru after a general survey effort of 240 person-hours (Cusi et al. 2015). The population is considered to be stable.
range: In Ecuador this species is known from the type locality near Puyo, in the province of Pastaza, from the upper watershed of Curintza in Parque Nacional Podocarpus, in the provinces of Sucumbios, Napo, Tungurahua, Morona Santiago and Zamora Chinchipe, including Cordillera del Condor (Flores 1988, Chaparro et al. 2011, Yañez-Muñoz et al. 2015, Cusi et al. 2015, Brito et al. 2017). In Peru, it is found in Cordillera de Kampankis within the Zona Reservada Santiago Comaina, Amazonas Region, and in the Alto Mayo Protected Forest, San Martín Region (Flores 1988, Catenazzi and Venegas 2012, Cusi et al. 2015). It is found between 1,000 and 1,800 m asl (Flores 1988, Yañez-Muñoz et al. 2015, Chaparro et al. 2011, Brito et al. 2017). It may occur between known localities at suitable elevations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is found in several protected areas, including Parques Nacionales Podocarpus and Sangay in Ecuador, and Alto Mayo Forest Reserve and Zona Reservada Santiago Comaina in Peru.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and adaptability to a wide range of habitats types and qualities.
habitat: This species can be found in scrub savannah, Pacific tropical forest and equatorial dry forest. It can also be found in human-modified habitats. This is an explosive breeder, laying eggs in a foam nest in temporary pools.
threats: The main threats are habitat loss owing to agricultural expansion and human settlement. It is reasonably adaptable, but probably cannot withstand very serious habitat degradation.
population: It can be abundant during reproductive bouts (recorded in 2002).
range: This species is known from southwestern Ecuador, where it occurs in Manabí, Guayas, Los Ríos, Cotopaxi, El Oro and Loja Provinces. It has an elevational range of 0–530 m asl. Reports from northwestern Peru (e.g. Frost 2017) need to be confirmed, however presence in northern Peru is very likely since it has been registered in Huaquillas (border with Peru, El Oro province; Ron et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Machililla National Park and Arenillas Ecological Reserve in Ecuador.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' population size and trends is recommended.  Additional studies on its distribution are needed, particularly regarding its occurrence in northwestern Peru.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,091 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals. In addition, it is suspected that the population will decline at a rate of at least 50% over the next 10 years, primarily due to extensive mining activities and associated contamination of water bodies in the Cordillera del Cóndor region of Ecuador.
habitat: This species inhabits primary and mature secondary elfin forest. Males have been heard calling among the leaves of riverine vegetation a few cm over water (Cisneros-Heredia and Morales-Mite 2008). It is presumed to breed in streams.
threats: Extensive large–scale copper and gold mining projects and associated contamination are causing serious habitat loss within the Cordillera del Cóndor (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, Guayasamín et al. 2020). The construction of roads for mining development gives rise to increasing rates of deforestation for agriculture and cattle ranching activities (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021).
population:
It was apparently fairly abundant at the time of collection, given the high number of calls attributed to this species that were heard from the canopy along the stream (Cisneros-Heredia and Morales-Mite 2008). In May 2009, one individual was collected at Los Encuentros, Zamora-Chinchipe (Ana Almendáriz pers. obs.) and two individuals were collected at Las Peñas, Los Encuentros in July 2013 (J. Brito pers. obs.). In July 2017 and April 2018, a total of 15 individuals were collected from the buffer zone of Reserva Biológica El Quimi, Morona Santiago (D. Almeida pers. obs.). 

Considering the severe decline in habitat as a result of extensive mining projects in the Cordillera del Condor (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, Guayasamín et al. 2020), it is suspected that the population will decline at an alarming rate, likely more than 50%, over the next 10 years (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
range: This species was formerly known only from its type locality: Destacamento Militar Cóndor Mirador, western slope of the Cordillera del Cóndor, Zamora-Chinchipe province, Ecuador, between 1,750–1,850 m asl (Cisneros-Heredia and Morales-Mite 2008). It is now also known from Las Peñas, Campo Maicu, Yantzatza, Paquisha Alto, Los Encuentros, and Zamora in Zamora Chinchipe province (Ana Almendáriz pers. obs. May 2009, Almendáriz and Batallas 2012; J. Brito pers. obs. July 2013; Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021) and the buffer zone of Reserva Biológica El Quimi in Morona Santiago province (D. Almeida pers. obs. July 2017, April 2018). It is thought to be endemic to the Cordillera del Cóndor, as it has not been found in either the Cordillera del Cutucú or the Cordillera Oriental (Guayasamín et al. 2020). Given its proximity to the border with Peru, it likely also occurs in there. Its elevational range is 812–2,311 m asl (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 1,091 km2, which represents five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are no known occurrences inside of protected areas (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021). However, some records occur in the buffer zone of Reserva Biológica El Quimi (D. Almeida pers. obs.), while others are close to Refugio del Vida Silvestre El Zarza. It is not known if the species occurs in the Cordillera del Cóndor binational park (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2009). 

Conservation Needed
Necessary conservation measures include the protection of remaining forests, and an assessment and mitigation of development and mining projects (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2009; Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits cloudy montane forest. Individuals have been recorded from low vegetation associated with dominance of elephant ear plants (Lynch 1979, Lynch and Duellman 1997). It has been recorded from primary and secondary forest, and it possibly also adapts to some anthropogenic disturbance (Lynch and Duellman 1980). Individuals are most frequently found on low vegetation, between 0.2 and 0.6 m above the ground, and sometimes found up to 3.25 m above the ground or on the leaf litter (Frenkel et al. 2016, Brito et al. 2017). It is presumed that it reproduces by direct development, like other species of the genus, although the place of egg deposition is unknown.
threats: Agricultural development, for both crops and livestock, as well as logging, are major threats to this species’ habitat, however the species may be somewhat tolerant of habitat modification.
population: There is little information on the population status and trends of this species. It is rare in the Cordillera del Cóndor (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. March 2018).
range: This species is known from the upper Amazon Basin in southern Ecuador and northern Peru, from 100–530 m asl, in the Pastaza Valley in Ecuador at elevations of 950–1,500 m asl. It occurs within the Ecuadorian provinces of Tungurahua, Pastaza, Morona Santiago, Zamora Chinchipe and Napo (Frenkel et al. 2016). The only specimen from Peru was discovered by C. W. Myers and J. Daly in 1977 along the Río Amazonas 3 km NE of Pebas, Loreto Region, however this record requires confirmation (Duellman and Lehr 2009, E. Lehr pers. comm. September 2017) and is therefore coded as Presence Uncertain in the species' distribution map. This species might occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within Parque Nacional Sangay, Reserva Ecológica Río Zuñag, Parque Naciaonal Podocarpus and Wisui Biological Station. In Ecuador, it is considered Least Concern.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, presence in protected areas and occurrence in an area where its habitats are not significantly threatened.
habitat: It can be found in lowland primary forest (Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). At Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, individuals were found in or near a semi-permanent pond in primary forest at night (Duellman 1978). It breeds in temporary ponds. It is not known if this species occurs in degraded habitats.
threats: It is presumably a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). In Ecuador, it is threatened by destruction around the Napo River.
population: This is a cryptic species; there is little information on the population status, however it is expected to be stable given its relatively widespread distribution in Ecuador. The sampling effort throughout its range is probably insufficient.
range: This species is known from northeastern Ecuador, at Santa Cecilia, Sucumbíos Province (type locality), and from the neighboring provinces of Orellana and Napo. Rodriguez and Duellman (1994) reported the species from the vicinity of Iquitos in Peru, but the record is of questionable identification (Peloso et al. 2014). Published records of this species for Manaus, Brazil are based on misidentifications and have not been included in this assessment (Peloso et al. 2014). While the species is known from relatively few sites, it is believed to be much more widespread. It occurs at elevations of 200–400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in Yasuní National Park and Estación Científica Jatun Sacha Ecuador.

Research Needed
Further research is needed to resolve the identity of Peruvian and Brazilian specimens. Further research on this species' distribution, population status and trends is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because although this species is fairly widespread – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 32,350 km2 – its range includes few protected areas, its habitat is experiencing continuing decline in extent and quality and and all individuals are considered to occur in less than 10 threat-defined locations, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This is a montane and cloud forest species, and is not known to occur in degraded habitats. Adults and juveniles have been found approximately 1 m above the ground in humid montane forest at night; one juvenile was on the ground by day. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: The major threat is loss of habitat for agriculture, selective logging, and human settlement.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from several localities along the road from Abra Pardo Miguel to Moyobamba, San Martín Region, on the eastern slope of the northern part of the Cordillera Central, Peru, and from one locality in Cajamarca Region (Duellman and Lehr 2009). It is found between 1,080 and 2,500 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 32,350 km<sup>2</sup>, and all individuals are considered to occur in less than 10 threat-defined locations. The taxonomy of the Ecuadorian subpopulations still needs to be confirmed (Duellman and Lehr 2009), but are retained here until further taxonomic studies are undertaken.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, it has not been recorded from any protected areas. It has been recorded from the Parque Nacional Podocarpus in Ecuador, however the true identity of the specimens needs to be further investigated. It is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends. Further research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of the Ecuadorian records.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, and presumed large population.
habitat: In the Andes, the species is present in scrubland and grassland, and in the more southern parts of its range it is found in forested areas. It has also been recorded from arable areas. Breeding takes place in the wet season in temporary ponds, peatlands, altiplano lagoons, slow flowing streams, and commonly in artificial wetlands, such as pools or ditches (D. Ferrer pers. comm. September 2017). No tadpoles have been found during the dry season (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. July 2015). Some aspects of reproductive biology, larval behavior, phenotypic plasticity and thermal physiology of the larvae have been studied in southern subpopulations (Sympson et al. 2006, Jara et al. 2006, 2007; Navas et al. 2010, Perotti et al. 2011).
threats: There are no major threats to this widespread and somewhat adaptable species; there are some localized declines through the use of agro-chemicals and over collection for educational use (dissections) at universities. In Chile and Argentina, it is threatened by hydroelectric dams, mining activities, unregulated tourism, livestock and overgrazing, road construction in fragile areas, peatlands desiccation, urbanization, and water pollution. In Peru, it is used for food and medicine; and the main observed threats in the habitat are grazing livestock (including llamas, alpacas, sheep), introduced trout species into the streams, and the destruction and pollution of bogs (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. July 2015). In Bolivia, it is used for as part of spiritual practices. Many specimens collected over the past 100 years have tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017).
population: It is generally abundant where it occurs. While surveys have been carried out, the methods used (Visual Encounter Surveys and transects) are sufficient for reporting the species' presence, but do not provide adequate information on abundance as the species is aquatic (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. July 2015). Local inhabitants in Peru have suggested that this species has declined dramatically compared to the 1990s (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. July 2015). In Bolivia, this species used to be very common in the 1990s; however, it has experienced declines since the early to mid 2000s. It is still found in drier parts of its range and appears to be recovering, but occurs in lower abundances compared to historically. It is very rare in humid areas and is not being recorded despite surveys (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
range: This species is found in the Andean slopes of Argentina, Chile (altiplano in the North to the southern Nothofagus region), Bolivia, and Peru (regions of Puno, Cusco, Junín, and Huánuco); also present in parts of Argentinian Patagonia (B. s. papillosus). Subpopulations from Region of Arequipa and upper parts of western valleys, between Tacna and Camaná, in Peru formerly considered this species are now assigned to Rhinella arequipensis (Cei 1972). This species has a wide elevational range from sea level (Azapa, Arica, Chile) to 5,100 m asl; however, in Argentina the species does not occur above 4,000 m asl (D. Ferrer pers. comm. September 2017).
useTrade: In Bolivia, this species is increasingly used as an amulet to attract luck and money, and at markets hundreds of dried frogs can be found hanging up for sale (A. Muñoz pers. comm. August 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas throughout its range. Specifically, in Peru it is believed to occur in Parque Nacional del Huascarán, Huayllay National Sanctuary, Junín National Reserve, Chacamarca Historical Sanctuary, Alto Cañete Cochas Pachacayo, Apurimac and Aymara Lupaca Reserve Zones, in Bolivia, it is known from Sajama, Ulla Ulla and Eduardo Avaroa protected areas, and in Argentina, it occurs in Parque Provincial Aconcagua, Monumento Natural Puente del Inca y Parque Provincial Cordón del Plata, and Reserva Natural Laguna del Diamante (Ferrer 2017). In Mendoza, Argentinean researchers have implemented closures of peatlands, diversion of trails, and management of livestock (D. Ferrer pers. comm. September 2017).

Conservation Needed
This species shows tolerance to human impacts, however these impacts should be controlled to ensure the population persists (D. Ferrer pers. comm. September 2017). As breeding sites of the species are used in successive seasons, it is necessary to identify breeding areas and perform long-term management (Ferrer 2017). To ensure the survival of this species, the releasing and stocking of trout should be strongly discouraged by both government programs and local people.

Research Needed 
In Chile, it is suggested that environmental impact reports should be undertaken in order to protect breeding areas. Comparative studies are required in peatlands with and without use (grazing, tourism, etc.).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 414 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera de Carpish.
habitat: This species inhabits moss-covered floors in primary cloud forests. Individuals have been collected during the dry season, at daytime, in very humid microhabitats (Chávez et al. 2015). They are likely not tolerant to habitat disturbance (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: The Cordillera de Carpish is not protected under Peruvian law, making it susceptible to deforestation for agriculture and timber extraction (Chávez et al. 2015). The main threat is habitat destruction as a result of agricultural activities, primarily from potato farming and livestock ranching. Furthermore, an interstate road which crosses Cordillera de Carpish (at both sides of Chinchao river) and the developing of mining concessions in the area are additional threats (Chávez et al. 2015). Harvesting of moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
