population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the three specimens that constitute the type series (Chávez et al. 2015). It does not appear to be common (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from two localities (Achupampa and Unchog forest) of the Cordillera de Carpish in Huánuco region, central Peru. It occurs between 3,130 and 3,340 m asl. It is likely to occur between the two known sites (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs at two threat-defined locations and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 414 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
As the Cordillera de Carpish is known for its high levels of endemism, legal protection of the Cordillera de Carpish is recommended (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), threats are mostly localized, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited—its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 356 km<sup>2</sup>—most of the population is thought to occur within a well-protected national park and threats outside of the park are localized and not thought to be causing significant declines.
habitat: This species inhabits high elevation wet, montane grassland (puna). Individuals have been found in humid grassland surrounded by rocks and mountains and under stones of a dry riverbed. A female brooding a clutch of 20 eggs has been observed (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: No anthropogenic disturbance is currently threatening the subpopulations within Río Abiseo National Park (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). Most of the global population is expected to occur within the national park because the microclimates and wet grasslands in the park are preferable to the drier grasslands outside of the park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018). There is some habitat loss and fragmentation due to mining in the vicinity Parcoy which could be affecting the species (G. Chávez pers. comm. March 2018), but these activities affect a very small part of the population, are not thought to be contributing to significant declines, and the species is thought to be adequately protected (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018).
population: Its population status is unknown (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018). The species was described from 20 specimens collected from Parcoy in 2014 (Chávez et al. 2015). In 2010, specimens subsequently identified as this species were recorded from an area on the border of Río Abiseo National Park, where the subpopulations appeared to be healthy (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
range: This species is known from several localities in the Andean highlands of La Libertad and San Martín Regions, both inside and outside of Río Abiseo National Park, Peru. It occurs between 3,550 and 4,125 m asl (Chávez et al. 2015, Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 356 km2, however it almost certainly occurs more widely within the national park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been found in Río Abiseo National Park (Chávez et al. 2015).
   
Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although its known distribution is limited, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 652 km<sup>2</sup>, it has an abundant and stable population, there are no current threats, and it occurs in a large protected area.
habitat: This species inhabits montane forest. Individuals have been observed perch on low vegetation at night from 19:00 to 22:00. Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"No major threats to this species have been identified."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">No major threats to this species have been identified.
population: It is abundant in the Río Abiseo National Park. It is the most common species of Pristimantis living in the montane forests of the valley above 2,600 m (Lehr et al. 2013). For example in July 2000, 233 individuals belonged to this species out of 536 total captured individuals of Pristimantis, nearly twice as many individuals as the second most common species in the genus (Lehr et al. 2013). During the same study, an average of 13.1 frogs/person-hour of search effort were captured (total effort 17.8 person-hours during four nocturnal transects). The population status is considered to be stable (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality in the upper drainage of the Montecristo river (a tributary to the Abiseo river) within Río Abiseo National Park, on the eastern slopes of the Andes in Mariscal Cáceres Province, San Martín Region, Peru. It occurs at elevations from 2,650 to 3,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded in Río Abiseo National Park.

Research Needed
Since the specimens were collected over a decade ago, a re-evaluation of the population status of this species is important (Lehr et al. 2013). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 801 km2, it occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of habitat.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits transitional montane forest, and it is found in slightly disturbed forests and water next to mud roads (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). Males have been observed sitting in shallow water of small temporal water bodies along a narrow unpaved road in late afternoon and in a small artificial pond at night (Moravec et al. 2014). Specimens from the area of Rio Huatziroki were found in low dense forest covering a sharp montane ridge. All observed individuals were in breeding condition during the months of January, February or June (Moravec et al. 2014). One female contained numerous small pigmented oviductal eggs in February. Tadpole of this species are unknown, though it presumably breeds by larval development.
threats: Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and Pui Pui Protected Forest are currently well protected and there are no major threats to this species within these protected areas. There is some encroachment of agriculture and cattle grazing in the buffer zone of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, as well as, selective logging that could be a potential threat to this species (R. von May and E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
population: This species is locally abundant in the buffer zones of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, and only a few individuals were found in the other known localities (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the eastern slopes of the Peruvian Andes, in the buffer zones of Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park (Pasco Region) and the Pui Pui Protected Forest (Junín Region). It is likely that this species has a wider distribution throughout montane forests in the Peruvian regions Pasco and Junín (Moravec et al. 2014). It occurs at altitudes between 1,800–2,230 m asl, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 801 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park and Pui Pui Protected Forest.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although it has a restricted range—its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 57 km<sup>2</sup>—the population is considered to be abundant and stable, it is well protected within Manu National Park and Sanctuario Nacional Megantoni, there are no major ongoing threats, and the species is unlikely to be impacted by past or future outbreaks of chytridiomycosis.
habitat: It inhabits wet puna and the upper limits of elfin forest. Specimens were collected at the end of the rainy season and during the dry season inside clumps of grass and under stones and fallen trees. Males were calling during the day around noon. Similar to its congeners, it is likely that this species breeds in terrestrial habitats by direct development.
threats: Cattle grazing and pasture burning are minor threats to the species. The pathogenic fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, has yet to be reported from this species, but it has been found to infect individuals of the related species, Bryophryne cophites (Catenazzi et al. 2011). However, direct developing frogs such as this species are not likely to be affect by chytrid (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is known from several specimens collected in 2007-2008 and the population seems to be abundant and stable (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known four close localities, at elevations of 3,506–3,651 m asl, on the Amazonian versant of the Cordillera Oriental of the Peruvian Andes, Cusco Region, southern Peru. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 57 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within Sanctuario Nacional Megantoni and Manu National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and natural history.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable because this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,650 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the Peruvian Andes due to the expansion of agriculture.
habitat: This species inhabits dense cloud forest adjacent to rocky, fast-flowing streams (Rivera-Correa et al. 2016). Specimens were collected while calling at night, perched on tree branches ca 1.8 m above the ground and ca 2 m from the edge of a stream. Although there is limited information on its reproductive biology, it is expected to breed in streams by larval development, as with other congeners.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"In montane regions on the eastern slopes of the Andes, cultivation of coffee, tea, and rocoto (a type of chili pepper) has caused extensive deforestation (Catenazzi and von May 2014)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13057,"3":{"1":0},"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">In montane regions on the eastern slopes of the Andes, cultivation of coffee, tea, and rocoto (a type of chili pepper) has caused extensive deforestation (Catenazzi and von May 2014).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species. The type series is comprised of two adult male specimens which were collected in 2011-2012 (Rivera-Correa et al. 2016).
range: This species is known from two localities, separated by 100 km on the highlands on the eastern slope of the Cordillera Central in northern Peru: Comunidad Shipasbama in Pedro Ruiz Gallo Province and La Jalca, km 10 from La Colpa–Rodríguez de Mendoza in Chachapoyas Province, both in the Region of Amazonas (Rivera-Correa et al. 2016). It has also been recorded in the vicinity of Rio Abiseo National Park on the boundary between San Martín and La Libertad (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). Its elevational range is between 2,180 and 2,300 m asl. The distribution of this recently described species is still poorly understood, however the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 8,650 km2, and all individuals occur in three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: This species inhabits undisturbed lowland, primary forest with a high pre-dominance of bamboo (Guadua spp.) and a dense understory. It is probably not resilient to habitat disturbance (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. April 2018). All specimens have been found at night during the rainy season, perching on low bushes of the forest understory (Padial et al. 2016). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: In December 2017, the Peruvian Congress approved a bill that declared it in the national interest to construct a road to connect the towns of Puerto Esperanza and Iñapari, in the Ucayali and Madre de Dios regions, respectively (Fitner and Novoa 2018). If approved, the road would pass through pristine forests of the eastern potion of Alto Purús National Park, placing 275,000 ha of forest at risk (Fitner and Novoa 2018). However, it is still unknown whether this species occurs in this potentially affected area, or even within the park.
population: Little is known about the population status or trends of this species.
range: This species is only known from two close localities in the lowlands of the Peruvian Amazon, along the Sepahua River (a small tributary of the Urubamba River) in Ucayali Region, Peru (Padial et al. 2016). It occurs between elevations of 350–415 m asl. It appears to be restricted to the bamboo-dominated forests of the western versant of the Fitzcarrald Arch, although it may have a broader distribution in similar habitats along the lower hills of the eastern versant of Cordillera del Sira and Cordillera Vilcabamba, as well as the headwaters of the Purus and the Piedras rivers (Padial et al. 2016). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 67 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded in the western buffer zone of Alto Purús National Park, but has yet to be recorded within the boundaries of the park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 84 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the upper Huallaga drainage on the eastern versant of the central Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This nocturnal, arboreal species inhabits lower montane forest. Male specimens were collected at the beginning of the rainy season, calling at night, perched on leaves 2 m above ground. Although bromeliads were present, individuals were not observed using these plants. One specimen was collected calling at night on a leaf 2 m above the ground in a patch of fragmented secondary forest, surrounded by orange plantations and corn cropland. This species presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: Few biological surveys have been conducted within Tingo María National Park because terrorism and drug trafficking made the area inaccessible during the 1980s and 1990s. The habitat surrounding the subpopulation at Sharco is fragmented and affected by human activities such as cattle grazing and orange plantations. The upper Huallaga drainage is highly disturbed by agriculture activities which fragments the submontane and montane forests (Catenazzi and von May 2014).
population: Few surveys have been conducted within Tingo María National Park since its creation, although surveys within the park during 2014 found this species to be locally abundant (Chávez and Catenazzi 2016). The population status remains unknown until additional surveys take place.
range: This species is known from the type locality, Garganta de la Bella in Tingo Maria National Park, and ca 27 km as the crow flies to the south at Sharco, both on the eastern versant of the central Andes in Huánuco, Peru. It occurs at elevations between 1,095 and 1,700 m asl. With only two known localities, it is difficult to predict the potential distribution range of this recently described (2016) species, however the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known range is 84 km2 and all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Tingo María National Park, a small protected area covering 4,777 ha.

Conservation Needed
Due to the species presumed dependence on forest habitat, protection of this habitat is required.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: A terrestrial species active on the ground or low vegetation. Restricted to lowland primary tropical rainforest. Eggs are laid on leaves; tadpoles develop in temporary waterbodies. It is not present in modified habitats.
threats: No major threats, a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as logging and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is not a common species, but it is relatively easily encountered
range: This species is found in Peru, close to the Iquitos region (Departamento Loreto), and along the basins of the Tambopata, Manu and Madre de Dios rivers (Departamento Madre de Dios). It is present in Acre, Brazil and also occurs in northern Bolivia. It occurs at elevations of up to 200m asl.
conservationActions: In Peru, this species is known to occur in Parque Nacional Manu, Tambopata National Reserve and Gueppi Reserved Zone, and might also occur in Allpahuayo Mishana Reserved Zone, Pacaya Samiria National Reserve, and Bahuaja Sonene National Park. It is not present in any Brazilian protected areas however the forests of this State are still well conserved.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This is an arboreal species living in pristine tropical rainforests, usually found on trees around temporary and semi-temporary pools during the wet season. A specimen from the Gran Sabana region of Venezuela was found calling from a Heliconia leaf near the edge of a temporary pond in the forest after a rain. It lays eggs on leaves and tadpoles develop in pools. At Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, individuals were found at night on bushes and low trees in forest (Duellman, 1978). At Yasuní National Park, Ecuador, specimens have been collected in open areas and floodable forests on shrubs and aquatic edges (Ron, 2001).
threats: Various forms of habitat loss no doubt impact local populations, but overall, this species is not significantly threatened.
population: It is generally uncommon (common in Suriname).
range: This species’ geographic range extends from southeast Venezuela to French Guiana, Amazon basin in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia. In Venezuela, it has been reported from the States of Bolívar (Reserva Forestal Imataca, and km13 on the road from El Dorado to Santa Elena de Uairén), and Amazonas (base of Cerro de la Neblina, and Mavaca river). Its altitudinal range is 0-500m asl.
conservationActions: Several populations are found within protected areas. In Ecuador, its geographic range overlaps with Reserva de Producción de Faunística Cuyabeno, Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, and Parque Nacional Yasuní. The population from Reserva Forestal Imataca in Venezuela has a high risk of becoming endangered once the forest is subject of logging practices and consequent depauperation of the original pristine forest vegetation.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is usually found on trees around temporary pools in lowland primary and secondary tropical rainforest and forest-edge habitats. The eggs are deposited on leaves and the tadpoles develop in temporary waterbodies. It can be found in modified habitats at the forest edge.
threats: There are no major threats, it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as logging and agriculture (crops, livestock etc.).
population: It is a common species.
range: This species is known from the upper Amazon basin in Ecuador, the lowlands east of the Andes in the Departments of Huánuco, Loreto, Ucayali and Madre de Dios, Peru; northern Bolivia and western Brazilian Amazonia. It has an altitudinal range of 100 to 400 m asl.
conservationActions: In Peru this species is known to occur in Parque Nacional Manu and Tambopata National Reserve, and might also occur in Allpahuayo Mishana Reserved Zone, Pacaya Samiria National Reserve, Alto Purus Reserved Zone and Bahuaja Sonene National Park, Peru. It is present in many Brazilian protected areas and presumably in protected areas in Ecuador and Bolivia.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because of an observed population decline of close to 30% over the last 10 years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation in its range and chytridiomycosis, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion A.
habitat: This species inhabits well-preserved humid montane forests (Padial et al. 2009). The species breeds by larval development in streams and juveniles have been recorded in riverside vegetation, surrounded by agricultural zones and open areas, which suggest that its tadpoles could develop in disturbed habitats (Chávez et al. 2013).
threats:
In Peru, the population experienced drastic declines due to outbreaks of chytridiomycosis in the late 1990s, but it is not clear whether recent recolonisations indicate that the species will be susceptible to future outbreaks. The Bolivian subpopulations also experienced declines, even within suitable habitat, suggesting chytridiomycosis played a role. 

Habitat loss is the major ongoing threat throughout its range at present. In Peru, expanding human settlements, slash and burn agricultural practices (e.g. coffee and rocoto crops), and road construction are causing continuing habitat loss (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). In Bolivia, the species is threatened by cattle grazing, small-holder farming, expanding human settlements, as well as, construction camps for the Ivirizu Hydroelectric dam inside Parque Nacional Carrasco (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population:
Since it was described in 1912 at Santo Domingo de Carabaya, Puno, Peru, no additional specimens were allocated to this species until it was rediscovered during an expedition to the type locality and the surrounding area in November 2006, when five specimens were collected (Padial et al. 2009). However, an eight-day survey to the type locality in 2016 failed to locate adults or tadpoles (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Additional specimens were collected from the Kimbiri River, Vilcabamba Mountains, Cusco, Peru in subsequent years (Padial et al. 2009). Surveys in Parque Nacional Manu found the species to be abundant in the late 1990s, but surveys in 2008 and 2009 found that it had almost entirely disappeared (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Since 2015, the species appears to be recolonising previously occupied sites in the lower elevations of the cloud forest in Manu; however, the species is still missing from a large part of its former range in the park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).

In Bolivia, it was very common in the Yungas of La Paz in the 1990s, but declines took place in the early to mid-2000s. It is now common in some sites as demonstrated by surveys in 2015–2019 (S. Reichle and J. Aparicio pers. comm. September 2019). As of 2018, it is a common species in Cochabamba, but occurs in lower densities compared to R. justinianoi (R. Aguayo and O. Quinteros pers. comm. September 2019). While the majority of the declines seem to have occurred in the early to mid-2000s, it is reasonable to suspect a population decline of 20-25% in the last 10 years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation and chytridiomycosis.
range: This species is known from several localities along the Amazonian versant of the Andes from central Bolivia (Cochabamba and La Paz) to southern Peru (Cusco and Puno). All Bolivian specimens formerly considered R. fissipes now belong to this species (Padial et al. 2009, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Records from Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén in Peru require confirmation (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs between 1,300 and 2,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Peru, it occurs in Parque Nacional Otishi (Barboza Sánchez 2014) and Parque Nacional Manu (Catenazzi et al. 2013, 2011). The type locality is within the buffer zone of Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene and it is very likely to occur within the park. It may also occur in Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén (Chávez et al. 2013), Santuario Nacional Megantoni, and Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). In Bolivia, it has been recorded from Parques Nacionales Carrasco, Madidi and Pilon Lajas (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

Conservation Needed
Recommended conservation measures include improved management of the existing protected areas and additional habitat protection.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2, there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although it has a restricted distribution – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 128 km<sup>2</sup>, it primarily occurs in a protected area where there are no major threats at present.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits cloud forest, páramo (above 3,100 m asl) and dwarf forest or montane evergreen forest (below 3,100 m asl). Specimens have been observed walking on the leaf litter during the night and under moss. Females lay eggs under leaf litter and inside of plant roots and the eggs undergo direct development (Motta et al. 2016).
threats: No major threats to this species have been identified, as most records are from within a national sanctuary. Agricultural activities and cattle farming are generating deforestation in the buffer zone (WWF Peru 2017), but this is predominately occurring at elevations below where this species occurs.
population: In 2009, 19 specimens were collected from the vicinity of the type locality, within Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe (Motta et al. 2016). Between 2013 and 2014, 15 individuals of this species were observed during surveys over 38 person-hours at Laguna La Victoria in Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe in Cajamarca (J.C. Cusi pers. comm. April 2017). The population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the Namballe and Tabaconas sectors of Tabaconas-Namballe National Sanctuary, in the northern Andes, San Ignacio province, Cajamarca Region, Peru (Motta et al. 2016). It occurs between 2,800–3,300 m asl and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 128 km2. It is expected to have a relatively small and ecologically restricted distribution as with other high Andean species in the genus.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded within Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe, which was established in 1988 to protect the biodiversity and the role of the páramo ecosystem in the Cordillera de Huacabamba.'

Conservation Needed
Rigorous management of the protected area to prevent further encroachment of deforestation is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2, there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 37 km<sup>2 </sup>– there are no ongoing threats and it occurs entirely within a well-protected national sanctuary.
habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits dwarf forest or montane evergreen forest (above 2,700 m asl) and páramo (above 3,100 m asl). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: No major threats to this species have been identified, as most records are from within a national sanctuary. Agricultural activities and cattle farming are generating deforestation in the buffer zone (WWF Peru 2017), but this is predominately occurring at elevations below where this species occurs.
population: Little information is available on the population size and trends of this species. It is known from the holotype and two additional specimens collected in 2009 (Motta et al. 2016).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: sector Namballe in Tabaconas-Namballe National Sanctuary, San Ignacio province, Cajamarca Region, Peru, between 2,960 and 3,115 m asl. It is expected to have a relatively small and ecologically restricted distribution as with other high Andean species in the genus.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded within Santuario Nacional Tabaconas Namballe, which was established in 1988 to protect the biodiversity and the role of the páramo ecosystem in the Cordillera de Huacabamba.

Conservation Needed
Rigorous management of the protected area to prevent further encroachment of deforestation is the best guarantee for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although its known distribution is limited – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12 km<sup>2 </sup>– it is thought to be distributed more widely and occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland primary forest. The habitat at the type locality consists of a complex of forest terraces and small palm swamps. The holotype was found calling and submerged inside a narrow, water-filled hole at the base of a large tree, 1.5 m above the ground (Ron et al. 2016). The calls are highly unusual for frogs because they are a loud chuckle resembling the song of a bird. Calling behavior suggests that it breeds in tree holes and is a canopy dweller (Ron et al. 2016). No females, amplectant pairs, clutches, or tadpoles have been observed.
threats: There is no information on threats, but there is plenty of suitable habitat remaining in the region.
population: Little is known about its population status due to its cryptic call and habits (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018). At least six individuals were detected during 18 hours of visual encounter surveys (0.375 individuals/hour) in the vicinity of the type locality (Ron et al. 2016). The detection of the calls of six additional individuals at the type locality suggests that the species can be relatively abundant (Ron et al. 2016). However, the species may be difficult to observe in ground-level surveys.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, in the headwaters of rivers Ere and Campuya, at 145 m asl, in the Putumayo river basin in Maynas Province, Loreto Region, Peru, near the boundary with Colombia. A specimen reported as Tepuihyla tuberculosa by Duellman (1974) from Rio Querari (Amazonas, Brazil) probably refers to this species, but its identity requires confirmation (Ron et al. 2016). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known range is 12 km2, but it is likely to occur more widely in the Amazon basin (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2018).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has not been recorded from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Its habitat is cloud forest, where the trees are generally spaced widely, separated by 2–3 m, in tall shrubland. Wet depressions and small ravines are scattered throughout the area, with slightly taller (4-9 m high) elfin forest. This species breeds by direct development.
threats: There is no information about the threats to this species.
population: Its population status is unknown. The holotype is in poor condition and therefore the validity of this species is uncertain (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality: Cordillera Azul, Pass of Carretera Central, in Huánuco Region, Peru. It occurs at 1,650 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It might occur in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul, but this requires confirmation.

Research Needed
Further taxonomic research is needed to determine the validity of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017). More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This nocturnal species inhabits montane forest and páramo (Duellman and Venegas 2016). Individuals have been found by day inside bromeliads 2-4 m above the ground in montane forest, and at night walking on moss near the edge of a patch of montane forest on a slope covered by páramo (Duellman and Venegas 2016). Its breeding strategy remains unknown. No information is available as to whether tolerate any degree of habitat disturbance.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It has only recently been described and is known from a single adult female (holotype) and five subadult paratypes (Duellman and Venegas 2016).
range: This species is known only from type locality in the northern Cordillera Central: Hornillo, Rodríguez de Mendoza Province in northern Amazonas Region, Peru, at 3,308 m asl (Duellman and Venegas 2016). It is unknown whether it might occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 95 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat at its type locality in the northern Cordillera Central of northern Peru. This listing is precautionary, as it might occur more widely than presently known following additional surveys.
habitat: This arboreal species inhabits humid montane forest. The holotype was found by day inside a large bromeliad attached to a rocky outcrop (Duellman and Venegas 2016). At Quintecocha, an individual was perched on herbaceous vegetation by day on a trail in a patch of montane forest (Duellman and Venegas 2016). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Its breeding strategy remains unknown."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13229,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Its breeding strategy remains unknown. The type locality is surrounded by pastureland, however no information is available as to whether tolerate any degree of habitat disturbance.
threats: The type locality consists of extensive pastures for cattle and small patches of forest (Duellman and Venegas 2016). The threats are unknown, but presumably this species is affected by habitat loss for livestock.
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It has only recently been described and is known from a single adult female (holotype) and one juvenile specimen collected in 2012 (Duellman and Venegas 2016). However, d<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">ue to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from two localities: Abra Barro Negro, Chachapoyas Province (Amazonas Region) and Quintecocha, Marical Caceres Province (San Martín Region), in the northern part of the Cordillera Central in northern Peru (Duellman and Venegas 2016). It occurs at elevations between 3,119–3,290 m asl. It is unknown whether it might occur more widely, but the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of its current known range is 95 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Los Chilchos Private Conservation Area, designated in 2012.

Conservation Needed
Some form of habitat protection at the type locality is recommended.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern since, although its current distribution is limited, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat and its distribution is believed to be larger than currently known.
habitat: This species inhabits montane cloud forest. The type locality lies in the valley, surrounded by steep mountain slopes covered by primary rainforest with bromeliads, ferns, and epiphytic mosses (Lehr and Moravec 2017). Adult specimens have been collected at night on vegetation up to 1.5 m above the ground, while juveniles occupy lower positions in the vegetation (Lehr and Moravec 2017). Reproduction is expected to occur by direct development.
threats: The species occurs in the northeastern portion of buffer zone of Pui Pui Protected Forest, which is remote, contains extensive suitable habitat, and is not prone to major threats (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it has only recently been described based on five adult females and ten juveniles (Lehr and Moravec 2017). Because of its remote location and difficult access, no biological surveys had been conducted in the Pui Pui Protected Forest prior to the 2012–2014 expeditions that led to this species' discovery (Lehr and Moravec 2017).
range: This species is only known from the type locality at the northeastern border of the Pui Pui Protected Forest, ca 18 km (straight airline) northwest of the town of Satipo, Pichanaqui District, Chanchamayo Province, Junín Region, Peru (Lehr and Moravec 2017). It occurs between 1,700 and 1,800 m asl. It is expected to occur more widely (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from just outside the Pui Pui Protected Forest, and likely occurs within the protected area (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Given that the only known locality lies outside the boundary of the Pui Pui Protected Forest, the long-term protection of this species will depend on the type of land use in the area (Lehr and Moravec 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2 and it occurs in [XX] threat-defined locations, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable, however its habitat is included in a protected area and does not appear to be significantly threatened, there are no ongoing threats, and the population is considered to be stable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 96 km<sup>2 </sup>and it occurs in two locations, thus making the species close to qualifying for a threatened category, however this recently described species is expected to occur more widely, much of its habitat is included in a well-protected area and does not appear to be threatened, the species is common both within and outside of the protected area, and the population is considered to be stable.
habitat: This species inhabits upper montane forests and high Andean grasslands. Specimens have been found inside moss pads (Lehr and von May 2017). A female was found guarding 20 eggs inside moss, with an average diameter of 3.5 ± 0.1 mm (Lehr and von May 2017). Reproduction occurs by direct development (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
threats: A substantial portion of the habitat of this species is formally protected and in a highly remote area of the eastern Andes. The Pui Pui Protected Forest is relatively well protected and thus there are no known threats to the species within the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). This species is threatened by habitat loss caused by deforestation for agriculture and livestock in southern portions outside of the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Climate change may pose a threat to this species in the future, as the possibilities of migration upward to suitable habitat are limited (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Harvesting of moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is common both within and outside Pui Pui Protected Forest and it is considered to have a stable population (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known only from six localities in the Pui Pui Protected Forest and two localities outside of Pui Pui Protected Forest in Junín, Peru, from 3,400 to 3,936 m asl (Lehr and von May 2017). It may occur more widely both within and outside of the Pui Pui Protected Forest (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 96 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in two locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Pui Pui Protected Forest, which was established in 1985 and covers 60,000 ha encompassing montane forest and puna habitats (Sernanp 2010).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although it is currently only known from a single location, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is expected to occur more widely and is tolerant to a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species inhabits Peruvian Yungas forest and has also been found in agricultural areas, such as pastures and plantations. There is no information on its breeding biology.
threats: In light of the species' resilience to habitat disturbance and use of human-modified habitats, there are no known threats at present.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">The species is abundant at its type locality, including areas comprised of cacao plantations and pastures.
range: This newly described species is known only from the type locality, La Mar, in the Peruvian Amazon basin, Region of Ayacucho, at 694 m asl (Caminer et al. 2017). However it is expected to occur more widely (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017), so its current distribution map is not a meaningful representation of its range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern since, although it appears to have a restricted geographic range, it occurs in a protected area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat.
habitat: This species inhabits cloud forest. Most specimens were found under mosses in the cloud forest, aside from one male that was found under rocks and mosses under the riparian vegetation at the confluence of a small stream (Catenazzi et al. 2017). Female specimens had 15–16 large eggs in their ovaries, indicative of terrestrial breeding and direct development (Catenazzi et al. 2017).
threats:
This species occurs in a remote and protected area where no threats have been observed (Catenazzi et al. 2017). The upper puna and transitional habitats, as well as a narrow elevational band around the treeline are used for agriculture (potato cultivation), livestock (llamas grazing), fishing (exotic trout), and timber extraction. These land use patterns appear sustainable and there is little indication of human disturbance in the cloud forest, where the main use seems to be limited to trout fishing (Catenazzi et al. 2017).

Although the amphibian pathogenic fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been reported in several frogs from the nearby region of Abra Huallahualla and Coline (ca 22 km S by airline from the type locality) (Catenazzi et al. 2011), and is known to have caused the local extinction of many stream-breeding species in the montane forests of Manu National Park (58 km NW of Quispillomayo), terrestrial-breeding frogs such as Bryophryne do not appear to be threatened by chytridiomycosis, and their populations have persisted during Bd epizootics (Catenazzi et al. 2011, Catenazzi et al. 2014, Warne et al. 2016).
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the few specimens that constitute the type series. These specimens were found during a rapid amphibian survey in the upper Quispillomayo Valley from 22–31 May 2016 (Catenazzi et al. 2017).
range: This newly described species is known only from the Área de Conservación Privada Ukumari Llakta, Quispillomayo valley, in the province of Paucartambo, Cusco, Peru (Catenazzi et al. 2017). It is found 2,795–2,850 m asl. This species appears to have a small geographic range, although it should be noted that the exact geographic and elevational range is currently poorly understood.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within the Área de Conservación Privada Ukumari Llaqta, a protected area recognized by Peruvian environmental ministerial decree (N° 301-2011-MINAM) in 2011.

Research Needed
Further information is needed on its distribution, populations status and trends, as well as, its natural history.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species inhabits wet montane grassland. The holotype was found in wet grassland covered with mosses, near the Park rangers’ station and entrance to Río Abiseo National Park at Ventanas (Rodriguez and Catenazzi 2017). Little is known about its natural history, although it is presumed that it reproduces by direct development similar to other members of the genus.
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"The threats to this species are unknown."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">The threats to this species are unknown.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Rio Abiseo National Park at Ventanas, La Libertad Region, Peru, at 3,820 m asl. It is expected to have a small geographic range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs on the boundary of Rio Abiseo National Park, though it remains unknown as to whether it occurs further within the park

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species inhabits wet montane grasslands. The three known specimens were found within a 100 m<sup>2</sup> area in the wettest flat area of the Manachaqui Valley, among dense moss vegetation (Rodriguez and Catenazzi 2017). It is presumed that this species has a cryptic mode of life restricted to moss, and reproduces by direct development similar to other members of the genus.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the few individuals that comprise the type series (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Lake Manachaqui in the Manachaqui Valley, near Río Abiseo National Park, La Libertad Region, Peru, at 3,600 m asl (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). It is expected to have a small geographic range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has so far only been found outside of Río Abiseo National Park, but might be present in areas of the same habitat within the park. 
Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its restricted distribution—extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca 41 km2—it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under any significant threat and has an apparent healthy population.
habitat: This species inhabits elfin forest and puna. Most specimens were found in mosses and leaf-litter in elfin forest patches, ranging from 0.01 to 5 ha in size, surrounded by wet montane grassland (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). The holotype was found in the grassland adjacent to forest patches, during a rainy night (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). Some eggs (4.5 mm in diameter) have been found with adult specimens, suggesting parental clutch attendance.
threats: There is currently no anthropogenic disturbance threatening the population within the Río Abiseo National Park (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). One specimen collected in 1988 tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, however the pathogenic fungus does generally not threaten terrestrial-breeding frogs in the Peruvian Andes (Catenazzi and von May 2014) and no dead specimens of Phrynopus were found during surveys in Río Abiseo National Park (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
population: It appears to have appear to have a healthy population within Río Abiseo National Park, with at least one specimen found in every sampled forest patch (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). A short survey within the park and surrounding areas (down to Pampa del Cuy) in 2010 revealed the presence of this species (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality: Pampa del Cuy, Río Abiseo National Park, Mariscal Cáceres Province, San Martín Region, Peru (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). It occurs from 3,225–3,550 m asl and its EOO is estimated to be 41 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs within in Río Abiseo National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and natural history. Continuous population monitoring inside the park is recommended to provide stronger support for future assessments of the conservation status of this species (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although it has a restricted distribution—with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca 41 km2—it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under any significant threat and it has an apparent healthy population.
habitat: This species inhabits the leaf-litter of tropical moist montane forest. The reproductive stage of the holotype indicates that the species may reproduce in the dry season (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). Although no eggs were found with the specimens, the large size of the well-developed eggs in the holotype strongly suggests direct development (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
threats: There is currently no anthropogenic disturbance threatening the population within the Río Abiseo National Park (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
population: It appears to have appear to have a healthy population within Río Abiseo National Park (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality in the upper reaches of the continuous mountain forests of Río Abiseo National Park, Mariscal Cáceres Province, San Martín Region, Peru (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017). It occurs from 2,890–3,110 m asl and its EOO is estimated to be 41 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been found within Río Abiseo National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and natural history. Continuous population monitoring inside the park is recommended to provide stronger support for future assessments of the conservation status of this species (Rodríguez and Catenazzi 2017).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because of an observed population decline of 30% over the last 10 years (2009–2019), likely due to the effects of chytridiomycosis compounded by habitat loss and climate change.
habitat: It is a terrestrial species of open montane puna, grassland and páramo habitats. It is frequently found under rocks close to small seasonal waterbodies and peat bogs, or at the sides of streams (Cortez 2001). It has also been found under rocks and in or around ponds formed by glacial melt and cushion bogs. It breeds explosively in slow-moving streams and small ponds. It is present in irrigated agricultural land.
threats:
This species appears to have undergone rapid, dramatic declines, including disappearances within undisturbed habitat, which has been associated with chytridiomycosis as observed in many other montane, stream-associated species in the Andes. Climate change or the synergistic effects of multiple factors could have played a role in the declines. The species is still being recorded at some sites, but in much lower numbers than historically. It is possible that the chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) may have been implicated in reported mortality events and declines reported by local farmers in Peru (von May et al. 2008, Catenazzi et al. 2011). Specimens have tested positive for Bd in Peru (Seimon et al. 2007, Catenazzi et al. 2011), although Seimon et al. (2007) noted that individuals did not appear to exhibit clinical signs of chytridiomycosis. Bolivian specimens collected in 2001 and 2013 also tested positive for Bd (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017).

In both Ayacucho and Apurimac Regions of Peru, the habitat of this species is threatened by fires to generate and maintain pastures for livestock (V. Vargas pers. comm. 2014). The effects of climate change (e.g., droughts; decreasing humidity, precipitation and glacial cover) are also considered to pose an ongoing and future threat to this species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population:
It is generally a locally common species. In Chile, it has several fragmented subpopulations with low densities (Fíbla et al. 2020). It is a rarely recorded species in Argentina but this is likely related to the difficulty in accessing their habitat. In Bolivia, it was a locally common species in the 1990s, but it experienced population declines in the early 2000s; as of 2019, it is still being recorded in some sites, but in lower densities than historically (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

In Peru, 2,619 tadpoles and adults were found over four person/days in 2005, while in 2008, 187 tadpoles and adults were recorded over four person/days (von May et al. 2008). Most of the 2005 records were tadpoles in ponds. The number of tadpoles in 2008 was severely reduced, and local farmers reported finding both dead individuals and a population decline over the previous five years in Marcapata, Cusco (von May et al. 2008). Observations of widespread severe declines and dead individuals within the Peruvian subpopulations have been made and reports from local farmers have stated that frogs that were once present have disappeared (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Therefore it is reasonable to estimate 30% declines in the global population over the past 10 years (2009–2019).
range: This species occurs from central Peru to central Bolivia, northeastern Chile and marginally into northwestern Argentina. In Peru, the species is present in the central and southern Regions of Ancash, Arequipa, Ayacucho, Lima, Cusco, Huancavalica, Junín and Pasco. In Bolivia, it occurs in the Departments of Cochabamba, La Paz, Oruro, Potosí and Tarija (De la Riva et al. 2000). In Chile, the species is known from Putre, Portezuelo de Putre, Parinacota, Chungará Lake, Lauca Sur and Colpa–Colpita in the Arica y Parinacota Region, close to the Peruvian border (Cei 1958, 1962; Veloso et al. 1982, Sallaberry et al. 2007, Fíbla et al. 2020), as well as, the Quebe wetlands, Enquelga, Isluga, Toroni, Cotaculco, Río Ocacucho, Cancosa, Lagunillas, Collacagua, Piga, and Huasco in Tarapacá Region (Moreno et al. 2001, Sallaberry et al. 2007, Bonacic et al. 2015, Fíbla et al. 2020), and Coska in Antofagasta Region (Fíbla et al. 2020). In Argentina, the species was collected in six localities in Jujuy between 1970-1980 (Ferraro 2012). It has an elevational range of 3,000–5,200 m asl (Duellman and Veloso 1977, Seimon et al. 2007).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia, it is present in the Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Apolobamba, Reserva Nacional de Fauna Andina Eduardo Avaroa, Parque Nacional y Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Cotapata and Parques Nacionales Carrasco and Sajama. In Peru, it has been recorded from Reserva Nacional Salinas y Aguada Blanca and Reserva Nacional Pampa Galeras in Junín, and in the Área de Conservación Regional Bosque de Puya Raimondi Titankayocc and Santuario Histórico de la Pampa de Ayacucho, in Ayacucho (V. Vargas pers. comm. 2014). It occurs in the Reserva de la Biósfera Laguna de Pozuelos in Argentina (Vaira 1998, Ferraro 2012), as well as, Parque Nacional Lauca and Parque Nacional Isluga in Chile (Veloso et al. 1982, Fíbla et al. 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected areas where this species occurs, and expanded habitat protection elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
Given the apparent declines in Peru, population monitoring of this species is recommended, as well as, research on the potential impact of chytrid fungus. Due to the wide geographic distribution of this species and its high degree of fragmentation, it is possible to infer that there is more than one lineage of P. marmoratum (Fíbla et al. 2020), therefore taxonomic work through integrative studies that cover the entire distribution of the species is recommended.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: The habitat of the Laguna Bombom consists of grassland, shrubs, herbaceous plants, stones, rocks and creeks (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). The holotype was found under a stone, at 11:55 hr (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). It is presumed to breed by direct development as with other members of the genus.
threats: The Cordillera de Carpish is not protected under Peruvian law, making it susceptible to deforestation for agriculture and timber extraction (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). New regimes of humidity and temperature caused by climate change are a threat to this species' cloud forest habitat. Harvesting of Sphagnum moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It is only known from a single specimen collected in 2013.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Laguna Bombom, Cordillera de Carpish, Churubamba District, Huánuco Province, Huánuco Region, Peru (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). It occurs at 3,582 m asl. It likely occurs more widely, however it probably has a restricted distribution as with other species in the genus (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species does not occur within any protected area.
 
Conservation Needed
As the Cordillera de Carpish is known for its high levels of endemism, legal protection of the Cordillera de Carpish is recommended (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
 
Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species inhabits Unchog elfin forest. The habitats consist of trees (ca 5 m in height) with moss-covered branches, bushes, ferns and moss-covered rocks and stones (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). The holotype was found under a rock, at 15:45 hr, the paratype was found under a rock at 10:30 hr (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). It is presumed to breed by direct development as with other members of the genus.
threats: The Cordillera de Carpish is not protected under Peruvian law, making it susceptible to deforestation for agriculture and timber extraction (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). New regimes of humidity and temperature caused by climate change are a threat to this species' cloud forest habitat. Harvesting of Sphagnum moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species. It is only known from a two specimens collected in July 2013.
range: This species is known only from two localities in Cordillera de Carpish: Quebrada Chaglla and from road to Gloria Pata, Churubamba District, Huánuco Province, Huánuco Region, Peru (Lehr and Rodríguez 2017). It occurs at elevations from 3,276–3,477 m asl. It likely occurs more widely, however it probably has a restricted distribution as with other species in the genus (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species does not occur within any protected area.
 
Conservation Needed
As the Cordillera de Carpish is known for its high levels of endemism, legal protection of the Cordillera de Carpish is recommended (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
 
Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 152 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 1–2 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera del Condor, southern Ecuador.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical montane shrubland and grassland, characterized by patches of shrubs with gnarled branches, abundant mosses and lichens. It is nocturnal and is associated with terrestrial bromeliads that contain high concentrations of water. Reproduction takes place by direct development as with other members of the genus. It lives in sympatry with Hyloscirtus condor, Hyloxalus mystax, and several species of Pristimantis (Brito et al. 2017).
threats: Extensive large–scale copper and gold mining projects and associated deforestation (agriculture, logging, road-building) and contamination are causing serious habitat loss within the Cordillera del Cóndor (Chicaiza and Yánez 2013, Mazabanda et al. 2018, RAISG 2020). These activities represent a serious threat to subpopulations apart from those in the highest parts of the reserve (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021).
population: At the type locality, the vocalisations of numerous male individuals were heard where terrestrial bromeliads were abundant (Brito et al. 2017). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is known from Cerro Plateado, on a sandstone plateau in one of the highest sites in the Cordillera del Cóndor, in the province of Zamora Chinchipe, between 2,045 and 2,860 m asl (Brito et al. 2017). Given its proximity to the border with Peru, its presence in this country is likely. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 152 km2, which represents 1–2 threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place  
It occurs within Reserva Biológica Cerro Plateado.

Conservation Needed
