Necessary conservation measures include rigorous management of  the existing protected area, protection of the remaining habitat, and an assessment and mitigation of mining and infrastructure projects (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021; Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to the extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements of this recently described species.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical primary montane rainforest. The holotype was found at night, sitting on a leaf at 1 m above the ground (Lehr et al. 2017). Reproduction is presumably by direct development.
threats: The species is currently only known from within Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, which is well-protected; however, if the species occurs outside of the park, agriculture expansion into the park's buffer zone may be a threat to this species' habitat (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). The Yanachaga mountain chain is one the remaining large forested areas in this region of Peru, and there is increasing human pressure to convert the land for agricultural activities, for example, "Rocoto" (chili pepper) plantations, and selective logging inside the buffer zone of the park.
population: It is known only from the five specimens, one collected in 2012 and four collected during the 1990s, which comprise the type series (Lehr et al. 2017). Its population status remains unknown.
range: This recently described (2017) species is known only from the type locality in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park, Huancabamba District, Oxapampa Province, Pasco Region, Peru, at 2,950 m asl. It may occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Yanachaga-Chemillén National Park.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, as well as, threats, should it be found more widely.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 20 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Andes of Junín, Peru.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical humid montane forest. The vegetation at the type locality consists of Peruvian feather grass (Stipa ichu), large layers of mosses, small bushes, trees, and forest patches (Lehr et al. 2017). The male holotype was found calling from the center of Peruvian feather grass in the early afternoon during light rain in the month of May (Lehr et al. 2017). A female was recorded guarding 20 eggs inside moss (Lehr et al. 2017). Reproduction is presumably by direct development.
threats: Habitat loss and disturbance is ongoing in both valleys where this species occurs, due to the cattle raising and agriculture, however these activities are more acute in the Toldopampa valley than in the Tasta valley (Lehr et al. 2017).
population: It is known only from the seven specimens, collected in 2012 and 2013, which comprise the type series (Lehr et al. 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This recently described (2017) species is known from two localities in the Peruvian Andes: the type locality in the Tasta valley, "Runda" and the Satipo-Toldopampa Road at km 134 on left side of road coming from Satipo (4.2 km airline from the type locality), Junín, Peru. It occurs at elevations from 3,350–3,463 m asl, the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its known range is 20 km2, and all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations. It may occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has not been recorded from any protected areas, however the type locality is 7.5 km [airline] from the border of Pui Pui Protected Forest (Lehr et al. 2017).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where the species is known to occur.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Additional surveys are needed to determine if the species occurs in protected areas, such as Pui Pui Protected Forest.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to the extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements of this recently described species.
habitat: This species inhabits high-altitude Andean grassland or puna. Specimens have been found during early afternoon inside moss (Lehr et al. 2017). Two females were observed guarding eggs in the month of June (Lehr et al. 2017). Reproduction is presumably by direct development.
threats: The species is currently only known from within Pui Pui Protected Forest, which is well-protected.
population: It is known only from the seven specimens, collected in 2013, which comprise the type series (Lehr et al. 2017). Its population status remains unknown.
range: This recently described (2017) species is known only from the type locality: Pui Pui Protected Forest, Laguna Sinchon, Satipo Province, Junín Region, Peru, at 3,890 m asl. It could occur more widely within the protected area at suitable elevations (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Pui Pui Protected Forest (Lehr et al. 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, as well as, threats, should it be found more widely.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 231 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the central Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical montane Polylepis forest and puna. The vegetation at the type locality consists of Polylepis trees, small bushes, ferns, moss, and Peruvian feather grass. At the type locality, specimens were found in the afternoon in a forest patch under rocks near a house; other specimens in the type series were collected under rocks and moss (Lehr et al. 2017). Reproduction is presumably by direct development.
threats: A substantial portion of the habitat of this species is formally protected and in a highly remote area of the eastern Andes. The Pui Pui Protected Forest is relatively well protected and thus there are no known threats to the species within the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). This species is threatened by habitat loss caused by deforestation for agriculture and livestock in southern portions outside of the park (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Agriculture and cattle raising are more acute in the Toldopampa valley than in the Tasta valley (Lehr et al. 2017). Harvesting of moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is known from the specimens that comprise the type series (Lehr et al. 2017) and is not considered to be a common species (E. Lehr pers. comm. March 2018). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from four localities outside and two localities inside the Pui Pui Protected Forest in Junín, Peru, between 3,350 and 3,890 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 231 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur in two threat-defined locations. It is unlikely to have a much wider distribution (E. Lehr pers. comm. March 2018).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Pui Pui Protected Forest, which was established in 1985 and covers 60,000 ha encompassing montane forest and puna habitats.

Conservation Needed
Ongoing protection of the Protected Forest is required to ensure the species can survive despite ongoing habitat loss and degradation.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to the extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements of this recently described species.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical montane cloud forest. The vegetation at the type locality consists of small bushes, small trees, forest patches, Peruvian feather grass, fern, and moss layers (Lehr et al. 2017). Specimens have been found inside Peruvian feather grass bunches in the early afternoon and at night (19:00–21:00 hrs) on low vegetation up to 1 m from ground inside forest (Lehr et al. 2017). Males called during rain in late morning and afternoon, and at night (Lehr et al. 2017). Reproduction is presumably by direct development.
threats: The species is currently only known from within Pui Pui Protected Forest, which is well-protected; however, it is been recorded on the boundary of the protected area. If the species occurs outside of the protected area, agriculture may be a threat to this species' habitat.
population: It is known only from the nine specimens, collected in 2012, which comprise the type series (Lehr et al. 2017). Its population status remains unknown.
range: This recently described (2017) species is known only from the type locality: Pui Pui Protected Forest, Quebrada Tarhuish, left bank of Antuyo River, 'Shiusha', Satipo Province, Junín Region, Peru, at 3,318 m asl. It may occur more widely.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Pui Pui Protected Forest (Lehr et al. 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, as well as, threats, should it be found more widely.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,151 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat in the Peruvian Andes.
habitat: It is a terrestrial species inhabiting humid puna with mosses and bunchgrass, above the treeline. It exhibits some resilience in the face of habitat disturbance, and may be found in low intensity farmed areas. Most individuals have been found beneath stones during the day or walking about in deep moss. Males have been heard calling at night from 20:30–22:30 (Duellman et al. 2011). Females have a single median brood pouch, which is used to brood the eggs until they hatch into froglets via direct development. On average, females have about 20 eggs (n=34) that measure about 6 mm in diameter (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
threats:
The major threat is extensive habitat loss due to agriculture (tea and coffee), burning of grasslands (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017) and the development of infrastructure for tourism (Aguilar et al. 2010).

The chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been detected in this species at Kosñipata and other montane locations around Cusco (A. Catenazzi and V. Vredenburg pers. obs., Catenazzi et al. 2011, Kosch et al. 2012). In 2009, B. dendrobatidis prevalence was 18.2% (n=11) and mean infection intensity (Zswab) was 3,788.4 (Catenazzi et al. 2011). This species, however, appears to be resistant to the disease due to stronger anti-Bd skin bacteria (Burkart 2015, Catenazzi, Vredenburg et al. unpublished data).
population: This species is common at Abra Acjanaco (Duellman et al. 2011). During a 1975 study, 12 individuals were collected at Abra Acanacu, 25 km NNE Paucartambo (Péfaur and Duellman 1980). Surveys in Cusco during 2007 and 2008 detected 20 individuals over 25 person-days and 15 individuals over 32 person-days, respectively (von May et al. 2008). In January 2009, several males were heard calling (exact number unknown) at Abra Acjanaco (Duellman et al. 2011). In the same year, 11 individuals were observed during surveys in montane forests along the Paucartambo–Shintuya road in Kosñipata Valley, Manu National Park (Catenazzi et al. 2011). Twelve frogs were collected along the Paucartambo-Shintuya road in the eastern slopes of the Cordillera de Paucartambo, Cusco during June–August 2012 (Burkart 2015). Surveys in 1996-1999, 2008–2009, and 2012–2016 recorded this species repeatedly within its known distribution, however slight declines in the subpopulations have been observed over this time and the species is not quite as abundant as it has been previously (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. 2017). Two dead individuals have also been recorded over this time period, although the cause for this is unknown (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. 2017, Burkart et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from the crests and high Amazonian slopes of the Cordillera Oriental of the Andes in Cusco, Peru. Records from the Department of Cajamarca are most likely to be in error and have not been confirmed to belong to this species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Presently, several subpopulations in the Cordillera Oriental in the Region of Cusco are assigned to this species: 3,080–3,580 m asl on the slopes of Abra Amparaes, 3,160–4,080 m asl on the slopes of Abra Málaga, and 3,100–3,200 m asl on the slopes of Abra Marcapata, though not all of these may represent G. excubitor. It has an altitudinal range of 3,080–4,080 m asl. It occurs in five threat-defined locations and its EOO is 6,151 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is recorded from Manu National Park, Machu Picchu Historical Sanctuary, ACP Abra Málaga and ACP Ukumari Llakta, a private reserve established on 9 March 2007 covering a territory of 1,053 ha between Málaga Chico and Río San Luis. 

Conservation Needed
Further habitat protection is required.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats. There is a need for close monitoring of the status of this species given the detection of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited—extent of occurrence (EOO) of 603 km<sup>2</sup>—the population is considered to be stable, threats are currently localised and not considered to be causing significant habitat loss, it tolerates a moderate degree of habitat disturbance, and it occurs in two protected areas which are both well protected.
habitat: It inhabits montane primary and secondary forests (Lehr et al. 2004, A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). Individuals have been found at night, primarily on ferns about 1.5 m above the ground (Lehr et al. 2004), close to the river (associated to riparian vegetation) and sometimes in secondary vegetation (C. Aguilar pers. comm. August 2011, A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs within a matrix of mixed land use (secondary vegetation, pastures; C. Aguilar pers. comm. August 2011) and is known to tolerate moderate habitat disturbance (C. Aguilar pers. comm. August 2011). As with other congeners, this species is expected to breed by direct development.
threats: Subsistence farming and small-scale livestock farming have been traditional activities in this region and are also occurring in at least one of the localities where this species is found, such as Vaquería (C. Aguilar pers. comm. August 2011, R. von May and A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017). However, it is difficult to determine at this time whether these activities truly constitute threats to this species, given that it appears to be tolerant to the moderate disturbances caused by this level of habitat alteration.
population: This is considered to be a locally common species, with about ten individuals found in a 100 m transect at San Alberto (C. Aguilar pers. comm. August 2011). In 2013, one specimen was collected from Pui Pui Protected Forest over 12 person-days, where it is not considered common (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Its population is considered to be stable (A. Angulo, R. von May and E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). In August 2014, two individuals were found in the buffer zone of PNYC at Vaquería over two person-days (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). In November 2014, two individuals were found in the buffer zone of PNYC at Vaquería and one individual was found at San Alberto over 3 person-days (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This frog is known from six localities in the general area of San Alberto, in the southern part of Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén (PNYC), as well as several localities in the buffer zone of PNYC (A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017) and the Pui Pui Protected Forest (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017) in the yungas ecoregion of the Cordillera Oriental, Oxapampa province, Regions of Pasco and Junín, Peru, from 2,050 to 2,765 m asl (Lehr et al. 2004, Chávez et al. 2013). Its EOO is 603 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is currently only known from Parque Nacional Yanachaga-Chemillén (Chávez et al. 2013) and Pui Pui Protected Forest (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera del Condór region of Ecuador.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical humid montane shrubland and forest. It is associated with streams and stunted vegetation characterized by the presence of mosses, orchids and lichens. It reproduces by direct development, as with other species in the genus.
threats: Expansion of the agricultural frontier in the Cordillera del Cóndor is an ongoing threat to this species (Brito and Almendáriz 2018). In addition, the region where this species occurs is an active mining concession (RAISG 2020). Access roads to mining areas can fuel new pressures on the forests including higher rates of deforestation and resource extraction (e.g., logging and wood harvesting), the rapid expansion of new agricultural frontiers towards ecologically sensitive areas, and potential contamination of water bodies and soils (Guayasamín and Bonaccorso 2011).
population: It is only known from two individuals collected in 2009 (Brito and Almendáriz 2018), and subsequent visits to the vicinity of the type locality since then have not reported additional individuals (Almendáriz et al. 2012, Brito et al. 2014; D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is known from single location at the type locality of Paquisha Alto (2,100 m asl), one of the highest points of the Cordillera del Cóndor, in southeastern Ecuador (Brito and Almendáriz 2018). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its extant range is 5 km2, and while it is likely that this species also occurs in Peru given to its proximity to the border between the two countries (Brito and Almendáriz 2018), it is unlikely to have an EOO greater than 100 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The type locality lies within Bosque Protector Cordillera del Condór.

Conservation Needed
It is essential to maintain and effectively protect the existing natural habitat.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of a population decline of at least 50% over the last three generation lengths (18 years; 2001–2019) due to the synergistic effects of chytridiomycosis, habitat loss and degradation, climate change, and over-harvesting (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
habitat: It is a riparian, semi-aquatic frog of streams, waterfalls and slow moving water in montane grasslands and shrublands. It can be found at the edge of the lake, in streams and ponds created by deglaciation, and bogs. Breeding takes place in small lakes, streams and rivers with good water quality. It has also been observed to reproduce in both wet and dry seasons, using high elevation bogs (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. July 2015).
threats:
This or a closely related species is currently subject to human consumption in southern Peru and Bolivia (Angulo 2008, Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019), and it is susceptible to water extraction, eutrophication and pollution of waterways through agricultural activities (livestock and agrochemicals) and domestic use. It is not currently threatened in Chile.

The species has tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) infection (Seimon et al. 2005, 2006) in the Cordillera Vilcanota of southern Peru and specimens exhibited clinical symptoms of chytridiomycosis. Healthy specimens, however, were found in the region of Puno, also in southern Peru, during fieldwork conducted in February 2006 (I. De la Riva pers. comm.). There is evidence of upward range expansion of this and another two anuran species to newly available habitat brought about by recent deglaciation in the Andes of Peru. The large increase in the upper limit of known Bd infections (from 4,112–5,348 m asl) also expands the spatial domain of potential Bd pathogenicity (Seimon et al. 2007). Specimens collected from Bolivia during 1980–2002 also tested positive Bd (Burrowes and De la Riva 2017). The effects of climate change (e.g., droughts and decreasing precipitation and humidity) are also considered to pose a serious future threat to the species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population:
In Peru, it is locally common, although declines have been reported for the population of Lake Sibinacocha (Seimon et al. 2006). Population surveys carried out from 2003–2009 have recorded fewer individuals from 2005 onwards. In 2008, 3-day surveys in Lake Sibinacocha by T. Seimon did not record a single individual; however, over the course of 10 days in 2009 two individuals were found by the same researcher (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. January 2010). There is a risk that this species may become locally extirpated at Sibinacocha. In the province of Chucuito, Puno, there was a reasonable number of individuals up until March 2010 (C. Aguilar pers. comm. January 2011). 

In Bolivia, this species was formerly very common in the 1980s and 1990s (I. de La Riva pers. comm. September 2019). Declines in the humid parts of its Bolivian range were observed during the early 2000s; while these areas represent a relatively small proportion of the distribution, they represent a high proportion of the population because the conditions are more favourable for the species (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). It has completely disappeared from some Bolivian sites (e.g., Cooco), while in other sites it is now found in much lower abundances than historically (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

In Chile, the species is reported to have large subpopulations, and to be abundant in high plateau streams; although these subpopulations represent a small proportion of the population.

It is estimated that the population overall has experienced a decline of more than 50% over the last three generation lengths (18 years; 2001–2019) due to the synergistic effects of chytridiomycosis, habitat loss and degradation, climate change, and over-harvesting (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
range: This species has the broadest distribution of any Telmatobius species. It is known from the Andean region of southern Peru, northern and central Bolivia and northern Chile. It is recorded in Peru from the Lake Titicaca and Cusco areas, with uncertain records from Ayacucho (not mapped). In Bolivia, it is recorded from the departments of La Paz, Oruro, and northern Potosi (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019). It is present in the altiplano of northern Chile (Parinacota, Lauca River, and Chungara Lake, Parinacota Province), and its range has recently been extended southwards to Cancosa (Tarapacá region; Sáez et al. 2014). It occurs from 1,800-5,244 m asl. Records from Argentina, on the Bolivian border, likely belong to Telmatobius rubigo. The subpopulations reported from the highlands of Cochabamba, Bolivia probably actually refer to Telmatobius hintoni (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
useTrade: This species is captured for food, juice, and medicinal products. The percentage of offtake is unknown, but reportedly unsustainable.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Bolivia, the species has been recorded from Parque Nacional Cotapata, Parque Nacional Sajama, and Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Apolobamba. In Peru, it presumably occurs in Reserva Nacional del Titicaca and it is known to occur at archealogical sites such as Sacsayhuaman and Tambomachay. In Chile, it occurs in Parque Nacional Lauca. 

Conservation Needed
The option of a captive-breeding programme might need to be explored for this species.

Research Needed
It is plausible that some populations of this widespread species are extinct or have declined due to chytridiomycosis, but further survey work is needed to investigate this. Taxonomic studies are required to verify the identity of the Bolivian subpopulations (A. Muñoz pers. comm. August 2015).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 97 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Bolivian Andes due to subsistence agriculture, cattle grazing, and wood collection.
habitat: It is known from a steep area in the upper reaches of cloud forest (De la Riva et al. 2005). Active individuals can be found during the day and night on the forest floor and paths (De la Riva et al. 2005). This species is presumed to be a larval developer in streams.
threats: This species is threatened by heavy subsistence agriculture, cattle grazing, and timber collection for house construction and firewood, which has reduced much of the nearby habitat to secondary forest. This species might be highly threatened by the fungal disease chytridiomycosis, which has decimated other anuran species in Bolivia, including other cloud-forest bufonids (De la Riva and Aparicio 2016).
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species as there have been no surveys for it in the type locality since it was first seen there in 2001. It was recorded as recently as 2016 when 1-2 individuals were observed in Parque Nacional Madidi (M. Ocampo pers. comm. September 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13247,"3":{"1":0},"4":[null,2,16773836],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality at Laitique on the banks of the river Pelechuco, around five hours walk downstream from the village of Pelechuco towards Apolo, and Palcabamba in Franz Tamayo Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia (De la Riva et al. 2005, J. Aparicio and I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019). It is now also known from a locality in the adjacent Parque Nacional Madidi (M. Ocampo pers. comm. September 2019). It is also likely to occur in other areas of the Cordillera de Apolobamba, including nearby Peru (De la Riva et al. 2005). It is known to occur at elevations between 2,466–2,820 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 97 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur at a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The only known localities for this species are within the Área Natural de Manejo Integrado Nacional Apolobamba and Parque Nacional Madidi.

Conservation Needed
Recommended conservation measures include continued and strengthened management of protected areas where this species occurs.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of human pressures on the landscape through agricultural use and logging, as well as chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,592 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This terrestrial, diurnal frog inhabits lowland tropical moist forest and "rolling hills", and can be found in primary and possibly slightly degraded habitats. It only occurs near small brooks or streams within primary and older secondary forest. At night they have been observed perching on leaves up to 50 cm above the ground (Schulte 1989). Tadpoles are deposited in slow-moving streams (Twomey and Brown 2009) and have been observed in brooks with very little water (Schulte 1989).
threats: The major threat is the loss of forest habitat through agriculture (coffee, palm oil and rice), livestock production, and subsistence wood collection (Catenazzi and von May 2014). Much of its habitat is near human settlements, and ongoing deforestation could have a strong negative impact on this species (Twomey and Brown 2009). It is also under threat due to illegal collecting for the pet trade.
population: Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, as well as harvesting for the pet trade, the population is suspected to be decreasing. During 2004–2007 surveys, approximately 50 individuals were detected over more than 300 person days, in the San Martín Region (von May et al. 2008).
range: This species was previously only known from the type locality and adjacent areas including the Tarapoto-Yurimaguas road (San Martín Department). It is now also known from the southern Cordillera Escalera National Park nearby Tarapoto including the Cainarachi Valley, in the region of San Martín, Peru (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). It occurs between 215–1,051 m asl (J. Brown pers. comm. August 2017), however it is more common in the Huallaga canyon between elevations of 250–750 m asl (Twomey and Brown 2009). It likely occurs between known localities, although surveys are required (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,592 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There is a high market demand for this species (Twomey and Brown 2009).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within the Cordillera Escalera Regional Conservation Area and the buffer zone of Cordillera Azul National Park. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival. It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into the distribution, population status, ecology and threats affecting this species, especially with regards to the impact of illegal trade. There is a need for population monitoring of the status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and harvesting.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,920 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat outside of protected areas in the Cordillera Azul.
habitat: This species occurs in undisturbed premontane forest, particularly in habitats adjacent to streams, though it appears to have extremely specific habitat requirements. In Contamana, it has been found alongside three different streams, but only in restricted areas along these streams. Adults are found under logs or under piles of leaf litter and appear to be more active after a heavy  rain. Males appear to call from the leaf litter throughout the day, but usually remain well-hidden beneath the leaf litter. Reproduction likely takes place near small streams and forest pools, and tadpoles are deposited within shallow forest pools.
threats: There is a small amount of habitat loss in the Cordillera Azul near Río Huallaga caused by agricultural activities, including coffee, banana and palm oil plantations (Brown and Twomey 2009). The Sierra del Divisor also faces imminent threats from oil and mining development, road and pipeline construction and illegal logging. However, the degree of impact of these threats on this species remains unknown.
population: This species is exceedingly cryptic and is nearly impossible to detect, especially if males are not calling. It appears to be patchily distributed, but can be common in some areas (Twomey and Brown 2009). The population appears to be severely fragmented, as only two disjunct subpopulations have been encountered and these are restricted to small areas (Brown and Twomey 2009). During 2007 surveys in Callanayacu, only three individuals were captured within a 200 m stretch of habitat (68 person-hours), despite the fact that numerous male were calling in the vicinity the entire time. Surveys in Contamana were only able to detect a total of six frogs despite 60 person-hours in 2006 and 48 person-hours in 2007. Due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This recently described (2009) species is known from two locations, one in the Serranía de Contamana in the Loreto Region and the  other in the Huallaga Canyon in the northern Cordillera Azul (Brown and Twomey 2009). These two  sites are 130 km apart and separated by the Ucayali floodplain,  which may represent a significant barrier between these two subpopulations (Twomey and Brown 2009). While this species may range widely throughout the Cordillera Azul and Sierra del Divisor, it may just as likely be restricted to the Serranía de Contamana and extreme northern Cordillera Azul (Brown and Twomey 2009). Its elevational range is 230–600 m asl and its EOO is 3,920 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present within Cordillera Azul National Park and in the buffer zone of the Sierra del Divisor National Park, established in 2015. Much of this species’ potential habitat is protected in the Cordillera Azul National Park, although the extent to which this species occurs in the park remains unknown (Twomey and Brown 2009). It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
Ongoing management and protection of the species' habitat is required.

Research Needed
More information about this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats are needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,540 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the buffer zone of the Manu Biosphere Reserve and in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve of southeastern Peru.
habitat: This species occurs in the transition zone between montane and lowland forest; it can be found in both mature and regenerating forests with continuous canopy cover. It occurs near rocky streams during the dry season and near temporary water bodies during the rainy season (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017). Crevices or holes made of boulders or roots are used as refuges. Males typically call from exposed positions of rocks, leaf litter, or woody debris. Calling activity occurs throughout the year, most frequently in the early morning between 05:00–09:00 and late afternoon between 16:00 to 18:00 (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017). At night, individuals perch on low vegetation between 0.1 to 0.5 m above the ground. Reproduction occurs near permanent and seasonal streams. Clutches of 22–25 eggs have been found in small rocky cavities where they are guarded by males and, upon hatching, are transported to lentic water along streams, or in shallow, slow-moving streams (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017).
threats: Outside of Amarakaeri Communal Reserve the forest habitat has experienced some degradation due to conversion of forests to subsistence farming (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). Mining, both legal (mining concessions) and illegal, are also an issue within the reserve (Servindi 2009, Finer 2016), as is road construction (Ojeda 2015) and illegal logging (Servindi 2009).
population: It has been described from a type series consisting of 16 specimens collected between 2004–2016 (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017). It is considered to be a locally common species, with at least 80 individuals observed between 2004–2015 (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known from the Amazonian slopes of the Andes in southeastern Peru (Manu Province, Madre de Dios Region) at nine geographical localities, from 340–850 m asl (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017). Three localities are in the buffer zone of the Manu Biosphere Reserve and another six localities are in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve where it may occur more widely than currently recorded. The EOO of its current known range is 1,540 km2 and it occurs in three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There is no information yet as to whether this newly described species is harvested for the pet trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded in the buffer zone of the Manu Biosphere Reserve (The Manu Learning Centre, Erika Lodge, and Aguas Calientes, Shintuya) and in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve (Serrano-Rojas et al. 2017).

Conservation Needed
There is a need for continued habitat protection in the Madre de Dios Region.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because although this species is fairly widespread, its range includes few protected areas, its habitat is experiencing continuing decline in area, extent and quality and its population is considered to be severely fragmented, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Near Threatened because, despite it being fairly widespread and the range including several protected areas, the extent of occurrence (EOO) approaches the threshold for the Vulnerable category under B1, there is continuing decline in area, extent and quality, and it occurs in less than 10 locations, making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species occurs in lowland tropical rainforest. Individuals have been found on mossy areas along river banks or perching on a vegetation near the water during at night. Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to breed in fast flowing streams by larval development, as with other congeners.
threats: This species is mainly threatened by habitat loss from gold mining, illegal logging, and the construction of new roads. Gold mining has already destroyed streams around the type locality rendering them unusable (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Chytridiomycosis is likely to have been a threat to individuals occurring above 1,000 m Asl and any declines will have taken place in the 1990s, but individuals in the lowlands are not significantly exposed to the threat of infection by this disease (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: This does not appear to be a commonly encountered species, but it can be locally abundant. In 300 m of creek, with an effort of 12 person hours, 20 individuals were found (G. Chavez pers. comm. April 2017); this is a good result for an Atelopus species. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the piedmont of the Cordillera Oriental of southeastern Peru in the Departments of Cusco, Madre de Dios and Puno. It has an altitudinal range of 400–1,080 m Asl and its EOO is 21,482 km<sup>2</sup>. Although it has not yet been found in Bolivia, its range likely extends into Madidi National Park.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
One locality, Pozo Samanio, is situated between two protected areas, the Reserva Comunal Machiguenga and the Santuario Nacional Megantoni. Another locality, Chinguriato Alto, lies within the Santuario Nacional Megantoni. The species may also be present within Manu National Park, Reserva Nacional Tambopata, Reserva Comunal Amarakaeri, Bahuaja Sonene National Park in Peru, and Madidi National Park in Bolivia.

Research Needed
More information is needed about this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats. There is a need for close monitoring of the status of this species given the potential threat of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern since, although its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,816 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat and it is somewhat adaptable to habitat modification.
habitat: This species can be found in disturbed unflooded Amazonian lowland forest with sandy substrates and in disturbed terra firme forest at the alluvial zone (Moravec and Köhler 2007). Individuals can be found during the daytime, within the leaf litter or on top of fallen trees. They appear to feed on ants, and the presence of large unpigmented eggs in the holotype suggests terrestrial mode of reproduction (Moravec and Köhler 2007). The holotype is a gravid female collected in March. Therefore, it is possible that the species reproduces at least in the wettest period of the year (February-May) (J. Moravec pers. comm. 2007). Males and larvae of this species are unknown (Moravec and Köhler 2007).
threats: Threats include deforestation and urbanization of the landscape, road network building, and white sand mining (J. Moravec pers. comm. 2007). In the Ere-Algodón watershed, extractive activities such as logging and small-scale mining are the primary threats to the ecosystem (Venegas and Gagliardi-Urrutia 2013). However, given that it has been found in disturbed forest and there is extensive suitable habitat remaining in the region, these are not considered to be significant threats to its population at present.
population: Little information is currently available on the population status of this species, however the population is considered to be stable given that there is extensive suitable habitat remaining across its range. It was most recently detected during a rapid biological inventory of the Ere-Algodón watershed during 15–21 October 2012 (Venegas and Gagliardi-Urrutia 2013).
range: The species is known from the surroundings of Iquitos, Reserva Nacional Allpahuayo-Mishana, and one locality from the Ere-Algodón watershed in Loreto Region, Peru (Moravec and Köhler 2007, Venegas and Gagliardi-Urrutia 2013). The specimens from Ere-Algodón extends its previously known distribution ca 190 km to the northwest (Venegas and Gagliardi-Urrutia 2013). It occurs between 110–200 m asl and is likely to occur more widely throughout the Amazon basin (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. April 2018).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Reserva Nacional Allpahuayo-Mishana (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. April 2018) and a forest study area of the Universidad Nacional de la Amazonia Peruana (UNAP, in Iquitos) called Centro de Investigación y Enseñanza Forestal Arboretum "El Huayo". A nature reserve lies near the known localities, which could provide the species with necessary protection (J. Moravec pers. comm. 2007).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its distribution, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: This species is found in a mixture of elfin forest with epiphytic moss, lichens, and some bromeliads up to about 3,350 m asl, above which it inhabits puna, including (Stipa). The holotype was sitting on a mossy cliff during rain by day (Duellman 2013). Its breeding strategy remains unknown. No information is available as to whether tolerate any degree of habitat disturbance.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, but there is general deforestation as a result of an increase in livestock and other agricultural activities, and selective logging.
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species. It is known only from the holotype collected in 1989 and a paratype collected in 1972 (Duellman 2013). It is apparently difficult to find (Duellman 2013).
range: This species is known only from the north slope of Cerro Barro Negro, Chachapoyas Province, Amazonas Region, Peru (Duellman 2013). It occurs at elevations from 3,320–3,440 m asl (Duellman and Trueb 2015).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">The species is only known from a single location within a bowl-shaped valley, surrounded by naturally dry—and therefore unsuitable habitat—and some areas that have been intentionally deforested. It is therefore listed as Vulnerable as current management practices of the forest habitat seem to be sustainable, but any change in management could rapidly affect the species.
habitat: This species inhabits the relatively undistubed cloud forests of the Pachachaca watershed. Many arboreal bromeliads were found in the area, but it is unknown whether adults use them as retreat sites. A juvenile was recorded from the inside of epiphytic bromeliads about 3 m above the ground, suggesting that this species may use bromeliads as diurnal shelters (Catenazzi and von May 2011). All individuals were found at night on vegetation 1.5–3 m above the ground, implying that it is a nocturnal and arboreal species (Catenazzi and von May 2011). It is presumed that reproduction occurs via direct development, though since only a single female has been found (with a dorsal pouch lacking eggs or embryos), it is uncertain whether this species exhibits direct development similar to most of the species in the genus.
threats: Local management seems to include a certain level of small-scale logging, and forest on the other side of the ridge has been destroyed by agricultural activities. However, the use of habitat at known sites seems to be sustainable and does not currently present a severe threat to the species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Any change in management could affect the species, such that it becomes severely threatened in a short period of time.
population: The species was described from only four individuals. No additional population data has been reported.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, the Chinchay cloud forest in the upper watershed of a tributary of the Río Pachachaca, north of Río Apurimac, in the Cordillera Oriental, Pacobamba district, Apurímac region, Peru (Catenazzi and von May 2011). The cloud forest is a naturally isolated patch of about 2,000 ha and is restricted to the upper slopes of the Pachachaca watershed, bound at 2,200 m asl by the transition to the dry forest of the Pachachaca Canyon and at 3,800 m asl by ridges separating the moist and forested watershed from the drier surrounding puna (Catenazzi and von May 2011). This species occurs at 3,000 m asl. All individuals are considered to occur at a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions 
The species is not known from any formally protected areas, but it occurs in the Mancomunidad Saywite - Choquequirao - Ampay, which is a jointly managed area emphasizing ecotourism as a means of regional economic development.

Conservation Needed 
Protection is needed to prevent habitat destruction from expanding agriculture.

Research Needed
More research about the population size and trends, distribution, natural history, and threats is needed. There is a need to closely monitor the population status of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient given the lack of recent information on its distribution, population status and threats in central Peru.
habitat: This species can be found on the forest floor of the Amazonian flanks of the Andes (Heyer 1994). It is thought to occur almost exclusively in closed forest habitats (Heyer 1994). While there are no direct data on this species, reproduction may take place in foam nests in temporary ponds.
threats: While the type locality (Chontilla) appears to be in a relatively good conservation status, some intervening areas in between the known localities are threatened by habitat loss due to increased agricultural activity, which is largely driven by government policies (land tenancy of the area is conditional upon converting forest to agricultural land). The Palcazú Valley is severely fragmented in its lower and mid-altitudinal reaches. The establishment of large livestock grazing  areas is identified as the main mechanism of habitat fragmentation in the vicinity of Yanachaga Chemillén National Park. Illegal logging inside the Oxapampa-Asháninka-Yánesha Biosphere Reserve, as well as migratory agriculture and unsustainable use of agrochemicals are also threats (UNESCO 2016). Although the environmental impact assessment study of Block 107 did not record this species in 2008, the establishment of several oil concessions in the area could likely pose a threat to the remaining subpopulation (Larsen 2015), should it still be extant at this site.
population: This species is only known from the type series and museum specimens. Recent field surveys (September 2007 and May 2008) did not record this species in the vicinity of its type locality (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. June 2010). An environmental impact assessment study conducted in Block 107 in both dry and rainy seasons also failed to record this species in Chontilla; however, it is possible that these latest surveys may have been conducted in the other peak of Chontilla. During February 2015, systematic nocturnal surveys were performed on the north-western slopes of the Sira: 1 hr 30 min surveys with two observers at each 100 m elevation, between 800 and 1,500 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). In March 2015, five observers conducted surveys on the same ridge for four hours from 1,500–1,850 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). In March 2016, two people searched for two hours at the highest peak on the ridge, between 1,800 and 1,925 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). All searches were unsuccessful in detecting any individuals of this species; however it could be that these searches occurred above the elevational range of the species.
range: This species is known from the double-peaked Mount Chontilla at 780 m asl, in the Iscozazin Valley, Pasco Region, from Serranía del Sira, Huánuco Region (Heyer 1994), and from Tingo Maria (651 m asl), Huánuco Region (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2017), in central Peru, east of the Andes. Although the species description lists its upper elevational range as 2,500 m asl, the 2009 El Sira Communal Reserve Master Plan indicates that the elevational range of the reserve oscillates around 2,000 m asl. Furthermore, the El Sira specimen was examined by Duellman and Toft (1979, as Leptodactylus wagneri), who determined its elevational range in this area to be 500–690 m asl. Thus, it is considered to occur between 500–780 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 8,075 km2.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is no information on this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species can be found within the Yanesha Communal Reserve (Chontilla is within this reserve), and it might also occur in El Sira Communal Reserve, Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillén and Bosque de Protección San Matias San Carlos, although its presence at these protected areas needs to be verified. All of these conservation areas are within the Oxapampa-Asháninka-Yánesha Biosphere Reserve, established in 2010 (UNESCO 2010). 

Conservation Needed
Enforcement is needed to curb the current and future threats to the Yanesha Communal Reserve.

Research Needed
Surveys in the appropriate elevational range are urgently needed to relocate this species at its known localities and in the intervening areas.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, its area of occupancy (AOO) is likely even more restricted, it is considered to occur in XXX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in its AOO and the extent of its habitat in [Region]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 781 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the southern Peruvian Andes.
habitat: This is a forest edge species restricted to the zone of wet puna grassland directly adjacent to montane cloud forest; it is not known whether or not it can occur in modified habitats. Its breeding strategy is not confirmed, but this might take place in water.
threats: There are not believed to be any major threats to this species at present, but it might be susceptible to habitat degradation in the future. The road passing through the type locality runs through the length of the Abra Málaga Private Conservation Area and increases the chance of land slides. The road also increases access to forests and the likelihood of deforestation. Furthermore, it presents the same traits as other amphibian species that have been impacted by chytridiomycosis; one out of two samples from 2011 tested positive for the fungus (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
population: It is a very rare species. In 2008, surveys at the type locality and San Luis were unable to detect any individuals over four person-days (von May et al. 2008), a survey to the type locality in March 2009 did not record the species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017), and surveys at the type locality and San Luis in February 2017 also failed to record the species (F.P. Condori and A. Ttito pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species occurs in Urubamba Province, Cusco Region, Peru at San Luis, on the western slope of Abra Málaga (a pass in the Cordillera Oriental) within the Abra Málaga Private Conservation Area, and at Wiñay wayna within Santuario Historico Machu Picchu (L. Mamani Ccasa pers. comm. April 2017). Its range map includes both known sites, which represent two threat-defined locations, and the intervening area. Its altitudinal range is 2,000–3,780 m asl and its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 781 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Abra Málaga Private Conservation Area and the Santuario Historico Machu Picchu. It may also occur within the Choquequirao Regional Conservation Area. 

Conservation Needed
This species would likely benefit from improved habitat protection at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
There is a need for further surveys and close monitoring of the population status of this species. More information is needed on this species' distribution, ecology and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits cloud  forest, often characterized by the presence of many bromeliads and moss. Reproduction occurs by larval development, whereby eggs are deposited on leaves and larvae develop in streams.
threats: Although the Sira area is relatively inaccessible, there is illegal logging, coca plantations, cattle farming, subsistence farming, and illegal mining taking place in the region, and there are concerns that these are also occurring within the boundaries of the Reserva Comunal El Sira (Exploration Sira). However, these activities are predominantly taking place at lower elevations, and any potential effects on the species remains unknown. Presumably the Ecuadorian subpopulations are being locally affected by deforestation for agriculture, livestock, and wood extraction.
population: The population status of this species is not known, however it is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. In Ecuador, specimens have been recorded in 2008 and 2012 (Guayasamín et al. 2014).
range: This species was formerly only known from the Serrania de Sira, Huánuco Region, Peru at 1,500 m asl. Following the synonymy of Nymphargus puyoensis under this species by Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin (2014), it is now also known from the provinces of Sucumbíos, Orellana, Napo, Pastaza, and Morona Santiago in Ecuador, between 300–1,550 m asl (Duellman and Toft 1979, Flores and McDiarmid 1989, Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006, 2007; Cisneros-Heredia and Meza-Ramos 2007, Yánez Muñoz et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In Peru, it may occur in the Reserva Comunal El Sira. In Ecuador, its geographic range may overlap Parque Nacional Napo-Galeras. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 19,595 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three to nine threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the Andean foothills along the headwaters of the Río Madre de Dios basin.
habitat: This species occurs in forests of the Andean foothills. This area is covered by Amazonian forest with Guadua spp. formations as well as primary forest with predominant presence of trees of the genera Erythrina, Ormosia, Inga, Hevea, and Virola. Frogs are active on the ground at night during the end of the rainy season (April). Its breeding biology is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development similar to its congeners. Although testis and vocal slits were evident in all three males specimens that have been collected, they greatly differ in size (20.7–30.8 SVL), which might indicate that males reach maturity early in development (Padial et al. 2012).
threats: The species overlaps with large areas where creeks and streams are being destroyed by gold mining and this is a severe issue in the lowlands. The forest in which the species occurs is also destroyed by these activities, but because the species does not rely on running water for reproduction, it is possible that the species is able to survive in these areas (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Logging, cattle grazing, and oil exploration are also taking place throughout its range, which degrades and destroys its habitat.
population: The type series is comprised of three specimens recorded from two localities. Three additional individuals were collected during June–September 2013 (Villacampa Ortega 2013). The species is very common at Villa Carmen biological station in the buffer zone of Manu National Park, has been recorded from the Kosñipata Valley, and from lower elevations at the Manu Learning Center, which is also in the buffer zone of Manu National Park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Moreover the species was reported in 2016 from the buffer zone of the Bahuaja Sonene National Park near the Inca Mine at Santo Domingo (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known from several localities in the Andean foothills along the headwaters of the Río Madre de Dios basin, in Cusco, Puno, and Madre de Dios Regions of Peru (Padial et al. 2012). It occurs at elevations from 685–1,235 m asl, it occurs in three to nine threat-defined locations, and its EOO is 19,595 km2. It may occur more widely than currently mapped, possibly into Bolivia (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve and the private land of the Manu Learning Center in Madre de Dios. It has not been recorded in Manu National Park, but may occur there. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and life history is needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient because this species was only recently described and there are continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements. However, it is important to note that the type locality may be threatened by agriculture, so this species should be closely monitored.
habitat: This species inhabits primary humid montane forest. All individuals have been found during day in the leaf litter and under tree trunks (Lehr and Oróz 2012). It is presumed that this species has a cryptic mode of life restricted to the leaf litter and moss, and reproduces by direct development similar to other members of the genus.
threats: In 2010, the type locality showed some evidence of human activities, such as logging for firewood and construction of agricultural parcels (Lehr and Oróz 2012).
population: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species, as it is known only from the XXX specimens that constitute the type series."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is little information available on the population status and trends for this species. It is known only from the three specimens collected in 2010, which constitute the type series (Lehr and Oróz 2012).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality of Cordillera de Carpish at San Marcos, Umari District, Pachitea Province, Huánuco Region, Peru. It occurs at elevations between 3,100–3,190 m asl (Lehr and Oróz 2012).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in a small protected area, San Marcos Private Conservation Area.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 83 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Cordillera de Carpish, particularly in the eastern part of its range.
habitat: This species inhabits primary humid montane forest. The holotype was found during the day within moss. The vegetation of the type locality is characterized by the presence of plants of the families Myrthaceae, Clusiaceae, Cunnoniaceae, Ericaceae, Asteraceae, and the presence of the bamboo species Chusquea scandens (Lehr and Oróz 2012). It is presumed that this species has a cryptic mode of life restricted to the leaf litter and moss, and breeds by direct development similar to other members of the genus.
threats: The area of the type locality shows evidence of human activities such as logging for firewood. At Huanacaure (Cordillera de Carpish), there is ongoing habitat loss due to agriculture at the top of the mountain (G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2017). In general, there is still potential suitable habitat throughout the Cordillera de Carpish at present (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). Clearing of the vegetation on the trails to the Huanacaure Ruins presents a threat to this species as the vegetation is important for providing good humidity conditions for the moss on which this species depends (G. Chávez pers. comm. April 2017). Harvesting of moss throughout the eastern slopes of the Andes, especially within cloud forests, poses a potential threat to this species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is considered to be uncommon. Seven specimens were collected in 2014–2015 at Huanacaure, Cordillera de Carpish (Chávez et al. 2015). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Cordillera Carpish at San Pedro de Carpish and Ruinas de Huanacaure, Huánuco Province, Huánuco Region, Peru from 2,996–3,100 m asl (Lehr and Oróz 2012). Its EOO is 83 km<sup>2 </sup>and it occurs at two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species does not occur within any protected area.

Conservation Needed
As the Cordillera de Carpish is known for its high levels of endemism, legal protection of the Cordillera de Carpish is recommended (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited – extent of occurrence (EOO) of 300 km<sup>2</sup> – it occurs in two protected areas, one of which is well protected, and threats outside of the protected areas are currently localised and not thought to be causing declines.
habitat: It is known from cloud forest, where individuals were found under moss on tree trunks, on leaves of low vegetation, and under moss on the ground (Duellman and Hedges 2005, E. Lehr, R. von May and A. Angulo pers. comm. 2017). It is unknown whether this species can tolerate any level of habitat disturbance. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
